webTitle: Barmby crosses Stanley Park in £6m transfer

fields.headline: Barmby crosses Stanley Park in £6m transfer
fields.standfirst: Everton accept Liverpool's offer for their Euro 2000 midfielder
fields.trailText: Everton have agreed to sell the England midfielder Nick Barmby to Liverpool for around £6m. The 26-year-old, a member of England's Euro 2000 squad, shocked the Goodison club earlier this month by revealing that he wanted to join their Merseyside rivals.
fields.body:
Everton have agreed to sell the England midfielder Nick Barmby to Liverpool for around £6m. The 26-year-old, a member of England's Euro 2000 squad, shocked the Goodison club earlier this month by revealing that he wanted to join their Merseyside rivals.

The clubs agreed on the appearance-based fee after a week of negotiations. Barmby had one year of his contract remaining, and would have been available on a free transfer next summer. In a frantic day of transfer activity, Everton also confirmed the £2.5m sale of Don Hutchison to Sunderland, and announced the arrival of Alex Nyarko from Lens for £4.5m. The Ghanaian midfielder will join the club as soon as they receive a work permit.

Meanwhile, Sunderland have launched a £10m double bid for Arsenal's Ray Parlour and the Aston Villa defender Ugo Ehiogu. Both deals would break the club's current transfer record, set by the £4m purchase of Stefan Schwarz last season.

A club insider confirmed: "There are two bids in and they would both beat the current transfer record. The club is waiting for answers to come back." Sunderland had talks with Arsenal about four days ago in which they made their bid for Parlour, but Arsenal yesterday denied that he was for sale.

Peter Reid, the Sunderland manager, yesterday announced the signings of Tom Peeters, Belgium's young player of the year, and the Austria Under-21 goalkeeper Jürgen Macho, and said: "I would imagine there would be more signings."

Arsenal's quest to get a Portuguese passport for their £6m Brazilian Edu looks destined for failure, after the Portuguese consulate in Brazil estimated that the process would take at least two years. Edu has a Portuguese grandfather, but his father must get a passport before he can apply for one.

Mario Miranda of the Portuguese embassy in Brasilia yesterday dismissed the idea of speeding through the application. "All citizens are equal in the eyes of the law, independent of social, economic or political situation," he said. "It cannot be resolved in a matter of days." Arsenal, who refused to comment, must now decided whether to apply for a work permit.

One player without a work permit is Liverpool's American goalkeeper Brad Friedel, who was left stranded in the United States yesterday after the Department for Education and Employment refused to renew his work permit because he has not played in enough international matches.

Barcelona yesterday accepted a bid from Lazio for the Dutch international Boudewijn Zenden, valued at just under £8m. Lazio have already spent over £90m this summer on five major signings, including the world-record £37m transfer of Hernan Crespo from Parma.

At the lower end of football's financial scale, Bolton have signed the striker Michael Ricketts, 21, from Walsall for an undisclosed fee.

Bookmakers have made Bradford's Chris Hutchings their 8-11 favourite in the Premiership not to be in his job at the end of the season - despite him being appointed less than four weeks ago.

webTitle: Healthy guide to dishing out the medals

fields.headline: Healthy guide to dishing out the medals
fields.trailText: After the first stage of Euro 2000, when teams such as England, Denmark, Sweden and Norway were sent home to shiver in what passes for a northern European summer, I made the rather fanciful suggestion that the better the climate a nation enjoys, the better the football.
fields.body:
After the first stage of Euro 2000, when teams such as England, Denmark, Sweden and Norway were sent home to shiver in what passes for a northern European summer, I made the rather fanciful suggestion that the better the climate a nation enjoys, the better the football.

In response to this claim, Geoff Bartholomew, a reader, wrote in with a significantly more sophisticated analysis of what makes a country good at sport. He compared the results of Euro 2000 with the World Health Organisation's league table of healthy nations and came up with startling results.

France, No1 in the table, beat Italy, No2, in the final. And if that might pass as mere coincidence, the two semi-finalists were also well up the WHO league of nations: Portugal at number 12 and Holland 17th.

Given that the top 10 of the chart is cluttered with states such as Andorra, Monaco and San Marino who, frankly, whatever the glowing condition of the populace, are so small they will never trouble the international scorers, there must be something in this.

The links are obvious. A benevolent cycle is produced: a healthy population will be more inclined to take up active pursuits and in turn a fit population is healthier than a sedentary one. It looked a rather marvellous concept until I tried to apply the theory to predict the outcome of the Olympics, with a view to bankrupting my local bookies.

And then it all collapsed. The host nation Australia, likely to enjoy a golden autumn in the swimming pool if nowhere else, is just 32nd on the WHO list, while the United States is at No37, sandwiched between Costa Rica and Slovenia.

Other big Olympic hitters such as Brazil (125), Russia (130), and Kenya (140) are even more poorly placed. And while it would be good to hear what the national anthems of Malta (5), Singapore (6) and Oman (8) sound like, it is much more likely to be the familiar tones of the German tune (25) we hear when it comes to dishing out the gold.

One thing, though: on WHO statistics, the UK is ranked 18th in the world. Which as a guide to predicting our final position in the Olympic medals table, is probably as accurate as you could find.

webTitle: Eagles hope 100m Chinese can't be wrong

fields.headline: Eagles hope 100m Chinese can't be wrong
fields.trailText: He may not have thought it at the time but, as Steve Coppell sat cramped by the spare tyre in the back of a speeding Chinese police car, things were looking up.
fields.body:
He may not have thought it at the time but, as Steve Coppell sat cramped by the spare tyre in the back of a speeding Chinese police car, things were looking up.

The Crystal Palace manager had accidentally been left behind at the Shanxi stadium here having watched his team beat Shanxi Guoli 2-0 on Tuesday night. "That's the first time the coach has ever left without me," he sighed. "You'd think someone might have noticed."

For the second year running, Palace's pre-season preparations have taken them to the Far East, and on Thursday they played China in front of 45,000 fans and a television audience of over 100m. After a pre-season like this, the main event may be something of a letdown.

The catalyst to the tours was the signing of Fan Zhiyi, the Chinese captain, and Sun Jihai in 1998. Although the latter has since rejoined Dalian, Fan remains a key member of Palace's first team and is a star of David Beckham proportions in the Orient.

Last year the Eagles became the first western side to play in Kunming and Harbin, even though the club were stuck in administration. But, with Simon Jordan completing his takeover at Selhurst Park three days before the squad left, this trip has been hailed as the dawn of a new era.

"You can't ask for a better start than to be shown live to 100m people," said Phil Alexander, Palace's chief executive. "The Chinese are fanatical about football and we have had massive exposure. We will have made money from both our trips here."

Bora Milutinovic has coached three different national teams in the World Cup finals but on Thursday his prospects of remaining China's manager were bolstered by a 3-1 victory over Palace.

"We lost to an international side whose experience and quality took their toll after the first half-hour," said Coppell. "There's no disgrace in that."

fields.headline: Hoey in Premier League row
fields.trailText: Premier League and government officials met yesterday to resolve the row over a new independent watchdog-style body that is threatening to undermine its credibility with football fans.
fields.body:
Premier League and government officials met yesterday to resolve the row over a new independent watchdog-style body that is threatening to undermine its credibility with football fans.

The sports minister Kate Hoey has become embroiled in a bitter stand-off with the Premier League over the composition of the body, which will be known as the Independent Football Commission and will be responsible for ensuring that clubs treat their fans properly in a number of areas ranging from merchandising to ticket prices.

Hoey has put forward two names, the former Football Supporters' Association chairman Rogan Taylor and the former task force deputy chairman and Labour peer Lord Faulkner. Both have the backing of football supporters' groups which claim that the body would lack credibility without them.

The Premier League has objected to both, claiming that they are too close to the former task force and too involved with football supporters. It insists that the new body must be totally independent.

The culture, media and sport secretary Chris Smith said that yesterday's meeting had been constructive but that the commission's members had not been finalised. Smith said: "We are still in discussion with all the interested parties to see whether we can establish an agreement over the names for the commission."

Smith added that the commission would deal with complaints from individual fans and that it was expected to be functioning by the start of the coming football season.

Hoey was recently involved in a heated row with Richard Scudamore, the Premier League chief executive, following a chance meeting in the House of Commons, over Taylor and Faulkner's nominations.

The IFC will have no powers to impose sanctions against clubs but can recommend ways of improving their treatment of fans. The former cabinet minister Jack Cunningham is expected to be named chairman. Others whose appointments have been agreed include the retired policeman Sir John Smith, former football commentator Brian Moore, leading civil servant Deidre Hutton and Lord Taylor, the Conservative peer.

webTitle: The future of English football is secure. Just ask Millwall

fields.headline: The future of English football is secure. Just ask Millwall
fields.standfirst: Fear not, the nation's youth is learning how to pass - in south London, writes  Sarah Hughes :   Three to watch out for
fields.trailText: At first glance Millwall's youth academy in south London looks nothing out of the ordinary. Unlike larger clubs there are no state-of-the-art facilities, no high-tech gym and no army of staff catering to the boys' every need.
fields.body:
At first glance Millwall's youth academy in south London looks nothing out of the ordinary. Unlike larger clubs there are no state-of-the-art facilities, no high-tech gym and no army of staff catering to the boys' every need.

But though it does not look special, Millwall's youth academy is among the best in the land. The much-hyped teenage striker Cherno Samba and fellow local boy Goma Lambu are in the England Under-16 squad to play Brazil at the Stadium of Light tomorrow, and another Millwall prospect, Charlie Hearn, played in the England Under-18 side at the age of 16.

Whereas Arsenal and Chelsea are condemned for preventing their young talent from developing, at Millwall the boys are encouraged to progress to the first team when they are ready. According to the youth director Nicky Milo, "if they're good enough then they're in the team, it's as simple as that".

Milo believes the secret of Millwall's success lies in prioritising coaching above all else. "The main problem with the game in England is the lack of qualified coaches. It's not that we lack talent but that we don't teach these boys how to think about the game. You could be great on the ball but you won't make it if you don't understand how to use that talent. The FA should be concentrating on that aspect of the European game above all others."

It is a warning the FA would do well to heed in a week dominated by accusations that, under the control of (mainly Premiership) clubs, youth development in this country is in danger of dying altogether.

The FA technical director Howard Wilkinson was moved to condemn the Chelsea chairman Ken Bates's recent claims that there weren't enough good English players, saying: "It does seem a paradox to me that you [Chelsea] should invest heavily in an academy when you've decided the kids you're producing aren't going to be good enough anyway."

When the teenager Jay Bothroyd joined Coventry from Arsenal this week for £1m he hit out at his former employers. "Arsenal want to buy success," he said. "The manager's job is always on the line, he needs success now. If a few young players come through that's a bonus but they're not really interested in youth."

To be fair to Arsenal, Bothroyd's claims were slightly specious given that Arsenal won the FA Youth Cup. Nor has all their young English talent leaked away: the promising left-back Ashley Cole is expected to step up into the first team next season.

But behind Bothroyd's bluster lies a more pertinent truth: young players who succeed at academy level often find their path to the first team blocked by an established foreign star. Milo offers a case in point.

"We have a boy at this academy who was initially at Arsenal," he says. "He'd done well in their youth side but by the time he joined us he had played less reserve games than any of our boys; on some levels he was much less experienced than our lads, yet he had played for a bigger club with better facilities."

Nor was he the only one. The current first-team player Marc Bircham has been at Millwall since he was 15, after a brief spell at QPR. He chose to drop down to a Second Division club because otherwise he felt he was unlikely to break through.

"It's not that they have a bad system there," Bircham says. "But you'd look into the first team and see they were constantly buying players rather than promoting from the ranks. Their aim was surviving in the Premiership and my dad felt I would never get my chance if I stayed there."

The FA's youth director Les Reed concedes that the English game is lagging behind its European counterparts but maintains that the correct youth structure is in place and will soon be producing young talent in the numbers required.

"The turning point for the French was when they failed to qualify for the 1994 World Cup," he says. "They restructured their entire system, with Gérard Houllier taking over as technical director and his assistant Aimé Jacquet moving up to become national coach.

"Then they instituted a philosophy that embraced the game at all levels down to grass roots. By setting up centres de formation and establishing the school of excellence at Clairfontaine, they were putting a long-term plan in place.

"By the time they won the World Cup the French were already four years down the line, and it wasn't easy for them: they came in for heavy criticism once they dropped David Ginola and Eric Cantona from the squad, but they had the backing of the French federation and their plan paid off."

Reed argues that it is the appointment of Wilkinson - a controversial figure in any discussion of England's future - which has enabled the FA to put a similar plan in place, with special attention paid to youth development and to ensuring the best young footballers are not lost to injury or forced out of the game.

As for why it took another four years after England failed to qualify for the 1994 World Cup before Wilkinson was appointed, Reed admits that England's hosting Euro 96 hampered rather than helped the national game.

"Terry Venables had a simple remit as England manager: win the tournament," he says. "We had no qualifying games and everything he did as manager was geared towards ensuring a strong England performance. He did not have time to consider grass-roots aspects of the game because England couldn't afford to fail on home ground.

"Since then we have concentrated on the youth set-ups and now have a very, very strong pool of young players. The important thing is not to rush them through and cause burn-out but to give them a chance to develop and learn about the game."

These pleas for time are depressingly familiar, but the Under-16s' 3-0 victory over Thailand on Tuesday showed signs of promise. Players such as West Ham's Glenn Johnson, Blackburn's Ciaran Donnelly and Samba all looked comfortable on the ball, happy moving out of defence and able to link well with one another. And thankfully, bearing in mind tomorrow's sterner test against Brazil, they all appeared to know how to pass the ball.

Steven Schumacher Everton

Under-16 caps: 9

England's Under-16 captain is a combative midfielder in the Steven Gerrard mould, happy to tackle back but providing a strong link between the midfield and front men. More comfortable on the ball than your traditional midfield hard men, Schumacher was recently singled out for praise by the coach Dick Bate for his - wait for it - passing ability.

Glenn Johnson West Ham United

Under-16 caps: 7

Yet another product of Tony Carr and Jimmy Hampson's West Ham 'starlet' factory. Johnson is a centre-back with the unusual (in England) ability to take the ball out of defence and link with midfield. Hotly tipped to break into the West Ham first team over the next couple of seasons.

Cherno Samba Millwall

Under-16 caps: 8

Currently at the centre of a battle between Millwall, his agent and a variety of Premiership clubs, this talented striker has broken into the England Under-16 side despite having only recently turned 15. He is tipped to join Leeds or Liverpool in a deal that could see Millwall receive as much as £2m in compensation. Strong in the air, Samba stands out as much because of his technical skills on the ball as his ability to win it.

webTitle: For 50 years one moment has haunted Brazil. Why?

fields.headline: For 50 years one moment has haunted Brazil. Why?
fields.standfirst: Alex Bellos on the historic day that scarred a nation's psyche
fields.trailText: Alex Bellos on the historic day that scarred a nation's psyche
fields.body:
It is one of football's more eccentric rituals. Every weekday, Isaías Ambrósio, an engaging 73-year-old Brazilian, travels to the Maracanã stadium in Rio de Janeiro where he relives a football match that happened 50 years ago.

He stands overlooking the pitch, sweating in morning sun, retelling the moments when Brazil lost the 1950 World Cup final to Uruguay. "On the 33rd minute, with only 12 minutes remaining," he narrates with the dramatic intensity of a radio commentator, "Gigghia takes the ball from the middle of the pitch." He turns around and points at the grass, where a few men are laying turf. "And he goes and goes and goes and" . . . silence. He pauses and takes a breath. Then, in a sombre tone, slowly, reluctantly, inevitably: "Goal for the Uruguayans."

Tomorrow is the 50th anniversary of the most famous defeat in the history of Brazilian football, the day that the world's most gifted side unexpectedly lost 2-1 at home to a young team from their tiny southern neighbour. An estimated 200,000 spectators - the largest crowd at any football match - stood witness. Of that number, all but 280 were cheering for the "invincible" hosts. It was such a grandiose humiliation that, even now, the wounds have not healed.

Never mind that Brazil became world champions eight years later, in Sweden; and again four years after that, in Chile, in 1970 with the legendary team that included Pelé, Gerson, Jairzinho and Rivellino; and again in the United States in 1994. The final of July 16, 1950, still weighs heavily on the Brazilian soul.

A football match has probably never had such a strong and enduring impact on the emotional life of a nation. "For me, the game is still in the present. The story is not over," laments Isaías Ambrósio, whose daily commentaries are part of an expanding universe of idiosyncratic comings to term with defeat. In Brazil, the match has inspired more literature than any other sporting event. Nelson Rodrigues, the country's most celebrated playwright, wrote in 1966 that: "Everywhere has its irremediable national catastrophe, something like a Hiroshima. Our catastrophe, our Hiroshima, was the defeat by Uruguay in 1950."

This sounds a ludicrous exaggeration but he was very serious, and many Brazilians would still agree. Three books have been published to coincide with the 50th anniversary analysing the defeat and its consequences for the Brazilian psyche.

"I was motionless, sitting on a concrete step, watching the sun shine obliquely on the pitch, hearing the silence of the crowd, a silence not even broken by the sobs, in brutal gasps, of the collective orphaning," grieves the novelist Carlos Heitor Cony, a member of the prestigious Brazilian Academy of Letters. "Survivors of that cruel afternoon believed they would never again be happy. What happened on July 16 1950 deserves a collective monument, like the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. These are the things that build nations, a people drenched in their own pain."

A film was even made about the match. In Barbosa - made by the award-winning Jorge Furtado - the protagonist goes back in time to warn goalkeeper Moacyr Barbosa that Gigghia is going to shoot to the bottom left corner of his goal. In the words of the narrator, the goal had to be annulled because the "defeat stuck like a sign of destiny, proof that in this country nothing ever works out".

Barbosa became the scapegoat, the personification of the national trauma. Even though he was unanimously voted best goalkeeper of the 1950 World Cup by journalists, in the aftermath he became the country's whipping boy in a way that was shameful by any standards. He told a documentary that the saddest moment was 20 years after the match when he was spotted by a woman in a shop. "Look at him," she said to her son, "He is the man that made all of Brazil cry."

One sportswriter wrote that Barbosa was victim of the greatest injustice in footballing history. Even his colleagues shunned him. When, in 1993, he went to visit the Brazilian squad's training camp he wasn't allowed in for fear he would bring them bad luck. Shortly before he died, almost penniless, last April, he said: " Under Brazilian law the maximum sentence is 30 years. But my imprisonment has been for 50."

The goalkeeper is the subject of the recently-published Barbosa, A Goal Is Fifty Years Old, by Roberto Muylaert, one of Brazil's most distinguished journalists. In it he reveals a sublimely bizarre fact that gives the whole tale another surreal twist. In 1963 Barbosa invited friends to a barbecue at his home. Only when the guests arrived did they realise why. The fire was flaming unusually high and was hissing from burning paint. Barbosa wasn't using ordinary wood: he was burning goalposts. The Maracanã's "fateful" goalposts were being reduced to ashes by the man whose life had been branded by them. Muylaert describes the bonfire as a "liturgy of purification". Barbosa deliriously compared himself to a cannibal: "That well-seasoned steak with onion and vinegar sauce that I ate could symbolise Gigghia's leg pumping with the camphor of the game."

But why was the 1950 World Cup Final much more than a game of football? First, it was the only time Brazil has ever hosted a soccer world cup. The Maracanã, built for the tournament, was the world's largest stadium - a world-champion stadium built for a world-champion team. It was the embodiment in concrete of Brazil's footballing sovereignty.

Second, it was a study in sporting hubris. Brazil had demolished Sweden 7-1 and Spain 6-1 in the final round. Only a draw was needed against the unfancied Uruguayans. Brazil's victory was considered such a fait accompli that the Rio mayor announced triumphantly on the loudspeaker system shortly before the kickoff: "You, players, who in less than a few hours will be hailed as champions by your compatriots. You, who I already salute as victors."

According to Roberto Muylaert, victory was supposed to signal "the emergence of a renewed and respected nation that would finally show the planet the strength, quality and discipline of a first world country". Instead, it reinforced a perennial feeling of inferiority.

The match set up the contradictory mentality that has underlined Brazilian support in the following half-century. For Brazil, the opposition is irrelevent. Brazil is always playing against itself, against its own demons, against the ghosts of 1950. The anthropologist Roberto DaMatta, in a paper submitted to the Ibero American Studies Centre, describes in serious academic tones that the defeat was "possibly the biggest tragedy in contemporary Brazilian history". He writes: "The defeat brought a united vision of the loss of a historic opportunity. It happened at the beginning of a decade in which Brazil was looking to assert itself as a nation that had a great destiny to fulfil. The result was a tireless search for explications and blame."

In his book, Anatomy of a Defeat, Paulo Perdigão says: "Of all the historical examples of national crises, the World Cup of 1950 is the most beautiful and most glorified.It is a Waterloo of the tropics and its history our Götterdämmerung. The defeat transformed a normal fact into an exceptional narrative: it is a fabulous myth that has been preserved and even grown in the public imagination."

One reason that it has stayed in the collective consciousness is that it was the last event in Brazil to happen before television, which arrived two months later, in September 1950. The 200,000 who saw the game were up 10% of the population of Rio. Almost everyone in Rio has a family member - often a living one - who was there. The whole city feels as if it personally witnessed the catastrophe.

Gigghia's goal was caught on film. The few seconds that show the Uruguayan's run, the shot, Barbosa's dive and then the goalkeeper slowly picking himself up have become Brazil's equivalent of the Zapruder footage of John Kennedy's assassination - endlessly analysed, somehow timeless, and showing a moment that defines a nation's history. The goal and the gunshot that killed Kennedy, both have, believes Muylaert, "The same drama, the same movement, rhythm, the same precision of an inexorable trajectory'."

One of the immediate consequences of the defeat was the scrapping of the white shirts that had until then been the Brazilian strip. In their place were introduced the yellow tops that have become the world's most recognisable - and romantic - footballing fashion brand. Carlos Heitor Cony believes something else was lost. "In 1950 we lost that innocence, that excitement that we inherited from the Indians when they saw the [Portuguese] ships approaching [in 1500]. Maybe it was best that way. Painfully, accidentally, we became adults."

Perhaps the greatest irony is that the game is not remembered with quite such importance by the victorious Uruguayans - who have never won a World Cup since, or even come close. On Monday at the Maracanã I asked a Uruguayan tour guide, Juan José Olivera, how his compatriots feel about Brazil's obsession with the defeat. "Young Uruguayans don't really care about the past," he said. "They don't talk about the 1950 World Cup. It happened too long ago."

 Alex Bellos's book on Brazilian football will be published by Bloomsbury in 2002.

webTitle: I am English and admire Keegan, Cantona admits

fields.headline: I am English and admire Keegan, Cantona admits
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan is not alone after all. Despite his failed campaign for Euro 2000, the England coach has found an ally in the substantial shape of Eric Cantona.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan is not alone after all. Despite his failed campaign for Euro 2000, the England coach has found an ally in the substantial shape of Eric Cantona.

Here to promote a weekend beach football tournament in that well known London resort Richmond on Thames, Cantona explains in an interview today on Radio 5 Live's Chiles on Saturday programme that Keegan's only mistake was to defend.

"If you try to defend," the great one says of the English, "you will never be as good as the Italians. You are so much better when you try to score. If England had kept playing like they did in the first 20 minutes against Portugal you would have beaten anybody."

Never one to shy away from eccentricity, Cantona reveals that he feels more English than French. "The bottom line is, I am English," he says, though he is based in Barcelona. "I feel closer to England than France. I love the football here, the fans are very passionate." Particularly at Selhurst Park.

"There are some very good players here," he adds. "I should know, I played with them at Manchester."

Which is the nicest thing anyone's said about Gary and Phil for some time.

webTitle: US tobacco firms liable for $145bn in damages

fields.headline: US tobacco firms liable for $145bn in damages
fields.standfirst:
Smoking: special report
Audio: Jane Martinson in New York
fields.trailText: A US jury has ordered five of the world's largest tobacco companies to pay an unprecedented $145bn (£97bn) for harming hundreds of thousands of sick smokers in Florida.
fields.body:
A US jury has ordered five of the world's largest tobacco companies to pay an unprecedented $145bn (£97bn) for harming hundreds of thousands of sick smokers in Florida.

If upheld on appeal, it would represent the largest amount of punitive damages ever awarded in the US, dwarfing the $5bn demanded from the oil company Exxon in 1994 after the Exxon Valdez oil disaster. The award is bigger than the most recent estimate of Denmark's gross domestic product.

Last night's case was also the first to be successfully fought on behalf of thousands of largely unidentified plaintiffs rather than named individuals.

Lawyers for Philip Morris, the largest company involved in the case, said that it would go out of business if forced to pay its share - some $73.96bn.

"If this verdict ever comes to pass, I can truly predict that every one of these companies will go out of business," Dan Webb, an attorney for Philip Morris, said. "There is no industry, not a country in the world, that could withstand a verdict of this size."

Philip Morris, RJ Reynolds, Lorillard, Liggett and Brown & Williamson - which is owned by the British company BAT - are all expected to appeal.

Attorney Stanley Rosenblatt, the lawyer who brought the historic lawsuit with his wife, made a scathing attack on the industry and his profession. He accused his opponents of "talking nonsense" and of failing to tell the truth about how much they could afford to pay.

The companies argued that damages should have been around closer to $150m (£100m).

William Ohlemeyer, the general counsel for Philip Morris, described the two-year case decided by a six-member jury as "a mockery" and said it was illegal because it was brought on behalf of 500,000 or more plaintiffs who would need to bring their own claims.

Among an "endless list of errors" was a judge who could become one of the beneficiaries of the award and a "lawyer who would become the richest person in America if this is allowed to stand".

Several Wall Street analysts also believe that the companies have grounds to appeal. They point to the fact that 28 other US states have all rejected similar class-action cases against the tobacco industry after citing the individual responsibility of smokers.

David Adelman, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, called the ruling "absurd". He estimated that the US tobacco businesses owned by the five companies were valued at about $25bn by the market.

If approved by the judge, the companies will have to post a $100m bond to guarantee the payment during the appeals process which could take more than two years. They are also expected to appeal this.

The case could go on for decades as an estimated 700,000 smokers would need pursue their own claims through the courts in order to share the punitive damages.

Michael York, an attorney for Philip Morris, said last night that the judge could reduce the award because it contravened his own advice to jurors that they should not ask for more than the industry could pay.

The Florida jury awarded $12.7m for actual damages to three people in the case earlier this year after finding the industry liable for conspiracy, selling dangerous products and causing the illnesses of several hundred thousand smokers.

webTitle: Straw bows to Lords on soccer thug law

fields.headline: Straw bows to Lords on soccer thug law
fields.standfirst: Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw yesterday agreed two important concessions in his football hooligans bill in an attempt to win Tory support for the measure and a safe passage through the Lords before the summer recess.
fields.body:
Jack Straw yesterday agreed two important concessions in his football hooligans bill in an attempt to win Tory support for the measure and a safe passage through the Lords before the summer recess.

He has tabled key amendments following private correspondence with the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, and representations from former law lords and the former attorney general, Sir Nicholas Lyell.

Mr Straw is redrafting the bill to make it clear that potential troublemakers will be barred from travelling abroad by magistrates only if it is believed they have committed or contributed to an act in Britain or elsewhere which would constitute a criminal offence in Britain.

The bill, as drafted, would give magistrates powers to impose a banning order even if the past disorderly behaviour would not be considered suffi ciently serious as to be regarded criminal in the view of British or foreign courts.

The change, to be debated in Commons committee stages on Monday, is likely to remove Sir Nicholas's main grounds for continued opposition to the measure.

The move may, however, deepen the divisions in the Tory party where Miss Widdecombe is struggling to prevent it from openly splitting on the issue.

The Conservative party abstained at the second reading, but will be under pressure to vote for the measure at the third reading next week, so reducing the scope for opposition in the Lords.

In a second concession, Mr Straw has also decided to limit the police powers to detain someone for 24 hours.

The bill as originally drafted gave the police powers to detain someone prior to seeking a banning order solely if it appeared to the constable that the behaviour of the individual was such that immediate in quiries should be made about their past behaviour.

This largely subjective test will be replaced with a requirement that the behaviour of the individual gives the officer reasonable grounds to believe they may have contributed to violence or disorder in the past.

The past act of violence or disorder of which the officer has suspicion would also have to be of a criminal standard.

There had been fears that the bill as originally drafted meant the police could detain someone merely because of their dress, demeanour or even a tattoo.

Although the amendments may appear technical, they go to the heart of the concerns raised by many senior Conservatives worried at the civil liberties implications of the proposals.

Mr Straw's office was in touch with the Conservatives yesterday to inform them of the proposed amendments.

Home Office draftsmen drew the bill so widely because they wanted to give police powers to stop a potential hooligan whom they believe is intent on committing a crime.

Intent to commit a crime, such as violence or disorderly behaviour, is not necessarily an offence in itself. The bill will still face a rough passage since the police will retain powers, albeit circumscribed, to detain for 24 hours even though no criminal offence has been committed.

Concerns remain that magistrates in imposing a banning order can take account of any decision by a public authority, a catch-all provision in the view of the bill's critics.

A number of lawyers have also warned that the power to arrest simply to make inquiries about someone's past will represent a breach of the Human Rights Act when it comes into force on October 2.

Home Office officials deny this, saying the police already have wide powers to arrest someone on suspicion that they are likely to commit an offence.

fields.headline: Boris's bons mots
fields.standfirst: Anecdotal evidence on political success
fields.trailText: "Hot dang!" as the man himself might exclaim. Boris "Boffo" Johnson is on his way to Parly! The strawberry-blond with the floppy fringe is set to replace the strawberry-blond with a floppy fringe as the Conservative member for Henley-on-Thames.
fields.body:
"Hot dang!" as the man himself might exclaim. Boris "Boffo" Johnson is on his way to Parly! The strawberry-blond with the floppy fringe is set to replace the strawberry-blond with a floppy fringe as the Conservative member for Henley-on-Thames. One can see why the Tories of Michael Heseltine's old seat would warm to our Boris. Some of them have been getting pretty restless over the years, watching their MP getting ever cosier to Europe and its single currency. While that nice Mr Johnson promises to be much more sceptical toward Brussels - despite his protestations yesterday that he is "mustard keen" on the place.

Boris will have wowed the selection committee with his insider's knowledge of the evil European citadel, garnered in a spell there for the Daily Telegraph. Indeed, his track record as a journalist will have done him no harm at all. The good burghers of Henley will know that Fleet Street has a knack for producing first-rate political minds: Michael Foot, Roy Hattersley, Nigel Lawson. To say nothing of Julie Kirkbride and Norman Fowler.

But Boris will have had another advantage. Apparently the Henley hustings took the form of a panel game, modelled on Have I Got News For You? The Spectator editor has been a guest on that programme and is bound to have outshone his less media-savvy rivals. But is this a suitable preparation for a life as a national decision-maker at Westminster? Surely Boris's lovable buffoonery will have to be dropped if he is to make it as a credible politician? Maybe not. For Mr J may have understood that, in today's celebrity-obsessed world, a knack for telling a good anecdote on TV can matter just as much as policy nous - perhaps even more. He will have seen how Ken Livingstone's sense of humour enabled him to trump his enemies: he may deploy just the same trick to shimmy past his colleagues in his rise up the Tory greasy pole. So good luck Boris, old bean - and ginger beers all round!

webTitle: Terror stalks Serbs in a land ruled by hatred

fields.headline: Terror stalks Serbs in a land ruled by hatred
fields.standfirst:
The losers of the Kosovo war are victims of repression, kidnappings and killings

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The losers of the Kosovo war are victims of repression, kidnappings and killings.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn in Gornje Dobrevo, Kosovo
fields.body:
It was barely midday but the funeral wake was already under way. Behind a ramshackle red brick house in this dusty little village, several generations of the Filipovic family had gathered to pay their respects to one of their own.

Burko Filipovic, a young man in his twenties, was killed when he drove over a landmine. Nobody knows exactly who buried the mine, but it is clear that it was meant for someone like Burko. It was left on a road used by Serbs and Serbs are not welcome in postwar Kosovo.

It is more than a year since the war ended, but the horrors of ethnic cleansing are still fresh to many Kosovo Albanians. The Serbs have not been forgiven and for the 100,000 of them who remain in Kosovo, living alongside nearly 2m Albanians, the threat to their lives is very real. Ironically they look to Nato, seen by many Serbs as an army of occupation, to keep revenge-minded Albanians in check.

The sobbing began when Slobodan Filipovic held up the blackened and shredded remains of his dead son's jeans. The women, clad in black, began to wail and the men twitched as they gazed gloomily into their cognacs.

"This is not a life, this is survival. The only difference between us and the Jews before the second world war is that we don't have to wear yellow stars," Zorica Filipovic said after the tears had finally stopped.

Slavisa Filipovic says he knows who is to blame but will not name any names. "This is a terrible crime and it was done by my neighbours... They did this to their closest neighbours. I used to ask them if they needed anything." Now, he claims, they phone him only to issue death threats.

Major Norking of the Swedish battalion, whose job it is to protect the village, points to the crater in the dusty road where the mine was concealed. The local Serbs are, he explains, under siege and cannot go anywhere.

At least three people, including Burko, have been blown up in the last two weeks and there is, he adds, little doubt that the mines were laid recently with the express intention of killing Serbs.

Serb children are escorted to the local school, while the adults dare not venture into the fields to harvest their crops because they are convinced that they too will step on a mine. But the Serbs are determined not to be driven out of Kosovo.

"We don't intend to move and many more of us will probably be killed but we won't leave Kosovo. This is our country," the village's steely head man Jorgic Zikica vows.

"The Serbs have been living here for centuries and we're living on our land and we want to live here," Sinisa Vasic, a villager, adds.

He admits, however, that the current situation is unbearable. "There are no jobs and our area of movement is getting smaller and smaller. They are kidnapping and killing us so how can we be optimistic?"

Salvation, in the eyes of many Serbs, lies in the unlikely return of the Yugoslav army and police who are hated by the Albanians and were bombed out of Kosovo by Nato. "They are the police and part of our country... They are able to provide law and order," Slavisa Filipovic, the family's self-appointed spokesman, declares, adding that Nato's K-For taskforce has so far been unable to guarantee the Serbs' security.

Slavisa has not dared enter Pristina, Kosovo's administrative capital, for over a year. He claims that more than a thousand Serbs have been murdered in the past year, while a further thousand have been kidnapped.

Some 40,000 Serb homes have also been burned to the ground. "Nobody has been put on trial for all these crimes. Is murder not murder because it is revenge?"

In the Serb enclave of Gracanica, Father Sava Janjic, an Orthodox priest who acts as a spokesman for moderate Serbs, tells a similar story. The Serbs are, he says, being systematically persecuted and their culture deliberately destroyed.

"One year after the war in Kosovo we have one repression and one discrimination supplanted by another. Only the roles have changed. The level of intolerance and hatred is so great that if I walked in the streets of Pristina I would be killed in several minutes."

Constantly escorted by two K-For Norwegian soldiers, Father Sava holds court in a room plastered with photographs of the 80 Serb churches and monasteries destroyed by Albanian extremists since the end of the war. In immaculate English, learned while studying to be an English professor at Belgrade University, he claims that many in the Albanian community are determined to empty Kosovo of Serbs.

"Their logic is that the fewer Serbs in Kosovo the sooner they'll get independence because when there are no Serbs in Kosovo there will be no reasons for the Serbs to keep any claim to Kosovo."

Nato and the aid agencies, whose jeeps clog the streets of Pristina, are acutely aware that their mission will only be judged a success if the 150,000 Serbs who have fled Kosovo in the last year return. And for that to happen the killing must stop.

Paula Ghedini, a UNHCR spokeswoman in Pristina, admits that there is a long way to go. "Most ethnic minorities in Kosovo today are prisoners in their own homes. They are being attacked and harassed on a daily basis."

Her boss, UNHCR head of mission Dennis McNamara, is convinced that a proper judicial system and an even-handed police force are the only way forward.

"The political necessity for the return of the Serbs is very real. Kids can't be allowed to stone old ladies when they go to market with impunity. That has to be stopped."

Kosovo Albanian politicians are willing to denounce attacks on the Serbs but that it as far as they will go. Behind-the-scenes pressure from the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, and from Nato has so far fallen on deaf ears.

The attitude of Hashim Thaci, the former political leader of the now disbanded Kosovo Liberation Army, is typical. Flanked by two burly bodyguards, his rhetoric is impressive but short on detail.

"Minorities from a Kosovar perspective means honour and glory and we will respect those values," he says, when asked if the Serb minority has a place in Kosovo. "I'm in the service of tolerance and oppose violence. My wish is not to have Serbian victims at all."

But with local elections due in October and few signs of Serb participation, the international community knows that it has to do something quickly.

The UN's Bill Nash believes that displaced Serbs must be encouraged to return. "The Serb returns issue is one of the major ones the international community should deal with. If you break that logjam you can solve a lot of issues."

Thousands of new homes are to be built by the EU and various charities and some of these could be made available to returning Serbs.

Yet, even in this most divided of towns, there are signs of hope. The Serbs have, after much soul searching, agreed to set up a joint cement factory with the Albanian community.

fields.headline: Tories 'will never switch to euro'
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The head of the Tories' campaign to oppose the single currency said yesterday that the party will extend William Hague's pledge to save sterling beyond the lifetime of the next parliament.
fields.byline: Kevin Maguire and Julia Hartley-Brewer, political correspondent
fields.body:
The head of the Tories' campaign to oppose the single currency said yesterday that the party will extend William Hague's pledge to save sterling beyond the lifetime of the next parliament.

Lord Bell, chairman of the Conservative Keep the Pound Campaign, suggested to anti-euro diehards that the pledge would be almost indefinite.

The PR guru's prediction goes beyond the official Conservative line, which is to rule out entry only until the election after next. He also indicated that only tactical reasons prevent many senior party figures from publicly backing a "never, ever" promise to retain sterling.

Questioned why the Tories current policy only safeguards the pound for five more years, he said: "You can draw the conclusion that the pound will be safe in the conservative party, both at the next election, during the next period of government and afterwards."

The Tory peer made his comments at a London meeting of Congress of Democracy, a cross-party coalition of anti-single currency groups and individuals.

The hardline signal risks inflaming tensions in the Conservative party at Westminster. Rebels led by Ken Clarke are threatening to put pro-euro statements in their constituency manifestos while a significant number of rightwingers now want the party to quit the European Union.

Lord Bell's thinking is known to be similar to that of senior figures around Mr Hague.

Trevor Kavanagh, the political editor of the Sun, told the meeting that 85% of the 10m readers of the country's biggest selling paper wanted to keep the pound and that Mr Murdoch remains implacably opposed to the new currency.

"I see absolutely no question of that changing and I think indeed there is no indication of that on any of the titles that he owns in this country at the highest level," he added.

If accurate, Mr Kavanagh's statement suggests that Labour plans to soften hostility shown by the Times, and possibly the News of the World, to the euro will prove fruitless.

The Labour MP Austin Mitchell and a Green party spokesman, Mike Woodin, told the gathering of 200 campaigners that only a broad cross-party fight could save sterling, although Mr Woodin admitted he did not like Lady Thatcher and Mr Murdoch as allies.

His discomfort will be have been heightened by Michael Shrimpton, a senior figure in the Bruges Group, who said the campaign had to learn lessons from the RAF's wartime campaign against Germany: "Unless we go on the offensive and keep up the offensive like Bomber Harris did, we won't win."

Hague targets 'tax hole'

William Hague last night attempted to draw the battle lines for the general election by accusing Labour of reverting to its traditional colours as a "party of tax and spend".

The Conservative leader said the government's pledge to increase public spending by £43bn over three years would leave a hole of £17bn in the public purse - one requiring the equivalent of 5p on the basic rate of income tax to fill.

Mr Hague's attack followed Labour's claim that his party's spending plans contained a £16bn hole. His words indicated that he was seeking to place the economy, and tax and spending in particular, at the centre of the election battle.

He spoke after chairing a shadow cabinet "away day" at a London hotel to finalise the Conservative manifesto and decide strategy for the general election, which could be less than a year away. He said it had been "one of the best shadow cabinet meetings we've had since the last election", and added: "The next Labour government, if they were to win the election, would be a tax raising government, just as they have been in this government."

The shadow cabinet was buoyed by the latest opinion poll, giving Labour only a 10 point lead over the Tories, after Tony Blair's worst month in office. It agreed a policy document to be published in September and voted on by party members at the annual conference in October.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, will announce next week the result of the comprehensive spending review, in which he is expected to allocate an extra £43bn to public services. Mr Hague said: "They can't demonstrate that they will be able to spend those sums of money, so I think it is for them to try to demonstrate how they can possibly guarantee such spending totals."

His spokesman said details of the shadow cabinet's "brain-storming" ideas would be announced soon.

fields.headline: Ruling exposes loophole for drivers
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Thousands of motorists could escape punishment for dangerous or drunken driving following a ruling yesterday by a judge that part of the Road Traffic Act 1988 breaches drivers' human rights.
fields.body:
Thousands of motorists could escape punishment for dangerous or drunken driving following a ruling yesterday by a judge that part of the Road Traffic Act 1988 breaches drivers' human rights.

Thousands more who have been convicted could seek to have their cases reopened after the Human Rights Act comes into effect in October.

Judge Peter Crawford ruled at Birmingham crown court that the requirement for drivers to tell police if they were behind the wheel of the car breaches the protection against self-incrimination, a key element of the right to a fair trial protected by article 6 of the European convention on human rights.

He dismissed dangerous driving prosecutions against Amesh Chauhan, 22, and Dean Hollingsworth, 23, both of Birmingham, who were accused of being part of a gang racing cars around the city centre. The case is the first of its kind in England, but last February Scotland's appeal court threw out a drink driving prosecution against Margaret Brown, 30, after she confessed to police, who found her over the alcohol limit at an all-night supermarket, that she had driven her car there.

The Road Traffic Act makes it an offence to refuse to give police the name and address of the driver, effectively forcing drivers to incriminate themselves.

The judgment followed the Scotland Act, which incorporated the European convention into Scottish law as part of the devolution process last year. It caused an outcry in Scotland where hundreds of prosecutions have been held up pending an appeal.

The Human Rights Act, which incorporates the convention into English law, will not come into force until October. But lawyers said judges are taking it into account in the run-up to the act so as not to clog up the courts with ap peals and challenges from October.

The crown prosecution service is almost certain to appeal against Judge Crawford's ruling. A spokeswoman said: "We are studying the judge's remarks very carefully and will be seeking counsel's advice to see what to do next."

The Human Rights Act has retrospective provisions which could allow those already convicted on the strength of their own admissions that they were driving the car to have their convictions reopened.

But Ben Emmerson, a human rights QC, said the judges would probably use their dis cretion to limit appeals to cases where "substantial injustice" had resulted.

The two Birmingham men were sent standard police letters warning them that they might be prosecuted and asking them to give the name and address of the person driving at the time.

Owen Davies, a QC specialising in criminal law and public law, said: "It sounds like an outrageous decision but it is not if you consider the underlying principle. The right not to incriminate oneself is a curb on the oppressive use of might by the state."

Jonathan Walker, a partner in the Birmingham solicitors, Challinors Lyon Clark, said it would be open to police to remove the threat of prosecution for failing to give the information. "But without the threat of prosecution, people are not going to bother answering the letter, which puts them in a bit of a hole."

webTitle: The five deaths that link a village in middle England to a CJD epidemic

fields.headline: The five deaths that link a village in middle England to a CJD epidemic
fields.standfirst:
Special report: what's wrong with our food?
How human BSE emerged
fields.trailText: The village of Queniborough in Leicestershire was yesterday at the heart of a national investigation into an apparent "cluster" of five victims of the human form of BSE.
fields.body:
The village of Queniborough in Leicestershire was yesterday at the heart of a national investigation into an apparent "cluster" of five victims of the human form of BSE.

For the second time in less than two years, doctors and scientists began asking whether this was just an extraordinary coincidence or something that might help explain the spread of the harrowing disease.

A teenage mother, Stacey Robinson, 19, was first to die in August 1998. Stacey, who left a young son Josh, only moved to Thurmaston, three miles from Queniborough, shortly before her death.

Ms Beyless moved to Hampshire in 1991 but returned to Glenfield, seven miles from Queniborough, when she fell ill in March 1996, the same month the then Conservative government announced a probable link between eating beef during the 1980s and the arrival of a horrible new disease.

Glen Day, a 35-year-old van driver from Queniborough, died in the same month as Ms Beyless.

It's such a rare disease. Pam ate well. We always ate meat. It used to be ever so cheap in those days."

The connection with Queniborough (parish population 2,297) had not gone unnoticed by the CJD surveillance unit in Edinburgh. They tried to find a link between the three cases other than the connection to the village. They could not. But last month they were back. A 19-year-old man had died in Leicester royal infirmary. His identity remains confidential but he is thought to have come from the cluster area. A 25-year-old is slowly slipping towards death nursed by his mother at home and is considered another probable victim. He once lived in Rearsby, just one-and-a-half miles from Queniborough.

First, the national death toll has risen sharply to 67. Eight other probable victims remain alive but their condition, if it is vCJD, is incurable. The news of the Queniborough cluster followed.

Was BSE more prevalent in cattle than in other parts of the country? What abattoirs operated locally? Who were the local butchers? Where were the local restaurants and burger bars? Was there a problem with the water courses? And most difficult of all, what were the families of victims eating? Was it the same as other families who have so far been free from the disease?

The government may have been advised by statistical experts that the fact that such a high number of people appear to have caught the slow-burning disease locally is unlikely to have occurred by chance. But chance it still might be.

Robert Will, head of the CJD unit at Ed inburgh, said: "Statistical evidence of a cluster might be of importance in identifying further information on the causes of vCJD. But I am a bit cautious about it. We have previously identified clusters which in the end turned out not to be significant. That is the problem with rare phenomena _ I am still not sure we will find anything definite from this statistical anomaly."

Apparent links between some victims and Ashford in Kent are among those that have been previously examined by the unit. Members have used 1991 censuses to try to gauge the structure of local populations but sometimes their inquiries have had to go much further back.

Roy Anderson, the Oxford epidemiologist and government adviser on the disease, said the number of vCJD cases was "trickling upwards". In 1995 there were three cases, 10 in 1996, the same in 1997, and 18 in 1998. Last year the number fell to 14, but this year there had been 12 cases already and the epidemic could be starting.

Epidemic

"This year's figure is likely to be bigger than previous years. It is still too early though to say whether the epidemic will be small, medium or large."

It is understood that Leicestershire hospitals may soon be included in a national survey of tonsils and appendixes removed from patients since the late 1980s. These are areas parts of the body in which the disease is known to incubate before emerging into obvious signs. Checks carried out on tonsils and appendixes elsewhere in the country have so far failed to uncover any trace of the disease. Meanwhile Philip Monk, consultant in communicable diseases in Leicestershire, said: "We have received a lot of assistance from national experts in their field. It is early days. We may however soon be at the stage where we are close to being able to develop a hypothesis."

There did not seem to have been panic locally. "We have had people phoning in with very helpful information but we have not had worried people."

The Beyless family's faith in authority was shaken to the foundations by the death of their bubbly and sociable daughter. They no longer eat beef. But other villagers in this quintessential slice of middle England feel differently. Queniborough, with its smart thatched roofed and Tudor cottages, lies in the middle of farmland hunted by the Quorn and the Cottesmore.

There is sympathy for the vCJD victims, but strong feelings for the farmers too.

A 56-year-old farmer, who refused to give her name, said: "This is terrible. It's not going to do any good at all."

Sue Allen, 39, a villager, said: "My grandad was a butcher so I've eaten meat all my life. I buy beef now it's back on the bone. I think you'll find a lot of people who will feel very sorry for our butcher."

David Clarke, the local butcher, was near to losing his cool by mid afternoon yesterday.

He insisted: "We are talking about something from the 1980s - not something that is necessarily relevant to the present time.

"It's unfortunate that the local butcher has to take all the flak when 90% of the food bought in the village is from local supermarkets.

"We always get our meat from reputable suppliers and it's always good quality.

"The whole community is stunned by having their home village linked to this disease."

Mr Clarke said he was confident customers would rally round.

Retired hosiery worker Lucy Bigley, 76, stuffing a silverside cut of beef into her handbag said: "I've been coming here for 40 odd years. I think the disease must have been brought into the village from outside."

fields.headline: A new killer
fields.standfirst:
How human BSE emerged

Special report: what's wrong with our food?
The five deaths that link a village in middle England to a CJD epidemic
fields.trailText: How human BSE emerged
fields.body:
The families of victims call it human BSE, rather than its scientific name of variant CJD. Those who watched the first young people die from the horrific new disease were always convinced their loved ones had effectively been poisoned by eating infected beef.

Ten were dead - Stephen Churchill the first in May 1995 - before doctors and other scientists told the Conservative government in March 1996 this probably was the case. Now the death toll is 67 and eight others are thought to have the incurable condition, which often manifests itself in mood swings and depression, before involving the slightly shambling, swaying gait associated with BSE-infected cows. Gradual loss of bodily functions follow before a harrowing death.

Important knowledge has been gained since the momentous announcement of the probable link with beef, but the theory remains unproven if stronger than ever. The disease's signature of bright blotches of abnormal proteins in the brain is similar to that identified in BSE cattle.

All the victims have been of the same genetic make-up, one shared by 40% of the population, although whether this means they are more likely to contract the condition or simply develop clinical signs more quickly is still not clear.

The most favoured theory is that these rogue proteins are responsible for de stroying healthy ones next door and creating "holes" in the brain. The appendix and tonsils are also thought to be hotbeds for signs of the disease before it becomes outwardly apparent.

Treatment to modulate the disease , let alone cure it, is a distant prospect. Incubation periods are unknown although the suspicion is that it could be between a few years and more than 30. The guess is that most people who have died so far were infected before measures designed to protect food from the most infected parts of cows were introduced in 1989. This means some victims were actually infected as babies.

webTitle: How No 10 put spin on staff to impress BBC

fields.headline: How No 10 put spin on staff to impress BBC
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: A series of leaked memos from No 10 reveals how Downing Street spun the BBC to cast Alastair Campbell in a favourable light in a BBC documentary to be shown tonight.
fields.body:
A series of leaked memos from No 10 reveals how Downing Street spun the BBC to cast Alastair Campbell in a favourable light in a BBC documentary to be shown tonight.

Civil servants and the prime minister's special advisers were told to smile and be polite for the cameras during staged meetings, according to emails passed to the Guardian.

The memos, sent to senior staff by Anji Hunter, Tony Blair's private secretary, ordered Mr Campbell's colleagues to be on their best behaviour during filming of The News From No 10, to be shown on BBC2 at 7.40pm.

One message, sent from Ms Hunter to Mr Campbell and other members of Mr Blair's office, suggests the programme's director, Michael Cockerell, was only allowed to see carefully selected meetings. "The day has dawned for Michael Cockerell to film," wrote Ms Hunter on April 11. "We will be in the study, which as you all know is where we usually meet [a tongue-in-cheek reference to the fact that internal meetings are seldom held in No 10's study, because it does not have room for all the senior staff.] If we can keep numbers down (much smaller room), it would be good."

The messages suggest that filming was restricted to meetings which could be controlled. "We have picked this one for him to do as there is less to discuss, what with [Budget] purdah, local elections and Easter hols coming up."

Ms Hunter also poked fun at the behaviour of Lord (Charles) Faulkner, a cabinet office minister and friend of Mr Blair: "Charlie F is appearing in front of the Transport Select [committee], so we are spared the late, shirt-flapping arrival."

In an earlier memo, Ms Hunter asks officials to be polite for the cameras. "Michael Cockerell (plus notebook and beady eye) will be observing this meeting, so perhaps a little more cool efficiency, bonhomie towards our ministerial colleagues and decorum".

Both No 10 and Mr Cockerell have insisted that the fly-on-the-wall programme presented No 10 in an unvarnished state.

Another email, sent later in March, hints that Downing Street was able keep the BBC team at arm's length from sensitive subjects: "You can all breathe easy - Cockerell's been binned from today's meeting," Ms Hunter wrote.

Permission for the BBC to film was approved by Mr Campbell despite opposition from senior staff, who feared the programme could cause a backlash against the government's special advisers.

webTitle: Labour rhetoric brings cynicism, minister warns

fields.headline: Labour rhetoric brings cynicism, minister warns
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's excessively rhetorical claims had inadvertently contributed to the spread of public cynicism toward politics, Charles Clarke, the Home Office minister, warned his party yesterday.
fields.body:
Labour's excessively rhetorical claims had inadvertently contributed to the spread of public cynicism toward politics, Charles Clarke, the Home Office minister, warned his party yesterday.

In a pamphlet published by Progress, Labour modernisers who support Tony Blair, Mr Clarke wrote: "We need to avoid any soundbite or statement which suggests change has actually been achieved, when actually what we have done is to put another building block into place."

The minister admitted: "We have sometimes unintentionally assisted our enemies in their campaigns to destabilise and spread cynicism about all politics and politicians...

"We have sometimes seemed to acquiesce in the view that a policy announcement, a future budget allocation, a new law, was itself a change achieved, when in reality it was only a step along the way."

Mr Clarke also attacked the cynicism engendered by what he called the John Humphrys Tendency, a reference to the BBC Radio 4 interviewer's seeming stance of unwillingness to accept anything a politician said at face value. He wrote: "It is not simply a question of making a speech, writing a newspaper headline, publishing a policy document, changing a law or making a budget allocation.

"Delivering change requires more again - it requires organisations to change, professional disciplines to change, cultures to change, and people to change."

He warned the government had to be especially careful not to raise expectations that it could not fulfill in the short term. "After 1997, I think the people of this country are understandably impatient for change, so much so that they find it difficult to see the tremendous amount that has already been achieved. And they become depressed if they think that we are claiming that more change has actually happened than they themselves have yet experienced."

In what may be seen as a criticism of Downing Street tactics, he argued that Labour needed to find allies willing to embrace change, rather than confront potential enemies. Equally, he urged the government to allow different models of power and government to be tried out in different parts of the country.

Charges by Conservatives, he wrote, "that we are out of touch and spin too much, must be contested by open and public acknowledgment that the process of change is difficult. I believe that is what the prime minister was doing by references to the 'lashes on his back' and to the 'forces of conservatism'. That is the essence of the slogan which I believe to be very powerful and very true: 'A lot done, a lot more to do'."

In the pamphlet, Mr Clarke was joined by the health secretary, Alan Milburn, in warning against accepting a false choice between Labour's heartland vote and the middle class. Mr Milburn wrote that the coalition Labour built to win in 1997 was not one of expediency but a natural coalition. Labour's true task was to unite the country against social injustice, rather than engender division; the only beneficiaries of the heartlands argument, if translated into a political strategy, would be the Conservatives.

fields.headline: Two's company, three's a riot
fields.standfirst: Governments feel more at ease when their subjects are cowed. Perhaps that was the reason for the terrorism bill
fields.trailText: Governments feel more at ease when their subjects are cowed. Perhaps that was the reason for the terrorism bill.
fields.body:
The terrorism bill became law this week. It appears that the government received information (I cannot expand because of the lives of agents in the field) that there has been disquiet in one of the colonies. Apparently, matters came to a head in 1916, when a badly organised revolution failed to achieve independence. In what woolly liberals described as an overreaction, the rebel leaders were executed. Failing to understand the checks and safeguards underpinning the shootings (for example, the wounded James Connolly was firmly tied to a chair to prevent him from falling while he was being shot), Irish people swung behind the revolutionary movement as it stepped up its efforts to defeat Britain.

There followed partition and an on-off struggle for full independence. By the late 60s, the national question had receded, but civil rights issues (mainly demands for an end to discrimination in housing and suffrage) led to the crown's representatives in uniform battering marchers. That brutality helped to bring the IRA back into being. Britain responded with internment, Bloody Sunday, the Emergency Provisions Act and, when the war came to England, the Prevention of Terrorism Act. Support for the war increased with every piece of repression.

I'm boring you, so let's fast-forward. In the 90s, the IRA abandoned its paramilitary strategy and Britain set about replacing emergency legislation. But the government would never wish to lose its alluring mystique. It would never let our relationship with it become boring by doing something predictable. So it has added spice by bringing in a law that is more repressive than the old ones.

Actually, we should have expected as much. After all, the end of the cold war led to the expansion of Nato and the intelligence services. This might just be seen as a kind of inappropriate response disorder, of a piece with government policy in general. For example, a school needs help, so it is penalised; a school doesn't need help, so it is rewarded. But the matter of danger to the public involves a subtly different set of imperatives.

Governments feel more comfortable when their subjects walk in fear. If there were nothing left to fear, the government would launch an initiative to tackle cannibalism, goblins or laudanum parties, to create the impression that something requiring legislation is going on. If all else fails, there is always the Rogue Madman Who Will Stop At Nothing threat. I am sure that, when republican splinter groups throw in the towel, the British government will announce that the new threat comes from the Continuity Bond Villain Army, or a previously unknown Islamic group holed up in the Mourne mountains.

"Emergency legislation" is exciting - all sirens and bells. It wasn't that the government had left a legal loophole before 1974, whereby you could put a bomb in a pub and they couldn't touch you for it. In fact they'd do you whether you put a bomb in a pub or not. But this new law does not appear to be intended simply to wind the public up. The government is entirely genuine about wanting to curtail freedom. It is genuinely rattled by direct action. Terrorism has now been redefined to include "serious damage to property" and action "designed seriously to interfere with or seriously to disrupt an electronic system". The latter clause was introduced in the Lords by Lord Bach in response to the Love Bug. Whether he meant the over-hyped computer virus or Herbie the anarchist Volkswagen, I don't know. But it means that if you jam the government's fax machines or mess around with its website (or Coca-Cola's), you are a terrorist.

You are also a terrorist if you damage a Hawk jet on its way to Indonesia. If you get drunk on your stag night and nick one, you will be dealt with by the laws covering high jinks; but if you are motivated by support for the people of East Timor, you can face life imprisonment - as you can if you damage anything during any form of political or environmental activism. Under the act, things that might otherwise constitute criminal damage become terrorism when done to advance a cause and when designed to intimidate the public or "influence the government".

Moreover, under the act, "the public" and "the govern ment" both cover the entire world. And if you urge Iraqi Kurds to rebel, you will be "inciting terrorism overseas", unless you are in the government, as John Major obviously was when he did it. The attorney general will decide whether such prosecutions go ahead, so that we don't embarrass our friends.

It is also an offence to have a hand in organising a meeting of three or more people, in public or private, which is to be addressed by someone belonging to or professing to belong to a proscribed organisation, whatever that person is speaking about. Perhaps you won't get the full 10 years if the discussion is about a possible ceasefire.

In any event, many more of you are terrorists as of Tuesday. Think of yourselves as freedom fighters, but say you are just mindless vandals if you want to get away with a fine.
