It would never let our relationship with it become boring by doing something predictable. So it has added spice by bringing in a law that is more repressive than the old ones. Actually, we should have expected as much. After all, the end of the cold war led to the expansion of Nato and the intelligence services. This might just be seen as a kind of inappropriate response disorder, of a piece with government policy in general. For example, a school needs help, so it is penalised; a school doesn't need help, so it is rewarded. But the matter of danger to the public involves a subtly different set of imperatives. Governments feel more comfortable when their subjects walk in fear. If there were nothing left to fear, the government would launch an initiative to tackle cannibalism, goblins or laudanum parties, to create the impression that something requiring legislation is going on. If all else fails, there is always the Rogue Madman Who Will Stop At Nothing threat. I am sure that, when republican splinter groups throw in the towel, the British government will announce that the new threat comes from the Continuity Bond Villain Army, or a previously unknown Islamic group holed up in the Mourne mountains. "Emergency legislation" is exciting - all sirens and bells. It wasn't that the government had left a legal loophole before 1974, whereby you could put a bomb in a pub and they couldn't touch you for it. In fact they'd do you whether you put a bomb in a pub or not. But this new law does not appear to be intended simply to wind the public up. The government is entirely genuine about wanting to curtail freedom. It is genuinely rattled by direct action. Terrorism has now been redefined to include "serious damage to property" and action "designed seriously to interfere with or seriously to disrupt an electronic system". The latter clause was introduced in the Lords by Lord Bach in response to the Love Bug. Whether he meant the over-hyped computer virus or Herbie the anarchist Volkswagen, I don't know. But it means that if you jam the government's fax machines or mess around with its website (or Coca-Cola's), you are a terrorist. You are also a terrorist if you damage a Hawk jet on its way to Indonesia. If you get drunk on your stag night and nick one, you will be dealt with by the laws covering high jinks; but if you are motivated by support for the people of East Timor, you can face life imprisonment - as you can if you damage anything during any form of political or environmental activism. Under the act, things that might otherwise constitute criminal damage become terrorism when done to advance a cause and when designed to intimidate the public or "influence the government". Moreover, under the act, "the public" and "the govern ment" both cover the entire world. And if you urge Iraqi Kurds to rebel, you will be "inciting terrorism overseas", unless you are in the government, as John Major obviously was when he did it. The attorney general will decide whether such prosecutions go ahead, so that we don't embarrass our friends. It is also an offence to have a hand in organising a meeting of three or more people, in public or private, which is to be addressed by someone belonging to or professing to belong to a proscribed organisation, whatever that person is speaking about. Perhaps you won't get the full 10 years if the discussion is about a possible ceasefire. In any event, many more of you are terrorists as of Tuesday. Think of yourselves as freedom fighters, but say you are just mindless vandals if you want to get away with a fine. comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Africa wakes up to Aids
fields.standfirst: Durban's lesson is that it is preventable
fields.trailText: The goal of the Aids 2000 conference in Durban this week was to "break the silence". This was what the UN organisers had identified as the biggest obstacle to tackling the Aids crisis in sub-saharan Africa
fields.body:
The goal of the Aids 2000 conference in Durban this week was to "break the silence". This was what the UN organisers had identified as the biggest obstacle to tackling the Aids crisis in sub-saharan Africa. As they pack up in Durban today, they can justly claim that they have gone a long way to achieving their goal. Finally, the world has sat up and taken notice of the scale of the catastrophe in many African nations. Finally, Africans have been talking openly and in detail about what urgently needs to be done and how to do it. When the president of Botswana told the conference that his country faces extinction, he sent shock waves around the world.

By holding the conference in the epicentre of the disaster - South Africa: it has the largest number of HIV infections in the world - it exposed how Aids has become inextricably linked with poverty and underdevelopment. (It is unfortunate that with the next conference in 2002 due to take place in Spain, this dimension is likely to recede.) Southern Africa makes real the words of scientists such as Roy Anderson, who stated in Durban that Aids is the biggest infectious disease to befall humanity.

The hope has to be that this will prove a turning point in the will to tackle Africa's terrible plight. That was the rallying cry of Nelson Mandela's finely crafted speech yesterday. Stepping into the confusion within South Africa sown by President Thabo Mbeki's equivocation on the link between HIV and Aids, he threw the full weight of his authority behind the scientists and laid out a detailed set of proposals for how to bring the HIV infection rates down. These could prove a blueprint for African nations across the continent. Because the most crucial lesson in Durban was that this tragedy is preventable. Public education campaigns do change sexual behaviour, as Uganda's example has shown. Drugs can prevent mother-baby transmission, if they are free and available.

What the Durban conference has also helped clarify is that this is not a problem that the developed world can afford to ignore. Unicef was just one of the international agencies in Durban promising to rectify the slowness of its response. There is still a long way to go - not enough money and the drugs are still too expensive - but Durban's important achievement was to remind the world that Aids remains a terrifying threat to humanity.

webTitle: Fiji's race warrior tells world to 'butt out'

fields.headline: Fiji's race warrior tells world to 'butt out'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Fiji coup
fields.trailText: Fiji found itself edging into the league of pariah states yesterday as George Speight, who ousted a multi-ethnic democratic government in the name of domination for indigenous Fijians, strengthened his grip on power.
fields.body:
Fiji found itself edging into the league of pariah states yesterday as George Speight, who ousted a multi-ethnic democratic government in the name of domination for indigenous Fijians, strengthened his grip on power.

An insouciant Mr Speight told outsiders to "butt out" of Fiji's affairs and leave it to native Fijians to decide their own direction.

For the moment, he seemed in control. His preferred candidates were in place as president and vice-president, and a new transitional administration was being formed to include some of his close collaborators.

Mr Speight and his followers got the amnesty they were promised in a deal with the military after his henchmen surrendered the weapons they used to occupy parliament, where they had held a group of politicians hostage since mid-May. Among these was Mahendra Chaudhry, forced out as Fiji's first ethnic Indian prime minister.

Mr Speight's group has an assurance from power-brokers in the army and the indigenous Great Council of Chiefs that the 1997 constitution, which increased the political rights of Indo-Fijians, will be revoked. It is already suspended.

Among many international condemnations of the Speight faction, that of New Zealand's foreign affairs minister was one of the most stinging: "These people are self-serving ... they don't like democracy because democracy didn't serve their own ends," Phil Goff said.

Mr Speight, who handed in 70 weapons including semi-automatic guns and landmines as a condition of the amnesty for him and his men, said such critics should "butt out". There would be no return to a government led by Indo-Fijians.

"Any attempt by anyone to return Fiji to the status quo before May 19 [when the rebels brought parliament to a halt] will be met with the same resistance we showed to the army of this country," he said.

"It's about time the world started listening to the fact that Fijians have the ultimate right to determine where Fiji goes in the future."

The United States, Australia and New Zealand have all urged their citizens to leave Fiji due to the unstable situa tion. The civilian coup has weakened not only the government but also the police and the army, which temporarily stepped in while the government was in limbo.

With police nervous of intervening, there was more trouble in the vital tourism industry: tribesmen armed with knives and pipes attacked a luxury resort and beat up its European manager in a dispute over land rights.

Meanwhile, the Great Council of Chiefs installed Jope Seniloli as vice- president, having appointing Josefa Iloilo as president on Thursday.

Mr Speight is claiming victory, confident that the new president will support his side's nationalistic and anti-Indian philosophy when it comes to putting together a government to replace the one led by Mr Chaudhry.

The rebel leader clearly felt he was pulling the strings when it came to drawing up a cabinet list: "I have left it to the discretion of the president," he said, "but you know he might want to change a couple of names in there but there are certain key people in the key portfolios that must be in the hands of our people."

The chairman of the chiefs' council meeting was the former prime minister, Sitiveni Rabuka, who led the 1987 coup against a government formed by two mainly Indo-Fijian parties. He denied the chiefs had simply done Mr Speight's bidding although both Mr Iloilo and Mr Seniloli had been endorsed by the rebel leader.

But he conceded that the crisis had left the Fiji islands very damaged: "Nobody wins a coup," he said. "The whole nation suffers. He [Speight] is free to enjoy his self-perceived victory."

Mr Speight claimed to be acting on behalf of indigenous Fijians when he and his gang raided parliament on May 19 and took Mr Chaudhry and 26 others hostage.

But while there has been some talk of sanctions in support of the restoration of full rights for Indo-Fijians, the in ternational community - while it might come up with some symbolic punishment - seemed reluctant yesterday to impose new hardships on the country.

The past two months of disruption has already hurt the main industry, sugar, and tourist bookings have plummeted. An expected exodus of Indo-Fijian businessmen and professionals will further reduce domestic investment.

Australia's foreign minister, Alexander Downer, said any Fijian attempt to disenfranchise the country's ethnic Indian population, who 44% of the total, was doomed but he was wary of cutting trade and aid links.

"We're not prepared to destroy the Fijian economy," he said. "I know some people say we should, but I think that would be grossly irresponsible."

Fiji's tourist image as a South Pacific paradise is tarnished after attacks on island resorts by indigenous landowners, some wearing balaclavas and wielding knives.

In the worst case, managers of the Laucala Island Resort, Ric and Carol West, aged 48 and 44, were beaten and tied up by drunken villagers carrying cane knives and steel pipes who vandalised the facilities. The resort shut down when the coup began two months ago.

The villagers freed the Wests and left just in time to benefit from yesterday's amnesty for "political acts" by Mr Speight and anyone acting in his name.

webTitle: Researchers find serious flood risk on US east coast

fields.headline: Researchers find serious flood risk on US east coast
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: American geologists say they have found evidence that large parts of the east coast of the United States are at risk from huge waves which could put cities like New York, Philadelphia and Washington at risk from serious flooding.
fields.body:
American geologists say they have found evidence that large parts of the east coast of the United States are at risk from huge waves which could put cities like New York, Philadelphia and Washington at risk from serious flooding.

Normally, the disaster-mongering strand in American life focuses its attention on the possibilities of a geological apocalypse on the west coast, where earthquakes and the waves they cause are thought most likely to strike. But the new research suggests that the threats are at least as real on the more heavily populated Atlantic seaboard.

The danger in the east comes from large amounts of water trapped under high pressure by sediment on the east coast continental shelf about 100 miles off the coast of New Jersey, say two Pennsylvania State University geologists, Peter Flemings and Brandon Gugan.

If expelled violently after an earth tremor, the result could be to cause undersea landslides and to send waves speeding towards the coast.

Writing in the journal Science, the two scientists say that their research reveals that rocks on the relatively shallow continental shelf are so porous that they are geologically unstable. Pressure in the deeply buried layers of rock is more than sufficient to drive the water sideways until it breaks out and into the ocean.

"We found a potential for water trapped there under pressure to surge out and cause landslides or to seep out slowly," Mr Flemings said. "Undersea landslides are known to cause tidal waves, and we agree with recent reports from other researchers that there is potential for expulsive events in the continental slope along the east coast," he added.

Earlier this year a team of researchers from the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution in Massachusetts reported that they had discovered unusual amounts of gas trapped under a 25-mile stretch of the slope east of Chesapeake Bay. Blowouts from the gas could also cause waves, they concluded.

Geological cracks in the ocean floor were discovered about 60 miles east of the mouth of the bay. The Massachusetts researchers calculated that the cracks meant a risk of undersea landslides causing 20-foot high waves along coasts stretching from Maryland in the north to North Carolina in the south. Cities such as Washington, Baltimore and Norfolk would be at risk of serious flooding, while shipping - including the US navy's Atlantic fleet, which is stationed at Norfolk - would also be at risk.

webTitle: A country inflicting wounds on itself

fields.headline: A country inflicting wounds on itself
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Fiji coup
fields.trailText: George Speight's demand for political supremacy for ethnic Fijians looks close to being rubber-stamped by the country's elite, Fiji's Great Council of Chiefs.
fields.body:
George Speight's demand for political supremacy for ethnic Fijians looks close to being rubber-stamped by the country's elite, Fiji's Great Council of Chiefs.

Josefa Iloilo, the man selected by the council as the new president, is a traditional chief from the western part of Fiji's main island, Viti Levu. He is expected to include in his interim administration several of the rebel politicians who held the country to ransom.

The country's next constitution is likely to reserve the prime ministership for an indigenous Fijian, and significantly boost Fijian representation in parliament.

Already, Indo-Fijian homesteads near Mr Speight's home village in eastern Fiji have been ransacked, and some burned to the ground.

The victims had little recourse because the neighbouring police station, at Korovou town, had been seized by rebel militants.

Nearby, an Indo-Fijian wedding party travelling through a roadblock set up at Korovou was stopped by villagers who fleeced the group for jewellery and cash. A policeman called the action "political", implying that it was covered by the amnesty for Speight followers agreed by Mr Speight and the army.

In the squatter settlements around the capital, Suva, Indo-Fijian families have been pushed out of their homes on the Jittu estate, after refusing to make payments demanded by indigenous Fijian neighbours.

Sixty Fiji Telecom workers went on strike this week until their Indo-Fijian general manager, Pratap Singh, was removed from his post.

Under British colonial rule, some 60,000 workers from the Indian sub-continent were imported between 1879 and 1916, mainly to work on sugar plantations. Bonded labour ended in 1920, and Indo-Fijians commenced their long struggle for greater political rights.

By the 1960s, Indians briefly formed a majority of the population, but now they make up 44%, with indigenous Fijians at 51%.

After independence in 1970, an alliance between the descendants of white settlers and leading indigenous Fijian politicians held sway.

Indo-Fijians had considerable business success, but their parties were kept on the opposition benches. In 1987, two largely Indo-Fijian parties - the Fiji Labour party and National Federation party - won elections and briefly formed a government. Mahendra Chaudhry was its finance minister.

Two weeks later, a military coup led by Lieutenant-Colonel Sitiveni Rabuka put ethnic Fijian politicians back in charge until Mr Chaudhry's election in May last year.

After the 1987 coup, some 75,000 Indo-Fijians - including doctors, lawyers and businessmen - left for New Zealand, Australia and Canada. The same is likely this time around.

Domestic investment has also been low ever since 1987, largely because wealthier Indo-Fijians diversified their assets abroad.

Affirmative action programmes for native Fijians have not worked well.

Many poorer Indo-Fijians work in the sugar industry. Indian cane farmers often lease farms from the native Fijians, who own 83% of all land in Fiji.

Until 1997, cane farmers had reasonably secure 30-year leases, but since then increasing numbers have been evicted as their leases expired.

With an indigenous supremacist government in power, many more will be evicted, but now without compensation.

Jonathan Fraenkel is Lecturer in Economic History at the University of the South Pacific in Suva, Fiji

webTitle: Chubais falls victim to oligarch purge

fields.headline: Chubais falls victim to oligarch purge
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Pressure on Russia's leading tycoons intensified yesterday with the decision by a parliament watchdog to investigate the legality of the privatisation the country's electricity monopoly - run by the former architect of Russia's economic reforms, Anatoly Chubais.
fields.body:
Pressure on Russia's leading tycoons intensified yesterday with the decision by a parliament watchdog to investigate the legality of the privatisation the country's electricity monopoly - run by the former architect of Russia's economic reforms, Anatoly Chubais.

The media in Moscow interpreted the Audit Chamber's decision to investigate whether Unified Energy Systems (UES) illegally sold shares to foreigners when it was privatised in the 1990s as the latest in a string of legal attacks on the oligarchs - the businessmen who made fortunes in Russia's transition to capitalism.

The key architect of Russia's privatisation programme and a former finance minister under Boris Yeltsin, Mr Chubais worked alongside President Putin in St Petersburg. He secured his oligarch status when he moved from politics to become chief executive of UES.

Mr Putin has repeatedly stressed his intention to battle against the oligarchs.

Mr Chubais said he believed the charges wer politically motivated, and added: "The grounds for declaring the sale of UES shares to foreigners invalid are ridiculous and legally unsound."

webTitle: 'In face of the threat posed by Aids we must rise above our differences and combine our efforts to save people'

fields.headline: 'In face of the threat posed by Aids we must rise above our differences and combine our efforts to save people'
fields.standfirst:
Mandela goes where Mbeki fears to tread

International Aids Conference
UN Aids programme
fields.trailText: Nelson Mandela, the former South African president, yesterday used all his authority to end the destructive dispute in his country over the cause of Aids and urge scientists and politicians to work together in the battle against a disease that is devastating the continent.
fields.body:
Nelson Mandela, the former South African president, yesterday used all his authority to end the destructive dispute in his country over the cause of Aids and urge scientists and politicians to work together in the battle against a disease that is devastating the continent.

In a powerful and dignified speech, Mr Mandela offered Africa the leadership it needs in the battle against Aids and a blueprint for the way forward. To the delight of scientists and a rapturous reception from the 12,000 delegates at the closing ceremony of the international Aids conference in Durban, he said the rhetoric must end and action begin. He sent a coded message to his successor Thabo Mbeki that the delays over introducing new preventive measures and drug treatments to stop the spread of HIV must stop.

"The ordinary people of this continent and the world - and particularly the poor who on our continent will again carry a disproportionate burden of this scourge - would, if anyone cared to ask their opinions, wish that the dispute about the primacy of politics or science be put on the backburner and that we proceed to address the needs and concerns of those suffering and dying. And this can only be done in partnership.

"In the face of the grave threat posed by HIV/Aids, we have to rise above our differences and combine our efforts to save our people. History will judge us harshly if we fail to do so now, and right now.

"Let us not equivocate: a tragedy of unprecedented proportions is unfolding in Africa. Aids today in Africa is claiming more lives than the sum total of all wars, famines and floods and the ravages of such deadly diseases as malaria. It is devastating families and communities; overwhelming and depleting health care services and robbing schools of both students and teachers."

Mr Mandela praised Mr Mbeki as "a man of great intellect who takes scientific thinking very seriously and he leads a government that I know to be committed to those principles of science and reason".

But he went on: "He will, with me, be the first to concede that much more remains to be done _ The challenge is to move from rhetoric to action, and action at an unprecedented intensity and scale."

He spelled out what needed to be done, including, to cheers and applause, the introduction of drugs to prevent women in labour passing HIV infection to their babies - an issue that the Mbeki government has dragged its feet on.

Mr Mandela said that his country must look to Uganda, Senegal and Thailand which had successfully started to turn the tide of HIV/Aids. He set out a detailed and unequivocal blueprint for Africa.

"Promoting abstinence, safe sex and the use of condoms and ensuring the early treatment of sexually transmitted diseases are some of the steps needed and about which there can be no dispute. Ensuring that people have access to voluntary and HIV counselling and testing services and introducing measures to reduce mother-to-child transmission have been proven to be essential in the fight against Aids."

At the same time, he said, "we need to continue the international effort of searching for appropriate vaccines" as well as working with families and communities to care for children and young people and protect them from violence and abuse.

He made it plain he was prepared to offer the kind of leadership to Africa in its struggle against Aids that scientists had hoped for from Mr Mbeki. "We need, and there is increasing evidence of, African resolve to fight this war. Others will not save us if we do not primarily commit ourselves."

But the international community had to help. Africa did not have the resources it would take to defeat Aids. "Partnership with the international community is vital. A constant theme in all our messages has been that in this globalised world, we have in deed again become the keepers of our brother and sister. That cannot be more graphically the case than in the common fight against HIV/Aids."

His words were greeted with relief at the conference, which has been dominated by the dispute over whether HIV is the cause of Aids, or if it is caused primarily by poverty.

Hoosen Coovadia, the South African paediatrician chairing the conference, said after Mr Mandela finished: "You cannot imagine how your speech is music to our ears. It has answered so many spoken and unspoken questions."

webTitle: Head faces jail for hitting pupil

fields.headline: Head faces jail for hitting pupil
fields.standfirst: Headteacher faces jail for hitting unruly child
fields.trailText: A headmistress with 35 years' experience as a teacher was yesterday facing the possibility of a prison sentence after being convicted of slapping an unruly 10-year-old boy across the face.
fields.body:
A headmistress with 35 years' experience as a teacher was yesterday facing the possibility of a prison sentence after being convicted of slapping an unruly 10-year-old boy across the face.

Marjorie Evans, 55, who has been suspended since the incident in September last year, was found guilty of hitting the boy when he started struggling after being told he could not go to a swimming lesson with classmates at his school in south Wales.

The verdict was immediately condemned by the school's chairman of governors and by Mrs Evans' union, the NUT, which has said it may appeal.

Gethin Lewis, secretary of the NUT in Wales, said parents and teachers would hear about the case with disbelief.

"There will be shivers of fear throughout classrooms in England and Wales when news of the case gets out. The authority of teachers and headteachers has been put into question by this decision."

Mrs Evans, denied hitting the boy, but was yesterday convicted of assault by magistrates in Abergavenny, Gwent, following a five-day trial. Sentencing has been adjourned for two weeks and Mrs Evans has been warned she could face a jail term.

Neither the boy, who is now aged 11, nor the school can be identified for legal reasons.

Mrs Evans, described in court as a teacher with a glowing reputation, told magistrates that she had restrained the boy after he tried to push, punch and headbutt her.

But the court was told that she had used her open palm to slap the "sullen" pupil after momentarily losing her self-control.

Christopher Rees, for the prosecution, said it had not been necessary for the teacher to defend herself and her actions could not be described as reasonable force.

The court heard that on the day of the incident the school was facing a staffing crisis and that the headmistress had to leave her office to fill in because the boy's teacher had a medical appointment.

The boy, who has learning difficulties and was on medication, wanted to go swimming but had been banned from going because of earlier bad behaviour.

He told magistrates that an argument broke out over work he was keeping in the classroom. He said the headmistress grabbed him and took him outside.

"She picked my trays up and pushed them against my chest. I pushed her and she fell backwards on to the bench. I was trying to run away and then she slapped me across the face."

Sandra Cutler, a special needs teacher at the school, said Mrs Evans later admitted hitting the pupil. She said the admission was met with a stunned silence by staff. "She seemed almost proud in the way she said it."

The magistrate, Vivian Manning-Davies, said most people would believe it unthinkable that a headmistress would assault a young pupil. But, he told Mrs Evans: "The longer the case has gone on, the more I have been persuaded to think the unthinkable. He was giving you a torrid time that morning and I'm quite satisfied that despite your years of training you simply snapped and lost your temper".

However, Mr Lewis said: "At no time did she slap him. The magistrate did not believe the evidence of the majority of teachers in the school. He believed one person who came forward at a late stage. I'm advising her to appeal because this has major consequences for the teaching profession."

Graham Powell, chairman of governors at the school, said: "Sometimes the law is an ass. She is an excellent teacher and I have grave doubts that this actually happened. If she takes my advice then she will appeal against this."

He said Mrs Evans, a head teacher for 18 years, would remain suspended while the probation service dealt with the case.

As parents yesterday defended Mrs Evans' running of the 300-pupil school it emerged that Monmouthshire education authority was investigating fresh allegations that children at the school had on occasions been treated "inappropriately" by staff.

Phil Cooke, the council's director of education, said the matter would be looked into as a matter of urgency by child protection agencies including police and social services.

However, the mother of one child at the school said Mrs Evans was "firm but fair" and was well-respected by teachers and staff.

She said parents would like to see her back in school despite the conviction.

webTitle: Out to lunch: Meridian picnic unites France

fields.headline: Out to lunch: Meridian picnic unites France
fields.standfirst:
Audio: Paul Webster at the picnic
NetNotes: the 14th of July
fields.trailText: France celebrated the first Bastille Day of the millennium in style yesterday, with a vast picnic stretching from the English Channel to the Spanish border, and only slightly dampened by the country's coldest July for 20 years.
fields.body:
France celebrated the first Bastille Day of the millennium in style yesterday, with a vast picnic stretching from the English Channel to the Spanish border, and only slightly dampened by the country's coldest July for 20 years.

Up to 4m people were expected to attend the "Incroyable Pique-Nique", along the line of the French meridian, which was abandoned in 1911 in favour of the Greenwich one. A red and white check tablecloth ran from Dunkirk in the north, across Paris to Prats-de-Mollo, in the south, crossing 337 communes, where up to 13,000 trees have been planted over the last eight months as part of France's millennium festivities.

The picnic was devised as a simple event bringing the nation together on the day France celebrates the 1789 revolution that led to the creation of a republic.

But the poor weather dampened the fun in many areas. Television showed picnic tables being set up in torrential rain in the south, and people eating their sandwiches under plastic sheeting in the countryside outside Paris.

Festivities began on Thursday night, when relay teams set out from both ends of the meridian in a baton race across country by foot, motorbike, car and plane. Air traffic was halted at Orly airport, Paris, as the baton was carried across the runway.

Whereas Britain decided to mark the new millennium with a £758m dome at Greenwich, the French event cost about £4.5m to organise, with everyone bringing their own baguettes and wine, and, in keeping with the revolutionary tradition, sharing them.

In Paris there were parties in Pigalle, in the Palais Royal, in the courtyard of the Louvre and in the Luxembourg gardens, where picnickers were granted special permission to sit on the grass. Standard bearers from eight European countries headed France's traditional Bastille Day military parade, which featured 140 planes and helicopters, 3,800 soldiers and 320 vehicles. Reuters

webTitle: Radio 3 snaps up Kershaw, late-night DJ cast aside by Radio 1

fields.headline: Radio 3 snaps up Kershaw, late-night DJ cast aside by Radio 1
fields.trailText: Fan power forced the BBC into one of its most bizarre about-turns last night when Andy Kershaw, the cult DJ dumped by Radio 1, was rehired by Radio 3.
fields.body:
Fan power forced the BBC into one of its most bizarre about-turns last night when Andy Kershaw, the cult DJ dumped by Radio 1, was rehired by Radio 3.

Kershaw, the Lancastrian whose late-night slot put world music stars like Youssou N'Dour on the map here, was dropped by Radio 1 in May amid a storm of protest about the direction the station was going in.

Controller Andy Parfitt was assailed from all quarters for his "shabby treatment of Radio 1's most innovative voice" and pilloried for allegedly pandering to the teen market with a diet of boy bands and commercial pop.

As condemnation of the decision grew, Kershaw, who had been angry at the graveyard slot he had been forced into after 14 years, refused to host his final few shows.

But yesterday Roger Wright, Parfitt's opposite number on Radio 3, stepped in to an nounce a new slot for the DJ on his World Routes programme beginning this summer.

Kershaw will travel the world for the programme, presented by Lucy Duran, and bring back regular reports and recordings he has made on the road.

Signing up Kershaw is a coup for Wright, who has been trying to broaden Radio 3's appeal.

Kershaw joked last night: "I imagine I'll be coming in once a month with a bunch of un popular records, just as I've always done.

"About six months ago I had lunch with Roger Wright and he asked me if I'd be interested in doing bits and pieces for him. What convinced me was when he said: 'I want Radio 3 to be more than a classical music station'."

He said he knew he had to go with Wright when he told him that the thing he most liked about his old show was "that I never know what's coming next".

"That was exactly what the Radio 1 controller hated about my programme," said Kershaw.

He has spent the past few months working on a book about his travels, as well as doing his World Service programme.

"One of the things I was worried about was would there be a lot of hostility from the traditional core audience of Radio 3 - an ex-Radio 1 DJ coming in and playing African music?" he said. "I was more worried for Roger Wright than for me."

Wright also announced that the playwright Mark Ravenhill, best known for his West End play Shopping and Fucking, had been commissioned to write a play for Radio 3.

The commissioning of the controversial Ravenhill, who is known for his expletive-strewn scripts, highlights Wright's mission to set the genteel Radio 3 apart from its commercial radio competitor, Classic FM. The play, which does not yet have a title, will feature in a season of new works called The Wire.

Wright said yesterday that Ravenhill's work would not be bleeped out.

"If you commission writers you want them to be themselves, not tell them how to write.

"But that's not to say that we're pushing boundaries of taste and decency.

"If there are a large number of expletives we will probably put a health warning on it."

He added: "It's a mature, intelligent, grown-up audience, who should be able to make their own minds up."

fields.headline: Medical students reject Darwin
fields.trailText: More than 10% of medical students at a university last year rejected the theory of evolution, according to a study by scientists published yesterday.
fields.body:
More than 10% of medical students at a university last year rejected the theory of evolution, according to a study by scientists published yesterday.

Almost as astonishingly, this view was shared by between 4% and 11% of first-year biology students in every intake at Glasgow University for eight separate years, the research has found.

A "significant minority" of both groups of students shared the Biblical belief of American anti-evolutionists - often previously dismissed in Britain as naive- that God created life out of a void.

The students were nearly all Christians or Islamic. But researchers believe the findings are probably applicable to other universities across Britain.

One of the scientists, Roger Downie, of the Glasgow Institute of Biomedical and Life Sciences, said yesterday that it was "salutary" to discover as many as 11% of a UK university class rejecting biological evolution.

Until now, this had tended to be dismissed as a mainly US factor.

"We would not be concerned if students, having assessed the evidence, were sceptical of aspects of evolution," Dr Downie said

"However, most rejectors did so on the basis of religious belief: this is hardly compatible with the open-mindedness expected of a prospective scientist."

These students were also more likely to disbelieve three other main scientific findings: that cigarettes cause lung cancer; that emissions from power stations cause acid rain; and that gases from aerosols deplete the earth's ozone layer.

The research paper is to be published in the Journal of Biological Education. It studied between 160 and 518 students during each of the years in the expanding biology department and 225 medical students.

webTitle: Parents speak of 'gut instinct' that Sarah is alive

fields.headline: Parents speak of 'gut instinct' that Sarah is alive
fields.standfirst:
E-fit of Sarah Payne suspect
Graphic: What's happened to Sarah?
Sussex police
Timetable: Sarah's disappearance
fields.trailText: Sarah Payne's parents yesterday spoke of their certainty that she would be found unharmed. Although the hunt for their eight-year-old was approaching its third week, Sara and Michael Payne, both 31, refused to contemplate the possibility they would never again see her alive.
fields.body:
Sarah Payne's parents yesterday spoke of their certainty that she would be found unharmed. Although the hunt for their eight-year-old was approaching its third week, Sara and Michael Payne, both 31, refused to contemplate the possibility they would never again see her alive.

But detectives leading the investigation into her disappearance admitted that they were "starting to bed in for a long haul".

Their focus has shifted in the past 24 hours to a white van seen by Sarah's brothers in a lane near Kingston Gorse, West Sussex, on July 1, at the time she vanished. The boys noticed that the van had no windows in its rear doors when it passed them minutes after they had last seen their sister.

Police yesterday were analysing DNA samples from two suspects released on police bail last week, and examining a van.

In the interview at a hotel in Arundel, a pale and drawn Sara Payne, holding tightly to her husband's hand, said her feeling that their daughter was still alive was a gut instinct: "We have always remained positive. It's not a hope, it's a certainty. We are not going to waver from it."

She recounted her memory of the last moments with Sarah, and their other children, Lee, 13, Luke, 11, and Charlotte, six. "We all went for a walk down to the beach. We chatted and we said hello to the three geese on the pond. The children wanted to play on the beach. We gave the two girls a kiss and said the usual thing of stay together, watch out for each other, and they went off to play."

Smoking continuously, the mother said: "You sleep, you wake up and you haven't really slept. You wake up exhausted." The first thing she did when she opened her eyes was say good morning to Sarah. "I am with her, mentally with her. I talk to her constantly, as any mother would."

Her husband said he kept one of his daughter's bracelets in his pocket for comfort,and would often stand in front of the bathroom mirror to talk to her. The first week had been horrendous, he said, the only chance of sleep being when the body refused to go on.

The couple looked constantly to each other for reassurance as they described how the family thought of Sarah constantly. Charlotte was finding it difficult to sleep, and Luke was very emotional.

Mr Payne described how, when the family sat down to eat, Charlotte would occasionally say Sarah might be hungry too, and "when you give Charlotte a cuddle she sometimes says, 'Sarah might like a cuddle too', and that is really hard."

Mrs Payne described Sarah's "bubbly, happy character", and both parents recalled how loud she could be and how she was often told to "pipe down, the people in the next house can hear". Mr Payne added with a sigh: "The house can be very still, and it's so quiet now."

Mrs Payne said Sarah had been very aware of "stranger danger" and would often come home and give everyone else in the family a talking-to.

Lighting another cigarette, she said she and her husband had promised their children: "When Sarah comes home, we will both be giving this up."

Luke told Meridian Television: "At the moment it does not feel like she has actually gone. It feels like she is just sleeping round her friend's house or something. And then sometimes it just hits me, and I am not that happy."

"We all went for a walk down to the beach. We chatted and we said hello to the three geese on the pond. The children wanted to play on the beach. fields.headline: No more ghostly voices
fields.standfirst:
Spin-doctors: Anonymous briefings are being abused, so Alan Rusbridger introduces a Guardian policy to give our readers a fairer deal

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Alan Rusbridger: Spin-doctors: Anonymous briefings are being abused, so Alan Rusbridger introduces a Guardian policy to give our readers a fairer deal.
fields.body:
If you concentrate hard enough tonight you may glimpse a man called Godric Smith on television. No, I had never heard of him either until recently. He is, in the nicest possible way, an anonymous looking man: balding, early forties in a self-effacing two-piece suit.

What do we know about this Godric Smith? We know that, despite reading classics at Oxford, he supports struggling Cambridge United. We know he is married with two children and lives in north London. And that since 1998 he has been the prime minister's deputy press spokesman.

Do I crave to know more about Godric Smith? With all respect to Mr Smith, I cannot say that I do. In an ideal world he would remain a relatively anonymous figure and be the giver of dispassionate, factual information on behalf of the prime minister. It would be nice if he would speak on the record and, preferably, on camera. Otherwise, it would be a relief to know nothing about him.

Mr Smith has a small, non-speaking role in Michael Cockerell's film about Mr Smith's boss, Alastair Campbell, which is being shown on BBC2 this evening. The two men could not be more different. Not even his worst enemy would call Mr Campbell shy, self-effacing or balding. Unlike Mr Smith, Mr Campbell is not a career civil servant. Whereas Mr Smith is anonymous, Mr Campbell is only supposed to be anonymous. He is the subject of at least one full-length book and a television profile. The only thing the two men have in common is a shared passion for Nationwide League football teams.

How, one wonders, could these two men conceivably perform the same role? One is a self-confessed propagandist, the other a career Whitehall information officer. One is a bruiser, a spinner and, if necessary, an assassin. The other is supposedly apolitical. The service which employs Mr Smith requires him to be "objective and explanatory, not tendentious or polemical ... or liable to misrepresentation as being party political".

The difference between the two men might matter less if we, the press, had not connived with them in pretending they are one and the same person. Both have for a long time sheltered behind the comfortable semi-anonymity of being "a Downing Street spokesman", or an "official source", or "a source close to the prime minister". After Michael Cockerell's programme it is difficult to see how this coyness and circumlocution can possibly continue.

Indeed, after tonight's programme, it is difficult to see why anyone would want the present arrangements to persist. The interaction between Mr Campbell (even on his best behaviour) and Her Majesty's Lobby appears close to what psychotherapists term "an abusive relationship" - one in which the part ners feel trapped in a downward spiral of passive-aggressive behaviour.

A recent bestselling American self-help book on the subject identified helpful ways of identifying the symptoms: "Does your partner seem irritated or angry at you several times a week? Does he deny being angry when he clearly is? Do you frequently feel perplexed and frustrated by his responses, as though you were each speaking a different language?"

Both partners in this increasingly loveless relationship - Mr Campbell and the Lobby - would answer "yes" to all of the above. Yet, as any self-help devotee will tell you, the destructive thing about these abusive relationships is that - though it makes them miserable - neither party can escape.

And, true enough, Mr Cockerell's film ended with forlorn Lobby journalists complaining bitterly that Mr Smith's kindly, caring, objective briefings were no fun. They wanted to get back to the daily ritual of mutual abuse.

There is a serious point behind all this, which is that the word "spin" is to this government what "sleaze" was to the last. Whether it is the press or the government who is chiefly to blame is in a sense beside the point. Something has to be done to untie the knot before Westminster politics and press become terminally polluted by mutual cynicism and disrespect.

It appears that this thought has already dawned on Number 10. The decision to pull Mr Campbell out of day-to-day close combat with the Lobby was Mr Blair's. This week's televised press conference was a White House- inspired device to speak directly to the public without the filter of the Lobby.

But the sterile nature of the present relationship is also appreciated by the more thoughtful members of the press corps. Elinor Goodman, the political editor of Channel 4, gave a speech this week in which she said: "I think it is arguable that political journalists have been a corrosive force over the past 10 years. My own view is that the symbiotic relationship between politicians and the media has helped create an age of cynicism in which it's extremely difficult to have a rational debate."

The Guardian was one of three papers to leave the Lobby in 1986 in protest at the way in which systematic unattributable briefings were being misused. That generation of Lobby correspondents was not sympathetic: the Lobby voted 67 to 55 to keep all briefings off the record.

It is ironic that such movement as there has been since to put the briefings on the record has largely come from government. Mr Campbell himself has tiptoed some way to greater openness, with edited versions of the daily briefing on the Downing Street website.

But even he has stepped back from going the whole way. When the Guardian published the first verbatim transcript of a Lobby briefing in March, he dropped us a quiet note saying that he had not intended that all Lobby briefings should now be fully on the record and attributable. At the same time the cost of the Strategic Communications Unit has risen from £77,633 in 1997/8 to £839,440 in the current year.

It is not clear that much would be gained from again boycotting these semi-open Lobby briefings. But in future all Guardian journalists attending them will, as a matter of policy, identify who the briefer is. It is no longer right that readers should be in doubt whether this is Alastair spin or Godric briefing.

More difficult is the whole question of attribution. In politics - as in virtually every other walk of life - people will often speak more honestly if they are allowed to speak anonymously. The use of non-attributed quotes can thus assist the reader towards a truer understanding than if a journalist confined him/herself to quoting the bland banalities that often pass for on-the-record quotes.

One example: a recent article in the Guardian was the subject of a drily critical letter from Lord Wigoder. He drew attention to no fewer than 11 anonymous quotes attributed to such sources as "a Labour business adviser", "a senior Labour figure" and "one wealthy businessman."

I know - because I made inquiries - that virtually all these quotes came from people with direct knowledge of the relevant matter. As an editor, I was satisfied that this was an exceptionally well-informed and accurate piece of reporting. The Guardian reader was, I thought, well-served.

But journalism which is not believed has failed. If many readers felt they had insufficient clue as to whether the alleged "sources" spoke with authority and remained deeply sceptical about the provenance of the quotes, then it is difficult to make a case that the article did serve our readers well.

What, to take another recent example, are we to make of the recent front page splash in a mid-market tabloid: "Power crazed and bonkers" was the bold headline above a picture of Gordon Brown. The story was a brutal attack on the chancellor sourced to "a government colleague".

The article was by the paper's political editor - ironically, one of the journalists who led the Independent out of the Lobby 14 years ago. The attribution was so vague as to be meaningless to any reader. The Observer's famous earlier anonymous attack on Brown - "he has psychological flaws" - was at least sourced to "someone who has an exceedingly good claim to know the mind of the prime minister".

Even this quote would not have got through the editorial process of the New York Times. Its style guide reads: "Anonymity must not become a cloak for attacks on people ... If pejorative remarks are worth reporting and cannot be specifically attributed they may be paraphrased or described after thorough discussion between writer and editor.

"The vivid language of direct quotation confers an unfair advantage on a speaker or writer who hides behind the newspaper, and turns of phrase are valueless to a reader who cannot assess the source."

These are good rules, though - as those who have worked in both countries admit - they are easier to apply in the monopoly environment of New York broadsheet journalism than in the ruthlessly competitive world of Fleet Street.

If applied here, the curtain would come down on whoever it is whose job it is to drip anonymous poison over the heads of Harriet Harman, Frank Field, Ken Follett, Lord Winston, Clare Short, Ken Livingstone, Stephen Byers, Mo Mowlam, Gordon Brown, David Clark or whomever the victim of the moment is deemed to be.

But it is not absolutely clear that the bringing down of this curtain would inevitably cause greater enlightenment amongst readers. Would the public interest have been served by denying readers the knowledge that the skids were under John Biffen or Francis Pym?

S hould the papers of the day have kept quiet about the increasing friction between Mrs Thatcher and Geoffrey Howe, simply because no one would go on the record about it? If part of the truth about the present government is that it is genuinely riven by personal bitterness and mistrust, how can it be truthful to ignore the fact?

One of the reasons that some journalists feel locked into their love-hate relationship with Mr Campbell is that they feel he truly knows and understands the day to day thinking of the prime minister. Some reporters are adamant that the interests of the reader are best served by being able to quote him, even if they are obliged to disguise the origin of the quote.

We do not claim great moral superiority in these matters on the Guardian. But I do feel that we could do better in trying to break with some of the worst customs that have become ingrained in political reporting over the past 10 or so years.

In addition to naming the spokesman at official lobbying briefings, we will adopt a stricter code on the use of anonymous pejorative quotes. And we will encourage reporters to be as specific as possible about the source of any anonymous quotation. "One MP", or "a government colleague" is so weak as to be meaningless. "Senior minister" is an advance. "Cabinet minister with direct knowledge of the negotiations" is better still. By now the reader can genuinely evaluate the worth of the remark.

We will codify these guidelines and publish them: doubtless we will break them from time to time. But we will do our best to make a start on the road to more valuable and evaluate-able reporting. It would be good if you - the readers - had some input into the process.

You already use the independent readers' editor and letters columns to make your views known. In that respect, I believe the Guardian is already the most open and honest paper in Britain. But it would be interesting and helpful to hear the general views of readers on how we can best convey the true flavour of British politics as it is lived, breathed and briefed about.

Alan Rusbridger is editor of the Guardian. alan.rusbridger@theguardian.com

fields.headline: News in Brief
fields.trailText: Britain is set for a record year for foriegn tourists despite the strong pound, which has reduced the number of visitors from Europe by 2% in the first five months of this year.
fields.body:
Tourist boom expected

Britain is set for a record year for foriegn tourists despite the strong pound, which has reduced the number of visitors from Europe by 2% in the first five months of this year.

North American visitors are up 4% and tourists from other parts of the world have risen 7%, according to the office for national statistics.

DNA offer to cure stalker

TV weatherman Bill Giles said yesterday that he would undergo a DNA test to convince an obsessed niece who has been stalking him for 10 years that she is not his daughter.

Joanna Toner, 40, of Tiverton, Devon, was jailed for 2 years at Barnstaple crown court on Monday after she admitted breaching an order not to contact Mr Giles, 60.

Aid workers risk murder

Humanitarian aid workers are increasingly at risk of murder, particularly in Africa, according to research published in the British Medical Journal yesterday.

Between 1985 and 1998, 253 out of 375 deaths among relief workers were the result of violence, most in cross-fire.

Comet on view tonight

A comet visible to the naked eye will appear in the Great Bear constellation (also known as the Plough) towards the western horizon tonight.

Comet Linear will attain its maximum brightness around July 23, coming within 71m miles of the Sun.

Vauxhall recalls Astras

Vauxhall is recalling 3,000 Astra models built in 1998 because of a possible seat-positioning problem, it announced yesterday.

webTitle: Relatives jailed for attack on doctors

fields.headline: Relatives jailed for attack on doctors
fields.trailText: Three relatives of a severely disabled boy who punched, kicked and bit hospital doctors because they believed that the child was being allowed to die were jailed yesterday.
fields.body:
Three relatives of a severely disabled boy who punched, kicked and bit hospital doctors because they believed that the child was being allowed to die were jailed yesterday.

Doctors, who thought nothing more could be done for David Glass, were attacked by his uncle and two aunts after they gave him the painkiller diamorphine.

The boy then recovered and was discharged on the night of the fracas, prompting the family to accuse doctors of giving up on him too easily.

David's mother, Carol Glass, has claimed that had it not been for the actions of her relatives, her son, who was 12 at the time, would have died.

The three relatives, all from Portsmouth, Hampshire, were convicted of violent disorder and causing actual bodily harm. Diane Wild, 42, was jailed for 12 months, while Julie Hodgson, 47, and Raymond Davies, 44, received nine-month sentences.

During the trial at Portsmouth crown court the jury heard how David was admitted to St Mary's hospital in the city in October 1998 to have his tonsils removed.

But the boy, who was born with a brain condition which left him profoundly mentally and physically disabled, suffered a serious chest infection.

The doctors expected David to die within hours and gave him diamorphine, a drug often used to ease pain for the dying.

But the boy's family accused the doctors of trying to hasten his death and demanded that treatment be halted.

The doctors went to leave the room, believing there was nothing more that could be done, when "pandemonium" broke out. Wild told Dr Joanne Walker: "You are not going. I want you to witness the death of a child you have killed."

When Dr Walker tried to raise the alarm, Wild grabbed her by the hair, pushed her on to a hospital bed and kicked and punched her.

Outside the room, Dr Walker was pushed over and kicked by a number of people. Up to 12 members of the family were involved.

During the trial Dr Walker said: "The noise level and the shouting and obscenities were just unbelievable."

Another doctor, Mark Ashton, was bitten by Wild and then grabbed, punched and kicked by Davies. Dr Ashton broke down during the trial as he described how the children's ward was turned into "Armageddon" during the row.

He heard one woman tell Dr Walker: "If he dies I am going to break your neck and mash you to a pulp before you can hit the panic button."

Mrs Glass, 39, claimed outside court that members of her family had taken steps of their own to restart her son's breathing. "The reason my son is alive is because I knew what was best for him," she said. In a letter to the court, she said: "My sisters and my brother saved David's life." She described her relatives as heroes.

The family's defence argued the "unique circumstances of the incident" should be taken into consideration, claiming the violence was "a million miles" from a typical Saturday night brawl in the accident and emergency department.

They pointed out that the three still cared for David, who is now 14, on a daily basis.

Family and friends wept in court as Judge Roger Shawcross sentenced the three.

He said: "I regard what you did as quite outrageous and in no way heroic. You attacked doctors seriously, a man and a woman who devote their lives to the care of young children. It is your fault and your fault alone if David's care suffers while you are in prison."

A spokesman for Portsmouth Hospitals NHS trust said: "We are satisfied that the final outcome illustrates that violence against NHS staff will not be tolerated."

Before the trial Richard Bishop, chief executive of the trust, explained: "We believed David Glass may have been dying. He was in considerable distress and diamorphine will reduce distress so that if he did die he would die with dignity."

The case first hit the headlines in April 1999 when Mrs Glass launched a failed high court attempt to have the doctors' actions declared unlawful.

Her case focused attention on the right of a parent to decide how a child should be treated - even if a doctor was convinced another course of action was correct.

Her counsel said she objected to diamorphine being given as she believed it would depress her son's breathing and could hasten his death.

She wanted the court to rule on whether doctors could legally withhold or give treatment contrary to the parent's wishes without court sanction.

He heard one woman tell Dr Walker: "If he dies I am going to break your neck and mash you to a pulp before you can hit the panic button." Mrs Glass, 39, claimed outside court that members of her family had taken steps of their own to restart her son's breathing. "The reason my son is alive is because I knew what was best for him," she said. In a letter to the court, she said: "My sisters and my brother saved David's life." She described her relatives as heroes. The family's defence argued the "unique circumstances of the incident" should be taken into consideration, claiming the violence was "a million miles" from a typical Saturday night brawl in the accident and emergency department. They pointed out that the three still cared for David, who is now 14, on a daily basis. Family and friends wept in court as Judge Roger Shawcross sentenced the three. He said: "I regard what you did as quite outrageous and in no way heroic. You attacked doctors seriously, a man and a woman who devote their lives to the care of young children. It is your fault and your fault alone if David's care suffers while you are in prison." A spokesman for Portsmouth Hospitals NHS trust said: "We are satisfied that the final outcome illustrates that violence against NHS staff will not be tolerated." Before the trial Richard Bishop, chief executive of the trust, explained: "We believed David Glass may have been dying. He was in considerable distress and diamorphine will reduce distress so that if he did die he would die with dignity." The case first hit the headlines in April 1999 when Mrs Glass launched a failed high court attempt to have the doctors' actions declared unlawful. Her case focused attention on the right of a parent to decide how a child should be treated - even if a doctor was convinced another course of action was correct. Her counsel said she objected to diamorphine being given as she believed it would depress her son's breathing and could hasten his death. She wanted the court to rule on whether doctors could legally withhold or give treatment contrary to the parent's wishes without court sanction.

webTitle: TV show calls in the voyeurs

fields.headline: TV show calls in the voyeurs
fields.trailText: Armed with just one suitcase each and shorn of the luxuries of modern living, 10 volunteers were sealed off from the world yesterday to take part in a voyeuristic game show that will either be the most talked-about piece of television this year, or simply a turkey.
fields.body:
Armed with just one suitcase each and shorn of the luxuries of modern living, 10 volunteers were sealed off from the world yesterday to take part in a voyeuristic game show that will either be the most talked-about piece of television this year, or simply a turkey.

The participants in Big Brother, one of whom will be evicted from a house (built at a film studio in east London) by a viewer vote each week, are competing for a £70,000 prize.

The five men and five women - all are in their 20s and 30s and have never met before - have been denied items such as CD players, mobile phones, radios, pens, paper and even calendars.

The project is designed to play on the public's voyeuristic tendencies - Channel 4 never misses an opportunity to hint that even the most intimate moments will be shown. And judging by the comments of the participants posted on the show's website, it seems that the 10 have been chosen with one thing in mind: Anna, 29, pledged to pack a sex aid; Andrew, 23, said his Mastermind specialist subject would be "brothel cultures of the world".

A 24-hour webcast began yesterday (www.channel4.co.uk/ bigbrother), and the boys and girls quickly organised themselves into the two bedrooms. Daily TV updates begin next week, and the first "eviction" will take place on July 28.

Each week the group will nominate two candidates for eviction, and the public will make the final choice by telephone and internet.

The Big Brother production team sets the group various tasks - if the challenges are completed successfully, the particpants can win supplements to their daily allowance of £1.50 each. The allowance can be spent on anything they choose, but the decision is one they have to make together.

Much is riding on Big Brother: in Germany and the Netherlands, it has been a smash hit on the scale of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? Some 40,000 applied to take part in the British version, which is being made by Bazal productions, part-owned by the Guardian Media Group.

10 people game for a show

Andrew , 23, describes himself as a "ladies' man" and boasts of being "excellent entertainment value".

Craig , 28, says he "loves a challenge", and has packed whisky and condoms .

Darren , 22, loves to dance and is obsessed with his hair. Has three children and considers himself easy going.

Nicholas , 32, a bachelor from a family of nine, a qualified alternative healer, takes kung fu lessons every week.

Thomas , 30, the youngest of seven children, lives on his parents' farm. Says he will miss the telephone and internet.

Anna , 29, a former trainee nun, has worked in a women's prison. Will miss "pubs, pals and sex" most.

Caroline , 37, a saxophone player and fan of alternative therapies, once sold sex aids.

Melanie , 26, an Elvis Presley fan who will most miss her fake leopard skin coat.

Nichola , 28, dreams of being in a circus act, and seeks "fame and fortune".

Sada , 27, describes the show as "a chance of a lifetime to learn more about myself".

fields.headline: Victim's face 'was stamped on'
fields.trailText: A 16-year-old boy accused of murdering another teenager took a running kick to his head as his victim lay on the ground and shouted "Michael Owen" before stamping on his face, Liverpool crown court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A 16-year-old boy accused of murdering another teenager took a running kick to his head as his victim lay on the ground and shouted "Michael Owen" before stamping on his face, Liverpool crown court heard yesterday.

The boy's co-accused, boy B, told the jury how the pair and a third boy carried out the attack on Michael Moss, 15, to get criminal injuries compensation for him, which they could share.

The prosecution alleges the three boys, all now 16, re-enacted a scene from the film Reservoir Dogs by trying to cut off Michael's ear during a two-hour attack at a playground in Litherland, Merseyside.

All three boys deny murder. They cannot be named for legal reasons.

Boy B said his friend, boy A, had heard you could get £300 to £400 for a single stitch and Michael wanted the attack carried out.

Recalling the attack in the early hours in October last year, boy B told his barrister, David Steer QC, how he kicked and punched Michael in the face before he and boy A went to get a third friend, boy C, and returned to the scene.

Later, boy B said: "[Boy C] was kicking him in the face with the back of his heel. He kept stamping on his balls and in that area. I then saw him taking run-ups and shouting 'Michael Owen' and kicking him in the head." Boy B said he began to walk away but he was distracted by the sound of a bottle smashing.

Boy B said the group were using the bottle because cuts would be worth more for Michael's false claim for criminal injuries compensation.

The case continues.

webTitle: If the price is right: Artists' view of house-buying

fields.headline: If the price is right: Artists' view of house-buying
fields.trailText: The house in Winchester in Hampshire is unquestionably des-res. There is a sale board outside and viewers will be handed a brochure,  writes Maev Kennedy .
fields.body:
The house in Winchester in Hampshire is unquestionably des-res. There is a sale board outside and viewers will be handed a brochure, writes Maev Kennedy .

But unease sets in on crossing the threshold. The clipboard-clutching guide assures viewers the owner has every intention of redecorating the bathroom - when he will presumably remove the tumbler with a glaring glass eye beside the pill box labelled "George's spare eye". She points out the useful socket, but not the one-bar electric fire plugged into it and teetering on a window ledge directly above the bath.

She admires the master bedroom but does not explain the expensive grey suit jacket lying on the bed, slashed to ribbons.

When the tour reaches the attic, stuffed with dimly-lit doll's houses, even the most fanatical house hunter should have twigged that this is not property, it is art.

"House in Winchester" is one of thousands of installations around the UK for Year of the Artist, and plays on the obsession with property prices - and the fact, heartbreaking to estate agents, that viewing houses for sale is a leisure activity.

The week-long installation opens today and is the work of nine artists, graduates of the Winchester art college. It is actually the home of one of them, Colin Harper, and is not for sale.

fields.headline: Hospital killing inquiry call
fields.trailText: A senior judge expressed "grave concern" yesterday after hearing how a nurse showing signs of dangerous behaviour was allowed to work in the National Health Service, then killed a colleague.
fields.body:
A senior judge expressed "grave concern" yesterday after hearing how a nurse showing signs of dangerous behaviour was allowed to work in the National Health Service, then killed a colleague. Mrs Justice Hallett had heard that Mlungisi Tshabangu carried out the frenzied stabbing attack in front of patients at Bromley hospital in Kent. She asked for inquiries to be made about measures taken since, saying the dead man's family had a right to know.

Tshabangu, 34, of Orpington, denied murdering care assistant Lee Field, also 34, on February 12. He admitted manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility. He was suffering from paranoid psychosis at the time.

Tshabangu had abused steroids for years in pursuit of his body-building hobby, the Old Bailey heard. He had also shown hostility to colleagues at previous hospitals where he worked.

Trained in South Africa, he first came to Britain on an NHS scheme to recruit staff from overseas. At his first hospital in Stanmore he became abrupt. Rather than face a meeting to discuss his behaviour he went to South Africa for three months, said Aftab Jafferjee, prosecuting.

He returned in 1998. At Selly Oak hospital in Birmingham he slapped a woman staff member. He had already been offered a job by the Royal London hospital with a verbal reference. There he was spoken to about his relationships with colleagues, and in October 1999 he joined Bromley hospital.

Mr Field, from Catford, south-east London, was attacked from behind and slashed 25 times in a "ferocious onslaught" by Tshabangu, said Mr Jafferjee.

Tshabangu was remanded for sentence later this month. Bromley hospital had launched an inquiry and other bodies were inquiring into procedures of recruitment from abroad, Mr Jafferjee said.

webTitle: Liverpool drink ban to beat crime

fields.headline: Liverpool drink ban to beat crime
fields.trailText: Police in Liverpool have been given powers to seize glasses and opened bottles of alcohol in a measure aimed at reducing street crime.
fields.body:
Police in Liverpool have been given powers to seize glasses and opened bottles of alcohol in a measure aimed at reducing street crime.

The bylaw, introduced yesterday, is the first of its kind in England and Wales. It goes further than the alcohol-free zones introduced in other cities such as Belfast and Coventry.

Police in Liverpool will have the power to remove glasses and bottles of alcohol in areas designated as alcohol-free zones. The aim is to reduce alcohol related crime and the use of glasses and bottles as weapons.

Council leaders believe that it will act as a model for other local authorities, with Manchester expected to make a similar application next month.

Chief Inspector Cliff Walker, the operations manager for Liverpool city centre, said: "This is an important extra power that will enable us to continue to rid our streets of violent and alcohol related crime."

Councillor Malcolm King, chairman of the council's licensing committee, said the bylaw was a watershed in creating a safer city centre.

"The city's streets are littered with discarded bottles at the weekend. People only have to pick one up, and immediately they have an offensive weapon. The city is a relatively safe area, but by implementing this bylaw we can help to make it even safer and a more fun place to enjoy yourself."

Drinking was banned in parts of the city centre in March.

The move has been welcomed by the home secretary, Jack Straw. He told the Local Government Association conference: "A drunk in the street is unlikely to appeal to Strasbourg because his can of Tennants has been confiscated."

fields.headline: Salute to photographer
fields.standfirst: University honours Guardian's Don McPhee
fields.trailText: Don McPhee, the Guardian photographer whose wit and humanity have delighted readers for 30 years, was awarded an honorary degree yesterday by Manchester Metropolitan University.
fields.body:
Don McPhee, the Guardian photographer whose wit and humanity have delighted readers for 30 years, was awarded an honorary degree yesterday by Manchester Metropolitan University.

McPhee has spent all his Guardian career in Manchester, recording its life and using it as a base from which to explore Britain and much of the wider world.

He celebrated his honour by sailing in his narrow boat, San Seriffe - named after spoof islands created for a Guardian April Fool edition 20 years ago - as close as he could get to Bridgewater Hall for the ceremony.

McPhee's aim has been to celebrate the diversity of humankind. Sometimes he is amused, as in his portrait of two farmers at a Yorkshire horse sale and of two pensioners on the beach at Blackpool.

Sometimes he finds the exact image which speaks volumes about the event. In 1984 he photographed a striking miner in a party helmet eyeballing a policeman among the line protecting the Orgreave coking plant near Sheffield.

He had failed to link with the other snappers corralled on the police side. So he joined the pickets. "Then I saw 30 police horses galloping at me. It was like being on the wrong end of the charge of the light brigade ... I just legged it."

fields.headline: Fruits of the doom
fields.standfirst: Thousands of tonnes 'left to rot'
fields.trailText: Soft fruit worth millions of pounds is being left to rot in the fields because of the booming economy, the National Farmers' Union said yesterday.
fields.body:
Soft fruit worth millions of pounds is being left to rot in the fields because of the booming economy, the National Farmers' Union said yesterday.

Low unemployment across the country has led to a shortage of seasonal fruit pickers and the NFU is being forced to appeal to find workers.

Thousands of tonnes of strawberries, cherries and raspberries are being left to rot, the NFU president, Ben Gill, said.

The dearth of pickers is also leading to an increase in the import of fruit such as strawberries, he said.

According to NFU figures, imports of strawberries rose 39% in the three years to 1998 - which means that British growers now supply less than half of the 72,000 tonnes bought in Britain each year, despite the country's perfect strawberry growing climate.

The lack of British fruit pickers is aggravated by a shortage of foreign students available for temporary summer work.

The NFU has set up an email address - at nfu.cropsatnfu.org.uk - for anyone who wants work as a fruit picker.

webTitle: Husband 'gave clues to wife murder plot'

fields.headline: Husband 'gave clues to wife murder plot'
fields.trailText: A wealthy book dealer twice gave clues that he was arranging for his second wife to be murdered, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A wealthy book dealer twice gave clues that he was arranging for his second wife to be murdered, a court heard yesterday.

Colin Harrold, 35, had disclosed to his first wife that he was having an affair, then allegedly told her he was "working on it" to ensure there would not be a costly divorce arising from his second marriage. On another occasion, Nottingham crown court heard, he told a woman he met in a bar that "money is changing hands, I'm doing something about it now".

The court also heard from the woman with whom he was having the affair about a day at a health farm where he pretended they were husband and wife.

Harrold denies murder and conspiring with Darren Lake, 31, the best man from his first marriage, to murder Diane Harrold, 36. Lake has already pleaded guilty to murder.

Mrs Harrold was found dumped in the swimming pool of the couple's home in Uffington, Lincolnshire, last October.

James Hunt QC, prosecuting, said cracks began to appear in their two-year marriage, apparently due to Harrold's unwillingness to start a new family, having had two sons from his first marriage.

Mr Hunt alleged that Harrold offered Lake £20,000 to murder Mrs Harrold, then throw her body into the outdoor swimming pool at their £335,000 home. Harrold went to Amsterdam and was in the city's red light district at the time the body was found by police.

A fortnight before the murder, the prosecution claimed, Harrold made a chilling revelation to Annette Beck, his first wife. She told the court: "He said he was having an affair with somebody, and he was in love with somebody. I said I knew how that felt, I was in love with somebody.

"Knowing how we had parted over money, I said it would cost him dearly and he said 'I am already working on it'."

The court heard that Harrold had met another woman, divorcee Tania McCarter, through Lake, and began what she said was a short affair. It included a secret trip in September to Ragdale Hall health farm in Leicestershire, where she was booked in by him under the name Tania Harrold. Miss McCarter told the court: "We had a good time. We were in the whirlpool bath, we swam in the swimming pool, and had lunch."

She went on: "We were in the jacuzzi, kissing and touching and having a cuddle. We were having a laugh."

Mr Hunt earlier told the court: "History does not relate what the real Mrs Harrold, Diane, was doing that day; but she was not at Ragdale Hall with her husband. He was playing away."

Another woman, Kim Milne, met Harrold and Lake one night at a bar in Peterborough, the court heard. She asked Harrold if he was married. He answered: "Yes, two years, two years too bloody long. Money is changing hands as we speak, I'm doing something about it."

Mrs Harrold, a former nurse, had inherited £90,000 when her mother died. She met Harrold through a lonely hearts advertisement and bought a beauty salon after their marriage in 1997.

A school friend of hers stayed with the couple in August. Joanne Hewitt told the court: "It was tetchy, there were arguments. Definitely the honeymoon was over. Diane had everything apart from what she really wanted, which was children. But he said he didn't want children."

The trial continues next week, when Lake is to give evidence.

webTitle: Fears for youth missing with cult

fields.headline: Fears for youth missing with cult
fields.trailText: Concern was growing last night for a 16-year-old boy who was persuaded to leave home within hours of meeting members of a religious cult.
fields.body:
Concern was growing last night for a 16-year-old boy who was persuaded to leave home within hours of meeting members of a religious cult.

Bobby Kelly's photograph has been circulated to police, and airports and docks were being watched, amid fears that he could be taken out of the country.

The schoolboy met members of the Jesus Christians, a little known cult founded by an Australian, as they handed out leaflets in a shopping centre in Romford, Essex, two weeks ago.

The same afternoon he packed some belongings and told his family he was "going with them". On Thursday his grandmother, Ruth Kelly, with whom he lived, asked the high court to help bring him home.

Mrs Kelly said that Bobby was planning to do a business studies course at college after completing his GCSEs.
