She and a church youth worker, David Whitehouse, have also seen him face to face - but only in the presence of cult members. Mr Whitehouse said the Jesus Christians group members told him the teenager would be going to Germany on a missionary trip within a fortnight.

He said: "Bobby seemed scared, as if he was very wary about what the group members would think about what he was saying. I asked where they lived and they said they moved around. They said they had slept in a forest the previous few nights.

"He has been with them for just over a fortnight. They have let him see me and his grandmother but never unsupervised. They said that was out of the question.

"He is a young Christian man with a strong interest in the Bible and that is what this group will have used to get close to him. These people have a veneer of respectability. They come across as if they are keen to follow Jesus but their actions tell a different story."

The Jesus Christians were formed by an Australian, David McKay, and are difficult to track down.

Their literature calls on converts to forsake their jobs, boss, even their family and friends.

"God is now your boss and he has a new job for you that will not wait," says a cult leaflet.

webTitle: No jail for 'body on sofa' father

fields.headline: No jail for 'body on sofa' father
fields.trailText: A man was given a suspended six month jail sentence at Norwich crown court yesterday for keeping the body of his dead son at home for up to four years before dumping it on waste ground.
fields.body:
A man was given a suspended six month jail sentence at Norwich crown court yesterday for keeping the body of his dead son at home for up to four years before dumping it on waste ground.

Anthony Burt, 63, who has been diagnosed as mentally ill, told relatives that his son, Steven, had left home in 1995 to look for work, an earlier trial at Ipswich crown court heard.

In fact the former accountant kept his body on a sofa at his house in Woodbridge, Suffolk, and only disposed of it when he decided to move home in 1998.

When police found Steven's corpse it weighed less than 2st. He was in his mid-20s at the time he died, probably in 1994. The exact date and cause of death were never established.

Members of the family had been worried about Steven before he died, as he barely ate and had lost weight.

Burt, who now lives in London, was found guilty of failing to give his son a Christian burial and causing a public nuisance by dumping the body.

fields.headline: Desperate jungle hostages ponder suicide
fields.trailText: Militant Muslim separatists in the southern Philippines yesterday freed one of the 40, mostly foreign, hostages they have seized over the last 11 weeks.
fields.body:
Militant Muslim separatists in the southern Philippines yesterday freed one of the 40, mostly foreign, hostages they have seized over the last 11 weeks.

The release came as one of the remaining captives wrote that their mental state was deteriorating so quickly it was only a matter of time before they started committing suicide.

Officials on Jolo, the jungle island where the Abu Sayyaf guerrillas are holding their prisoners, said that a Malaysian police officer, Abdul Jawar Selawat, 38, was freed thanks to the intermediary efforts of a local businessman.

Mr Selawat was among two French, three Germans, two Finns, two South Africans, a Lebanese, nine Malaysians and two Filipinos seized from the Malaysian resort island of Sipaden on April 23.

He is the second of the hostages to be freed; last month another Malaysian was released "as an act of good faith", according to the rebel leader Ghalib Andang. Since then Abu Sayyaf has also seized 16 Filipinos, three French television journalists and a German magazine reporter.

The Philippine government's chief negotiator, Robert Aventajado, denied that a million-dollar ransom had been paid to secure Mr Selawat's freedom. That is the figure the rebels have demanded for the release of each hostage.

However, Mr Aventajado admitted: "There was a promise of Malaysian help of funding livelihood projects in the area."

The governments of the European hostages are not contemplating such tactics, according to the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, who with his Finnish and French counterparts yesterday completed two days of talks in Manila with the Philippine president, Joseph Estrada, and senior officials.

"There was not one sentence, not one word said about that in our talks," Mr Fischer said at a press conference. All three ministers expressed confidence in the Philippine authorities to resolve the crisis and agreed it had to be done peacefully.

"That's their [the Philippine government's] commitment and that's what they eagerly want," Mr Fischer said. "But at the same time they want to act so not to create any subsequent crises."

Mr Aventajado said yesterday that he expected more releases "pretty soon because the hostage leader has established a direct link with me".

"Mr Andang did this by using the French journalists' satellite phone." He declined to be more specific but stressed: "We want to move as quickly as possible because we know the condition of the hostages."

The captives' worsening health was highlighted all too graphically yesterday by Finnish foreign minister Erkki Tuomioja, who released an open letter written by Finnish hostage Risto Vahanen.

Dated July 8 and written in capital letters on one page of a school exercise book on behalf of all the prisoners, the letter details how the hostages have "experienced dreadful night marches, [been] caught in the midst of firing, [and] suffered from thirst and hunger."

Mr Vahanen said their conditions, which had improved slightly in the last month, were "still miserable and inhuman".

"Our mental condition is getting worse every day and it is not far from one of us committing suicide in the nearest future," he wrote.

Their physical state was also deteriorating, he said, because of mental stress and lack of opportunities for exercise.

"This morning [German hostage] Mr Werner Wallert had a stroke and so far no doctor has arrived in the camp."

In an attempt to discourage an armed assault by the Philippine army, Abu Sayyaf has split its prisoners into smaller groups and scattered them around several jungle hideouts.

Mr Vahanen summed up many analysts' attitudes when he wrote: "The kidnapping drama seems to have got out of hands of everyone."

Mr Estrada is coming under increasing pressure to resolve the crisis, particularly before he leaves on a state visit to the US on July 25. Most criticism is over the constantly changing cast of official negotiators and the apparent increasing involvement of freelance go-betweens attempting to make a fortune out of the crisis.

It is not entirely clear what the guerrillas want as there are five leaders, all with slightly different agendas. Earlier this week officials said the bottom line was money but Mr Aventajado said yesterday: "There are political demands on the table that we need to attend to."

Abu Sayyaf is one of several groups campaigning for a separate Muslim state in the southern Philippines. Earlier this week the most prominent separatist organisation, the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF), suffered a huge reverse when the army overran its main camp on the island of Mindanao.

Following the defeat, MILF leader Hashim Selamat declared a jihad, or holy war, against the Philippine government.

fields.headline: Kickbacks scandal hits Brazil president
fields.trailText: A deepening political scandal which has already caused the first impeachment of a senator in Brazilian history is closing in on President Fernando Henrique Cardoso after a note surfaced showing he requested more money for a corruption-plagued construction project.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos  in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
A deepening political scandal which has already caused the first impeachment of a senator in Brazilian history is closing in on President Fernando Henrique Cardoso after a note surfaced showing he requested more money for a corruption-plagued construction project.

This week Mr Cardoso denied any wrongdoing after the note was published in the daily Folha de Sao Paulo newspaper. Two days earlier he had stated that he was not involved in the funding.

The Folha de Sao Paulo said: "The president's moral integrity is not in question. But the way his administration functions certanly is. It is inadmissible for the government to admit that the president signs documents without reading them."

"They basically have found a smoking gun," said David Fleischer, professor of politics at Brasilia University. "This is very worrisome for Cardoso."

The scandal concerns the theft of up to £60m of public funds from the building of a Sao Paulo courthouse to handle employment disputes.

In 1999, a congressional inquiry revealed that the person responsible for the project, senior judge Nicolau Dos Santos Neto, had helped to steal the money. The courthouse is still unfinished, most of the money is missing and Mr Dos Santos Neto is on the run.

Last month the affair claimed its most important scalp when congress impeached Senator Luiz Estevao, a prominent developer, over accusations that his company was the main beneficiary of the kickbacks. It was the first time that a member of the senate has been impeached in its 170-year history.

The impeachment was hailed as a significant shift in the culture of political impunity in Latin America's largest country.

There are demands for the resignation of the planning minister, Martus Tavares, who recommended the release of the extra money. Mr Tavares allegedly offered his resignation but it was refused, according to reports, because that would be an admission of guilt.

Mr Tavares criticised media reports for "opportunism", and said his ministry "understands that such news reports reflect, on the one hand, a lack of understanding of the budgetary process, and on the other, bad faith and opportunism by people interested in distorting facts to win political visibility".

In a special edition released after his statement, the political magazine Istoe quoted from taped conversations suggesting that Mr Tavares and Mr Cardoso's former chief of staff, Eduardo Jorge, were involved in the kickback scheme.

Members of congress voiced outrage over the revelation that the administration rubber-stamped the extra funding for the courthouse, with one senator from a party allied to the government demanding Mr Tavares' resignation.

Opposition members of congress - eyeing October local elections - went further, calling for a congressional probe into Mr Cardoso and his administration.

But economists fear that a congressional inquiry would bleed Mr Cardoso of support as he tries to implement his economic reform programme - seen as crucial to help the country recover from last year's devastating collapse of the currency.

webTitle: EU urged to establish conflict taskforce

fields.headline: EU urged to establish conflict taskforce
fields.trailText: The EU should set up a conflict prevention service, or Cops, with tasks ranging from mine-clearing and firefighting to the provision of legal and medical services, a leading security thinktank proposes today.
fields.body:
The EU should set up a conflict prevention service, or Cops, with tasks ranging from mine-clearing and firefighting to the provision of legal and medical services, a leading security thinktank proposes today.

The need for a rapid reaction corps combining paramilitary police and civilian roles has been dramatically exposed in Kosovo. It has also been highlighted by Javier Solana, the EU's security supremo, and Chris Patten, the European foreign relations commissioner.

"The end of the US-Soviet confrontation has altered the basic purposes of Nato, ended superpower competition in conflicts around the world and changed the strategic dynamic for states along the old east-west fault line in Europe," the British American Security Information Council (Basic) says today.

"Current threats to international security," it says, "include ethnic conflict within states, mass migration, economic and social upheaval, and natural disasters... A major task is to rapidly coordinate and deploy available human, financial and materiel resources to best effect."

Basic proposes a Cops force of 15,000, set up by 2005, able within 24 hours to deploy fully operational units backed up by effective communications and intelligence support.

The Kosovo crisis showed up the weaknesses of the international community in conflict prevention, peacekeeping and enforcing.

Keith Vaz, Britain's minister for Europe, in a letter to Dan Plesch, director of Basic, acknowledged flaws in the international community's "crisis response capability". But he added that Basic's proposals went further than what the EU envisaged.

EU countries have agreed in principle to contribute up to 5,000 personnel for international civilian policing operations by 2003.

webTitle: Army says it has hold on Tamil Tigers

fields.headline: Army says it has hold on Tamil Tigers
fields.trailText: The Sri Lankan military says it has brought the Tamil Tiger rebels' offensive to a halt around the main town in the northern Jaffna Peninsula, after what it reports as the heaviest fighting the area has seen for more than a month.
fields.body:
The Sri Lankan military says it has brought the Tamil Tiger rebels' offensive to a halt around the main town in the northern Jaffna Peninsula, after what it reports as the heaviest fighting the area has seen for more than a month.

The army says it has killed up to 100 rebels this week on the outskirts of Jaffna town. The Tigers say they have repulsed the army's advances and killed up to 50 soldiers.

The Sri Lankan army's spokesman, Brigadier Pallitha Fernando, said troops were staging hit and run attacks against the Tigers - including the use of snipers - and causing heavy casualties on the Tamil side. "In recent skirmishes the rebels on average lost between seven and eight men a day," he said.

He was not saying if or when the army would attempt a counter-offensive to recover large amounts of territory lost to the rebels in the Jaffna Peninsula in recent weeks.

"The fact that we have stalled the offensive of the rebels is in itself an achievement," he said, "because in May and June it looked as if they were going to capture Jaffna." He said the government was launching a crackdown to try to get 20,000 deserters -- nearly a quarter of the army's strength - to rejoin their units.

"If we are to make inroads against the Tamil Tigers we need the manpower. That is why the government has introduced tough new regulations by which people can receive a substantial prison sentence if they are found guilty of harbouring deserters," he said.

He conceded that there was some truth in reports that people with the right connections could evade army service: some army deserters were employed by Sri Lankan members of parliament, he agreed, but said it was a small number out of the total.

The latest fighting in Jaffna coincides with new efforts by the government to bring an end to Sri Lanka's 17-year civil war through constitutional changes.

The government is hoping that its proposals to revamp the constitution will get the approval of MPs before the country goes to the polls after parliament is dissolved in August.

A key part of the package is the formation of an interim council to administer the north and east areas of the island, areas which the Tamil Tigers say should be part of their independent homeland.

Last week the government and opposition concluded months of negotiations on the reform package. They agreed that Sri Lanka should have a new constitution, but disagreed over the timing of its introduction.

But the Tamil Tigers reject these devolution proposals - which slightly clouds President Chandrika Kumaratun ga's attempt to present the agreement as a breakthrough. In an interview with an Indian newspaper, the Bangelore-based Deccan Herald, a senior Tamil Tiger spokesman, Anton Ballasingham, said his organisation wanted nothing short of independence.

"This package serves only the interest of the majority community," he was reported as saying, "and fails to address the nationality or the ethnic issue. It is part of a new constitution which reinforces the interests of the majority by upholding the supremacy of the Buddhist religion and the Sinhala language. It ignores the fact that Tamils have their own religious and cultural identity."

In the run-up to the elections, a charm offensive by the Sri Lankan president will try to persuade as many minority Tamil and Muslim parliamentary parties as possible to back her proposals.

"We have much to do before we present the package to parliament," she said, "including making sure that it is implemented effectively. If we do that, we believe we will have met the most pressing need of the people, which is an end to the war and the establishment of permanent peace."

webTitle: Film festival lights up an old flame

fields.headline: Film festival lights up an old flame
fields.standfirst: A spa town in western Bohemia which was once the haunt of artists and royalty emerges from the communist era
fields.trailText: Champagne corks are popping and audiences flocking to a little-known spa town in western Bohemia this week for one of the summer's hottest events on central Europe's social calendar.
fields.body:
Champagne corks are popping and audiences flocking to a little-known spa town in western Bohemia this week for one of the summer's hottest events on central Europe's social calendar.

A decade ago Karlovy Vary was a down-at-heel town suffering from neglect after 40 years of Czechoslovak communism. It has now returned to its former glory - when, as Karlsbad, it attracted the cream of European royalty - thanks to an international film festival and clans of nouveau-riche Russians whose verve and cash have injected the sleepy town with a new lease of life. The Karlovy Vary film festival, now in its 35th year, is one of the oldest in the world and has been given an A-status by experts, ranking it alongside Cannes, Berlin and Venice.

Critics say its reputation is rising to compete with Cannes, which is just one month older. The New York-based Talk magazine recently hailed it as one of the hottest film festivals in the world.

The red carpet has been rolled out during the 10-day spree for an array of stars, including Woody Harrelson who was pumping the legalisation of cannabis with his documentary Grass; Edward Norton presenting his directorial debut, Keeping the Faith; Franco Nero, the star of Uninvited; and the British actor of Room With a View fame, Julian Sands. Angelica Huston and the Spanish director Carlos Saura are expected at the closing ceremony today.

In between screenings at cinemas scattered throughout the town, including in many of the spa hotels, festival goers are invited to take the healing waters and mingle with Russian and German patients undergoing electrotherapy and colonic irrigation.

In an effort to lure more sponsorship Warner Brothers this year recreated the masked-ball scene from Stanley Kubrick's Eyes Wide Shut. Teenage girls clad in lacy underwear whisked away male guests to dance in a private room.

It marks a departure for the festival. It had its first heyday in the 1960s during the era of Czech New Wave film led by directors like Milos Forman and Jiri Menzel. But in 1989 the opening of the free market marked a nadir in its history as state funding was slashed and corporate sponsorship failed to materialise. Many thought its days were numbered.

But in the past few years it has become hip once more, attracting sponsorship as well as stars like Lauren Bacall, Alan Alda and Gregory Peck, who famously had an emergency appendectomy in a spa hospital four years ago.

"It has undergone a remarkable transformation over the past decade," said its artistic director, Eva Zaoralova. "The success is rooted in the political changes and without this it would have suffered a consumptive death."

The festival's upturn in fortune comes at a time when the film industry in the Czech Republic is also experiencing a rebirth with top movie makers choosing to shoot blockbuster films and cult hits here, among them Mission: Impossible with Tom Cruise and Joan of Arc with Milla Jovovic.

Karlovy Vary's celebrity line-up will be given a further boost this weekend with the appearance of Johnny Depp who is currently in Prague shooting the Jack the Ripper film From Hell, and Hilary Swank, Oscar-winning star of Boys Don't Cry, who is shooting Pearl Necklace.

Karlovy Vary, situated close to the German border, is one of Bohemia's most picturesque and historic towns, boasting 12 natural hot springs and ornate colonnades, art nouveau mansions and tree-lined avenues. In the past it was a haunt for European royalty, including Edward VII, but in recent years it has become a stomping ground for the emerging Russian middle class.

Town officials estimate that around a tenth of the town's 50,000 population is now Russian and that they own two-thirds of the hotels.

The Russian tradition goes back a long way. Peter the Great took the waters in 1711, Turgenev and Gogol came to write. Goethe, Beethoven and Schiller visited to entertain the aristocracy of Habsburg Europe.

But nowadays and unlike most other film festivals, where commercialism and snobbery go hand in hand, Karlovy Vary offers more equality. Here blackties and backpackers mix congenially, queuing together for the chance to buy the 90 pence tickets to more than 700 film screenings.

"The younger film goers have been camping outside, even in miserable weather," said Helena Hajova, a festival spokeswoman. She said that 9,000 people had been accredited, doubling last year's numbers.

"Karlovy Vary is considered to be more fun and perhaps less businesslike than Cannes," the Hollywood Reporter's eastern Europe correspondent, Nick Holdsworth, said. "This is unusually a filmmaker's festival where people come to relax, enjoy themselves and watch each other's films."

fields.headline: Children abducted from Angola refuge
fields.trailText: Twenty-one children have been kidnapped, one killed and four wounded in an attack by 100 armed men on an orphanage in Angola's central highlands, the UN reported yesterday. It is the second attack on the home in Huambo province this year. Three children were killed in the earlier incident.
fields.body:
Twenty-one children have been kidnapped, one killed and four wounded in an attack by 100 armed men on an orphanage in Angola's central highlands, the UN reported yesterday. It is the second attack on the home in Huambo province this year. Three children were killed in the earlier incident.

A UN statement referred to the kidnappers as armed bandits who damaged the children's dormitories, destroyed the generator and workshop and stole mattresses, blankets and many other items.

It called last weekend's attack a "cowardly and unprovoked crime". The abducted children are aged between 11 and 18.

Tens of thousands of children have been abducted by Angola's anti-government Unita faction during the years of war in the country, with the boys forced to become soldiers or porters, while the girls were held as "wives" in Unita camps. Those released, or who have escaped over the years, have spoken of long forced marches across Angola.

Unita returned to war in 1992 after a UN-monitored election was won by the government. A shaky 1994 peace process under UN auspices collapsed in 1998.

In a new report on Angola the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, said that 1m people were dependent on food aid to survive, and another 2.5m reliant on other kinds of humanitarian assistance. Access by relief agencies has been curtailed because of continued fighting, and thousands of uprooted people live in refugee camps under appalling conditions, Mr Annan said.

The UN plans to conduct the second round of a big polio immunisation programme tomorrow, hoping to reach 2.9m Angola children under 5. But Angolan officials have been unable to negotiate access to areas held by Unita.

Ibrahim Gambari, UN undersecretary-general for Africa, recently in Angola, said this week that the UN had "to start thinking of how to bring this peace process forward because there is a growing recognition in Angola that military victory, by itself, will not bring the fighting to a complete stop".

webTitle: Street defence for Martin Luther King

fields.headline: Street defence for Martin Luther King
fields.standfirst: One woman has been protesting for 12 years at the 'negativity' of a museum dedicated to America's civil rights hero
fields.trailText: One woman has been protesting for 12 years at the 'negativity' of a museum dedicated to America's civil rights hero
fields.body:
Jacqueline Smith has spent a quarter of her life directly under the path of the bullet that killed Martin Luther King, the hero of the American civil rights movement.

Behind her home on the pavement is the site of the boarding house from which James Earl Ray fired the fatal round - unless you believe the conspiracy theorists - and in front is the balcony of room 306 in the old Lorraine Motel where King died in 1968.

Ms Smith's purpose, which she has pursued from her perch on the paving stones for 12 years and 177 days , is to persuade tourists to boycott the motel, now converted into the National Civil Rights Museum.

It is not that Ms Smith, a former singer, objects to honouring King's memory: quite the reverse, she is a passionate supporter. Rather, it is the tone of the museum that rouse her anger.

"It focuses on violence and negativity, not on hope and non-violence," she says, to her right a shopping trolley stuffed with personal effects, to her left a well-used pin-striped sofa that is her home.

"People get themselves excited over the replicas and then they go to the gift shop and purchase key chains. Nothing of substance is being done with Dr King's memory."

This, she says, would be better served were the motel used for housing, job training, education or health care. Ms Smith, once a desk clerk at the Lorraine and the last resident to be evicted when it was closed in 1988, has become a Memphis institution over the years. "What's up, Jacq?" says a man who drives by to show her his son's birthday card.

The motel was built in about 1925 and even in the 60s it was one of the few places where blacks could stay in the segregated city. Among the musicians who used it were Cab Calloway, BB King, Aretha Franklin, Count Basie and Nat King Cole.

It reopened as the National Civil Rights Museum nine years ago, the facade intact and with an old Cadillac Coupe de Ville and Dodge Royal parked under the balcony of room 306.

Inside there is a history of the black struggle with recreations of some of the landmark moments: the 1955 bus boycott in Montgomery, Alabama, when Rosa Parks refused to give up her seat for a white; the segregated Woolworth lunch counter that sparked protest in Greensboro, North Carolina, in 1960; and the jail cell where King was confined after being given a five-day sentence for violating an injunction banning marches in the wake of riots in Birmingham, Alabama, in 1963.

This last includes a transcript of a call between King and his wife Coretta while he was inside, a mixture of the almost comically mundane and the politically alert. "Who did you say called?" he asks. "Kennedy, the president," she replies, pausing to ask if he is taking his vitamin tablets. "How's it playing in the press?" he inquires before reassuring her that he has filed their tax return before the deadline.

King's motel room as it was at the moment he was shot, set in aspic right down to stubbed out cigarettes and the dregs of coffee cups, is the climax of the $9 million (£6m) museum that receives 135,000 visitors a year.

None of this cuts any ice with Ms Smith, who says she has not left the site of her protest for more than three hours at any one time since she started. She is turned out trimly in red shoes, a red pencil skirt and hooped top, delicately-framed spectacles and gold earrings: not exactly the stereotype of someone who lives on the street.

"Friends and family help out," she says. "Anybody can put some clothes on. My only interest is in looking nice so that the people have no fear of coming over to talk. Everybody likes a beautiful girl." Not, though, the museum's administrators, who prefer to ignore her. "She's not worth discussing," says Judith Black, the marketing manager. "But she emphasises what Dr King was all about, which was freedom of speech and expression."

Ms Smith, who takes to ski clothes and a tent when the winter bites, is convinced that there was more behind the killing of King than a lone gunman. In common with the King family, she cannot accept that Ray, acting alone, was responsible for such a tumultuous event.

But an 18-month investigation by the United States justice department reported last month that it had found no evidence to support a conspiracy.

Ms Smith remains undaunted. "We urge people to fulfil Dr King's dream to help others."

webTitle: A fine figure of a man, pity he's made of cardboard

fields.headline: A fine figure of a man, pity he's made of cardboard
fields.trailText: Emerging from the apartment block one morning this week, our downstairs neighbour, Marcello, discovered that, in parking his car, he had blocked the butcher's van.
fields.body:
Emerging from the apartment block one morning this week, our downstairs neighbour, Marcello, discovered that, in parking his car, he had blocked the butcher's van.

It was unforgivable, the butcher declared, a cretinous act that had stopped honest people going about their business while the perpetrator lazed in bed.

Marcello is a large, bullet-headed 50-year-old. He started to raise his palms in appeasement, for clearly he was in the wrong, until he noticed that all along the street faces were peering from windows.

We had been summoned by the butcher's anger to watch a spectacle. Trapped, Marcello hesitated. Everyone could see his car was clumsily positioned, but to move it in such circumstances would be humiliating.

He went on the offensive. Jutting his nose inches from the butcher's, he raised his voice to a rasping bellow to suggest he was dealing with an ignorante who could not judge distance, a maleducato with meat between the ears, a coglione, in fact.

Back and forth the battle raged until the entire street was watching. Marcello, with much the stronger voice, scored well and the butcher visibly wilted. Climaxing with an appeal to God to spare him meatpacking geometricians, he stepped inside and slammed the door.

What had just unfolded was a demonstration of bella figura... Literally, it means beautiful figure. But to Italians, and especially Romans, it is a profound expression that captures the essence of living: to look well, to cut a dash.

Pressed shirts, furs in summer, coordinated outfits and immaculate make-up are but the trimmings. The way you walk and talk, the people you know, what you do, or what people think you do, these are the tools to fashion a bella figura.

To lose face, to cut a brutta figura, is to lose everything. Daily life is a conveyer belt of events each with the potential to burnish or burn your image. After grasping this, Rome began to make a little more sense to me.

The old boy I asked for directions didn't deliberately send me the wrong way, he just didn't want to admit his ignorance.

The girl in the mobile phone shop didn't really want me to write a letter to head office, she just didn't know the procedure for replacing SIM cards.

The car rental clerk who suddenly insisted on speaking English wasn't rude, he just wanted to impress the brunette who had joined the queue behind me.

It was bella figura that prompted Mussolini to erect painted cardboard facades of mansions on the road to Rome to impress the visiting Hitler.

Shallow? Some Romans freely admit it. Harmless? Maybe not. Maintaining a bella figura at all costs can cause problems greater than a partially blocked street.

Putting image before substance, never admitting being in the wrong - these are reflexes common to all governments. But few take it to such extremes as Rome.

Ambitious reforms are unveiled amid much trumpeting. Nothing happens so they are unveiled again. More trumpets. A huge cock-up is discovered - but no one is responsible, no one is to blame.

It is tempting to go too far. Myriad ills can be sourced to bella figura. The phenomenon exists outside Italy, after all. But it was Italians who gave it a name.

After his victory Marcello retired to his terrace with a towel. Sweat poured from his head and chest.

It had been a close run thing. A bit more bravura and the butcher would have had him.

Marcello waited until sunset to move the car.

webTitle: Standard Life denies letters were foul play

fields.headline: Standard Life denies letters were foul play
fields.trailText: Standard Life yesterday denied allegations that it improperly influenced last month's crucial ballot on its mutual status despite admitting it sent letters to policyholders on other companies' headed paper urging them to vote no to windfalls.
fields.body:
Standard Life yesterday denied allegations that it improperly influenced last month's crucial ballot on its mutual status despite admitting it sent letters to policyholders on other companies' headed paper urging them to vote no to windfalls.

The insurer, whose members last month rejected windfalls of £5,000-plus after it was targeted by carpetbaggers, is embroiled in a row with a Belfast independent financial adviser, who claims the company sent letters to more than 400 of his clients advising them to vote for mutuality, without his permission.

Standard Life accepts that it sent out the letters, which were written on the adviser's own headed paper, but said its understanding was that the adviser had given his approval for this to happen.

The row follows a bitterly fought battle over whether the insurer should stay a mutual or convert to a public company and pay windfalls.

The insurer spent millions of pounds promoting the cause of mutuality in the run-up to the June 27 ballot, with advertisements and a series of mailings to its 2.3m members.

The letters were disclosed by the BBC. It reported that Colin Cavan, a bar owner from County Down, Northern Ireland, received a letter, apparently from his adviser, David McCullough, urging him to vote no to a windfall.

Mr Cavan was surprised because he had already consulted Mr McCullough, who had advised him to vote yes. Mr McCullough then discovered that other clients he had advised to vote for flotation had received similar letters.

It is understood that the insurer gave IFAs an opportunity to have letters supporting mutuality sent to Standard Life members who were their clients.

Standard Life says that in this case the adviser chose to take part and provided his letterheaded paper to the insurer.

The insurer says that it believes it had the adviser's permission to send the letters out to all his policyholder clients, and that he had seen its contents.

A spokesman said: "We believe we have conducted a thoroughly proper campaign in which we laid out the case for mutuality."

In all, the spokesman added, the company had received less than 200 complaints from members in connection with the ballot from a total mailing of 2.3m policyholders.

webTitle: Lynching provokes change in the law

fields.headline: Lynching provokes change in the law
fields.trailText: The Guatemalan president, Alfonso Portillo, is to introduce new laws in the wake of the lynching of eight men suspected by villagers of the rape of a child.
fields.body:
The Guatemalan president, Alfonso Portillo, is to introduce new laws in the wake of the lynching of eight men suspected by villagers of the rape of a child.

The men were burned alive last week, the latest of several lynchings carried out by villagers who believe that the justice system acts neither swiftly nor effectively enough.

Mr Portillo announced yesterday that he will introduce new laws to expedite prosecutions of suspects in crimes such as rape and kidnapping in an effort to restore faith in the criminal justice system.

There is also concern about the country's international reputation in the wake of the lynching of a Japanese tourist and a tour bus driver in May in the village of Todos Santos after a false rumour had spread that a busload of Japanese tourists had arrived to steal children for Satanic rituals.

"I will ask congress to modify laws that have held up prosecutions," Mr Portillo said. "The public ministry is very slow."

He also pledged to build 25 new police stations in remote villages and to introduce another 1,500 police officers into the force. He will ask congress for more money for policing.

The eight men were lynched in the village of Xalvaquiej, around 100 miles northwest of Guatemala City. They were stopped at a roadblock as they tried to leave and set on fire.

They were said to have been suspected of raping a girl last year and also to have been involved in an attempted kidnapping last weekend.

There have been rumours in the villages that children are stolen to be sold for body parts or for Satanic rituals. Those rumours have proved unfounded, but some children have been abducted to be sold and child prostitution in the capital is a serious problem.

fields.headline: Corus cuts 1,200 more steel jobs
fields.standfirst: Hint of more staff losses to come as sterling is blamed for hitting exports
fields.trailText: The damage inflicted on British industry by the strong pound was underlined yesterday by the announcement of a fresh wave of job losses at Europe's largest steelmaker.
fields.body:
The damage inflicted on British industry by the strong pound was underlined yesterday by the announcement of a fresh wave of job losses at Europe's largest steelmaker.

The Anglo-Dutch group Corus - formed by last year's merger between British Steel and Dutch firm Hoogovens - said it was cutting 1,200 more British jobs, taking the total in the past two months to 2,600, and warned that there could be more job losses to come.

Glyn Wheeler, head of Corus's construction and engineering division, where the new job losses were concentrated, pinned the blame firmly on the strong pound, saying sterling was continuing to hit exports into Europe.

"Despite a recent fall, the sustained strength of sterling against the euro continues to cause severe competitive disadvantages for our business and our UK customers," he said.

"Our business has traditionally exported around 50% [of production], the bulk of which is into euro markets where revenues have declined by 25% in recent years."

Corus said 670 jobs would be lost at its Scunthorpe plant, 530 at Teesside and 10 at its Dalziel plant in Scotland. The company said it hoped the majority of the job losses would be voluntary but added that it could not rule out compulsory redundancies.

The pro-euro AEEU union also attributed the job losses to sterling's strength, as well as overcapacity in the steel market, but said the company could have done more to safeguard the interests of its members.

AEEU general secretary Sir Ken Jackson said: "It's a big shock for Teesside and Scunthorpe. We've delivered productivity but the strong pound has wiped out all the gains. Corus is playing a short-term game of job cuts now but less investment for the future. It's not the right way forward.

"It's further proof that the strong pound is battering steel," he continued. "Germany and others are increasing production but the UK is cutting back. We can't go on like this forever."

Corus shares were little changed immediately after the announcement, which had been widely anticipated. They were trading down 0.75p at 95p in late morning trade. The stock has fallen 43% so far this year.

The unions are due to meet trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers on Monday to press their concerns about the pound.

Setting out a package of measures to help the sacked workers, including on-site jobshops to advise on vacancies, Mr Byers said: "I deeply regret the announcement of job losses in Teesside and Scunthorpe made by Corus today. Those people, businesses and communities affected by the decision can be assured that the government will play its full part in helping them. Providing new job opportunities for the future will be a priority."

Pro-euro campaigners seized on the figures. Simon Buckby, Britain in Europe's campaign director, said: "The job losses at Corus are the latest casualties of the relentless pressure that the high pound is putting on British manufacturing. Sterling's volatility outside the euro is causing jobs losses in Britain while stability in the euro-zone is causing strong economic growth and creating jobs.

"With 3m jobs linked to our exports to Europe, currency volatility is putting jobs at risk."

fields.headline: News in Brief
fields.trailText: Sierra Leone's mining minister said yesterday that all diamond exports have been banned until a certification system was in place to back up international efforts to stop rebels profiting from the trade.
fields.body:
Gem export ban in Sierra Leone

Sierra Leone's mining minister said yesterday that all diamond exports have been banned until a certification system was in place to back up international efforts to stop rebels profiting from the trade.

Mohamed Deen said the government had imposed the ban to comply with an embargo imposed by the UN security council on July 5 on diamond exports from the West African country.

US police filmed beating suspect

In Georgia, police punched and kicked a drunken driving suspect as he lay on the ground during an arrest recorded on videotape

Television stations taped the arrest from helicopters after police chased Marshall Dwight Studdard's truck through Atlanta. Police authorities are to review the tapes.

US rejects suit over Nazi hunt

A federal judge has tossed out Ukrainian-born John Demjanjuk's lawsuit claiming that a US justice department investigation into claims that he was a Nazi war criminal amounted to torture.

The district court judge ruled this week that the government has sovereign immunity and cannot be sued.

The lawsuit arose from the justice department's attempt to revoke Mr Demjanjuk's US citizenship because he failed to disclose working at a Nazi concentration camp. He says he was forced to work there.

Bombay slum buried in slide

Sixty-seven bodies have been pulled from under tonnes of sewage and debris in a Bombay slum buried by a landslide, officials said yesterday.

Rescue workers followed the stench of rotting flesh as they looked for victims on a hillside in the city's eastern suburbs. A burst septic tank is believed to have triggered the landslide.

Death of Congo hero's mother

The mother of slain Congolese nationalist independence hero Patrice Lumumba has died in the capital, Kinshasa, state television reported. Amato Julienne, who was approaching 100 years old, died on Thursday, it said. Patrice Lumumba was the first prime minister of the Congo, now known as the Democratic Republic of Congo, on independence from Belgium in 1960.

German official held for treason

A former government official in Helmut Kohl's time as chancellor was charged yesterday with treason for allegedly passing weapons and defence secrets to the East German Stasi spy agency in the 1980s.

"Henning G" was charged in 1996 with working for a foreign intelligence agency, but the case was closed after he confessed. New evidence has now been uncovered, a federal prosecutor said.

Girl, 4, weds puppy in India

A four-year old Indian girl has married a stray dog in a Hindu service. The ceremony in Monanpur, 35 miles north of Calcutta, was prompted by an astrologer who told the girl's father that it would transfer the evil effects of Saturn from the girl to the dog. The girl had suffered several illnesses.

webTitle: Street cred of trader who saw a gap in the market

fields.headline: Street cred of trader who saw a gap in the market
fields.trailText: John Hargreaves is not a name that resonates like Alexander McQueen, Versace or Jean Paul Gaultier.
fields.body:
John Hargreaves is not a name that resonates like Alexander McQueen, Versace or Jean Paul Gaultier.

But he almost certainly makes more money than many better known peers as he goes about dressing a sizeable chunk of the British population through his discount retailing chain, Matalan.

Competitors are not too proud to consider seeking to learn from his streetwise attitude towards giving the public the reasonably-priced, good quality clothing it wants.

The popularity of the Matalan stores is such that the 56-year-old Mr Hargreaves is worth $1.8bn (£1.1bn) according to US magazine Forbes, which recently listed him as one of Britain's richest men.

Mr Hargreaves' family owns 52% of Matalan which has clocked up extraordinary growth in sales and earnings in the past few years. Three of his children work in the business and are expected to succeed him when he retires.

The Hargreaves' success story reads like a Hollywood script.

The son of a Liverpool docker, he left school at 14 and learnt his early retailing skills selling seconds from Marks & Spencer in Preston market.

Five years later, his first clothing business, Jaymax, had grown to 30 stores.

Matalan was founded in 1985 after Mr Hargreaves went to the United States on holiday and was taken by the out-of-town discount stores.

And so the Matalan Discount Clubs were born - mixing designer labels and functional garb, while using cheap out-of-town rents to fund hyper-discounted prices. Customers joined for £1.

To keep prices low, Mr Hargreaves bought directly from factories.

The formula struck a chord with the British working and middle classes who embraced Matalan.

It was not just the discount clothing concept that was the key to success, as competitors could have easily undercut low prices.

Rather, it was Mr Hargreaves' fashionable as well as cheap formula that has made him the king of Britain's clothing retailers.

fields.headline: Ecclestone takes the checkered flag
fields.standfirst: Mystery shrouds F1's leading man
fields.trailText: Newspapers do not usually recommend that their readers buy other papers. But this week's edition of the Economist really is worth a spin down to your local newsagent for the extraordinary tale of one Bernie Ecclestone and his control over the finances of formula one motor racing.
fields.body:
Newspapers do not usually recommend that their readers buy other papers. But this week's edition of the Economist really is worth a spin down to your local newsagent for the extraordinary tale of one Bernie Ecclestone and his control over the finances of formula one motor racing.

For those who cannot meet the £2.60 cover price, we can disclose that the Economist's article screams away from the grid with an astonishing revelation: the Federation Internationale de l'Automobile - the FIA, motor racing's inter national governing body - agreed two weeks ago to grant the commercial rights in F1 racing until 2110 to Mr Ecclestone's firms for the paltry sum of £240m.

That is £2.18m a year for the sole television rights worldwide for a sport which attracts an annual TV audience of 5bn viewers, together with all sorts of rights to fees from the promoters who put on the 17 grand prix each year.

The story of how Mr Ecclestone manoeuvred himself into such a lucrative position is a tale with so many gaps, contradictions, denials and raw facts that beggar belief, it makes the head spin.

He began in October 1971, using money made dealing second-hand cars to buy the Brabham racing team. The next 29 years were spent dancing through the offshore financial havens of the world, all the while, according to the Economist, constructing a string of largely secret commercial arrangements with the creators of the F1 spectacle which appeared to defy commercial logic.

The result: "Mr Ecclestone's position in F1 is now unassailable. Promoters cede any media rights they have to him. Similarly ... the teams surrender the right to their images. So the circuits are disenfranchised from the broadcasters who, in turn, are disenfranchised from the teams. The teams are beholden to Mr Ecclestone. His long-standing associate, Mr [Max] Mosley, is in charge of the sport's governing body.

"Nearly all of F1's affairs are shrouded in extraordinary secrecy; not only are the terms of all agreements 'commercially confidential', but even the existence of some agreements is secret. Nobody inside F1 is seriously able to question how it is run. That is what happens when one man is allowed to establish such a financial stranglehold on a sport."

There is no evidence that Mr Ecclestone has done anything wrong. It is just that the whole way the finances of F1 are constructed looks odd.

When a business refuses to allow any sort of transparency, cloaking its ownership and profitability in the secrecy afforded by offshore havens, outsiders asked to help finance the venture get nervous. Which is why Mr Ecclestone has so far failed to float his business interests on any stock market and why he struggled to raise $1bn (£667m) on the bond markets last year.

Although the Economist does not refer to the fact, every investment bank taking on the Ecclestone challenge to turn some of his fabulous assets into hard cash has found themselves working rather harder than they can ever have envisaged.

America's Salomon Smith Barney tried first and then decided to sack itself. Then its US rival, Morgan Stanley, went racing after the fees only to suffer the ignominy of having to bring the German state-owned Westdeutsche Landesbank in to square the deal. WestLB completed last year's bond sale by buying two-thirds of the bonds itself and then issuing state-guaranteed WestLB bonds to finance the purchase.

The Ecclestone empire clearly exists in a sort of international commercial ether where something like investment risk must be impossible to quantify. What these blue-blooded names of the banking world were doing trying to sell Mr Ecclestone's paper to their clients is a mystery.

Swan's secrets

Ken Bates, voluble boss of Chelsea football club, is not in Bernie Ecclestone's league. But there is one little piece of controversy which has followed the man around for years: namely, who owns the 30% block of Chelsea registered under the offshore name of Swan Management.

Yesterday it seemed that BSkyB might now be in possession of one of the great secrets of British football after Swan sold a 3.9% stake to BSkyB as part of a pre-agreed deal to give the broadcaster 9.9% of the club.

BSkyB insiders say the company dealt through Patrick Murrin, a Chelsea non-executive and accountant who is also a close friend of Mr Bates. That is all that has emerged so far.

Perhaps Mr Bates or Mr Murrin or BSkyB might finally care to enlighten us as to who the largest shareholder in this high profile public company actually is. The desire for secrecy here is just baffling.

And the company will never be treated as a serious investment proposition until the matter is cleared up.

fields.headline: Man Utd's Edwards to go
fields.trailText: Manchester United is to confirm one of football's worst kept secrets by announcing on Monday that Martin Edwards is stepping down as chief executive.
fields.body:
Manchester United is to confirm one of football's worst kept secrets by announcing on Monday that Martin Edwards is stepping down as chief executive.

Mr Edwards is to be replaced by his deputy, Peter Kenyon, ending four decades of family control at the world's richest football club.

The 54-year-old is likely to remain a non-executive director on United's plc board, as well as chairman of its subsidiary football club. A United spokesman declined to comment.

Mr Edwards' resignation follows rumours of clashes with Professor Sir Roland Smith, non-executive chairman of the plc, and a deterioration in his working relation ship with the manager, Sir Alex Ferguson.

Analysts said the move illustrates the shifting ownership of the club from the personal fiefdom of the Edwards family to a stockmarket listed company controlled by City investors.

Mr Kenyon, an affable Mancunian and lifelong supporter of United, is highly regarded in football. He joined the club three years ago from Umbro, the sportswear manufacture where he was managing director, and is keen to maximise the global power of the United brand and its potential as a media asset.

Last night advisers to United said Mr Kenyon could become "the Michael Eisner of soccer" - a reference to the high profile Disney chief executive.

"There's little doubt that Peter has got what it takes to turn United into the Disney of soccer and become the Michael Eisner figure of the game," said John-Paul de la Fuente, chief executive of Media Content, the sports media advisers.

Mr Kenyon is taking over now to allow him time to settle in before next season.

Mr Edwards has been subject to regular, often vitriolic criticism from many United supporters during his 20 years in charge. The nadir of his relationship with fans came almost two years ago when he agreed to sell United to Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB for £623m.

But Mr Edwards has overseen startling financial growth. This year United became the world's first £1bn club after a strong performance by its shares.

fields.headline: Matalan records 31% jump in sales
fields.trailText: Matalan, the out-of-town fashion and homeware chain, has continued its blitz on the British clothing market - posting a 31% jump in comparable sales.
fields.body:
Matalan, the out-of-town fashion and homeware chain, has continued its blitz on the British clothing market - posting a 31% jump in comparable sales.

The figures are before Matalan's summer sale to start later this month, which is expected to push its growth even higher. In the 19 weeks to July 8, like-for-like sales grew 30.9%, while total sales for that period leapt 55.7%.

Matalan has been a beacon in a struggling British clothing market. Companies such as M&S and C&A, which is to close down, have struggled to capture new sales and big names like Bhs and Littlewoods have shifted their emphasis to discount lines after studying Matalan's success.

Mike Godliman, the research director at Verdict, said the British customer was seeking more and more value for money from clothing retailers.

"These sales figures are really unique in clothing at the moment. They are unheard of when you look at the sales figures of other retailers and most of them are struggling," he said.

Matalan's success has been in offering good quality clothing at discount prices, in its club membership of 4.9m to which it direct mails special offers, and in its marketing and store designs.

Matalan's share of the British clothing market has grown from 1.7% to 2%. John Hargreaves, founder and chairman of Matalan, said at the firm's annual meeting yesterday: "This continues to underline our view that our continued focus on product development, outstanding value for money and exceeding our members' expectations is reaping dividends. I believe we are in very good order to continue to enjoy sound trading through the remainder of the year."

In May, Matalan reported that pre-tax profits had grown 138% to £54.1m. The retailer is planning to add a further 19 stores to its existing 100 shops and have at least 200 by 2005.

Matalan says its direct buying as well as tight control over its scale and rate of store growth has allowed it to maintain a low-cost format.

Matalan's rise in sales is also expected to enable it to strike better deals in its direct buying from suppliers. Mr Godliman said the decision by some of Britain's traditional department stores to enter the discount market would force consolidation.

"I don't know when that market will reach saturation but we can't be far away. When that situation is reached then these types of companies are going to find it difficult."

Shares in Matalan rose 3.5p to 553.5p.
fields.bodyText: Matalan, the out-of-town fashion and homeware chain, has continued its blitz on the British clothing market - posting a 31% jump in comparable sales. The figures are before Matalan's summer sale to start later this month, which is expected to push its growth even higher. In the 19 weeks to July 8, like-for-like sales grew 30.9%, while total sales for that period leapt 55.7%. Matalan has been a beacon in a struggling British clothing market. Companies such as M&S and C&A, which is to close down, have struggled to capture new sales and big names like Bhs and Littlewoods have shifted their emphasis to discount lines after studying Matalan's success. Mike Godliman, the research director at Verdict, said the British customer was seeking more and more value for money from clothing retailers. "These sales figures are really unique in clothing at the moment. They are unheard of when you look at the sales figures of other retailers and most of them are struggling," he said. Matalan's success has been in offering good quality clothing at discount prices, in its club membership of 4.9m to which it direct mails special offers, and in its marketing and store designs. Matalan's share of the British clothing market has grown from 1.7% to 2%. John Hargreaves, founder and chairman of Matalan, said at the firm's annual meeting yesterday: "This continues to underline our view that our continued focus on product development, outstanding value for money and exceeding our members' expectations is reaping dividends. I believe we are in very good order to continue to enjoy sound trading through the remainder of the year." In May, Matalan reported that pre-tax profits had grown 138% to £54.1m. The retailer is planning to add a further 19 stores to its existing 100 shops and have at least 200 by 2005. Matalan says its direct buying as well as tight control over its scale and rate of store growth has allowed it to maintain a low-cost format. Matalan's rise in sales is also expected to enable it to strike better deals in its direct buying from suppliers. Mr Godliman said the decision by some of Britain's traditional department stores to enter the discount market would force consolidation. "I don't know when that market will reach saturation but we can't be far away. When that situation is reached then these types of companies are going to find it difficult." Shares in Matalan rose 3.5p to 553.5p.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: EC clears path for Hyder deal
fields.body:
EC clears path for Hyder deal

The European commission said it had cleared Southern Co's unit Western Power Distribution's bid for the Welsh water and elecricity company Hyder.

The combined entity posed no overlaps in electricity distribution as WDP was active in southwest England and Hyder in southern Wales.

The merger would not create a dominant position in electricity distribution nor would it do so in other electricity-related areas such as generation, transmission or supply activities, it said, adding that the water and sewerage services aspect of the deal did not raise competition concerns as Hyder was the only company active in this area.

DoCoMo looks at VoiceStream

Japanese mobile phone firm NTT DoCoMo is eyeing 20% of US group VoiceStream in a move that would bring it closer to Hong Kong ally Hutchison Whampoa, an industry source said yesterday.

But the source said DoCoMo, which on Wednesday announced a powerful European mobile phone joint venture with Dutch partner KPN Telecom and VoiceStream shareholder Hutchison, was also considering other targets.

The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that DoCoMo was in talks with Hutchison about teaming up to take a 49% stake of the US group, possibly paying $200 (£133) per share and valuing VoiceStream at $52bn.

Express Dairy on track

Express Dairies said it anticipates making its first "new economy" deliveries within the next couple of months resulting from its recent investment in and partnership with M-box, the integrated fulfilment service company.

But chairman Christopher Haskins said that trading conditions for the sector remained "very difficult" although there was some mitigation in his company's case with, "rationalisation benefits as a result of our Glanbia purchase".

He also said he believed the investment in M-box would provide an exciting, low-risk venture which will enhance the prospects for shareholders and franchisees.

Offer for Baan extended

Britain's Invensys yesterday extended its €2.85 (£1.78) per share offer for Baan to July 25 after failing to secure complete control of the troubled Dutch software group.

Invensys, an industrial automation and controls group looking to expand its software activities, aims to be a positive catalyst for the Dutch company - which has seen better days. The original deadline for the £762m offer in late May, expired on Thursday.

Invensys said it had either bought or received acceptances for 58% of Baan shares, short of the two-thirds needed to control the group and the 95% control needed to delist the company in Amsterdam.

US debt deal wins $225m

Efforts to reduce the debt burdens of some of the world's poorest countries were boosted late on Thursday when the US House of Representatives approved Bill Clinton's request for $225m (£150m) to pay America's contribution towards the international loans reduction programme.

fields.headline: Carphone float falls flat
fields.trailText: Carphone Warehouse, Europe's largest independent mobile telephone retailer, made a disappointing debut on the stock market in London yesterday as investors questioned the company's valuation.
fields.body:
Carphone Warehouse, Europe's largest independent mobile telephone retailer, made a disappointing debut on the stock market in London yesterday as investors questioned the company's valuation.

Shares in Carphone Warehouse were issued at 200p each and finished their first session at 211.15p.

The offer range for the float had been 170p-200p.

Trade in the stock was furious as it opened at 225p, valuing the group at £1.8bn. By the close of the day 88% of the shares issued in Carphone Warehouse's float had been traded.

Nick Bubb, analyst at SG Securities, said there remained risks with Carphone Warehouse that the market was pricing into the stock. The two main concerns were the uncertainty over its expansion into Europe and the knowledge that mobile market was cyclical and could hit a slowdown phase.

"A value of 150p a share gives them the benefit of the doubt," Mr Bubb said. "Two hundred pence never looked a very attractive price."

Charles Dunstone, founder of Carphone Warehouse, saw his 38% stake in the group worth about £657m after cashing in about £56m from selling shares.

Mr Dunstone said that he was pleased with the company's debut and not disappointed with the small amount of interest from retail investors.

"The people who wanted to be there for the long term got their full allocation," he said. "It's great to be at the end of three weeks of the roadshow and see that the institutional offer was 8.5 times oversubscribed."

The company said it would give priority share allocations in the float to retail investors who would agree to retain their shares for at least three months after listing.

Analysts said that for this reason the company only received 11,500 retail applications, which is small compared with the appetite by private investor for other floats such as Egg which drew 85,000 retail applications.

About one-third of proceeds raised from the float would be used to fund Carphone Warehouse's expansion across Europe.

fields.headline: ... an issue for Okinawa
fields.trailText: Madeleine Bunting sets out eloquently the challenge facing the world's leaders as they retreat to Okinawa for their summit (No credit to the creditors, July 10). But she suspects Jubilee 2000's assertion that lives could be saved immediately if the leaders agreed to stop taking debt payments from the poorest countries is "unsubstantiated".
fields.body:
Madeleine Bunting sets out eloquently the challenge facing the world's leaders as they retreat to Okinawa for their summit (No credit to the creditors, July 10). But she suspects Jubilee 2000's assertion that lives could be saved immediately if the leaders agreed to stop taking debt payments from the poorest countries is "unsubstantiated".

Debt payments are a persistent drain on the public funds of the poorest countries. Zambia spends $30 for each of its citizens on debt, nearly double the $17 a person it spends on health. Meanwhile, life expectancy is down to 43 years and falling, as Aids and malaria cuts through the population.

Two months ago in Abuja, 40 African presidents pledged to use money from the cancellation of their debts to fight malaria and other disease. Malaria is preventable and curable yet kills 1m people a year. As is clear from this week's Aids conference in Durban, programmes modelled on the success of Uganda to try and cope with HIV, which now affects 22m people in Africa, are well-developed and ready to implement. What is missing is funding - and this is where immediate cessation of debt payments can make a difference. For countries where there are insufficient guarantees that debt money will be well-spent, these payments can be held in a trust fund until there is confidence that it will be used in the interests of the poorest. In other countries, leaders should be held to their pledges to ensure the poorest benefit.

But the argument will be academic until western leaders keep to their own promises and actually cancel the debts. That is the challenge in Okinawa.

Adrian Lovett Jubilee 2000 Coalition

fields.headline: Drugs war is pulp fiction
fields.trailText: Just as the "war" against communism was buttressed by the robust necessity of McCarthyism, so the "war" against drugs is to employ "McCaffreyism" in its righteous cause (Hollywood, the new front line in drugs war, July 12).
fields.body:
Just as the "war" against communism was buttressed by the robust necessity of McCarthyism, so the "war" against drugs is to employ "McCaffreyism" in its righteous cause (Hollywood, the new front line in drugs war, July 12).

Working "closely with studio heads", (and with a budget that a Botswana health minister could only dream about), General Barry McCaffrey, the White House drugs tsar, wants a subliminal "accurate depiction of drug-use issues" to be squeezed into our minds as we munch our popcorn at the multiplex.

Perhaps Hollywood's next depiction of the American war of independence will place the cause of the cruelty and stupidity of all the English characters firmly on the opium they were eating for breakfast.

This initiative is going ahead despite the knowledge that every gangster film ever made ends with the criminal protagonist dead, awaiting death, or behind bars, with little noticeable dampening effect on the motivation of modern day malefactors. Meanwhile, McCaffrey's drug war warriors put the final touches to an impending biological weapons attack on Colombia.

Angus James London

 Pulp Fiction is described in the caption as a film "which showed characters using drugs such as heroin". So, not an anti-drugs film, then? But the character Mia, shortly after the scene pictured, overdoses on heroin to gruesome effect - a far more telling anti-drugs message, I suggest, than the efforts of Gen McCaffrey will produce.

Jocelyn Rose Milton Keynes

webTitle: No new deal for the poor

fields.headline: No new deal for the poor
fields.trailText: The government's annual report boasts poverty is being reduced (Poverty gap hits Labour boasts, July 14).
fields.body:
The government's annual report boasts poverty is being reduced (Poverty gap hits Labour boasts, July 14). I have a neighbour whose teenage son was recently stabbed to death: along with her grief, she faces a funeral bill of £2,000 to be paid from her weekly income of £64. Some end to poverty. And I wonder if Tony Blair would accept for his youngsters the experience of those who go through the New Deal to low-paid, meaningless and temporary jobs. Bob Holman Glasgow BOB@holman24.fsnet.co.uk

 The New Deal has created 50,000 jobs which otherwise wouldn't exist. But it cost over £5bn to set up. That means each job created cost the taxpayer £100,000.

Bill Murray Chester

 Good to see Ian Rushbrook coughing up £100K to Breast Cancer Care for Maggie's handbag (Report, July 14). I wonder if male politicians could raise as much for the much poorer prostate cancer charity? What price William Hague's baseball cap or John Prescott's spare Jag?

Rob Garbett Oxford

fields.headline: Ministers take high tone
fields.trailText: VS Naipaul and Doris Lessing (Novelist likens 'philistine' Blair to Mugabe, July 13) might care to recall that Tony Blair created, for the first time in Britain, a Department for Culture to sustain the cultural life of the nation. With the prime minister's strong personal support, grant-in-aid for the arts has been raised to the highest level ever.
fields.body:
VS Naipaul and Doris Lessing (Novelist likens 'philistine' Blair to Mugabe, July 13) might care to recall that Tony Blair created, for the first time in Britain, a Department for Culture to sustain the cultural life of the nation. With the prime minister's strong personal support, grant-in-aid for the arts has been raised to the highest level ever.

Our commitment to high art is unequivocal, but we see no tension between excellence and access. Every day a crowd the size of a Premier League football crowd visits Tate Modern. And where is this famous dumbing down? Not in Walsall or Salford. Not in Aldeburgh, in the hands of Thomas Adès, nor in London, where this summer, assisted by varieties of public subsidy, the pained literati might have enjoyed the Almeida's Richard II, Molière by the Comedie Française, Bach cantatas at Spitalfields or the Shostakovich string quartet cycle at the Wigmore.

Alan Howarth MP Minister for the Arts

Your report (Ministers admit dome was mistake, July 13) incorrectly suggests ministers believe it was wrong to go ahead with the project. In our evidence to the culture committee we both made it clear this was a unique venture, that visitor numbers were therefore difficult to forecast (but that those forecasts were widely accepted), and that in overall terms the project is already a success. The dome has been the catalyst for the regeneration of the Greenwich peninsula. Any allegations that ministers are seeking to distance themselves are completely unfounded.

Charles Falconer Cabinet Office

fields.headline: Pig manure
fields.trailText: Rural pubs may be less vulnerable to tacky, commercially driven name changes than their urban counterparts (Down the hatch, July 12); the same cannot be said for rural homes.
fields.body:
Rural pubs may be less vulnerable to tacky, commercially driven name changes than their urban counterparts (Down the hatch, July 12); the same cannot be said for rural homes. Every week names that reflect the relationship homes have to the environment, the local economy, history, genealogy or landscape are changed to what developers believe will attract potential buyers to the rural ideal.

A change to planning law to protect names that have a definite historical origin might arrest the loss of these vital and interesting indicators of an area's history - although what marketing strategy renamed a farmhouse in central Suffolk Hogshyte Hall I leave to imaginations more vivid than mine.

Graham Steel Shotley, Suffolk g.steel1@ntlworld.com

fields.headline: Jan Karski
fields.standfirst: Polish resistance hero who risked his life bringing evidence of the Holocaust to the west
fields.trailText: In the list of righteous gentiles, the highest compliment Jews can bestow upon those of other faiths, the Polish Catholic Jan Karski, who has died aged 86, stands alongside Oskar Schindler.
fields.body:
In the list of righteous gentiles, the highest compliment Jews can bestow upon those of other faiths, the Polish Catholic Jan Karski, who has died aged 86, stands alongside Oskar Schindler.

It was Karski, an eminent member of the wartime Polish resistance, who, on clandestine visits to the west, gave the Allies some of the first eyewitness accounts of the Holocaust. Western leaders responded with disbelief and incredulity.

Born in Lodz, the youngest of eight children, Karski was the son of Stefan Koziel- ewski, the owner of a small tannery and leather goods factory. He was deeply influenced by his mother, Walentyna, a supporter of Marshal Jozef Pilsudski, the revolutionary leader who ruled Poland after the 1926 coup d'etat. The fiercely Catholic Walentyna also imbued Jan with a tolerance for others, particularly for Lodz's large prewar Jewish population.

In spite of his mother's political ambitions for him, Karski wanted to become a diplomat. After military service, in 1936 he was sent to the Polish mission in Geneva, where he perfected his French, before going to London in 1937.

He returned to Warsaw a year before the Nazis invaded Poland in 1939. A few weeks later, the Soviets invaded from the east, and Karski, by then an artillery officer, was captured and sent to Kozel'- shchina, a Soviet prisoner- of-war camp. He managed to escape, disguised as a private; his fellow Polish officers were massacred at Katyn by the Soviets.

Karski's courage, linguistic skills and photographic memory made him a valuable courier in the Polish underground. But in Slovakia, in 1940, he was betrayed, arrested and tortured by the Gestapo. Eventually, after a suicide attempt, he escaped, helped by Polish partisans.

Further politicised by his experience at the hands of the Gestapo, Karski was determined to tell the west what was happening to the Jews in Poland. Disguised as a Jew, in 1942 he entered the Warsaw ghetto to witness the horrors he had heard rumoured. Then, disguised as a Latvian guard, he was smuggled into Izbica Lubelska, a concentration camp between Lublin and Belzec, where Jews were robbed before transportation to a death camp. He saw Jews being burned alive in quicklime.

By this time Karski had become known as "Witold", Poland's most famous courier. Leaders of all political factions - from anti- semitic Polish fascists to those who represented the Polish Jews - trusted him with messages for the Allies.

In London in 1942, and in Washington the following year, Karski briefed political and religious leaders, telling them of the extermination of Poland's Jews. But Allied leaders, including the American president, Franklin Roosevelt, reacted with indifference or disbelief. "Maybe they did not believe, maybe they thought I was exaggerating," he said in an interview in 1995.

Roosevelt, said Karski, "did not show any feelings, did not make any comment." He told Karski to tell the Poles that the Allies would win the war, and that the criminals would be punished. To Karski, the Allies seemed more concerned with remapping Poland's postwar borders than with the fate of Jews.

Alongside Roosevelt at Karski's meeting in Washington were the president's top Jewish advisers, among them Justice Felix Frankfurter, of the US supreme court. Having heard Karski's testimony, he said: "I am unable to believe you." Others, however, appeared to be more convinced. In London, Karski met the Polish emigré artist, Felix Topolski, and Arthur Koestler, then a refugee from Hungary, whose novel, Arrival And Departure, is partly based on Karski's experiences.

Karski remained in America and, in 1944, his memoirs, Story Of A Secret State, became a bestseller. After the war he became a US citizen and professor of international relations at Georgetown University. During the McCarthy period, he went on anti-communist lecture tours in Asia for the state department.

A Fulbright scholarship in 1974 resulted in his book, The Great Powers And Poland 1919-1945. Yet however highly his academic writings on diplomatic history were considered, he was always, to his concern, better known as the man who brought evidence of the Holocaust to the west. He appeared in Claude Lanzmann's epic film Shoah and, when many Poles criticised Lanzmann's portrayal of Polish anti-semitism, Karski stood by Lanzmann's point of view.

In 1994, he was made an honorary citizen of the state of Israel. On Jerusalem's Avenue of the Righteous, leading to the Holocaust musem, Yad Vashem, there is a tree planted with his name. He received many awards; perhaps the most important was a medal honouring him as one of the "righteous among nations". Engraved on the medal are these words from the Talmud: "He who saves one life rescues humanity."

Karski returned to Poland for the first time after the collapse of the communist regime in 1989, thereafter dividing his time between Poland and his home in Maryland. He married the Polish Jewish dancer Pola Nirenska in l956. She died in 1992.

Jan Karski, diplomat and resistance hero, born April 24 1914; died July 13 2000
