But Allied leaders, including the American president, Franklin Roosevelt, reacted with indifference or disbelief. "Maybe they did not believe, maybe they thought I was exaggerating," he said in an interview in 1995. Roosevelt, said Karski, "did not show any feelings, did not make any comment." He told Karski to tell the Poles that the Allies would win the war, and that the criminals would be punished. To Karski, the Allies seemed more concerned with remapping Poland's postwar borders than with the fate of Jews. Alongside Roosevelt at Karski's meeting in Washington were the president's top Jewish advisers, among them Justice Felix Frankfurter, of the US supreme court. Having heard Karski's testimony, he said: "I am unable to believe you." Others, however, appeared to be more convinced. In London, Karski met the Polish emigré artist, Felix Topolski, and Arthur Koestler, then a refugee from Hungary, whose novel, Arrival And Departure, is partly based on Karski's experiences. Karski remained in America and, in 1944, his memoirs, Story Of A Secret State, became a bestseller. After the war he became a US citizen and professor of international relations at Georgetown University. During the McCarthy period, he went on anti-communist lecture tours in Asia for the state department. A Fulbright scholarship in 1974 resulted in his book, The Great Powers And Poland 1919-1945. Yet however highly his academic writings on diplomatic history were considered, he was always, to his concern, better known as the man who brought evidence of the Holocaust to the west. He appeared in Claude Lanzmann's epic film Shoah and, when many Poles criticised Lanzmann's portrayal of Polish anti-semitism, Karski stood by Lanzmann's point of view. In 1994, he was made an honorary citizen of the state of Israel. On Jerusalem's Avenue of the Righteous, leading to the Holocaust musem, Yad Vashem, there is a tree planted with his name. He received many awards; perhaps the most important was a medal honouring him as one of the "righteous among nations". Engraved on the medal are these words from the Talmud: "He who saves one life rescues humanity." Karski returned to Poland for the first time after the collapse of the communist regime in 1989, thereafter dividing his time between Poland and his home in Maryland. He married the Polish Jewish dancer Pola Nirenska in l956. She died in 1992. Jan Karski, diplomat and resistance hero, born April 24 1914; died July 13 2000

fields.headline: Clare's right on condoms
fields.trailText: The Vatican should not be confused with a number of Catholic organisations working worldwide to combat the spread of Aids (Blair chides Short for attack on Vatican stance over Aids, July 12). Moreover the situation is complex.
fields.body:
The Vatican should not be confused with a number of Catholic organisations working worldwide to combat the spread of Aids (Blair chides Short for attack on Vatican stance over Aids, July 12). Moreover the situation is complex. As we describe in HIV/Aids In Southern Africa: "Research shows conclusively that good quality condoms are highly effective in preventing the transmission of HIV... However, theoretical efficacy in the laboratory is not the same as efficacy in practice, hence the higher documented failure rate of condoms as a contraceptive."

In many parts of Africa, the most accessible condoms are poor quality ones sold in the market singly and exposed to direct sunlight. This makes the rubber perish so the condom is effective neither for Aids prevention nor contraception. It is also the case that people who are poor and powerless, who know that they may well die young, are more likely to take risks. A sex worker may agree to sex without a condom if she is paid double the rate, as this would provide food for her family.

The local context is all-important. What is vital is that ignorance, an inadequate theology or obfuscation should not be allowed to hinder implementing preventable methods that work - whether by changing sexual behaviour or using condoms.

Miranda Godfrey Catholic Institute of International Relations Miranda@ciir.org

 Well done Clare Short for speaking out. She is not against HIV education, but sees the urgent necessity of providing millions of people at risk of HIV/Aids in less-developed countries with an immediate, accessible and affordable method of prevention. Currently that method is condoms. It is time the Catholic Church matched its compassion with pragmatism and reversed its position on condom use.

Wendy Thomas Population Concern

 Pharmaceutical companies are not preventing progress by declining to reduce their prices (Leader, July 8). Since 1998, Glaxo Wellcome has offered its anti-HIV medicines Retrovir (AZT) and Epivir (3TC) at significantly reduced prices (around 75% off the global price) for developing countries. In May 2000, as part of an initiative by five pharmaceutical companies and five UN agencies, the company extended this preferential pricing to include Combivir, the fixed-dose combination of Retrovir and Epivir.

Cost of medicines is only one of the issues in expanding access to treatment. Political commitment by governments is absolutely essential. Other key aspects include access to adequate medical infrastructure (doctors, nurses, counsellors and medical equipment) and reliable drug distribution systems. While companies like Glaxo Wellcome are committed to playing their part, creativity is needed to develop new funding mechanisms for large-scale and sustainable mobilisation of resources.

James Cochrane Glaxo Wellcome

 Robin Lustig (Comment, July 11) infers the transmission of HIV is influenced by the strength of the immune system. This is not so. But there are two other important links with poverty. HIV is transmitted more easily between sexual partners who do not use a condom; and in the presence of other sexually transmitted diseases.

Condoms are largely provided by international donors and, in conformity with neo-liberalism, cost recovery is encouraged, which excludes the poor from their use. And STDs can only be tackled by public health programmes, which have been undermined by IMF structural adjustment programmes. For these reasons Aids in Africa is largely a disease of poverty, over which its governments have little control.

Neil Thomas Cardiff University

fields.headline: Bill Blomfield
fields.trailText: I n 1943, Bill Blomfield, who has died aged 87, was critically injured when his Kittyhawk fighter crashed at Laverton, in the Australian state of Victoria.
fields.body:
I n 1943, Bill Blomfield, who has died aged 87, was critically injured when his Kittyhawk fighter crashed at Laverton, in the Australian state of Victoria.

After a year in hospital he went to Britain, suffering from war trauma, and sought treatment with an eminent London psychoanalyst, Henry Ezriel. The ensuing therapy changed his life.

A decade later, Blomfield graduated from Melbourne University medical school. He studied psychiatry and, from the late 1950s, practised as an analyst. He was a founding member of both the Australian Psychoanalytic Society and the Australian Association of Group Therapists. He also lectured and published on the philosophical underpinnings of psychoanalysis.

Blomfield also took degrees in science, arts and electrical engineering. But, above all, he possessed the intuitive skills to explore the mind. To account for the extraordinary diversity of his working life, he pointed to the common theme of "communication"; accordingly, he saw the purpose of analysis as "the release of creativity and the enhancement of human relationships".

Blomfield was born in Cooma, New South Wales and educated at the Sydney church of England grammar school and Sydney University. While still a student, he obtained a flying licence, and, by the outbreak of the second world war,was a member of the RAF on a permanent commission.

He served as a pilot in Egypt and India and, in June 1940, was posted to the Air Ministry in London, installing a modern VHF radio telephone and direction-finding system for the aircraft of Fighter Command. He later served as the RAF's chief signals officer in Malta, before being posted to the Royal Australian Air Force.

Deeply cultured, Blomfield loved modern poetry, especially the works of WH Auden. His practice of psycho- analysis continued until his final stroke, a few days before he died. He leaves his wife, Jocelyn, and children David, John and Christina from his first marriage.

Bill Blomfield, psychoanalyst, born September 28 1912; died June 6 2000

fields.headline: Ras Shorty I
fields.standfirst: Calypsonian who found religion after a life of sex and drugs
fields.trailText: Few life conversions have been more spectacular than that of the Trinidadian calypsonian and father of soca music, Ras Shorty I, who has died from bone cancer aged 58.
fields.body:
Few life conversions have been more spectacular than that of the Trinidadian calypsonian and father of soca music, Ras Shorty I, who has died from bone cancer aged 58.

As the notoriously free- living "Lord Shorty", he was the classic Port of Spain "saga boy" in the 1960s and early 70s, taking part in what he later described as an "orgy of the flesh"; as the self-styled "Love Man", he had a prodigious appetite for women, drink and drugs.

Then, in the late 1970s, he found religion, renounced worldly pleasures and moved deep into the remote Piparo forest in southern Trinidad, 50 miles from Port of Spain. There he built a house, changed his name to Ras Shorty I, grew dreadlocks and lived quietly for the rest of his life with his wife, Claudette, and their 14 children.

The constant thread in his life was music. In Piparo, he proved to be a great songwriter, producing new, avowedly spiritual, tunes that were as popular with the Trinidadian public as his previous, far more frivolous, output.

His greatest legacy, however, was as the force behind soca music, which, with its up-tempo and more funky outlook, brought calypso music into the modern era. Though of African descent, he also played a significant role in bringing the sounds of Trinidad's Indian community into the island's musical mainstream. A cover version of his song, Om Shanti, became a major hit in India.

Born Garfield Blackman in Lengua, Trinidad, Shorty - so named in ironic reference to his 6ft 4in frame - began singing at the age of seven, and made his breakthrough in 1963 with the song Cloak And Dagger. He quickly became known as the most outrageous of calypsonians, in a profession renowned for carousing lifestyles. Many of his lively and hugely popular compositions, such as Lesson In Love, were appropriately risqué and sex-orientated, and in 1973 he was charged with obscenity, a complaint only dropped after the inter vention of the Trinidadian prime minister, Eric Williams.

Shorty's most important mark was made with the 1974 album Endless Vibrations, which was the first to use the new soca rhythm. Like his Lord Shorty persona, his music was bold, loud, sensuous and larger than life. It was much copied, and has become part of the bedrock of calypso.

By 1977, however, Shorty had became disenchanted with the image he had created, and when Maestro, a close calypsonian friend and composer, was killed in a car crash, he underwent a dramatic change of direction, swapping his fancy clothes for togas and sandals, and retreating to the forest.

In Piparo, after a period of Rastafarian-inspired reflection and establishing a new-found faith in Christianity, he gathered together some of his talented children to form his own musical group, the Love Circle, and devoted himself to writing songs about spiritual matters and the dangers of hedonism.

Though he sometimes complained that "a lot of people can't accept the fact that I am no longer Lord Shorty", the new message he gave out was warmly received by most Trinidadians - as well as by those further afield, who came to hear his songs through the burgeoning 1980s world-music scene. In 1977, his anti-drug song, Watch Out Children - which warns against "a fella called Lucifer with a bag of white powder, he don't want to powder your face but bring shame and disgrace to the human race" - was an international success translated into 10 languages.

Latterly, in a song called Latrine Singers, he lambasted Trinidad's new generation of calypsonians for their obsession with sexually-fixated lyrics. Although the song caused heated debate in Trinidad - and earned Shorty some insults from younger singers - it did nothing to damage the respect in which he was almost universally held.

Shorty also continued his mission to promote the "Indianisation of calypso", writing a number of songs that presaged the current boom in Trinidad of Indian-influenced "chutney soca". Last month, he and his band released God's Calypsonian, containing reworkings of "Lord Shorty" hits that he had no objection to, plus more recent numbers.

Garfield Blackman (Ras Shorty I), calypsonian, born October 6 1941; died July 12 2000

fields.headline: Golden shares to be dropped
fields.trailText: The government is ready to relinquish its "golden shares" in a score of Britain's premier privatised companies in a move that will fend off a dispute with Brussels and could prompt a rash of takeover bids.
fields.body:
The government is ready to relinquish its "golden shares" in a score of Britain's premier privatised companies in a move that will fend off a dispute with Brussels and could prompt a rash of takeover bids.

Senior government sources said last night that there was no longer any reason for the state to hold on to its £1 special rights preference share in companies ranging from Cable & Wireless to BAE Systems.

The "golden share" taken on by the government on privatisation effectively protects companies from hostile takeovers and gives ministers a virtual veto over important activities - a stake viewed by the European commission's competition directorate as a breach of EU rules on the free movement of capital.

Brussels has threatened to take the government to the European court over its golden share in BAA, the airports operator privatised in 1987. The stake prevents anyone holding more than 15% of BAA's equity and the sell-off of London's Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted airports without government approval.

Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, is keen that consumers and/or taxpayers should benefit rather than give the companies something for nothing.

The residual stake cannot be traded and will have no surrender value to the Treasury which has raised tens of billions through a spate of privatisations since the 1980s.

The companies in which the government holds a golden share include C&W, P&O Stena Line, BAE, Rolls-Royce, BAA, National Grid, National Power, PowerGen, Scottish Power, Scottish Hydro-Electric, now part of Scottish & Southern Energy and British Energy, the nuclear power operator.

webTitle: Mellowed out in the age of 'larging it'

fields.headline: Mellowed out in the age of 'larging it'
fields.standfirst: Brand values Channel 4
fields.trailText: Launched on November 2 1982, Channel 4 started out with a public service remit to brand itself as "experimental, innovative, original and diverse" and devoted to "creative excellence and risk," to quote its chief executive Michael Jackson.
fields.body:
Launched on November 2 1982, Channel 4 started out with a public service remit to brand itself as "experimental, innovative, original and diverse" and devoted to "creative excellence and risk," to quote its chief executive Michael Jackson.

But, in the ensuing 18 years, ITV2 - as it was initially conceived in the 1970s - has undergone a series of identity crises and exercises in brand redefinition as its audience and the prevailing culture it inhabits have evolved.

Many viewers would no doubt argue that Channel 4, designed to be "off-mainstream" or "ahead of the mainstream," has become as establishment-minded as New Labour - however much it still courts controversy.

This week's decision to pull the plug on a £250m, 10-year deal for exclusive coverage of racing from Britain's "Super 12" tracks smacks of an over-fed broadcaster - Britain's wealthiest per viewer - behaving just like any other corporate entity with market muscle.

The incident illustrates the continuing confusion about the channel's role. It came days after news that a show once considered at the core of Channel 4's broadcasting pitch to a young, irreverent, classless audience - Chris Evans' TFI Friday - was to be axed after five years, even though it continues to draw 2.5m viewers.

But it still puts out shows such as Ibiza (and Greece and the Caribbean) Uncovered, paeans to the British lager lout and lass on hols, Denise van Outen's mildly smutty Something for the Weekend or Antoine de Caunes' asinine Eurotrash, alongside the relatively cerebral comedy Frasier. There are also excellent imported and home-grown dramas, high quality, probing news and current affairs and stalwart afternoon game shows.

Jackson, in charge for four years, has said: "I think a lot of the barriers between high and low culture, the serious and the trivial, have been crossed."

Channel 4, he says, is about "culture in the broadest sense ... what people are thinking and talking about". Or maybe what novelist VS Naipaul called the dumbing down in public life.

The gap between populist and challenging, ground-breaking broadcasting - for the "open-minded, inquisitive and forward-thinking" in Jackson's words - is certainly less clear than under Michael Grade, his predecessor, nastily described by the Daily Mail as the "pornographer-in-chief".

Channel 4 may still run into controversy - over plans for a confessional programme fronted by a Catholic priest or the gay soap opera Queer as Folk - but the station has mellowed in tune with the nation.

Britain is a more tolerant, relaxed country than at the height of Thatcherism and even old fogies enjoy the innovative test match cricket coverage (a joint £103m bid with Sky) with its Caribbean intros, snickometers, unusual camera angles and a rejuvenated Ritchie Benaud.

Through this mix, together with the introduction of advertising in 1993 and the ending of the ITV levy, the station has become rich.

Last year it turned more than £600m, a rise of 7%, and made profits of £46m compared with £26.3m in 1998. It plans to invest £100m in E4, a digital, all-day entertainment channel available on subscription to match the FilmFour channel.

Channel 4 has won plaudits for backing winning films amidst a sea of publicly-funded duds. East is East, the bitter-sweet comedy about an Asian family in Salford, cost £3m and took £10m.

FilmFour recently concluded a £90m deal for seven films with budgets of at least £13m, each to be made over the next three years with Hollywood Studio Warner Bros, and to exploit the US taste for the British genre of movies.

This financial success has not gone unnoticed in the Treasury where the chancellor is reportedly pondering a £2bn privatisation.

But Jackson and his fellow executives, ensconced in nearby Horseferry Road, are determined to resist - summoning the "diversity of supply, funding and structure" as the dividend of British television that should not be frittered away. FilmFour may, however, be floated off.

Last year the channel dropped its colourless "circles" logo, introduced three years earlier and heartily disliked, in favour of a bright, new identity costing £100,000. It's just the latest corporate makeover for a channel desperately seeking its place in a landscape being transformed by the advent of digital channels, WAP phones and TV-through-the-PC.

But Channel 4 has retained around a 10% share of the market, a healthy, lucrative slice for a station that some of its founding fathers and mothers regard as little more than "tits and willies".

Last year the channel dropped its colourless "circles" logo, introduced three years earlier and heartily disliked, in favour of a bright, new identity costing £100,000. It's just the latest corporate makeover for a channel desperately seeking its place in a landscape being transformed by the advent of digital channels, WAP phones and TV-through-the-PC. But Channel 4 has retained around a 10% share of the market, a healthy, lucrative slice for a station that some of its founding fathers and mothers regard as little more than "tits and willies".

fields.headline: A driving ambition
fields.standfirst: Interview with Moir Lockhead, chief executive, FirstGroup
fields.trailText: It is an unusual sight to observe the chief executive of one of Britain's largest transport companies, FirstGroup, standing outside a smart, suburban school in Baltimore on a bright summer morning waiting for the children to arrive.
fields.body:
It is an unusual sight to observe the chief executive of one of Britain's largest transport companies, FirstGroup, standing outside a smart, suburban school in Baltimore on a bright summer morning waiting for the children to arrive.

Moir Lockhead is not there by chance. The reason for his presence becomes apparent as the first of a fleet of 10 yellow school buses, a trusted and important aspect of America's educational system, hoves in to view and carefully deposits its young passengers at the school door. Each one is greeted warmly by the deputy headmistress and bounces off inside.

Lockhead is in Baltimore to complete a deal which could make the sturdy yellow bus as familiar a part of the British educational landscape as it is in the United States.

A handful of local authorities in Britain already operate them. But most use traditional buses, many of them old, which are not built specially for children. All school buses in the US are custom-built, with yellow and red flashing warning lights, escape routes through the roof, and special safety devices at the front to stop children falling in front of the vehicle.

Lockhead says that several local authorities from Scotland to London are ready to sign up to the project. It has the backing of the government because it will help to reduce congestion in large conurbations. In London alone, the Department of Transport says, cars on the school run add 20 minutes to the rush-hour travelling time.

From his modest office above a bus garage in Aberdeen, Lockhead runs a rapidly expanding multinational transport undertaking in Britain, the US and Australia, which received its biggest impetus, as did companies such as Stagecoach, when the Tories privatised first the bus industry and then the railways.

Apart from school buses, the company has numerous other American interests. These include vehicle repair and maintenance services for the police and fire brigade, and a landmark coach shuttle service designed to improve Washington's heavy congestion.

Lockhead is among a handful of executives who have moved seamlessly from the public into the private sector. Having worked tirelessly in the industry for 40 years, his big opportunity came in 1989 when he led a management buyout of the local bus company in Aberdeen for £4.5m.

Lockhead says: "We quickly recognised the need to grow and doubled our size in a matter of years through assiduous acquisition until we were brought to the stock market in 1994. Among the acquisitions were buses in Manchester and Glasgow, and we hit it big when we merged with Badgerline, a group with large interests in the west country."

Then came the interest in trains, slowly at first but bolstered by the unexpected 25% growth in passenger volume, FirstGroup is now one of the leading players. It operates Great Western from London to the west country and south Wales; North Western, a franchise stretching north and south of Manchester, and Great Eastern services into Liverpool Street. North Western makes a big loss with 1,450 train journeys a day covering 423 stations, whereas Great Eastern makes 650 journeys through only 20 stations, and is in profit.

Lockhead, a blunt talker, is critical about the state of the industry. "We need a new railway out of the old one. We need a new strategy, which is sadly lacking, and we need more investment, which we are not getting. I don't think Railtrack can cope with building a new railway by itself. It does need government help which at the moment it is not getting."

Lockhead speaks like a man in a hurry. "We're just about to get the government's 10-year transport plan. But we can't wait 10 years. We need action now."

The trouble, and Lockhead accepts the point, is that it takes years to turn round a railway which has been starved of investment for decades.

Lockhead appears to eat and breathe his job and you can't stop him once he's on a roll. So he's off bashing the franchise "renewal" process - under which private train companies have to rebid not only to run the service, but to design the area they would like to run it in. "It's extremely costly, particularly in the absence of any strategy, and because I don't know how the SSRA (Shadow Strategic Rail Authority) wants to develop the railway."

While backing Railtrack's claim for more government help, he is angry with the privatised company for its failure to carry out an adequate job. The £5.4bn upgrade of the west coast main line between London and Glasgow is beset with problems.

Its cost has more than doubled, and as a train operator, Lockhead is deeply resentful that the upgrade is pushing the loss-making North West Trains even more deeply into the red. He's training his sights on Railtrack. "Constant and badly planned work, particularly south of Manchester, is making it virtually impossible to operate a satisfactory service and we get it in the neck from our customers."

Safety warning

One of FirstGroup's franchises is Great Western, deeply implicated in the Southall rail crash where no safety warning systems were operating and which might have warned the driver of the impending tragedy. At the more recent Paddington disaster, the Great Western express which collided with a Thames train crossing its path had no chance to stop but was fitted with an advanced warning protection system (ATP).

Lockhead says Southall occurred before FirstGroup took over the franchise and that ATP, the most modern safety system on the railway, is installed on every train. He is defensive about the deaths. "I do not think that these two tragedies were caused by privatisation. In our case, the railway has become more demand led, and we put safety at the top of priorities. We want to keep the confidence of our customers, not drive them away."

Now a confirmed Aberdonian, Lockhead was born in Durham and completed a five-year engineering apprenticeship in Darlington and Newcastle. "During that process, I met my wife. She was the only one in the central office of a transport company surrounded by 300 males. We've been married for more than 30 years."

He and his wife run a 300 acre house and farm at Glassels, 20 miles out of Aberdeen, and breed Highland cattle. He has a manager and gets back as often as possible. "I'm a family man, but I'm away far too much. I try to keep the weekends free."

The less glamorous side of the business are the buses - where the money is made. Here profit margins are 15%. Until recently, the company was presiding over a declining industry, but outside London, growth is averaging 0.7% a year and First Group is holding its market share.

It has embarked on a series of quality partnerships with local authorities, sharing investment to improve bus routes. In Glasgow alone, passenger growth is around 4%.

So long as the government plays its part with the private sector, Mr Lockhead believes that public transport is set for an important leap ahead, even in an overcrowded island where congestion is suffocating the south east, the Midlands, and parts of the north of England and west Scotland.

At first sight, Lockhead does not strike one as a visionary. But his dream of public transport 10 years from now is of a system "where you can do everything by mobile phone. You will be able to link up with a real time system which will tell you if your train is running to schedule, and then be able to book a taxi to make sure that your travel plans are not ruined. And there will be a national smart card, enabling you to travel by bus, train and plane."

Pressing problem

Vertical integration will reduce the 25 franchise operators, allowing greater flexibility for the compnaies and the travelling public. But Mr Lockhead is concerned that an over-regulated rail industry will stifle enterprise and profits.

For the moment, one of the more pressing problems is how the main London rail termini will cope with the expansion of the rail network. Will there be double decker trains to cope with mounting passenger usage, expected to increase by 50% over the next decade, or longer platforms at stations such as Paddington, Waterloo and Liverpool Street?

Mr Lockhead would like the government to be "honest" - a word he says without caution. "Does it really want to see a meaningful transfer of traffic from road to rail, and if so how should it be done.?" Lockhead clearly believes that he is still waiting for the answer.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: null
fields.body:
Wessenden

The last cuckoo of the season had been heard but the rhodo- dendron blooms were still at their best as we crossed the tussock moor from Shooter's Nab to come in sight of this grand, northward draining valley on a recent hot day. There was a mirage effect across Meltham Moor, to wards the tor-dotted crest of West Nab.

Wessenden's string of four reservoirs reflected the shining summer sky; a dunlin piped repeatedly as we went, sure sign of high summer on the moor. And so we came down to the dark towers of encircling sycamores, shrouds for the forlorn shell of Wessenden Lodge where Edwardian shooting parties once assembled - in more recent times, rich repasts were served to walking parties.

Wessenden was the only refreshment spot on the Pennine Way for many, many moorland miles but now that service is a fading memory, too. The official line of the long distance footpath used to keep to the watershed well to the west; now the so-called "Wessenden alternative" has been adopted as the proper route. It makes sense; keeping to the shelter of this Pennine dale gives pleasanter, more sheltered going.

Once across the impounding wall of Wessenden Reservoir, the path contours in and out of a couple of dramatic, rock-girt cloughs and so climbs west again to the moorland skyline and on towards Standedge and Blackstone Edge.

The climb out of Blakeley Clough has been improved by the construction of stone steps, and the steady rise up the edge of Black Moss is now a flagged path. The former dance from peaty tussock to peaty tussock in a hopeless attempt to avoid the worst of the bog has been replaced by a steady progress on the welcome stone slabs, laid here in an attempt to preserve as much of the moor's natural surface as possible.

The demise of the textile mills in the valleys on both sides made available large quantities of these useful stones. Even so, a handful of "purists" claim such path- laying to be wrong, that we should continue to wallow unpleasantly through raw nature!

fields.headline: Aquarius Platinum
fields.standfirst: Our weekly look at the hot gossip in the internet chat rooms
fields.trailText: Aquarius Platinum. Could it be the age of you making money?
fields.body:
Aquarius Platinum. Could it be the age of you making money?

It's an Australian-based, Bermudan-registered, South African-operated platinum mining company floated at the end of last year.

Sounds a little dodgy to me.

Well, if you want to check it out yourself, try its website at www.aquariusplatinum.com.au. It also has a full listing on the Australian stock exchange.

OK. But surely all that glisters is not...

This time it might be. The worldwide demand for platinum fuel cells has leapt, lifting Aquarius's share price to a record high this month. In this country it is listed on the junior market AIM and is currently at 217.5p compared to 80p six months ago.

A fuel cell battery for mobile phones has just been unveiled and cars are increasingly being manufactured with platinum catalysts. General Motors has recently issued a statement reiterating its commitment to use platinum instead of palladium in its vehicles.

Even more exciting for investors, platinum fuel cells are now being developed which could eventually replace the car's combustion engine. Daimler Benz, Ford and GM all plan to use these cells on the production line from 2003. Emerging markets are also using more platinum.

Platinum jewellery sales are shooting up - in 1999 by 68% in the UK and 53% in China, and last year demand for the metal exceeded supply by 730,000 ounces. The platinum price is now at a record high.

For more information on the metal check out the Platinum Metal's Review's website at www.platinum.matthey.com/publications/pmr.html.

And is Aquarius well placed to take advantage of this?

This week, the company announced it has secured its third mining project, Everest South. This should be in production by 2002, and when it is, it will be Aquarius's largest mine yet. Aquarius has also just commenced production at a new mine in South Africa - Kroondal - two months ahead of schedule. When this mine reaches peak capacity, it will be churning out 100,000 ounces (metrication has evidently not yet reached the mining world) of platinum and 50,000 ounces of palladium a year.

It has also received very positive results from a feasibility study on another mine - Marikana, which is also in South Africa. The mine could contribute up to $72m in gross revenues.

What about the competition?

It is a small market, but those competitors that there are, are also doing very well. Anglo American Platinum, Impala Platinum and Northern Platinum are the biggest, and their share prices have risen 72%, 114% and 74% respectively, over the past few months.

Impala, the world's second largest platinum producer, is also Aquarius' biggest shareholder.

So what does the City say?

Share price estimates range from £10 in the medium term to £3 in the short term. Its London brokers are Williams de Broe.

And what do the small investors think?

The bulletin boards are a'buzzin - not surprising, as it is a very sexy sector at the moment. But remember, a lot of what is said in the unregulated cyber lounges is misleading, deceptive or just plain wrong.

Maurillac, writing on the Hemscott board, says: "I was going to get some, but my bank manager recommended them - put me right off!"

Another, more serious, chatter writes: "Rumour is that more expansion is to come (within three weeks). This looks a pretty good share to me."

Robur on UK-iNvest's board says: "The chart is not a buy or sell at the moment, though the huge increases in volume suggests that the price probably will break out and then become a definite buy. I would watch it very closely over the next few days."

Those Citytipsters (remember them? the group emailing anonymous, but generally accurate, share information to select people, in order, presumably, to see the value of their holdings go up) are understandably keen.

They say: "This week, we believe we have found one of the most exciting stocks, with a solid past performance and huge upward momentum. Aquarius has recently sprinted ahead to reach a closing price of 213p. At this current price, our research shows there is plenty of distance left to run and the target is £10."

webTitle: Put that pain where it belongs

fields.headline: Put that pain where it belongs
fields.trailText: Is your utility company turning a deaf ear to your complaints? Here we list the standard ways to make a complaint, plus less conventional ways to hit back if you are persistently ignored.
fields.body:
Is your utility company turning a deaf ear to your complaints? Here we list the standard ways to make a complaint, plus less conventional ways to hit back if you are persistently ignored.

Conventional

 Try Ofgem, the office of gas and electricity markets, at www.ofgem.gov.uk or 0800 888777. It will guide you to either the Gas Consumers Council or your local Electricity Consumers' Committee. These will take up your complaint with the company.

 If they cannot resolve the problem, Ofgem has statutory powers to make suppliers comply with licence conditions.

Unconventional

 Phone the head office (BG's is 01784 874000) and demand to speak to the chief executive or managing director, identifying them by name if possible. You probably won't get them, but you will get someone high up enough to ensure things are done. Making it clear you will be ringing that person every day until the matter is sorted, will concentrate their mind.

 Insist the company has the meter read - it hits the company financially. London Electricity, for instance, pays its sub-contractor £26 for each reading. Until the company establishes how much gas or electricity has been used, it has no legal right to charge for it.

 Don't pay bills by direct debit. Cheque handling represents a tremendous cost for any large business.

 Send payments to the head office rather than the payment processing centre. Enclose a few coins. Many companies have to send out a receipt even for one penny.

 Check you are on the lowest tariff. www.buy.co.uk/ personal/calculators has very simple calculators for gas, electricity and water charges.

Many companies have to send out a receipt even for one penny.  Check you are on the lowest tariff. www.buy.co.uk/ personal/calculators has very simple calculators for gas, electricity and water charges.

webTitle: Afloat on a sea of music

fields.headline: Afloat on a sea of music
fields.standfirst: The Grace Darling choir recently flirted with the big-time. Last week, as  David Ward reports, they took their special repertoire back where they feel more comfortable
fields.trailText: The Grace Darling choir recently flirted with the big-time. Last week, as David Ward reports, they took their special repertoire back where they feel more comfortable
fields.body:
Last week, a small choir named after a sea-going Northumbrian heroine celebrated its 10th anniversary with a concert in a pretty chapel dedicated to St Chad on the outskirts of Stockport, Greater Manchester. There were only 90 seats. It was a small audience but we were nervous, because we always are - but not as twitchy as we were last month when we made our debut at the Bridgewater Hall in Manchester.

At rather than in: we were not actually on the wide platform where Barenboim has conducted and Kissin played; instead we sang in the foyer as patrons arrived for a Hallé orchestra summer prom featuring bleeding chunks from choral masterpieces. As the big night approached, I had this ludicrous daydream that our performance would be so sensational the audience would demand the Hallé choir should shove off and let us do the second half of the gig.

It didn't happen. We were, after all, only the warm-up act: 40 minutes before the concert, 15 minutes at half-time. We sang as as concert-goers turned up to buy programmes, order drinks, eat Magnums, chat to friends, find the loos. We had chosen our programme carefully to suit the venue. We had dusted off a piece appropriately named Bridgewater, and also gave what these days is called a site-specific performance. The hall has a great glass prow jutting out over its entrance and that's where we sang: prow made us think of ships, ships of Titanic, and Titanic of Nearer my God to Thee, the great hymn played by bandmaster Wallace Hartley and his men as the liner slid beneath the icy waters of the Atlantic.

When we started, no one else was there. Then a few concert-goers turned up but pretended we weren't there. Then some stopped to listen; there was even some applause. This event was the big time, the high-point in the career of the Grace Darling Singers, founded in 1990 to sing a bizarre repertoire mainly for fun.

It was all my idea, a bit of folly begun by someone who can't sight read, hasn't got perfect pitch, can't breathe properly and failed O-level music with 38%. I wrote a piece for a local arts magazine inviting interest from anyone who wanted to do something a bit different from the output of the average choral society. About a dozen strangers (plus press-ganged friends) turned up and sang in my dining room while Emily, the late black and white cat, yowled. Our neighbour said the singing sounded heavenly as it drifted through her wall.

The first thing we did was the Grace Darling Song, a Victorian ballad celebrating the brave woman who helped rescue the crew of the stricken vessel Forfarshire. That song gave us our name and we adopted as our banner a dramatic portrait of Grace pulling on her oars. (It's a very nice tea towel, a souvenir from the Grace Darling Museum in Bamburgh.) Next, to cheer ourselves up, we sang a dirge called Peat Bog Soldiers, written during the Spanish civil war, and then I think we did Throw Out The Lifeline, a ballad in praise of temperance.

We have met monthly and settled into a specialised repertoire: church music in England and America from 1750 to 1850, written by local composers for their own choirs, the kind of music sung by the Mellstock Quire in Thomas Hardy's Under The Greenwood Tree.

Almost everything we do has been dug out and edited from long-neglected manuscripts and books by our musical director, who is doing a PhD in this stuff and knows about keys, cadences and contemporary performance practice. We have sung the hymns and psalms of James Leach of Rochdale, Richard Taylor of Chester, John Beaumont of Macclesfield, Daniel Read of Attleboro, Mass, Supply Belcher of Stoughton (Mass again), and JJ Stone of nowhere in particular.

We have a particular affection for a tune called Gilgal by Blind Billy Lonsdale of Bolton, a talented multi-instrumentalist who was kicked out of his church when he played a jig instead of a solemn melody at a Sunday morning service after a boozy Saturday night. And we have a kind of discreet passion for the work of William Billings of Boston, an incredibly ugly tanner who, a century and a half before Charles Ives, wrote American music that dances with delight and eccentricity.

I'd go so far as to boast that the Grace Darlings are leading the British celebrations marking the 200th anniversary this year of Billings's death. If the Hallé audience didn't take to his Rose of Sharon it would have stood condemned for its cloth ears. And yet, although we hit the big time with the Bridgewater (as we did when we recorded Sunday Half Hour for Radio 2), it's the small times we seem to enjoy most.

There was that night in south Manchester when we invited the audience to join us in a couple of numbers (including one of the earliest tunes for While Shepherds Watched; it's now better known as On Ilkley Moor Baht 'At) and heard this wondrous wall of Methodist sound coming at us.

We've sung three times to a cotton mill's massive steam engine in Oldham, and tried to stay in three-four time when a stoker was shovelling coal in four-four. We've hired a boat called the Grace Darling at Stratford, cruised down the Avon and frightened the wits out of passengers on the chain ferry by singing Nearer My God To Thee.

We've walked across fields on sunny summer days to sing for ourselves in lonely churches: one in Warwickshire was at the heart of a deserted medieval village; the other, in Cheshire, had a fine horse-drawn hearse which we serenaded with a funeral hymn from Shropshire.

But perhaps the best day was a trip to the beautiful church of St Lawrence above Rushton Spencer, near Leek in Staffordshire, where old Uriah Davenport taught and led his singers for 60 years until his death at 94 in 1784. If you go up to the gallery, you can find Uriah's initials picked out in studs on a bench. We went there to sing some of his own music at a Sunday service, and included his setting of Psalm 150, the one that goes on about praising the Lord with all kinds of instruments. The piece has its fair number of tricks, and the tenors have to pretend to be trumpets and the basses to be droning bagpipes.

We were quite nervous. The tenors suspended all movement in an attempt to avoid provoking distressing creaks from a bench which was beginning to flag after 250 years' loyal service. A thrush was singing sweetly in a tree which may have been around to tremble on September 14 1777, when an earthquake shook Rushton, throwing the congregation into great confusion. Perhaps Uriah's singers trembled too, and perhaps terror made them sing all the better; it usually works with us.

One of the joys of singing this kind of music is that just occasionally there is a time slip and you find yourself becoming at one with those 18th century singers who struggled to learn a piece which took them to the edge of their collective ability and sometimes beyond. We share their anxieties and tribulations, the lows when there is a cock-up, the adrenalin-drenched highs when we reach for something beyond the mere notes.

We sang Davenport's Psalm 150 at the Bridgewater in almost certainly its first Manchester performance. We hope the prom-goers enjoyed it (especially the bit where the tenors gargle like trumpets) but we would't have minded if they didn't. Last week, marking our own anniversary, we were back in the small time.

webTitle: Strain is awful, says friend of missing woman

fields.headline: Strain is awful, says friend of missing woman
fields.standfirst: Audio: Joanthan Watts in Tokyo
fields.trailText: The woman at the centre of the Tokyo police investigation into the disappearance of Lucie Blackman has told of the pressure she is under to help in the search for her childhood friend.
fields.body:
The woman at the centre of the Tokyo police investigation into the disappearance of Lucie Blackman has told of the pressure she is under to help in the search for her childhood friend.

Detectives questioned Louise Phillips for the fifth consecutive day yesterday as the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, appealed to the Japanese public for information on the whereabouts of Ms Blackman, who has been missing for two weeks.

The 21-year-old former British Airways stewardess disappeared after going on an afternoon date with a man, who is believed to have been a customer at the hostess bar she worked at in the Roppongi entertainment district of Tokyo.

Two days later, Ms Phillips received a phone call from a man claiming that her friend had joined a religious cult in Chiba, an area just east of Tokyo. "You'll never see her again," he said.

Detectives and Ms Blackman's father suspect that this call was a hoax, but with few solid leads suggesting any clear alternatives, investigators have asked Ms Phillips to go over what happened again and again.

"It has been the worst time of my life," Ms Phillips said. "The police are not treating me as a suspect, but I seem to be all they have to go on."

Every day this week, Ms Phillips has spent 10 to 12 hours at the Azabu police station, where she has been interviewed by up to five detec tives through an interpreter. Ms Phillips and Ms Blackman were educated at the same private school, worked for the same airline and, after flying to Tokyo together, shared an apartment and took jobs at the same hostess bar, the Casablanca.

Although Ms Phillips could leave Japan at any time, she has chosen to stay and assist in the police inquiries. "The police told me that if I go home they have got nothing to go on. When I heard that, I was determined to stay."

Other lines of investigation appear to be yielding few positive results. Police have distributed 30,000 leaflets appealing for help in Roppongi and around the area where the two women lived.

Toshihiko Mii, deputy superintendent of the Azabu police station, said, however, that there had been only 47 responses, none of which appeared promising.

Yesterday, detectives interviewed the Casablanca bar manager, Tetsuo Nishi.

Police have also taken copies of the bar's records of customer orders and out-of-hours dates. The Casablanca is known to push its hostesses to meet clients outside the bar. These "dohan" dates generate a large share of the bar's income.

Police are investigating the possibility that Ms Blackman was abducted by a customer while on a dohan.

A police spokesman said that detectives have not interviewed other hostesses at the Casablanca, nor a boyfriend that Tim Blackman, Lucie's father, mentioned to them on Thursday.

"We don't know who he is or where he is," said Mr Mii.

In an attempt to generate new leads, Mr Cook held an impromptu press conference yesterday after meeting Mr Blackman during a brief stop in Tokyo.

The foreign secretary said: "I would ask those in Japan who may have some information to reflect on the pain and the distress that this is causing Mr Blackman and his family.

"I have expressed the concern of the British government over the disappearance of Lucie."

webTitle: What have I got to do to get served?

fields.headline: What have I got to do to get served?
fields.standfirst: Richard Colbey reports on the never-ending battle to get some sense out of the corporations
fields.trailText: In 1997 Antje Ayala arrived in London from Germany, perhaps unfamiliar with how British utility companies operate. Shortly after she moved into her rented house in Catford, south London a bill for £803 from British Gas arrived addressed to the previous tenant.
fields.body:
In 1997 Antje Ayala arrived in London from Germany, perhaps unfamiliar with how British utility companies operate. Shortly after she moved into her rented house in Catford, south London a bill for £803 from British Gas arrived addressed to the previous tenant.

Ms Ayala returned it to BG with a note saying the last tenant had moved and asking that the supply be put in her name. She even sent the reading she had taken on the date she moved in. Almost by return of post, she was sent a bill addressed to her for that £803. She phoned the number on top of the bill, explained the position again and shortly afterwards was sent a statement on which the claim for £803 had been cancelled.

That should have been the end of the story for Ms Ayala. But two and a half years later that £803 is still haunting Ms Ayala. Every so often British Gas sends her another bill with that sum on it. Each time she contacts the company pointing out the facts. The time she spends waiting for her calls to be answered has become longer as BG has cut down on its staffing over the years and installed ever more convoluted telephone answering systems. She was never able to talk to the same person twice. There seemed to be no meaningful log of her calls.

Apologies became ever more fulsome as her complaints became more strident. No one ever offered her any compensation for the aggravation and wasted time, and she was too polite to ask. Still, like a particularly tenacious weed, the £803 kept appearing on her bills.

Last month it mutated into a demand for £4.07. While a deduction of nearly £800 might seem like a good result, there was no reason why Ms Ayala should pay even that sum. The demand was soon followed by a threat of legal action from BG. Her final letter of protest was being ignored when she contacted the Guardian.

As is often the case with those companies which adopt the most tyrannical approach to their customers, media intervention brings the quickest and most abject of apologies. A charming PR officer was promising the day after being called that the matter was finally sorted out, and reasonable compensation - £100 - would be proffered.

The phrases "of course this shouldn't happen", "computer error" and "we hope to learn from mistakes like this" were bandied about. The mere fact that BG has to employ a full-time press officer to deal specifically with billing complaints suggests that it will learn no more from Ms Ayala's case than all those that preceded it.

Richard Colbey is a barrister.

webTitle: Sad to say, taking hostages is illegal

fields.headline: Sad to say, taking hostages is illegal
fields.standfirst: Shoddy service isn't just the preserve of the big utility companies,  writes Richard Colbey.
fields.trailText: Therese O'Dell was in such a spin over a £269, 10-month-old washing machine that she held a repair man hostage for three hours to force his bosses to replace the machine.
fields.body:
Therese O'Dell was in such a spin over a £269, 10-month-old washing machine that she held a repair man hostage for three hours to force his bosses to replace the machine.

But be warned: taking hostages - even service engineers - is a serious criminal offence.

Mrs O'Dell, who lives in Somerset, bought her machine from Currys, part of the Dixons Group. She says the store insisted that she get the manufacturer to repair it under the guarantee, an excuse often used by shoddy retailers. Dixons' staff routinely tell customers they are not entitled to a replacement or refund more than 28 days after sale.

The Sale of Goods Act, though, squarely places the onus on the seller to rectify problems if a product is not of reasonable quality. Although goods don't, of course, have to last for ever, a washing machine that breaks down within a few months, as Ms O'Dell's did, is not of reasonable quality.

Electrical goods are prone to going wrong, and as there is no profit in fixing them, there is little incentive for retailers to provide meaningful after-sales service. Even making a call to the service centre can add up. Dixons clients have to pay national call rates to dial its customer services number, rather than the local rate offered by many big companies.

Then they have to play along with a complicated electronic message system only to be told they are in a queue. Experimenting with this number last week, Jobs & Money waited seven minutes and was then cut off.

The underlying contempt of the organisation for those who provide its profits was revealed to me last summer, when after a particularly traumatic experience with the non-delivery of a dishwasher, I asked to speak to Dixons' customer services director Tony Croft. I was told point blank: "The customer service director has a policy of not speaking to customers."

Generally speaking the company's official customer service number is best avoided altogether. I have found a more productive approach with Dixons is to ring its legal department (01442 353050) directly.

The initial response may be that the problem is a customer service matter, not a legal one. But you will be more persuasive if you point out that the company's failure to provide any meaningful customer service turns everything into a potential legal dispute.

Using that device I have twice had replacement goods delivered to me quickly, after encountering the "we can't do an exchange after 28 days" nonsense in the shops.

You may also want to point out that forcing you to turn to the guarantee instead, leaving you to contact the repair company, does not square even with the company's stated policy. A spokesman at Dixons' head office says: "If goods are faulty within 28 days we will offer a refund or exchange, and after that we will manage the repair within the first year."

The legal route is far better than Ms O'Dell's approach. It might be satisfying to take a hostage but she was fortunate that the engineer, his employers, Servis, and the local police all seemed to have a sense of humour and proportion.

Had they not, she would have had little defence to a prosecution for the common law offence of false imprisonment, which theoretically carries a sentence of life imprisonment.

To avoid the risk of being driven to crime, the best thing is probably to avoid national high street chains altogether.

Small retailers rely on their local reputation and rarely try to evade their obligations.

Not having the advertising costs and overheads of companies like Dixons they are often cheaper too.

webTitle: Drink your tea and don't play those patriot games

fields.headline: Drink your tea and don't play those patriot games
fields.trailText: Gazza and Shaza | Waitrose and Somerfield | More news from Wigan
fields.body:
We shouldn't get too upset about the ludicrous fake history in the new film The Patriot. You might as well complain that Bambi isn't an accurate depiction of ruminant artiodactyls.

What I found in America - on the rare occasions that those most courteous people ever raised the subject - was that you could shut them up with several killer facts: that the chattering classes in London heartily supported the colonists in the American revolution, since they detested George III every bit as much as the Americans did; that almost half the colonists were against severing the union, and were treated abominably by the rebels; and that the Boston tea party was a protest not against British taxes, but against the removal of the duty on tea. The men dressed up as Indians in Boston harbour were smugglers whose livelihood had disappeared.

Finally I would say: "the American revolution was a triumph for Britain, since British settlers under the command of a British general defeated German mercenaries under the command of a German king." They usually changed the subject after that.

 I went to the Party In The Park, the big Prince's Trust charity pop bash in Hyde Park last weekend, to bask in the rain. Our friend had, with incredible generosity, paid for VIP tickets for a dozen of us so that we had food, booze, and, most important, a tent in which to shelter during the deluge.

It was great fun to sit around a table with chums, drinking beer and eating hot smoked salmon while watching the acts on the giant screen, though I did pause for a ponder when Kylie Minogue came on and half the tent cheered enthusiastically. It was one of those weird moments, like when someone who seems quite normal suddenly tells you that his brain has been hijacked by aliens.

So I looked round and noticed that many of the guests in the hospitality tent were what children these days call "gazzas". A gazza is someone rich but oafish. He generally has hair that is either close cropped, or else expensively layered and gelled. He has a lot of face jewellery, including at least one ring in one ear. He wears designer T-shirts, and bizarre but costly footwear. His wife or girlfriend, called a "sharon", has layered bottle-blond hair and a tight-fitting black leather jacket.

I was fascinated by the etymology. Gascony gets its name from the Vascones tribe, who came north into what is now France round the 6th century. For a long time Gascony was the last remaining toe-hold of English power in south-west France, hence the large number of people in Britain called Gascoigne, one line of which finally spawned the rich but oafish footballer who has given his nickname to this teenage slang. Meanwhile, the Vascones who stayed in Spain became Basques, and their national costume named a tight-fitting bodice which stops just below the waist. This is now an item of slightly tarty lingerie, which is no doubt worn by many sharons (a name deriving, I suppose, from the Plain of Sharon, in Israel).

 About 28 years ago, the late Willie Whitelaw, then Ulster secretary, warned a bunch of us hacks over white wine and crisps that if the Protestant population of Ulster turned down the latest peace settlement, the British people would not tolerate it and would demand dramatic action - even to the extent of ripping up the Union. They did reject it, and the British people rolled over and let them. Now, with the "loyalist" population imitating the lads in Charleroi on a far grander scale - while just as noisily proclaiming their allegiance - we're letting them do it again. What will it take for us to scream at these people that enough is enough?

 The cheapest of the big supermarket chains, Somerfields, announced its disastrous results this week on the day that Waitrose, probably the most upmarket, opened a new store near us. Until May this had been a Somerfields, full of little old ladies, and poorer Indians and Pakistanis who will never make the Sunday Times list of Britain's richest Asian entrepreneurs. They would buy a small packet of generic chipolatas, a box of cheap biscuits, maybe half a pound of loose potatoes. They were still there this week, looking bemused at 19 spaghetti sauces, 20 buckets each containing a different kind of olives, and 37 types of fresh pasta. One of the byproducts of our booming consumer society is that, bit by bit, week by week, the poor seem to be getting squeezed even tighter.

 The annual Bulwer-Lytton prize for the worst, invented, introduction to a novel has, I'm pleased to say, been won this year by a Brit, Kevin Ruston of Barnet. But my own favourite past winner was around a decade ago: "Rosy-fingered dawn crept slowly past the clubhouse, over the golf course, and towards the copse, searching desperately for the car keys she had dropped the night before."

 More news from Wigan, that epicentre of gastronomy, the Périgord of Britain. One M Blundell writes from nearby Standish: "I thought it must have been an urban myth. But last week I saw one, large as life, being eaten in the centre of Wigan - a 'Wigan Butty', which is a pie inside a buttered barm cake!"

More news from Wigan Harry Potter sold 372,775 copies in its first few days, compared to only 3,855 sales of The Redemption Of Althalus, number two in the hardback bestseller list. The tenth is Gemini, by Dorothy Dunnett, which sold just 383 - one copy for every 1,000 Harry Potters. It must be the greatest gap ever in the top 10. I guessed one reason from chatting to James Naughtie at the Today programme party, held in the rain in the Chelsea Physic Garden. He had acquired copies for each of his three children, who were being visited by two cousins, each of whom had copies: "Our house was like the Athenaeum reading room for the whole weekend."

fields.headline: In a spin over Campbell
fields.trailText: In a match between Surrey and Leicestershire at the weekend, the Surrey batsman Alistair Brown made 295 not out. The game was played not in Leicestershire proper, but at Oakham School, Rutland.
fields.body:
In a match between Surrey and Leicestershire at the weekend, the Surrey batsman Alistair Brown made 295 not out. The game was played not in Leicestershire proper, but at Oakham School, Rutland. "It is apparently the highest score ever made in Rutland," the Sunday Times said. I love that "apparently". People are beginning to learn. If it had not been for "apparently" the Sunday Times would have been in inundated this week with claims that in a match between Upper Hambleton Clergy and an Edith Weston tradesmen's XI in the sultry summer of 1909, a visiting bishop carried his bat for 301.

It's a pretty sound rule in these matters that nothing is ever the longest, highest or first of anything. There are still said to be ancient people lurking in Cumbria who believe that Helvellyn is the highest mountain in England, an assumption long since proved wrong by modern technology. I weep for them.

Did you, perhaps, detect a momentary hesitation in the item above? Just after the words "Surrey batsman"? I feared as much. It was at this point I had to go downstairs and look up the spelling of Brown's first name in Wisden. There are various forenames which waste precious human energy by needing a check whenever you use them, but Alastair/Alistair is, in my view, the worst.

An otherwise excellent history of this newspaper by David Ayerst contrives to misspell the first name of its former editor Alastair Hetherington in its closing pages. I suspect this problem has a political significance too. People often ask me: "Why are you scribbler johnnies so rotten about the prime minister's secretary, Alastair Campbell? He seems a fine, upstanding young fellow to me and no mean tootler on the Scottish bagpipes, eh what?" I immediately launch into a steaming tirade against the evils of flamsterism; yet I wonder as I do so if that is really the root of the problem.

In my view, my trade is rude about Campbell because it is sick to death of having to check how he spells his forename every time he is mentioned. Because it is often shortened to Ali, it might be assumed to be Alistair. It is not. Alistair Campbell is a cricketer who plays for Zimbabwe, and I dare say the phone will ring in a moment with a claim that he once made 296 not out while batting in Rutland.

I now have my own mnemonic: "Alastair Campbell, alas". But if Labour is really determined to rid itself of media backbiting, it should bring in a law to clarify the issue. It could order, for instance, that those in this class employed in the government service must be Alastairs, and all the rest must be Alistairs. I dare say the Commons would swiftly pass an emergency bill to give this effect, though the Lords might give trouble. I weep for them.

The other day I stopped for a drink in Slaidburn, Lancashire, at a pub called the Hark to Bounty. This pub was once called The Dog. The local rector, a man called Wigglesworth, had a hound called Bounty which he used to tie up outside this inn when he called for a drink. One day this dog barked so imperiously for its walk to be resumed that the rector exclaimed: "Hark to Bounty!"; whereupon it was decided, for reasons inexplicable in our own allegedly more rational century, that this should become the name of the pub.

Was the local MP asked to intervene? Were questions raised in parliament? Was the minister for culture, the media and sport incited to make a statement? Of course not. But nowadays if the Lansdowne pub in Cheltenham dares to alter its name to the Dog 'n' Do'nut, huge ululations arise, from Tory MPs especially. These are people who over the years have grinningly condoned the deaths of great industries; who endlessly squawk against the depredations of what they vibrantly term "the nanny state"; who can rarely get through an innings of 295 not out without repeatedly uttering the parrot cry "get government off our backs". Yet let the brewers decide that, to keep the Rose and Crown viable, they will have to alter its name to the Vole and Vibrator, and the cry goes up for government intervention to halt such a filthy practice. Students of cant, not to be confused with students of Kant, must find this phenomenon gripping. Such people should only be permitted to enter pubs with names like the Hound and Hypocrite. I weep for them.

The world, as I think I've complained before, is suddenly full of tsars; drugs tsars, culture tsars or whatever. It is also jam-packed with gurus. A man called John Morgan, who died in awful circumstances this week, used to write a weekly column in the Times telling people how to behave. I hated his stuff, not least because of his ruling that a man committed a solecism whenever he used use blue ink, but I'm sorry that he is dead. Needless to say, reports of his death described him as an "etiquette guru". The day is coming when designations like this will be carved upon gravestones. True gurus are few and far between, and the term should be used only sparingly.

While I'm on this tack, could we please also have a break from the overuse of the pretty word "litany" (what a lovely name for a girl: were I not too old to have further daughters I would name my next one Litany.) This has now become merely a show-off way of indicating a list, as in the Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy's condemnation of William Hague: "Look at the litany of things he is coming up with." I would like to see the word litany reserved for solemn occasions only, of which this is not one. I fear the same may soon happen to "threnody", one of the loveliest words in the language, and a dishy name for a daughter too. To those who aren't quite sure what it means, Smallweed has this to say: I weep for you. And I'm not going to tell you, in case you start using it too.

Concerned: (Weston-super-Mare) writes Why do you never mention the Marquis of Vauvenargues any more?

Smallweed replies with kindly courtesy: I am frequently asked this question. I suppose it's because he is not very active nowadays, having died in 1747. Yet I venerate his memory. He would certainly never have used a term like "etiquette guru".

fields.headline: Wrong numbers
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... urgency, accuracy and corrections
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... urgency, accuracy and corrections
fields.body:
A team of consultants has been examining the internal workings of the Guardian and management throughout the company and has suggested many ways in which things could be improved, with a number of recommendations specifically relating to standards of accuracy. We shall see whether any system can be introduced which succeeds in reducing the need to run so many corrections, something which the exposure of error over a period of more than two and a half years, has failed to do. The situation might be summed up unkindly in a riddle. What runs daily without losing weight? The Guardian's corrections column.

It would be unrealistic to suppose that mistakes in any newspaper could be completely avoided or eradicated. Urgency will always be the enemy of accuracy. We might agree, though, that at present the paper is farther from anything we could accept as the irreducible minimum of mistakes than it should be. The corrections column gives only an indication of the position. Since it began in November 1997, it has run in an unchanging ratio of roughly one entry in the column to every five calls from readers - many of the calls pointing out the same thing, and more than a few suggesting an error where there was none.

Readers occasionally complain that a weakness of the corrections column is that it does not name names. They suggest that a policy of naming and shaming might encourage greater zeal in the pursuit of accuracy. In fact, journalists are named in the corrections column on only very rare occasions and that is how it will remain.

Quite recently a very senior journalist arrived at my door plucking handfuls of hair from his head and saying rather nasty things about the unknown subeditor who had changed his copy and rendered it incorrect. He had the support of another senior journalist in this and asked that the correction should make it clear that the error was introduced in the editing.

Happily I did not do that, but not so happily I went ahead with the correction which itself had to be corrected the following day because the subeditor had been right and the correspondent - our leading expert in the field in question to whom I would have turned on precisely this matter - had been wrong. (Thus I made one of my own occasional contributions to the corrections column). What I am saying is that apportioning blame is not always a simple matter, and getting it wrong makes matters worse.

Several staff journalists have suggested that I publish, if only within the paper, a league table by departments indicating where the errors are occurring. I am against that too because it would invite comparison between departments or sections that work under quite different conditions.

As it happens, though, I did roughly analyse by department the corrections that we had published in the six months from the beginning of November last year. The results were not particularly surprising. No part of the paper is immune, but then you knew that. The largest number of errors in the period I looked at came from the largest part of the paper - the main broadsheet section (excluding the sports and finance pages which were counted separately).

This does not mean that standards of accuracy are lower in the broadsheet. They are certainly not. You would have to take into account, apart from the number of words packed into those pages, the pressure of the deadlines applying to them, the number of changes made as the paper progressed through its various editions, and then perhaps, the level of scrutiny that these pages get from journalists and readers the following morning.

Some departments of the paper have already improved their systems of checking and revising. Even more will follow, we must all hope, in the light of the consultants' recommendations - one of their findings, by the way, was that some writers were not reading the corrections and clarifications column.

It is necessary to keep things in proportion. It is not complacent to remind ourselves, now and then, that the volume of corrections should be set against the huge output of words and pages every week, equivalent to something bigger than (the example I prefer) Don Quixote.

It is also a good idea to have some historical perspective. Errors have always occurred in the reproduction of texts, whether this was being done by hand, by a row of monks in a monastery, or by mechanical printing. It is the human element.

I draw your attention to the legend of St Ursula and the 11,000 Virgins, a curious number that one 19th-century authority suggested had come from a misreading of an abbreviation on medieval lists of martyrs: "XI M V" which was taken to mean 11,000 virgins, rather than the less spectacular but more plausible 11 martyred virgins.

We all make mistakes. The Guardian is trying to make fewer.

fields.headline: The last word on   compromise
fields.standfirst: Every human benefit, every virtue and every prudent act, is founded on compromise - Burke
fields.trailText: Every human benefit, every virtue and every prudent act, is founded on compromise - Burke
fields.body:
Orangemen on their marches and Israeli parliamentarians afraid that Ehud Barak will concede too much to Palestinians at Camp David this week prompt reflection on the nature and place of compromise in human affairs. In particular, they remind us of a familiar but profound fact that explains the vexed character of moral debate: there are almost always at least two diametrically different ways of seeing the same thing, depending on the point of view.

Thus the inability or unwillingness to compromise is intransigence or steadfastness, according to which end of the moral telescope you look through. An Orangeman will appeal to his principles, his traditions, his rights and the threats to all three in justifying what to outsiders seems his obduracy, his pig-headedness and his prejudices.

Moral skill is the ability to distinguish which is which. The risks of failing to compromise in any matter, great or small, scarcely need mention. An Italian proverb points out that it is preferable to lose the saddle than the horse, and Nikita Khrushchev, on whom the lessons of daily Soviet life were never wasted, famously remarked that "if you cannot catch a bird of paradise, better take a wet hen".

These wise acceptances mark the limit of compromise, which at its best should be satisfying to both parties, giving each the pleasure of believing that he has got more than he ought to have, while being deprived of nothing that is justly his own. The good negotiator aims to send both parties away believing that they have achieved this outcome by their own cleverness.

Whether compromise is appropriate is entirely a matter of what is at stake. Between nations and states accommodation is rarely impossible, and it is almost always better than tariff war or shooting war. But the liberal democracies were right not to compromise with Hitler, and it is a tragedy that they now too often compromise with tyrants morally indistinguishable from Hitler.

In many cases it is not difficult to decide whether to compromise, and the truth is that western governments do it too often, always with the aim of saving money and trouble at home, no matter how much cost in human agony is exacted abroad. And when difficult cases come, it is the mark of a mature political comity that it makes no compromises over the task of judging, nor over acting with resolve if required.

In private life, compromise is both a saviour and the destroyer. Obviously enough, no one can sustain a relationship without accommodating the other's character and some at least of his or her needs and ways. It means negotiation, always in the hope of constructive and mutually satisfactory adjustment. But the truism that people change over time is so often forgotten in relationships that failure, if it happens, comes as a surprise to the parties, who have missed their opportunities to renegotiate the old contract when new compromises were needed.

At the same time, too many relationships are premised on large compromises made by just one party. Traditionally it was women who made them, giving up whole-life possibilities to care for small children or elderly parents. Often the compromise concerns disparities in sexual interest, one party having to suffocate needs because the other fails to satisfy them - or to express them in such socially disapproved ways as adultery or resort to prostitutes, each itself a compromise that history and society have together reached as a way of containing the volcanic power of sex.

Most insidious of all is the compromise an individual makes with himself when ambitions begin to falter, and he begins to "accept his limitations" - a phrase that far more often denotes retreat and weariness in the face of failure than a just discernment of powers. Unamuno said that we are all potentially heroes and geniuses, if only we would have the courage and do the hard work necessary to becoming so. Perhaps - here finding the exception to Burke's rule - the one compromise we should never make is with life.

fields.headline: Sweet and very low down
fields.standfirst: Mel Steel  has all her bass instincts satisfied by the return of Me'shell Ndegéocello
fields.trailText: Mel Steel has all her bass instincts satisfied by the return of Me'shell Ndegéocello
fields.body:
Me'shell Ndegéocello isn't interested in formalities, introductions, or playing up to anyone's expectations. She walks on stage at London's Shepherd's Bush Empire like someone who would rather be anywhere else, and walks off it more than two hours later like a diva in absolute possession of herself, her band and her audience. "If you don't feel like fucking after hearing my music then I've done something wrong," she says. She does nothing wrong.

It's four years since Ndegéocello last performed in the UK, and even longer since the seat-wetting bass snaps and heavy vocal come-ons of her debut album, Plantation Lullabies, ensured her reputation as a heavyweight musician. The multi-layered weave of jazz, funk, rock and hip-hop laid down an irresistible backing for her radical political and sexual lyrics, and her second album, Peace Beyond Passion, got equally rave reviews.

Bitter, the new album, is a more introspective and acoustic affair, but live it's as mean and spinetingling as anything she's done. The set she plays is a mix of old and new, moving effortlessly from the restrained keyboards and plaintive lyrics of Outside Your Door to the heavy bass and heavier lyrics of Deuteronomy: Niggerman. Faithful and Loyalty sees Ndegéocello sitting back on the bass while Allen Cato's carries the groove on guitar. Elsewhere she gives up the bass entirely to young and gifted Londoner Anthony Tibb.

But two new tracks from her forthcoming album steal the show. The first, about her affair with a 17-year-old girl, is about as hot as is probably legal. The second is a searing, bass-driven polemic on the Yankee dollar and the state of the American black psyche.

There are three things you need, she says, for the perfect seduction: a fat, low-slung bass groove; some prettifyin' atmosphere; and some sweet talk. We were wickedly, deliciously seduced.
