fields.headline: Why do  I feel naked?
fields.standfirst: Jemima Stehli strips off. You take her photo.  Adrian Searle  has one question...
fields.trailText: Jemima Stehli strips off. You take her photo. Adrian Searle has one question...
fields.body:
On the walls of the Lisson Gallery's summer exhibition A Shot in the Head, which opened yesterday, are some photographs by Jemima Stehli. I am one of her subjects. For her Strip photographs, artist Stehli invited an all-male cast of critics, writers, curators and art dealers to pose for her. We posed for her, one by one, and she posed for us.

Sitting against a bright red background, with the lights full on me, I feel like a man in a Francis Bacon painting, churning on my seat. In my hand is the trigger, the cable snaking away to the camera that faces me. Also facing me, and between me and the camera, is the artist. She begins to undress. I've got 10 shots. I can fire when I like. I squeeze the bulb that drives the shutter. Everything about this situation feels loaded, and I'm extremely self-conscious. I find myself firing the camera whenever she appears awkwardly balanced - unhitching her bra, bending to take off her shoes, untangling herself from her jeans. I guess I'm trying to wrest some power from the situation, to catch her at a moment of vulnerability, to catch those moments between moments.

Some of her other sitters - her watchers, her admirers - try too hard to appear blase. Curator Matthew Higgs is expressionless, but his glasses are steaming up. Matthew Collings is all eye- popping, drop-jaw grin and uncontained body language. As much as I enjoy looking, and watching her moves, I realise she's the one in control. I take the photograph, but she's got me photographing myself, looking at her. I notice that one of my trouser legs has ridden-up, and that somehow that look of power and confidence I wanted to present (I was as careful to dress as Stehli was to undress, in my critic's black suit and Profumo-era tie) has managed to go awry. Rather more of me is exposed than I would like.

Of course the scenario was sexy. When it was over Stehli dressed again, and I found I could not, at that moment, watch her dressing, even though we know each other very well. She put the high heels back in their box. They're the ones she's used in her photographs of herself as one of Allen Jones's mannequin waitresses, kneeling to support a glass tabletop (his sculptures provoked feminist outrage at the end of the 60s) and her series of black-on-black and white-on-white still lifes of her own, fetish-dressed body, face down on the floor. One of those pictures has her naked too, except for those shoes.

We are all object and subject, watcher and watched. The role-play, and the striptease, are endless: whatever the critic's assumptions and affectations, we are at heart a voyeuristic breed. We want to see the bad thing happen as much as the good thing succeed. We think we undress our subjects with our prose, but in doing so we say more about ourselves than we know. This is as it should be.

 Jemima Stehli Strip is in A Shot in the Head at the Lisson Gallery, London NWI (020-7724 2739), till September 9.

webTitle: Fat cats and the glass struggle

fields.headline: Fat cats and the glass struggle
fields.standfirst: Sousa and politics?  Martin Kettle  is captivated by a rare US production
fields.trailText: Sousa and politics? Martin Kettle is captivated by a rare US production
fields.body:
Few people probably know that John Philip Sousa, America's early 20th century "March King", was also a composer of light operas in the manner of Gilbert and Sullivan. Fewer still will have ever seen one. And before this week it was all but impossible that anyone younger than the Queen Mother could have attended a performance of Sousa's final stage work, The Glass Blowers, which was premiered in 1913 and which has not been performed anywhere for 85 years.

The challenge of resuscitating Sousa's period piece is the kind of challenge in which the Glimmerglass opera company revels. Throughout its quarter century of existence this resourceful company has regularly tapped into a rich vein of old and new American opera, which it performs at Cooperstown in upstate New York. The latest results, unveiled at the start of this year's 25th anniversary season last week, must surely rank as one of the most successful initiatives yet at Glimmerglass.

The Glass Blowers is definitely not an undiscovered masterpiece. Musically, the material is at times astonishingly thin. It feels like almost half an hour before the score shades off into a minor key. But Sousa was a neat orchestrator, had a professional's touch for a jaunty two-step and a lilting waltz, and when it comes to a foot-tapping march he has few equals in musical history. It is no surprise that you emerge from a performance of The Glass Blowers humming the recurring march tune that the composer later adapted as From Maine to Oregon.

As Jonathan Miller showed in his ENO Mikado production, period operetta will struggle to retain a modern audience's attention for long without the intercession of a radical, confident and intelligent directorial hand. In just such a way, the saviour of The Glass Blowers is Christopher Alden, whose direction transforms Sousa's jumble of banality and bluster into one of the most undemandingly enjoyable theatrical nights imaginable.

For me, the biggest surprise was not that the piece exists at all, or that it was worth a hearing, but that it is so chock full of oddly compelling dialogue about such subjects as women's rights, the industrial class struggle and the rise of American imperialism. This is not to suggest that Sousa's tale of romantic entanglements among early 20th century New York high life is what one could call a serious work, still less a serious political work. But it is nevertheless unambiguously set in the US of robber-baron capitalists, exploited immigrant industrial workers, and the Spanish-American war of 1898. These settings help to generate some lines that you don't often get the chance of hearing in the opera house.

The workers' chorus, "My love is a blower, and he loves only me" had Glimmerglass's post-Lewinsky audience rolling in the aisles. The officer's lament over his sleeping soldiers, "I can't get 'em up in the morning" had everyone guffawing again. An aria in praise of the Red Cross, another one in favour of trade union brotherhood, and a duet about the difficulties of getting by "on 10,000 a year", mean that the reconstructed libretto of this operatic disinterment is an unusually interesting one.

Glimmerglass pulled out the stops for The Glass Blowers, with plenty of rehearsal time allowing Alden to mould a performance whose effervescent gaiety was based on strict theatrical and aesthetic discipline. In conformity with its traditions, most of the roles were taken by young singers, among whom Maria Kanyova as the feminist heiress Annabelle Vandeveer stood out, as did the Walsall-born baritone Richard Whitehouse as the Duke of Branford.

In a programme note to mark the company's 25th anniversary, company music director Stewart Robertson writes that Glimmerglass has always tried to encourage a style of singing that is "open, unmannered, bright and confident". Those qualities were also very much in evidence in the opening night performance of La Bohème, the first work ever performed at Glimmerglass in 1975, in a new production that Robertson himself conducted with great sympathy for his singers. James Robinson's new production deftly transposed the settings forward to first world war Paris. Impressively, as in the Glass Blowers, the historical awareness of the production never came between the work and the audience.

Glimmerglass has now firmly established itself in a purpose-built countryside opera theatre of an almost ideal size (it seats around 900 people). Its summer seasons focus on early opera (Handel's Acis and Galatea this year) and American works, with a core of sure-fire staples like Bohème and Salomé, all of which are mounted in new productions. With the company's former general manager Paul Kellogg now installed as head of the New York City Opera, there is a firm convention that the productions that first see the light of day in Glimmerglass will then move to Manhattan within the next year or so. So you don't have to travel to Cooperstown to see the works, but no one in their right mind would pass up the chance to do so.

 The Glimmerglass opera series runs till August 29. Details: 001 607 547 2255, www.cooperstown.net/glimmerglass

fields.headline: Parking is such sweet sorrow
fields.standfirst: Michael Billington has a few reservations about Romeo and Juliet staged in a Volvo
fields.trailText: Michael Billington has a few reservations about Romeo and Juliet staged in a Volvo
fields.body:
Michael Bogdanov once imported a sports car into Shakespeare's Veronese love tragedy, leading me to dub it the Alfa Romeo and Juliet. Brazil's Grupo Galpao go one better by making a large Volvo Estate the centrepiece of their Romeu & Julieta at Shakespeare's Globe. The vehicle doesn't go anywhere but it sets the tone for a jokey, 90-minute circus-style production that offers a violent contrast to the Globe's favoured style of doublet-and-hosed authenticity.

Imagine the rude mechanicals from A Midsummer Night's Dream staging a potted R'n'J in Portuguese and you get some idea of this production. The Volvo, whose windows wind down to reveal plush red curtains, is surrounded by stepladders. The actors sport clown make up and often progress on stilts. Everyone plays a musical instrument ranging from Romeu who accompanies himself on the accordion to the Nurse who sports a golden trumpet in the manner of Eddie Calvert. Parasols, pistols and pratfalls are also much in evidence.

It sounds very jolly, and at times it genuinely is. The Nurse honks the car horn to warn the lovers of Lady Capulet's arrival. Mercutio makes love to a female dummy. And the stilted, dying Tybalt threatens to topple into the crowd. But Grupo Galpao, a populist group whose origins lie in street theatre, never gets to grips with the tragic elements of the story. It's hard to take the tribal rivalry seriously when the actors belabour each other with wooden swords or when Mercutio does a hammed-up death exactly like Bully Bottom. And the cursory ending leaves you feeling that the lovers are the victims of bad luck rather than of destructive familial hate.

It would be silly to attack chalk for not being cheese; and I can see that in Brazil the attempt to incorporate Shakespeare into a street theatre style would have some social value. But, set down in the Globe, the production is simply visiting exotica: a colourful romp that induces a Last Night of the Proms audience reaction. On a global level, it also strikes me that the circus metaphor is in danger of becoming an exhausted cliche. In Brazil it may still have resonance. But in the west we have seen too many people, from Fellini, Brook and Anthony Newley to every avant-garde group you care to name, colonise it for it to have any residual life.

This may seem hard on this lively Brazilian troupe who put their heart and soul into the performance and who know how to adapt to the vagaries of the space. At one point, Eduardo Moreira's chunky-calved Romeu and Fernanda Vianna's gracefully balletic Julieta pause in their love-making as a helicopter whirrs overhead: a novel case of coitus interruptus. The physical skills of Grupo Galpao are also beyond doubt. But, at the end of 90 minutes, I felt I had met an endearing Brazilian troupe but learned very little new about Shakespeare's play beyond its amazing capacity for survival.

 Romeu & Julieta is at Shakespeare's Globe, London SE1 (020-7401 9919), till July 23.

On a global level, it also strikes me that the circus metaphor is in danger of becoming an exhausted cliche. In Brazil it may still have resonance. But in the west we have seen too many people, from Fellini, Brook and Anthony Newley to every avant-garde group you care to name, colonise it for it to have any residual life. This may seem hard on this lively Brazilian troupe who put their heart and soul into the performance and who know how to adapt to the vagaries of the space. At one point, Eduardo Moreira's chunky-calved Romeu and Fernanda Vianna's gracefully balletic Julieta pause in their love-making as a helicopter whirrs overhead: a novel case of coitus interruptus. The physical skills of Grupo Galpao are also beyond doubt. But, at the end of 90 minutes, I felt I had met an endearing Brazilian troupe but learned very little new about Shakespeare's play beyond its amazing capacity for survival.  Romeu & Julieta is at Shakespeare's Globe, London SE1 (020-7401 9919), till July 23.

fields.headline: Weightless in the underworld
fields.standfirst: Andrew Clements  is untouched by Per Norgard's new opera
fields.trailText: Andrew Clements is untouched by Per Norgard's new opera
fields.body:
Per Norgard's most recent theatre piece, first performed in 1996 and receiving its British premiere at London's Almeida this week, is best described as a staged song cycle. Though the music is parsed into 20 scenes, and the two protagonists, male and female, assume a range of specified roles - Wilhelm, Alice, war correspondent, soldier - the settings of poems by Apollinaire that make up the 65 minutes of Nuit des Hommes lack the characterisation, confrontation and dramatic tension of a conventional opera. Jacob Schokking's production is ingenious, but what it all adds up to is more problematic.

The "message" it intends to convey is bleak - "a vertical dive into the underworld - without a return ticket", in the composer's words - but neither the music nor the theatrical element engages sympathy or emotion. Despite two committed singers, Helge Ranning and Helene Gjerris, the audience is kept resolutely at arm's length in this exploration of love and war. Norgard's settings, underpinned by a string quartet, percussion, keyboards and electronic tape are generally declamatory and rarely lyrical, and the constant amplification of voices and instruments gives the sound an opaque, crude quality. The instruments are too often submerged.

Apollinaire's texts, with their wonderfully sensuous imagery, are sung in the original French, while flat, banal English translations are projected onto a screen behind the performers, intertwined with video images captured by cameramen at the front of the stage. The manipulation of these images is immensely skilful, and could in the right work have produced something very memorable; here, though, the musical substance is just too diffuse to give the show the weight it really needs.

 The final performance of Nuit des Hommes is at the Almeida, London N1 (020-7359 4404), tonight.

fields.headline: The guts and the glory
fields.standfirst: He was a surly, barely literate Chicago adolescent who stumbled into acting and went on to found one of the world's great ensemble theatre companies, which he is bringing to London this month. He graduated from tiny audiences to Hollywood fame but,  John O'Mahony finds, still keeps in touch with his live-performance roots

fields.body:
It is a glorious thing when Gary Sinise demonstrates the curious, tilting snarl that he affectionately calls "the sneer." First the head flicks back and the eyelids droop, an expression epitomising the concept of self-absorbed, somnolent cool. Then, as the upper lip curls, his sleek, sturdy features disintegrate into a combination of defiant faux- confidence and adolescent uncertainty.

In its tentative swagger, there are overtones of James Dean in Rebel Without A Cause and a hint of the young Paul Newman of The Hustler. For just a few moments, in a corner of the cosy Italian restaurant across the road from the Steppenwolf main auditorium in Chicago, Gary Sinise becomes what he once was: "a young punk, experimenting with all kinds of stuff, lashing out at authority".

This is precisely how drama teacher Barbara Patterson, now 70, first encountered the 16-year-old Sinise in a corridor of Highland Park high school in spring 1971: "I was going down this hallway," she recalls, "it was where some of the ne'er-do-wells hung out. Then I saw these guys, leaning against the wall, looking like gang members. We were doing the school musical and I said: 'you look like you stepped out of West Side Story'. I particularly looked at Gary, who seemed to be the leader and was sneering the hardest, and said: 'You look like you could be a Shark or a Jet. I want to see you at auditions this afternoon'."

It would prove a fateful encounter, one that would eventually become central to the mythology of one of America's greatest theatre ensemble: Chicago's Steppenwolf. Founded in a tiny church basement of his home Chicago suburb of Highland Park by Sinise and his high school friend Jeff Perry and Terry Kinney, the company had soon forged a distinctive style of performance of such physicality, intensity and emotional force that it left front-row audience members fearing for both their own and the actors' safety.

Blessed with brute talent, the company launched many outstanding screen careers, including those of John Malkovich, Joan Allen, Kevin Anderson, Laurie Metcalf (Roseanne's sister), John Mahoney (Frasier's father), and Sinise himself. Now approaching its 25th anniversary, Steppenwolf is mentioned by critics in the same breath as US legends such as the Group Theatre - from the 30s - and New York's Circle Repertory. Variety magazine calls it "the country's foremost actors' theatre". "A name synonymous with a visceral acting style full of raw passion," said Playbill magazine, "the uncompromising, in-your-face school of acting dubbed 'rock'n'roll theatre'."

The hallway confrontation between the drama teacher and the posturing youth would leave an equally profound, life-long impression on Sinise himself. An academic malcontent who left school barely able to read, he went on to become artistic director of Steppenwolf in the early 80s, initiating much that established the company nationally and internationally. Equally impressive for someone with minimal formal education, he went on to direct some of the company's most successful shows, including the 1982 production of Sam Shepard's True West which propelled John Malkovich to stardom, and the 1996 revival of Buried Child, which earned Sinise a Tony nomination. On screen, in 1992, he directed a masterly adaptation of Steinbeck's Of Mice And Men.

Only as he was approaching his forties did Sinise belatedly and remarkably - given his age - establish himself as a major movie actor, with roles in Forrest Gump (for which he received an Oscar nomination), Apollo 13, Ransom, and Mission To Mars. Along the way, he has earned the devotion of his directors: "When I worked with John Gielgud or with Richard Burton it was the same thing," says John Frankenheimer, who directed Sinise's Emmy-winning performance in the TV movie George Wallace, "his choices are 100% right. Gary Sinise is, quite simply, a great actor. If I had my way, I'd have him in all my movies."

In person, Sinise is fiercely down-to-earth and unpretentious. In his tatty jeans and scruffy baseball cap, he might slip by unnoticed were it not for that face, still unnaturally youthful at 45, classically American in its full proportions, and shot through with the naïve masculinity that has often marked out Hollywood leading men. Despite moving to Malibu in California in the late 80s, he retains every syrupy nuance of his Chicago accent - a slow methodical drawl so meticulously polite in that peculiar old-fashioned mid-western manner that you'd almost expect him to suffix every sentence with "ma'am" or "sir".

He's self-effacing: "I have simple tastes, simple desires. If you are going to try to dig out complex or contradictory strands, you're wasting your time." He still credits Barbara Patterson as the reason why all this happened and is in regular contact with his old mentor. However, as implied by his uncanny ability to play villains (Ransom, Snake Eyes) as well as all-American heroes, beneath the boyish exterior is a tension that hints at more.

"He has honesty, vulnerability and humour but a character underneath which can turn to menace quite easily," says director Ron Howard, in a comment that could apply as neatly to his character as his acting, "it's a kind of straightforward, working-class, 'feet planted on the ground' quality that at the same time says: 'you better stay out of my way'."

It is no surprise that Sinise is avidly anti-intellectual, a man who, even now, finds reading difficult: "I have friends who could start a book at six and finish it by midnight," he says, shaking his head, "I simply can't understand that. I wish I could read all those Tolstoy books and go through Joyce but I just can't. I'm still a very slow reader." At Steppenwolf, his aversion to all things literary has become something of a running gag: "We used to joke, even when Gary was artistic director," says Laurie Metcalf, "that he only ever read the plays that he was in."

Instead of any intellectual gloss, what Sinise delivers is pure passion. Even in conversation, it washes over him in great waves: "Theatre to me is for the gut, it's for the heart. That's what I get off on. I'm not a theorist. I'm not into intellectual masturbation. All I want is a simple reaction to the feeling of what is happening onstage, a visceral, gut reaction." In certain circumstances, it is easy to see how this untutored ardour might work to his disadvantage: "He bulls his way through a lot of situations and doesn't always show huge compassion for people," says Steppenwolf co-founder Terry Kinney. "If he feels something should happen, everyone else will be forced to make way."

His "spontaneity" has probably contributed to a turbulent personal life: his 19-year marriage to Steppenwolf ensemble co-member Moira Harris has endured numerous affairs and separations: "We've weathered many, many storms," Sinise says, "Many times it was questionable where we were going." But as most original Steppenwolf members will agree, it was this same ferocious zeal and sometimes blind commitment that held the troupe together when they were playing to single-figure audiences in a cramped basement: "Gary always had the strongest vision of the group," remembers Metcalf. "For some of us it was just sort of a summer fling. But for Gary it was always more than that. It was obviously what he wanted to do with his life.

"He had a whole reserve of passion stored up because he wasn't really putting it anywhere else. This gave him all the energy and fearlessness to move us ahead. " Ultimately, he forced them to believe, in what at the time must have seemed to outsiders as monumental folly or conceit, that they were a great company, and as Sinise commented at the time to his mother "some day, all the world will know".

Gary Alan Sinise was born in the quiet suburb of Blue Island, Illinois, about 20 miles south of downtown Chicago on the March 17 1955, first child of Millie (nee Alsip) and Robert L Sinise, a film editor who, early in his career, specialised in C-Grade horror flicks such as Blood Feast and Two Thousand Maniacs!. "I remember as a kid going down to the editing room," Gary says, "and my Dad would be working. I remember being five years old looking at these slasher movies of my dad, all this blood, chainsaws and screaming."

When Gary was nine, the family moved to Highland Park, the cluster of dormitory estates 30 miles north of downtown Chicago on the shores of Lake Michigan where life was for the most part "very normal and suburban", says Robert Sinise. Gary and his younger brother Randy played football. Sister Lori was a cheerleader. However, almost from the moment he began school, Gary showed, "no interest at all in academic studies", according to his mother. By the time he reached Highland Park High in 1970 he was the picture of disaffected, rebellious youth: long-haired, leather-wearing, dope-smoking and playing in grungy garage bands with names like Uproot Confusion, The Olde Molde and Dirty Brain. "I wanted to be Hendrix," he says, "I used to play guitar with my teeth."

Already written off by teachers as hopeless by the time Barbara Patterson collared him, Sinise was skipping classes and had had a brush with the law "for a pot-related offence". But then, in the great tradition of greasepaint epiphany, everything changed. After showing up at the West Side Story audition, simply out of curiosity, he landed the role of the Shark Pepe - "about two lines and a lot of strutting around". By the last night of the production, any scepticism had melted away and Sinise was hooked.

"One of the kids in the show brought him up front for the bow," says Barbara Patterson, "He was in tears. It was a moment of intense bonding for him, not just with theatre but with what he wanted to be." Equally importantly, it was at the audition that he first met Steppenwolf co-founder Jeff Perry, who was cast against him as Jet: "We were the odd couple," remembers Perry, "I was in glasses that were slightly larger than the rest of my entire head and he was in a leather vest. He was a rock star and I was what would now be considered a computer nerd. But we hit it off and soon we were inseparable."

While Perry moved on to study theatre at Illinois State University, where he met the final member of the original Steppenwolf triumvirate, Terry Kinney, Sinise stayed behind in high school, needing an extra six months to complete his diploma. On graduation in 1974, he converted a local Unitarian church into a stopgap theatre and gathered a group of high school friends to form a company, naming it after the Herman Hesse novel that happened to be lying around. Among the first Steppenwolf productions was the musical Grease, which Perry and Kinney travelled from university to see in June 1974: "They had lights made out of old coffee tins," Kinney remembers, "a makeshift lighting board and costumes out of the junkyard."

However, Sinise's acting prowess and verve was enough to convince Kinney to go ahead with a production of Tom Stoppard's Rosencrantz And Guildenstern Are Dead with Sinise and Kinney in the title roles and Perry as the Player King: "We had a wonderful time working together," says Kinney. "On the closing night we sat on a bench and said, 'we need to continue this'."

While Perry and Kinney returned to university to scout for actors, Sinise scoured Highland Park for premises, eventually settling on the Immaculate Conception Catholic School, which was prepared to let out a disused basement for the knock-down price of $1 a year. With the addition of Laurie Metcalf (then Kinney's girlfriend), Al Wilder and HE Baccus, who would become the first artistic director, company ranks soon began to grow: Joan Allen joined a year later in 1977.

John Malkovich was discovered in a production of The Man Who Came To Dinner: "It was the stupidest performance I ever saw," says Sinise. "I thought: 'we've got to get this freak into our theatre'." Malkovich's recollection is equally robust: "when they asked me, I sort of went, 'these assholes with their theatre'. I didn't really know them. And what I did know, I didn't really like. They were like the Angry Young Men, complaining about one thing or the other. And I thought, 'I'll stick this for a week, maybe for a month'. I thought that was as much as I could take. That was 25 years ago. They're still among my closest friends."

The ad-hoc company selection process also brought together Sinise with Moira Harris, whom he first saw playing Laura in Cat On A Hot Tin Roof. "It's a good way to first see your future wife," he says, "in a negligee." Though her skittish volatility couldn't be further away from his hard-headed common sense, they hit it off: "It was at some party in a friend's house after the show," she says, "I loved him because he was very quiet and sweet and shy. And of course I thought he was awfully handsome, like a young Paul Newman. And he took me home and that was it."

In the summer of 1976, this group convened in the cramped suburban basement, now equipped with 88 seats acquired in a fire sale, for the first fully-fledged Steppenwolf season, which included Ionesco's The Lesson and Leonard Malfi's Bird Bath. From the beginning, the dramas backstage were often no less heady and explosive than anything presented to the audience, with ensemble members jumping in and out of each others' beds, and meetings that became so heated that the police were sometimes called. These intense relationships would eventually lead to a clutch of weddings, including John Malkovich to Glenne Headly, Jeff Perry (after some love-triangle acrobatics) to Laurie Metcalf and, in 1981, Sinise to Moira Harris.

Onstage, this translated into a company style, which was, according to Perry, hardly subtle. While young companies on the East Coast immersed themselves in formal experimentation, Steppenwolf was placing all the emphasis on the vitality of traditional performance. Plays were chosen on the basis of the roles they offered, politics came a distant second to youthful aggression, and immediacy bordered on violence. "We didn't pull punches," says Kinney, "there was no fake hitting. We were punching each other. We were hauling on each other." Of all the ensemble members, it was Sinise's approach that most exemplified the company style: "More than any of us, he had this sheer unpredictability," says Perry, "a kind of danger that, when combined with real talent, you just can't help watching."

Very quickly, it became apparent that something sensational was taking place. The Chicago press raved. "Acting of staggering power", said the Chicago Tribune of Israel Horowitz's The Indian Wants The Bronx in 1977. It went on, "between them, Kinney, Sinise and Malkovich are giving some of the most accomplished and deeply felt performances it has been my pleasure to see on stage this year."

But despite the glowing notices and the company's growing status, the first years involved financial hardship and material struggle. It was not unusual for the actors onstage to outnumber the audience: "Sometimes, no-one would show up," says Sinise, "and we would just throw a party." Initially unpaid, he worked as a groundsman, Laurie Metcalf as a secretary, Malkovich in a stationery store, while Jeff Perry drove an ice-cream van.

Despite his devotion to the company, even Sinise found the pressure difficult to take and in 1979, he packed his bags and headed off to the West Coast, hoping to make a dent on Hollywood. "It didn't quite work out," he admits, "it was a miserable time." After a year of gruelling jobs as a soap opera extra - including a stint on Knots Landing playing a beach boy - he grabbed at the chance to return to Chicago in late 1980 as artistic director of Steppenwolf, when original member HE Baccus dropped out.

Sinise began to demand that Steppenwolf behave like a real professional theatre company, with structured meetings replacing the anarchic, uproarious, touchy-feely get-togethers of the past. He also surprised the rest of the company by making a more concerted drive towards directing. In 1982 he oversaw the production that established Steppenwolf on the US national theatre map: Sam Shepard's True West, which had been a dismal failure when premiered two years before at the New York Public Theatre.

Sinise's re-energised production in Chicago, with Malkovich as the drifter Lee and Jeff Perry as the anally retentive Austin, was an immediate smash, proclaimed by the Chicago Tribune, "a knockdown, slam-bang, all-out battle to the finish... one of the funniest, scariest evenings of theatre we're likely to see".

When the possibility of a New York transfer arose, dissent broke out in the company. Some feared it would collapse. When Sinise insisted, Perry dropped out (to be replaced in the Austin role by Sinise himself) with the rest demanding that the Steppenwolf name be removed. The premiere at the off-Broadway Cherry Lane Theatre in October 1982 was an instant sensation, trumpeted as the "New York acting debut of the decade", referring not to Sinise, or even the production, but to the performance of John Malkovich. The Village Voice reviewed only Malkovich's performance, ignoring everything else.

"It was very difficult for Gary," remembers long time Steppenwolf member Russ Smith, "You had David Bowie and Jackie Onassis knocking on the dressing room door, elbowing Gary out of the way to get to John." As the run continued, Sinise's feeling of isolation began to grow: "While I was happy things were happening for John, I was a little baffled at what was going on with me. His career was off and running. There were times when I'd go to Times Square and eat sandwiches and play Asteroids after the show and he'd go out with Antonioni or Cassavetes. I wasn't invited."

Just as the dissenters had predicted, the True West phenomenon, and Malkovich's sudden and spectacular rise was ultimately responsible for the fragmentation of a company built on a bedrock of ensemble cohesion and equality. "Opinions changed and all of a sudden everybody wanted to go to New York," Sinise remembers, "It was like an epidemic." Acclaimed New York transfers of Lanford Wilson's Balm In Gilead and Shepard's Fool For Love launched the Hollywood careers of Laurie Metcalf, who would soon appear in Desperately Seeking Susan, Glenne Headly (who would soon appear alongside husband Malkovich in Eleni) and Joan Allen.

But Sinise, who was still Steppenwolf artistic director, chose to stifle his own ambitions and make an attempt to keep the company together. At the time, his own per sonal life, in the shape of the often tumultuous relationship with his wife Moira Harris, had begun to unravel completely: "When we took True West to New York," says Harris, "We separated and dated other people. We were married but we had verbal separation agreement. Then he said: 'I don't know now - I've fallen in love with so and so'. I said 'Well okay, that's fine'. Then a week later he came back to Chicago, and we were back together again. But it went on for quite a while like that, him wanting me, me wanting him."

As in the Highland Park days, Steppenwolf, which had moved to its current Halstead Street location, offered stability and a safe haven. Perhaps smarting from the experience of being overshadowed in True West, Sinise concentrated even more on directing. In 1985, he oversaw a production of Lyle Kessler's Orphans, which would eventually transfer to the West End with Albert Finney (who won an Olivier award for the role), and in 1986 directed Tom Waits in the world premier of Frank's Wild Years, the singer/composer's two act opera.

These successes would lead to an invitation from David Puttnam, then head of Columbia Pictures, to make another assault on Hollywood, this time as a director. Sinise relinquished the artistic directorship of the theatre and relocated with Harris to where he still continues to live, in Malibu. His first, less than auspicious, script choice was Miles From Home, a rural saga about two brothers who torch their farm rather than let it be repossessed, that would eventually star Richard Gere in a plucky outcast role that might have worked if Sinise himself had played it. Despite an invitation to show the film in competition in Cannes, it garnered only tepid reviews: "Gary was quite devastated," remembers Russ Smith, "We moved on to Paris afterwards and it was impossible to shake him from his depression. It was a couple of years before he would even entertain the thought of doing another film."

Sinise retreated once again to Steppenwolf to play Tom Joad in the Tony award-winning 1990 production of Steinbeck's The Grapes Of Wrath, only reluctantly returning to Hollywood for Steinbeck's Of Mice And Men. This time everything came together. Reprising the role of George and Lenny that he and Malkovich had played at Steppenwolf 10 years earlier, and employing his father as film editor, Sinise produced what many critics regard as a miniature masterpiece. "This time, when we took it to Cannes," Sinise remembers, "we got a 15-minute standing ovation. They gave me a tape of it afterwards." But despite ecstatic reviews, marketing problems and budget constraints at Columbia meant that the film never reached its audience.

By now, however, Sinise's film acting career was taking off at last. He had already been cast as the legless Vietnam veteran Lt. Dan in Forrest Gump, for which he received an Oscar nomination, and would soon move on to Apollo 13. Then, via title roles in the TV movies George Wallace and the impressive Truman, he won big-screen leads in Ransom, Snake Eyes, and Mission To Mars. Sinise had finally crept out of the shadow of his Steppenwolf colleagues and blossomed into a Hollywood star.

With characteristic candour, he admits that some of the films he's appeared in have not quite possessed the artistic merit he once aspired to: "I'm in a certain age range and a certain look and the possibilities just keep getting nar rower and narrower," he says, "Add in the celebrity thing and that narrows the field. So I try to pick the best of what might be available to me and it doesn't necessarily mean it's going to be great."

But since success has come relatively late in life, he has been able to enjoy it without allowing fame to skew his true priorities: his family, first and foremost, which now includes Sophie, 11, McCanna, 9, and Ella, 7, and his resilient marriage to Harris, which, unlike the other Steppenwolf unions, somehow survives. And Sinise can devote himself to film work and fully enjoy the benefits of Hollywood without feeling that it defines him as an actor.

Despite Steppenwolf's loss of identity in the mid- to late-80s, it remains a sanctuary where original core members can creatively recharge and rekindle the old Steppenwolf spirit. Metcalf returns about once a year, as does John Mahoney. Malkovich's visits are a little less frequent, though he will be back later this year to direct Terry Johnson's Hysteria. And Sinise now makes appearances every two or three years, the latest being in the role of Randall McMurphy in the stage adaptation of One Flew Over The Cuckoo's nest, due at the Barbican in London later this month.

"I've never had that mainstream thing of wanting to go out on my own and be a star," he says, "My whole creative life has been nurtured by working in a group. A lot of actors are nomads, fighting to get through auditions, defending themselves when they get parts. They don't have a community where actors are respected and nurtured. I've had that here through Steppenwolf. I've always known that there was somewhere I could come back to, where I could feel at home."

 Steppenwolf's production of One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest is at the Barbican Theatre, London EC2 from July 27 to August 5. Tickets £8 to £29. Tel: 020-76388891.

However, as implied by his uncanny ability to play villains (Ransom, Snake Eyes) as well as all-American heroes, beneath the boyish exterior is a tension that hints at more. "He has honesty, vulnerability and humour but a character underneath which can turn to menace quite easily," says director Ron Howard, in a comment that could apply as neatly to his character as his acting, "it's a kind of straightforward, working-class, 'feet planted on the ground' quality that at the same time says: 'you better stay out of my way'." It is no surprise that Sinise is avidly anti-intellectual, a man who, even now, finds reading difficult: "I have friends who could start a book at six and finish it by midnight," he says, shaking his head, "I simply can't understand that. I wish I could read all those Tolstoy books and go through Joyce but I just can't. I'm still a very slow reader." At Steppenwolf, his aversion to all things literary has become something of a running gag: "We used to joke, even when Gary was artistic director," says Laurie Metcalf, "that he only ever read the plays that he was in." Instead of any intellectual gloss, what Sinise delivers is pure passion. Even in conversation, it washes over him in great waves: "Theatre to me is for the gut, it's for the heart. That's what I get off on. I'm not a theorist. I'm not into intellectual masturbation. All I want is a simple reaction to the feeling of what is happening onstage, a visceral, gut reaction." In certain circumstances, it is easy to see how this untutored ardour might work to his disadvantage: "He bulls his way through a lot of situations and doesn't always show huge compassion for people," says Steppenwolf co-founder Terry Kinney. "If he feels something should happen, everyone else will be forced to make way." His "spontaneity" has probably contributed to a turbulent personal life: his 19-year marriage to Steppenwolf ensemble co-member Moira Harris has endured numerous affairs and separations: "We've weathered many, many storms," Sinise says, "Many times it was questionable where we were going." But as most original Steppenwolf members will agree, it was this same ferocious zeal and sometimes blind commitment that held the troupe together when they were playing to single-figure audiences in a cramped basement: "Gary always had the strongest vision of the group," remembers Metcalf. "For some of us it was just sort of a summer fling. But for Gary it was always more than that. It was obviously what he wanted to do with his life. "He had a whole reserve of passion stored up because he wasn't really putting it anywhere else. This gave him all the energy and fearlessness to move us ahead. " Ultimately, he forced them to believe, in what at the time must have seemed to outsiders as monumental folly or conceit, that they were a great company, and as Sinise commented at the time to his mother "some day, all the world will know". Gary Alan Sinise was born in the quiet suburb of Blue Island, Illinois, about 20 miles south of downtown Chicago on the March 17 1955, first child of Millie (nee Alsip) and Robert L Sinise, a film editor who, early in his career, specialised in C-Grade horror flicks such as Blood Feast and Two Thousand Maniacs!. "I remember as a kid going down to the editing room," Gary says, "and my Dad would be working. I remember being five years old looking at these slasher movies of my dad, all this blood, chainsaws and screaming." When Gary was nine, the family moved to Highland Park, the cluster of dormitory estates 30 miles north of downtown Chicago on the shores of Lake Michigan where life was for the most part "very normal and suburban", says Robert Sinise. Gary and his younger brother Randy played football. Sister Lori was a cheerleader. However, almost from the moment he began school, Gary showed, "no interest at all in academic studies", according to his mother. By the time he reached Highland Park High in 1970 he was the picture of disaffected, rebellious youth: long-haired, leather-wearing, dope-smoking and playing in grungy garage bands with names like Uproot Confusion, The Olde Molde and Dirty Brain. "I wanted to be Hendrix," he says, "I used to play guitar with my teeth." Already written off by teachers as hopeless by the time Barbara Patterson collared him, Sinise was skipping classes and had had a brush with the law "for a pot-related offence". But then, in the great tradition of greasepaint epiphany, everything changed. After showing up at the West Side Story audition, simply out of curiosity, he landed the role of the Shark Pepe - "about two lines and a lot of strutting around". By the last night of the production, any scepticism had melted away and Sinise was hooked. "One of the kids in the show brought him up front for the bow," says Barbara Patterson, "He was in tears. It was a moment of intense bonding for him, not just with theatre but with what he wanted to be." Equally importantly, it was at the audition that he first met Steppenwolf co-founder Jeff Perry, who was cast against him as Jet: "We were the odd couple," remembers Perry, "I was in glasses that were slightly larger than the rest of my entire head and he was in a leather vest. He was a rock star and I was what would now be considered a computer nerd. But we hit it off and soon we were inseparable." While Perry moved on to study theatre at Illinois State University, where he met the final member of the original Steppenwolf triumvirate, Terry Kinney, Sinise stayed behind in high school, needing an extra six months to complete his diploma. On graduation in 1974, he converted a local Unitarian church into a stopgap theatre and gathered a group of high school friends to form a company, naming it after the Herman Hesse novel that happened to be lying around. Among the first Steppenwolf productions was the musical Grease, which Perry and Kinney travelled from university to see in June 1974: "They had lights made out of old coffee tins," Kinney remembers, "a makeshift lighting board and costumes out of the junkyard." However, Sinise's acting prowess and verve was enough to convince Kinney to go ahead with a production of Tom Stoppard's Rosencrantz And Guildenstern Are Dead with Sinise and Kinney in the title roles and Perry as the Player King: "We had a wonderful time working together," says Kinney. "On the closing night we sat on a bench and said, 'we need to continue this'." While Perry and Kinney returned to university to scout for actors, Sinise scoured Highland Park for premises, eventually settling on the Immaculate Conception Catholic School, which was prepared to let out a disused basement for the knock-down price of $1 a year. With the addition of Laurie Metcalf (then Kinney's girlfriend), Al Wilder and HE Baccus, who would become the first artistic director, company ranks soon began to grow: Joan Allen joined a year later in 1977. John Malkovich was discovered in a production of The Man Who Came To Dinner: "It was the stupidest performance I ever saw," says Sinise. "I thought: 'we've got to get this freak into our theatre'." Malkovich's recollection is equally robust: "when they asked me, I sort of went, 'these assholes with their theatre'. I didn't really know them. And what I did know, I didn't really like. They were like the Angry Young Men, complaining about one thing or the other. And I thought, 'I'll stick this for a week, maybe for a month'. I thought that was as much as I could take. That was 25 years ago. They're still among my closest friends." The ad-hoc company selection process also brought together Sinise with Moira Harris, whom he first saw playing Laura in Cat On A Hot Tin Roof. "It's a good way to first see your future wife," he says, "in a negligee." Though her skittish volatility couldn't be further away from his hard-headed common sense, they hit it off: "It was at some party in a friend's house after the show," she says, "I loved him because he was very quiet and sweet and shy. And of course I thought he was awfully handsome, like a young Paul Newman. And he took me home and that was it." In the summer of 1976, this group convened in the cramped suburban basement, now equipped with 88 seats acquired in a fire sale, for the first fully-fledged Steppenwolf season, which included Ionesco's The Lesson and Leonard Malfi's Bird Bath. From the beginning, the dramas backstage were often no less heady and explosive than anything presented to the audience, with ensemble members jumping in and out of each others' beds, and meetings that became so heated that the police were sometimes called. These intense relationships would eventually lead to a clutch of weddings, including John Malkovich to Glenne Headly, Jeff Perry (after some love-triangle acrobatics) to Laurie Metcalf and, in 1981, Sinise to Moira Harris. Onstage, this translated into a company style, which was, according to Perry, hardly subtle. While young companies on the East Coast immersed themselves in formal experimentation, Steppenwolf was placing all the emphasis on the vitality of traditional performance. Plays were chosen on the basis of the roles they offered, politics came a distant second to youthful aggression, and immediacy bordered on violence. "We didn't pull punches," says Kinney, "there was no fake hitting. We were punching each other. We were hauling on each other." Of all the ensemble members, it was Sinise's approach that most exemplified the company style: "More than any of us, he had this sheer unpredictability," says Perry, "a kind of danger that, when combined with real talent, you just can't help watching." Very quickly, it became apparent that something sensational was taking place. The Chicago press raved. "Acting of staggering power", said the Chicago Tribune of Israel Horowitz's The Indian Wants The Bronx in 1977. It went on, "between them, Kinney, Sinise and Malkovich are giving some of the most accomplished and deeply felt performances it has been my pleasure to see on stage this year." But despite the glowing notices and the company's growing status, the first years involved financial hardship and material struggle. It was not unusual for the actors onstage to outnumber the audience: "Sometimes, no-one would show up," says Sinise, "and we would just throw a party." Initially unpaid, he worked as a groundsman, Laurie Metcalf as a secretary, Malkovich in a stationery store, while Jeff Perry drove an ice-cream van. Despite his devotion to the company, even Sinise found the pressure difficult to take and in 1979, he packed his bags and headed off to the West Coast, hoping to make a dent on Hollywood. "It didn't quite work out," he admits, "it was a miserable time." After a year of gruelling jobs as a soap opera extra - including a stint on Knots Landing playing a beach boy - he grabbed at the chance to return to Chicago in late 1980 as artistic director of Steppenwolf, when original member HE Baccus dropped out. Sinise began to demand that Steppenwolf behave like a real professional theatre company, with structured meetings replacing the anarchic, uproarious, touchy-feely get-togethers of the past. He also surprised the rest of the company by making a more concerted drive towards directing. In 1982 he oversaw the production that established Steppenwolf on the US national theatre map: Sam Shepard's True West, which had been a dismal failure when premiered two years before at the New York Public Theatre. Sinise's re-energised production in Chicago, with Malkovich as the drifter Lee and Jeff Perry as the anally retentive Austin, was an immediate smash, proclaimed by the Chicago Tribune, "a knockdown, slam-bang, all-out battle to the finish... one of the funniest, scariest evenings of theatre we're likely to see". When the possibility of a New York transfer arose, dissent broke out in the company. Some feared it would collapse. When Sinise insisted, Perry dropped out (to be replaced in the Austin role by Sinise himself) with the rest demanding that the Steppenwolf name be removed. The premiere at the off-Broadway Cherry Lane Theatre in October 1982 was an instant sensation, trumpeted as the "New York acting debut of the decade", referring not to Sinise, or even the production, but to the performance of John Malkovich. The Village Voice reviewed only Malkovich's performance, ignoring everything else. "It was very difficult for Gary," remembers long time Steppenwolf member Russ Smith, "You had David Bowie and Jackie Onassis knocking on the dressing room door, elbowing Gary out of the way to get to John." As the run continued, Sinise's feeling of isolation began to grow: "While I was happy things were happening for John, I was a little baffled at what was going on with me. His career was off and running. There were times when I'd go to Times Square and eat sandwiches and play Asteroids after the show and he'd go out with Antonioni or Cassavetes. I wasn't invited." Just as the dissenters had predicted, the True West phenomenon, and Malkovich's sudden and spectacular rise was ultimately responsible for the fragmentation of a company built on a bedrock of ensemble cohesion and equality. "Opinions changed and all of a sudden everybody wanted to go to New York," Sinise remembers, "It was like an epidemic." Acclaimed New York transfers of Lanford Wilson's Balm In Gilead and Shepard's Fool For Love launched the Hollywood careers of Laurie Metcalf, who would soon appear in Desperately Seeking Susan, Glenne Headly (who would soon appear alongside husband Malkovich in Eleni) and Joan Allen. But Sinise, who was still Steppenwolf artistic director, chose to stifle his own ambitions and make an attempt to keep the company together. At the time, his own per sonal life, in the shape of the often tumultuous relationship with his wife Moira Harris, had begun to unravel completely: "When we took True West to New York," says Harris, "We separated and dated other people. We were married but we had verbal separation agreement. Then he said: 'I don't know now - I've fallen in love with so and so'. I said 'Well okay, that's fine'. Then a week later he came back to Chicago, and we were back together again. But it went on for quite a while like that, him wanting me, me wanting him." As in the Highland Park days, Steppenwolf, which had moved to its current Halstead Street location, offered stability and a safe haven. Perhaps smarting from the experience of being overshadowed in True West, Sinise concentrated even more on directing. In 1985, he oversaw a production of Lyle Kessler's Orphans, which would eventually transfer to the West End with Albert Finney (who won an Olivier award for the role), and in 1986 directed Tom Waits in the world premier of Frank's Wild Years, the singer/composer's two act opera. These successes would lead to an invitation from David Puttnam, then head of Columbia Pictures, to make another assault on Hollywood, this time as a director. Sinise relinquished the artistic directorship of the theatre and relocated with Harris to where he still continues to live, in Malibu. His first, less than auspicious, script choice was Miles From Home, a rural saga about two brothers who torch their farm rather than let it be repossessed, that would eventually star Richard Gere in a plucky outcast role that might have worked if Sinise himself had played it. Despite an invitation to show the film in competition in Cannes, it garnered only tepid reviews: "Gary was quite devastated," remembers Russ Smith, "We moved on to Paris afterwards and it was impossible to shake him from his depression. It was a couple of years before he would even entertain the thought of doing another film." Sinise retreated once again to Steppenwolf to play Tom Joad in the Tony award-winning 1990 production of Steinbeck's The Grapes Of Wrath, only reluctantly returning to Hollywood for Steinbeck's Of Mice And Men. This time everything came together. Reprising the role of George and Lenny that he and Malkovich had played at Steppenwolf 10 years earlier, and employing his father as film editor, Sinise produced what many critics regard as a miniature masterpiece. "This time, when we took it to Cannes," Sinise remembers, "we got a 15-minute standing ovation. They gave me a tape of it afterwards." But despite ecstatic reviews, marketing problems and budget constraints at Columbia meant that the film never reached its audience. By now, however, Sinise's film acting career was taking off at last. He had already been cast as the legless Vietnam veteran Lt. Dan in Forrest Gump, for which he received an Oscar nomination, and would soon move on to Apollo 13. Then, via title roles in the TV movies George Wallace and the impressive Truman, he won big-screen leads in Ransom, Snake Eyes, and Mission To Mars. Sinise had finally crept out of the shadow of his Steppenwolf colleagues and blossomed into a Hollywood star. With characteristic candour, he admits that some of the films he's appeared in have not quite possessed the artistic merit he once aspired to: "I'm in a certain age range and a certain look and the possibilities just keep getting nar rower and narrower," he says, "Add in the celebrity thing and that narrows the field. So I try to pick the best of what might be available to me and it doesn't necessarily mean it's going to be great." But since success has come relatively late in life, he has been able to enjoy it without allowing fame to skew his true priorities: his family, first and foremost, which now includes Sophie, 11, McCanna, 9, and Ella, 7, and his resilient marriage to Harris, which, unlike the other Steppenwolf unions, somehow survives. And Sinise can devote himself to film work and fully enjoy the benefits of Hollywood without feeling that it defines him as an actor. Despite Steppenwolf's loss of identity in the mid- to late-80s, it remains a sanctuary where original core members can creatively recharge and rekindle the old Steppenwolf spirit. Metcalf returns about once a year, as does John Mahoney. Malkovich's visits are a little less frequent, though he will be back later this year to direct Terry Johnson's Hysteria. And Sinise now makes appearances every two or three years, the latest being in the role of Randall McMurphy in the stage adaptation of One Flew Over The Cuckoo's nest, due at the Barbican in London later this month. "I've never had that mainstream thing of wanting to go out on my own and be a star," he says, "My whole creative life has been nurtured by working in a group. A lot of actors are nomads, fighting to get through auditions, defending themselves when they get parts. They don't have a community where actors are respected and nurtured. I've had that here through Steppenwolf. I've always known that there was somewhere I could come back to, where I could feel at home."  Steppenwolf's production of One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest is at the Barbican Theatre, London EC2 from July 27 to August 5. Tickets £8 to £29. Tel: 020-76388891.

fields.headline: Legends are made of this
fields.standfirst: The Kirov Opera season struck London like a great flash of lightning, says an enraptured  Tim Ashley
fields.trailText: The Kirov Opera season struck London like a great flash of lightning, says an enraptured Tim Ashley
fields.body:
Something momentous is happening at Covent Garden. I refer not to the shudder of exhausted gloom following the resignation of yet another chief executive from the Royal Opera House, but to the Kirov Opera's current residency, which has hit musical London like some great flash of lightning and left everyone shocked, shaky, elated and, above all, with their faith confirmed in the power of opera to illuminate the human condition and to transform the way we think and feel.

Audiences and critics (me included) have been roused on occasion to a state of almost hysterical rapture. In the interval of the single concert performance of Rimsky-Korsakov's the Snow Maiden, the usually sedate Floral Hall was whizzing with the kind of vibrancy that accompanies the creation of operatic mythology: "Isn't this the greatest thing you've ever heard?"

Accounts of the appearance of Callas in the 50s, or of Sutherland's first Lucia di Lammermoor involve this sort of buzz. Truly great operatic performances are things you can usually count on the fingers of one hand, and The Snow Maiden was one of them. Cast as its doomed heroine, a mythic sexual creature, part ice, part human, was Olga Trifonova. Seemingly sewn into a white satin dress, and glittering with diamante, she looked like a cross between Lolita and Marilyn Monroe, while her voice just hit you in the solar plexus - but then most of the voices that you hear at a Kirov performance hit you in the solar plexus.

Meanwhile, the accolades pour in. The few doubts raised have been minor: whether Prokofiev's Semyon Kotko was aesthetically or politically desirable; whether the old-fashioned productions of Tchaikovsky's Mazeppa and Mussorgsky's Khovanshchina really worked (Mazeppa, as far as I was concerned, proved to be an astonishingly vivid piece of theatre). No one argued that the performances were in any way faulty, with the possible exception of one singer, who may have been having an off-night in War and Peace (he was fabulous when I heard him in Semyon Kotko).

Comparisons have been drawn between the Bolshoi Ballet's epoch-making visit to London in 1956, and with the explosive impact of the Diaghilev era after the turn of the century. The latter may have been consciously inferred by the Kirov programming: we associate Diaghilev primarily with dance, as a tribute by the Kirov Ballet made clear; but until the outbreak of the first world war, he regularly presented opera performances as well, introducing Khovanshchina to western audiences as early as 1907.

The inevitable question that all this raises is why? What is it that makes the Kirov so special and has created this extraordinary impact? The Kirov phenomenon isn't new, but this is the first time we've been able to experience it on such an unprecedented scale, as an explosion of voices and orchestra in a repertoire that hasn't been explored in the west as much as it might have been. Much of the Kirov's power derives from Valery Gergiev's determination to restore the company's home, the Marlinsky Theatre in St Petersburg, to its pre-Revolutionary position as one of the world's greatest international houses.

Charismatic, energising and a notorious workaholic, he was appointed principal conductor in 1988, when the USSR was in its death throes, and immediately instigated an east-west artistic dialogue on a hitherto unprecedented scale. He promptly asked if he could borrow the Royal Opera's staging of Boris Godunov, and invited the avant-garde British producer David Freeman to direct Prokofiev's inflammatory the Fiery Angel as a co-production between the Kirov and Covent Garden. The current London season is the culmination of over a decade of effort, both on his part and that of his loyal supporters in both England and Russia.

Gergiev's achievement, however, lies not only in opening the world of Russian music and performance to the west, but in drawing on both Soviet and Imperial traditions to forge an ensemble of international stature. The Kirov is, first and foremost, a company, a group of people working together with equal commitment, a set-up far removed from the western system of jet-setting singers pitching up wherever to slot their own interpretation of a role into a new or pre-existing production. It would be wrong to assume that western opera houses don't deliver great performances (the Royal Opera's Der Rosenkavalier, for instance, was one of the outstanding achievements of last season). It's just that you don't always get the cogency of ensemble work that seems to flow from the Kirov each time you hear them.

It should also be remembered that many of the Kirov's current performers were born and brought up under the Soviet system, which, whatever its political faults, assiduously fostered musical talent in a way that western democracy never quite has done. Singers from what was once eastern Europe have testified to the encouragement they received, as well as the strenuous, knackering schedules they were often forced to adopt. Some have expressed despondency at talent going to waste in the west, where money is all, and lack of funds sometimes means that singers don't always get the musical education they require. The legacy of the Soviet system accounts, in part, for the Kirov's overwhelming line-up of great voices, the like of which you rarely hear gathered together on a single evening. It's one reason why they knock you flat, and remain one of the greatest operatic ensembles in the world.

 The final performance of War and Peace is today at 4pm. The Kirov Ballet continues in rep at the Royal Opera House, London WC2 (020-7304 4000), during August.

fields.headline: Into the ladies with Caprice
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
Being stalked is every celebrity's nightmare, but maybe now they can hit back with the latest ready-to-wear technology. This was ably demonstrated in Being Caprice (Alt-TV, C4), in which the lissome media-babe had obligingly agreed to wear a tiny hidden camera for 10 days while she went through her exhausting schedule of parties, chat shows and awards ceremonies. It only went to show that while the camera doesn't lie, its footage does exactly what it's told in the editing suite.

The film gave the illusion of intimacy, never more so than when a panicky Caprice decided she had to pee just before receiving Maxim magazine's Woman of the Year award. A voyeur's dream, surely - alone with Caprice in the ladies' loo, as she carefully spreads toilet paper on the seat before sitting on it. But anti-climax had pursued her into the cubicle. "Oh God! I can't go! I can't believe this!" wailed the international style icon, hastily re-robing and offering barely a glimpse of thigh.

On this evidence, being Caprice consists merely of one long round of drudgery as she drags herself through endless appointments and picks her way through avenues of photographers, only to return home to an empty house and a fridge containing nothing but those Muller yoghurts with lumps of fruit in them (Caprice kept spilling dollops of yoghurt down herself, but restricted herself to the prim expletive: "Shoot!"). No boyfriends. No candle-lit dinners for two. No romantic weekends pottering round the Cte d'Azur in an E-Type Jag. Just a damp couple of days at her forlorn-looking empty house in Los Angeles.

A psychiatrist might conclude that Caprice suffers from a dangerously split personality. Incontrovertibly, her whole life has been geared to turning herself into a carefully-designed and maintained fantasy object, like a computer-generated facsimile of what glamour is supposed to mean in the current media climate. And she knows it. "It's unbelievably superficial," she confessed, submitting to yet another barrage of flashguns. "It's vain. It's catty. It's bitchy. And I love it."

Not much ambiguity there, but on other occasions our heroine felt moved to complain about the press's outrageous habit of blowing stories about her out of all proportion. Imagine that! For instance, the Sun became very excited about her possible romantic liaison with Prince Andrew, prompting Caprice to turn all indignant. All she had done, she seethed, was "have dinner with a friend of mine".

When she recorded a pop single, she was disgusted by the "cynicism" that greeted it in the media. The press were sceptical about her songwriting skills. Most insulting of all: "They were comparing me to Naomi Campbell! I just thought how dare you!"

Perhaps Caprice is merely a victim of her own success. She has invented a public persona so irresistible to men's magazines, Hello! and even Playboy that there's no room for the "real " Caprice, if there ever was one. "I've been put in the spotlight in such a way where it's every single day," she lamented, as though her career had nothing to do with her and she was merely an onlooker. "It's not like I'm in the papers once a month - it's all the time." But what does she want us to do? Drool over her photographs or make her a soothing cup of tea?

Friends (C4) returned, but is having to work desperately hard to camouflage the fact that the cast's car wrecks and squabbles over money are more interesting than their show. fields.headline: Driven to distraction
fields.standfirst: 'We hear a lot about road rage, but if cars were banned the murder rate would double as the last bastion of solitude was taken away'
fields.trailText: 'We hear a lot about road rage, but if cars were banned the murder rate would double as the last bastion of solitude was taken away'.
fields.body:
By the time you read this, I will be in Torquay. Okay, as great first lines go, it's not "Last night I dreamt I went to Manderley again" or "Hale knew, before he had been in Brighton three hours, that they meant to murder him". If I'd written that I was in Montenegro, or Arizona, the phrase would have a sort of Gothic grandeur; it's the "Torquay" that robs it of its doomed glory. But sometimes doomed glory is a bore, and niceness is all you want or need.

I like everything about Torquay, and the first brilliant thing about it is the drive there from Brighton. Just as I didn't start going abroad until 1995, I didn't start being driven on motorways until a couple of years later. Just as well, really; both my husbands were blessed with short and filthy tempers, and I'm sure that any attempt at motoring would have brought our ill-starred unions to even faster and nastier ends. But then I had the good luck to take up with a young man of unparalleled patience and good humour, and we began to take motoring trips. Now I love them, with the zeal of a very late convert.

I like everything about driving: the maps, the service stations, the beautiful, long, sexy motorways, where the rushing of cars from the arterial roads makes you feel like Raquel Welch in Fantastic Voyage, all of us corpuscles streaming into the white-hot body politic of modern Britain. Motorways (cue Black Box Recorder: "The English motorway system/Is beautiful and strange") makes me feel oceanic and very loving towards mankind in a way that oceans themselves never do; all of us, rushing about our all-important business that we will one day discover wasn't important at all, moving frantically away from our deaths, we imagine, when of course every move we make, in any direction, brings us closer to them - how can you not love a crazy little species like that? We're just so cute!

On a motorway, I feel very impatient with green ideals, which would see us condemned to eke out our lives in one little patch, never pushing on here and there for fear of spoiling the ecology. It's a nice life for a tree, but no life for a human in all our restless and complex perfection.

In cars, I like to look at other people, and see them completely unselfconscious and secure as they are in no other area of life. For many people, confined by the drudgery of boring work and dull marriages, driving is the only time they are truly alone, in limbo, answerable to and belonging to no one. It is the only time they may experience anything like silence, as the demands and longer hours of being an ever-better parent and an ever-harder worker eat into our lives; the arrival of the mobile phone and its babbling captives has effectively rendered the train, once such a blessed retreat from ceaseless jabbering, into a regular little talkathon, but if it's your car you can keep your own phone turned off. We hear a lot about road rage, but I bet you anything that if cars were banned tomorrow, the murder rate would double as the last bastion of solitude was taken away from millions of over-worked, under-loved people. Road rage is not about roads at all, but about the rage in the rest of our lives; only in our cars do we feel free enough to express it.

Such is my love of motoring that, the other day, I cracked my boyfriend up - so much so that he had to pull over until he stopped laughing - by inquiring with genuine interest and excitement: "So, which is your favourite colour traffic light - red, green or the orangey one?" But I was really interested.

Growing up, ours was the only family that didn't have a car (when I typed that sentence then, look you, I accidentally typed "didn't have a care" instead, and as Freudian slips go that's a pretty good one). Instead, we went on holiday by train, and I can't help thinking this had a good deal to do with the incredible happiness of our family holidays. There can be no doubt that it is preferable to transport children in trains rather than cars; if the little darlings don't have somewhere they can stretch their legs and run about inside a vehicle, I find, their behaviour becomes so bad that it is a great temptation to let them stretch their legs and run about outside the vehicle. Like on the motorway.

Cars seem to me a very adult pleasure, like sex and drugs; and, like them, are not really appropriate for children. The sight of the modern child ferried from door to door, from home to school, day in, day out, is one of the most depressing of recent times, completely robbing children of the chance to explore and mature. Similarly, the commuter sitting in his car for two hours when a train could get him to work in 50 minutes makes no sense at all.

But though it may not be the most efficient form of transport known to man, driving can be fantastically pleasurable, something those on both sides of the current petrol price row seem to have forgotten. To the Daily Mail, the car is a grim necessity; to the government, it's an unnecessary menace. I suggest they both lighten up and sit down to watch the old English flick Genevieve together, which will surely give them a bit of perspective.

Like sex and drugs, cars are neither "good" nor "bad"; they are as merely good or bad as the people using them. At the moment, bad motorists seem to get away with far too much. The test should be made harder and the licence re-applied for every five years. If anyone is found driving under the influence of alcohol, their car keys should be taken away on the spot and never returned. If someone actually kills someone through careless driving, they should be dealt with the same as any other murderer. But most motorists are not irresponsible monsters; wincing under the accusations of spreading pollution, asthma and all manner of air-borne evil, they could actually use a little more Me time.

"Is Your Journey Really Necessary?" asked billboards beside the roads of Britain during the war and after, encouraging drivers not to waste petrol. What I'm proposing is a motoring culture in which driving is done as a pleasure, and in fact where only the unnecessary journeys are undertaken - every drive a wanted drive. We have worried ourselves out of guilt-free drinking, smoking and eating; it would be a shame if our anhedonia grew so all-consuming that the simple pleasure of driving towards somewhere nice on a sunny day with someone you love was also put beyond the pale.
