fields.body:
The boy from Transylvania never slept at night. As soon as he got to Paris, he fell in love with its low-life, its high-life, its wet and empty streets. He became a noctambulist, walking the city after dark, wandering everywhere, from Montparnasse to Montmartre. Sometimes, he took a friend: he hung around the artists' cafes with Henry Miller, and went to dance-halls on the outskirts with the writer Raymond Queneau. But mostly, he went out by himself. He became, in Miller's phrase, "the Eye of Paris", always, Miller remembered, "on the look-out, sniffing the air, rummaging around in every nook and cranny, his gaze always far away. Everything, literally everything, was of interest to him." He walked until he could smell fresh croissants in the cafes and feel the still-wet ink on the morning papers. Only then did he go to bed.

Until that moment, he had been Gyula Halász. In Paris, he was Brassaï, and although it would be years before he picked up a camera, he was to become one of the most influential photographers of the 20th century. Halász arrived from Brasso (the town from which he took his name), then part of Hungary and now in Romania, in 1924. He had studied at the Academy of Fine Arts in Budapest, and at art school in Berlin. He wanted to be a painter, was confident of his talent, and had no interest in photography. He even said he felt contempt for the newer medium, and many years later was to regret having been unmoved when he met the great photographer Eugene Atget and saw his now famous work.

He earned money by writing articles for German and Hungarian newspapers, and throughout his life he wrote with eloquence and ease. He painted the odd portrait and sketched caricatures, but it wasn't much of a living. He had to hire photographers to illustrate the articles he wrote - André Kertész was among them - and after a while he thought he'd do better financially if he took the pictures himself. But these practical concerns weren't the only things on his mind. He later spoke of his conversion to photography as if he'd been driven to it, despite himself. Really, it was his life as a nightwalker that made him want to - or need to - take up a camera. He felt he had to record his nocturnal visions in some immediate way, and from that moment Brassaï was a new man. Although he was born in Brasso in 1899, he later said that Paris, 1933, was when he had come to life, and his real date and place of birth no longer held any meaning.

Centennial celebrations, however, have taken their cue from the date on his passport. The Pompidou Centre in Paris has organised a spectacular exhibition of his work, including drawings and sculptures, which will come to London in February next year. The exhibition kicks off with some of Brassaï's portraits of artists - Picasso, Matisse, Dali, Giacometti - as if to position him among more famous men, or to situate him in a particularly creative era. Although Brassaï published a wonderful book about his relationship with Picasso, he always wrote so well that it's hard to separate the truth from the myth. How friendly was he with that group? He claimed he was never a surrealist, except in that he aimed to give the everyday a "fantastical" slant, and yet he produced 150 photographs for their magazine, Minotaure. When reading his various books, letters and diary jottings, it's worth bearing in mind the fantastical slant he may have given many things.

An anecdote from his first days in Paris offers an early warning. Desperate for money, Brassaï writes up an entirely fabricated interview with Count Kokotzoff, the former Russian prime minister. He submits it to the editorial office, which immediately syndicates it to 15 German newspapers. A week or so later, the editorial office asks for the Count's address. Brassaï panics. Not only has he never met the Count, but he doesn't actually know if he is still alive. Several Russian friends insist the Count is dead. Brassaï finds him, however, in hiding from the Bolsheviks, somewhere near the Champs Elysées. He stakes out the Count's palace. He begs him not to refute the article. It is a tribute to Brassaï's charm that the Count agrees to ignore the article, and even writes Brassaï a letter expressing the high esteem in which he now holds him.

It was a peculiar talent of his to fit in with every class of society. He became a protégé of one Madame D-B, who gave him a studio and introduced him to the rich and famous. Meanwhile, as he wandered the streets, he found that strangers "bared their souls" to him. He was a listener and a chameleon, his friends all said; he could put himself at anyone's level, he always observed and never judged. At the end of 1929 he bought his first camera, and put these skills to a new use. He began to capture what he saw. Success was almost instant.

What Brassaï saw, of course, was the Paris night. He had chosen photography, he later said, partly because it was "a medium specific to our time", but since it was also the medium of writing in light he had to make a new art form out of it by writing in darkness. In an article written in 1933, he explained how he made up his technique as he went along: how he waited four minutes or more for an exposure, how he avoided the immediate light of the lamp-posts, diffusing it behind trees or with distance, reflecting it in rainy streets, using only available light but excluding its source from the frame. It was important to him to capture that strange lighting, to seize the night as he knew it, full of unnerving shadows. His photos seem to be recording some crime, or searching for it. They are not crime scenes in the way that Weegee's are - flashgun shots of real police evidence; nor do they depict crimes in the metaphorical way Atget's were said to - portraying the sharp, unpeopled detail of a possible aftermath.

Brassaï's photos have the furtive curiosity of the stalker. They look as if they are evoking crime in the way that the photographer in Antonioni's Blow-Up innocently did: the murder must be in there somewhere, you think as you look at them: is it by the canal, next to the jail, between the glistening rails of the Gare St Lazare, or in the crowded wings of the Folies Bergère stage? "The night works by suggestion," Brassaï said, "it never fully reveals things."

He was regularly commissioned by a penny magazine called Détective. Many say it was just a job, like the articles he used to dash off for the papers, giving them titles such as Paris Dog Cemetery and How Sardines Lose Their Heads. But I think his work for Détective says a good deal about Brassaï's imagination. He once photographed a narrative series, called A Man Dies In The Street, in which he recorded a growing and diminishing crowd around a corpse, and the paramedics who take it away. He gave other photographs titles that evoked Détective's style of fiction. A group of gangsters climbing a wall is called "Pour un roman policier", which is translated in its English caption as "For a detective story", but rather than a commission it is more likely to mean "towards a detective novel": a tribute, or an offering, that might one day expand and add up to a thriller. In any case, in the work he did for that magazine, fact and fiction merged: on one occasion, a gangster came to his door and held a knife to his throat, not for having photographed him, but because the caption in the magazine had labelled him an "assassin".

How avant-garde Brassaï was can be seen from the most random-seeming historical details. For example, he was arrested three times while working because, when he told the police he was taking photos, they thought this a poor excuse - everyone knew you couldn't take photos at night; he must have been dumping a body in the canal. Though innocent on those occasions, Brassaï was guilty on others: in the 30s, taking photographs in brothels was illegal. Brothels themselves weren't illegal, but they had to have their shutters closed. And since it was assumed that the shutters would have to be opened in order to let in the light for a photograph, this odd law was established: brothels were to remain enclosed, and unrecorded. Yet some of Brassaï's most famous images were taken in brothels, or "houses of illusion", as they were called. They are artful, knowing references to the paintings of Degas (whose favourite brothel Brassaï fondly mentions), but they are also hasty, tilted snapshots, taken in the heat of a ravaging moment or in the rush of undress. In one photograph, a woman in a black camisole, silk stockings and snakeskin heels is seen from behind, washing herself in a bidet. In the corner, a man is hunched over, tying his shoe, while his braces are still undone. They have pulled the curtain tightly shut, wrapping its edge around a bathroom pipe, so intense is their need for privacy. How, then, have they been photographed? Where is Brassaï? Can we really be seeing this?

Famous as these photos now are, there is still something shocking about them: it's not their nudity, it's their very existence. They are like early fly-on-the-wall documentaries - impossible, intrusive, abrasive, riveting. Later on, it became known that the man in this photo, as in the ones of Suzy's brothel, in which the naked prostitute stands by a sink or is embraced while showing her pubis through her fringed skirt, was Brassaï's assistant. Oddly, though, this doesn't make the photographs any less voyeuristic, it just makes Brassaï more complicit. He is both an actor and a voyeur in a scene of his own construction - a revelation that has presented a problem to commentators on Brassaï's work. It is often said that his photographs have a documentary quality to them, but, as the exhibition curator Alain Sayag points out in his catalogue essay, Brassaï, on the contrary, set everything up very carefully. The punter was his assistant, and passers-by were his friends. So what was Brassaï doing? Some years later, when he had photographed Picasso's sculptures, the artist said his pictures were so "truthful" they were "like a blood sample that allows you to analyse and diagnose what I was at those moments". But on another day in Picasso's studio, as Brassaï was photographing his chair and slippers, Picasso stated that the photo would not be "a document", because Brassaï had moved his slippers. "I never place them that way," he said. No one other than Picasso, however, would know that, and the question that arises then is why Brassaï chose to compose his scenes with this documentary aesthetic.

"I invent nothing, I imagine everything," Brassaï once said, explaining that what he depicted was never false, it was just part of the way he saw the world. With this in mind, his pictures become more admirable than mere documents, and more complicated than photographs that set out to be art (such as those of Man Ray, to whom Brassaï claimed to be "diametrically opposed"). Brassaï, a Hungarian émigré in love with Paris and the varied spectacles of its night, found a way of filtering through a camera the images he had in his head. He did not just photograph what was there, he mixed what was there with his own, subjective, love-struck gaze. Late in life, Brassaï was asked why he had taken up photography, since he had held the medium in such low regard before. He replied that he needed an immediate way to record what he had seen in his "nocturnal wanderings". He had walked the streets of Paris for six years before he took a single photo and, he said, "I could no longer hold the pictures in me." It is a wonderful phrase - as if Brassaï's mind were the camera, and the technical apparatus just a necessary way of developing the latent images. He himself wrote a similar thing about Marcel Proust, imagining him to have collected snapshots throughout his life, which he remembered later: "Proust seemed to me to be a sort of photographer of mental images, with his own body as the sensitised plate." It seems logical, then - Brassaï's photographs cannot be documentary or, if they are, they're only records of the inside of his head.

Although Brassaï photographed his fancy new friends as well - their balls and their dinners, their masks and their dresses - it was the seamy side of Paris he most actively sought out. "Rightly or wrongly," he wrote, "it seemed to me then that this underground world was the least cosmopolitan, most lively, most authentic side of Paris, and that in the colourful figures who inhabited its underside there survived, from era to era, almost without change, the folklore of its most distant past." He photographed working girls in the street, he roamed the carnivalesque world of the funfair. He met Conchita the stripper ("that white negress"), and the depressed Gorilla-man with his baby son. He had his wallet stolen when he was following the gangsters in Big Albert's Gang, and didn't mind - "They got the loot, I got the pictures. It made sense. We each had a job to do."

In each of these cases, Brassaï got to know his subjects. He spoke to them for so long and with such familiarity that eventually he added to his chameleon nature a facility for a kind of anthropological ventriloquism. He wrote about them, reporting, inimitably, their thoughts and their speech. He noted of the gangsters, for example, that they had "20 expressions for love, about 30 for kissing, 10 for arousal, as many again for orgasm, more than 70 - a record! - for sex. 50 words describe the male organ, there are 15 for testicles, 20 or so for the female genitals, 20 for breasts, 20 for rear end." And he recorded that gangsters all gave themselves slang names that were words for fish ("mackerel", "herring"), while the police were named after birds ("chickens", "partridges" and, for cycling policemen, "swallows"). Hence, a gangster hide-out was an "aquarium", and prison was a "chicken coop". Brassaï even published a little book, The Story Of Marie, in which each page is a prose poem in the voice of a cleaning lady. He meant to add more, so that all of Paris could be heard to speak their mind aloud.

In a sense, though, that is what his best photographs were. His aim, he said, was to make it look as though it had been the subjects' idea, not his, to take the photos. His pictures of brothels and bars, gangsters and sculptors all seem to be taken by one of them, as if the camera itself were a part of that world, snapping in artful and sympathetic surveillance. By all sorts of ruses, Brassaï managed to get into to secret places - dodgy dancehalls and high-class opium dens - places which, as he put it, "refused to be witnessed". It was not enough to photograph canals and streets, he wanted to be indoors, to see Paris from inside out. Often he would spot an apartment at the top of a building he liked the look of, and he would wake up its shocked inhabitants, just to photograph the view. He was hardly ever refused entry, but he remembered one bitter occasion in particular. He knocks on the door of a seventh-floor attic, and a man and woman answer. They don't look directly at him, they don't turn on the light, but they ask him what he wants. "I'd like to see the view of Paris from your window," Brassaï tells them. "Go ahead, sir," the man replies, "have a look. We are not familiar with that view ourselves. We're both blind." Filled with shame, Brassaï runs away and never takes the picture. It was as if the Eye of Paris had come face to face with its own death.

The photographs he took at night made Brassaï's name. By 1933, his first book, Paris After Dark, had come out, and even before that he was so in demand it was as if, he wrote to his parents, "I were the only reporter in Paris". There was the commission to photograph Picasso's sculptures. (In Conversations With Picasso, Brassaï mentions having broken one of his sculptures while trying to photograph it. Picasso joked about this: "I told you so!" he said to a group of friends as Brassaï spilled something. "Brassaï breaks everything, knocks everything over, floods everything. Tomorrow he may start a fire here.") He met Salvador Dalí when Dalí still had a small moustache, and did some work for him. He photographed the phallic Art Nouveau swirls of the Metro and, most memorably, an orgasmic girl on a bed. Dalí incorporated this picture into a collage of his own for Minotaure, entitled The Phenomenon Of Ecstasy, in which several ecstatic female faces are overheard by a series of male ears. It was undoubtedly a reference to the notorious, banned film of the previous year, Extase, which made the future Hedy Lamarr famous. Critics have said that since the photo was Dalí's idea, Brassaï's credit is lessened, but Brassaï's remains the iconic image. Seen on its own, the photograph has a different charm - grubby and sensual, an elongated body and bare, scrunched shoulder leading to a half-open mouth. In another print, he enlarged the woman's face; it becomes a different image again: this time, the features of her face are the almost abstract subject - the slits of her closed eyes, the arched lines of her brows, the even squares of her teeth. And a small detail suddenly springs to attention: a hole in the bedcover is the same shape as her mouth, open as if ripples of ecstasy had been emitted all around her.

As a result of his surrealist connections, Brassaï did a series of portraits of artists in their studios - Maillol, Matisse, Dalí, Giacometti were all delighted with their photographs - which later became a book. But soon, perhaps as a result of his contact with these people, perhaps out of nostalgia or instinct, he began to yearn to return to "the plastic arts". He showed Picasso some of his drawings, and Picasso was so impressed he didn't understand why Brassaï had chosen to specialise in photography. "You're a born draughtsman," he told him. "Why don't you go on with it? You have a gold mine and you're working a salt mine." Brassaï defended his choice, saying that he didn't consider photography as "a second profession". But the truth was more complicated. He had been disillusioned with photography for some time.

At the end of 1937 he wrote to his parents in Brasso: "Photography is no longer a labour of love for me and I'm going to give it up as soon as possible." The battle to free himself from photography, as he put it, was ongoing. "Sometimes," he wrote in retrospect, "I was close to despair." Brassaï left Paris in 1940, along with some other friends, including Prévert. But he soon became anxious about his negatives, and returned. He wrote home asking for his mother's birth certificate, adding ominously, "it is sufficient to prove that two of one's grandparents are Aryan". But his war was, apparently, relatively uneventful. He spent time with Picasso in his studio, went back to drawing, and after the war married Gilberte Mercedes-Boyer, who had shared none of his pre-war life. He became a naturalised Frenchman, he made several small sculptures and wrote a great deal, publishing books on Henry Miller and Proust. He also accepted regular photographic assignments for Harper's Bazaar. But the fact was that after the war nothing was really the same. His photographs became more anecdotal, less timeless; destined, a cynic might say, for the picture postcard.

Brassaï had a number of projects he had been working on - a book called Intimate Paris, for example, commissioned by a newspaper proprietor who also owned a brothel and a condom factory; a book of his narrative series, such as A Man Dies In The Street and The Balloon Seller; a book of nudes, a book of cacti. But it wasn't until 1976 that his second book of night photographs was published, under the title The Secret Paris Of The 1930s. Here, he had the chance to look back, to reflect on his nocturnal wanderings and, more strikingly, to discover that much of what he had captured had already disappeared: the tram-rail polishers, the cesspit pumpers, the market workers, the rag-pickers, the tramps. Several times he makes statements of almost pitiful nostalgia: there should be museums for pavements, for example, or reservations for homeless people like those the Americans made for their Indians. This kind of comment seems so silly it is unintelligible, except as the unformulated realisation that his world was gone. The only things left were the photographs. He died in 1984, aged 84. Perhaps his pictures were always meant to be left as records for posterity. When Paris After Dark came out in 1933, one of the reviews contained a strangely prescient remark. "Photographers of 1933," it read, "you are working for the year 2000: only then will your talent be recognised."

 Brassaï: No Ordinary Eyes, is published by Thames & Hudson at £48.

But I think his work for Détective says a good deal about Brassaï's imagination. He once photographed a narrative series, called A Man Dies In The Street, in which he recorded a growing and diminishing crowd around a corpse, and the paramedics who take it away. He gave other photographs titles that evoked Détective's style of fiction. A group of gangsters climbing a wall is called "Pour un roman policier", which is translated in its English caption as "For a detective story", but rather than a commission it is more likely to mean "towards a detective novel": a tribute, or an offering, that might one day expand and add up to a thriller. In any case, in the work he did for that magazine, fact and fiction merged: on one occasion, a gangster came to his door and held a knife to his throat, not for having photographed him, but because the caption in the magazine had labelled him an "assassin". How avant-garde Brassaï was can be seen from the most random-seeming historical details. For example, he was arrested three times while working because, when he told the police he was taking photos, they thought this a poor excuse - everyone knew you couldn't take photos at night; he must have been dumping a body in the canal. Though innocent on those occasions, Brassaï was guilty on others: in the 30s, taking photographs in brothels was illegal. Brothels themselves weren't illegal, but they had to have their shutters closed. And since it was assumed that the shutters would have to be opened in order to let in the light for a photograph, this odd law was established: brothels were to remain enclosed, and unrecorded. Yet some of Brassaï's most famous images were taken in brothels, or "houses of illusion", as they were called. They are artful, knowing references to the paintings of Degas (whose favourite brothel Brassaï fondly mentions), but they are also hasty, tilted snapshots, taken in the heat of a ravaging moment or in the rush of undress. In one photograph, a woman in a black camisole, silk stockings and snakeskin heels is seen from behind, washing herself in a bidet. In the corner, a man is hunched over, tying his shoe, while his braces are still undone. They have pulled the curtain tightly shut, wrapping its edge around a bathroom pipe, so intense is their need for privacy. How, then, have they been photographed? Where is Brassaï? Can we really be seeing this? Famous as these photos now are, there is still something shocking about them: it's not their nudity, it's their very existence. They are like early fly-on-the-wall documentaries - impossible, intrusive, abrasive, riveting. Later on, it became known that the man in this photo, as in the ones of Suzy's brothel, in which the naked prostitute stands by a sink or is embraced while showing her pubis through her fringed skirt, was Brassaï's assistant. Oddly, though, this doesn't make the photographs any less voyeuristic, it just makes Brassaï more complicit. He is both an actor and a voyeur in a scene of his own construction - a revelation that has presented a problem to commentators on Brassaï's work. It is often said that his photographs have a documentary quality to them, but, as the exhibition curator Alain Sayag points out in his catalogue essay, Brassaï, on the contrary, set everything up very carefully. The punter was his assistant, and passers-by were his friends. So what was Brassaï doing? Some years later, when he had photographed Picasso's sculptures, the artist said his pictures were so "truthful" they were "like a blood sample that allows you to analyse and diagnose what I was at those moments". But on another day in Picasso's studio, as Brassaï was photographing his chair and slippers, Picasso stated that the photo would not be "a document", because Brassaï had moved his slippers. "I never place them that way," he said. No one other than Picasso, however, would know that, and the question that arises then is why Brassaï chose to compose his scenes with this documentary aesthetic. "I invent nothing, I imagine everything," Brassaï once said, explaining that what he depicted was never false, it was just part of the way he saw the world. With this in mind, his pictures become more admirable than mere documents, and more complicated than photographs that set out to be art (such as those of Man Ray, to whom Brassaï claimed to be "diametrically opposed"). Brassaï, a Hungarian émigré in love with Paris and the varied spectacles of its night, found a way of filtering through a camera the images he had in his head. He did not just photograph what was there, he mixed what was there with his own, subjective, love-struck gaze. Late in life, Brassaï was asked why he had taken up photography, since he had held the medium in such low regard before. He replied that he needed an immediate way to record what he had seen in his "nocturnal wanderings". He had walked the streets of Paris for six years before he took a single photo and, he said, "I could no longer hold the pictures in me." It is a wonderful phrase - as if Brassaï's mind were the camera, and the technical apparatus just a necessary way of developing the latent images. He himself wrote a similar thing about Marcel Proust, imagining him to have collected snapshots throughout his life, which he remembered later: "Proust seemed to me to be a sort of photographer of mental images, with his own body as the sensitised plate." It seems logical, then - Brassaï's photographs cannot be documentary or, if they are, they're only records of the inside of his head. Although Brassaï photographed his fancy new friends as well - their balls and their dinners, their masks and their dresses - it was the seamy side of Paris he most actively sought out. "Rightly or wrongly," he wrote, "it seemed to me then that this underground world was the least cosmopolitan, most lively, most authentic side of Paris, and that in the colourful figures who inhabited its underside there survived, from era to era, almost without change, the folklore of its most distant past." He photographed working girls in the street, he roamed the carnivalesque world of the funfair. He met Conchita the stripper ("that white negress"), and the depressed Gorilla-man with his baby son. He had his wallet stolen when he was following the gangsters in Big Albert's Gang, and didn't mind - "They got the loot, I got the pictures. It made sense. We each had a job to do." In each of these cases, Brassaï got to know his subjects. He spoke to them for so long and with such familiarity that eventually he added to his chameleon nature a facility for a kind of anthropological ventriloquism. He wrote about them, reporting, inimitably, their thoughts and their speech. He noted of the gangsters, for example, that they had "20 expressions for love, about 30 for kissing, 10 for arousal, as many again for orgasm, more than 70 - a record! - for sex. 50 words describe the male organ, there are 15 for testicles, 20 or so for the female genitals, 20 for breasts, 20 for rear end." And he recorded that gangsters all gave themselves slang names that were words for fish ("mackerel", "herring"), while the police were named after birds ("chickens", "partridges" and, for cycling policemen, "swallows"). Hence, a gangster hide-out was an "aquarium", and prison was a "chicken coop". Brassaï even published a little book, The Story Of Marie, in which each page is a prose poem in the voice of a cleaning lady. He meant to add more, so that all of Paris could be heard to speak their mind aloud. In a sense, though, that is what his best photographs were. His aim, he said, was to make it look as though it had been the subjects' idea, not his, to take the photos. His pictures of brothels and bars, gangsters and sculptors all seem to be taken by one of them, as if the camera itself were a part of that world, snapping in artful and sympathetic surveillance. By all sorts of ruses, Brassaï managed to get into to secret places - dodgy dancehalls and high-class opium dens - places which, as he put it, "refused to be witnessed". It was not enough to photograph canals and streets, he wanted to be indoors, to see Paris from inside out. Often he would spot an apartment at the top of a building he liked the look of, and he would wake up its shocked inhabitants, just to photograph the view. He was hardly ever refused entry, but he remembered one bitter occasion in particular. He knocks on the door of a seventh-floor attic, and a man and woman answer. They don't look directly at him, they don't turn on the light, but they ask him what he wants. "I'd like to see the view of Paris from your window," Brassaï tells them. "Go ahead, sir," the man replies, "have a look. We are not familiar with that view ourselves. We're both blind." Filled with shame, Brassaï runs away and never takes the picture. It was as if the Eye of Paris had come face to face with its own death. The photographs he took at night made Brassaï's name. By 1933, his first book, Paris After Dark, had come out, and even before that he was so in demand it was as if, he wrote to his parents, "I were the only reporter in Paris". There was the commission to photograph Picasso's sculptures. (In Conversations With Picasso, Brassaï mentions having broken one of his sculptures while trying to photograph it. Picasso joked about this: "I told you so!" he said to a group of friends as Brassaï spilled something. "Brassaï breaks everything, knocks everything over, floods everything. Tomorrow he may start a fire here.") He met Salvador Dalí when Dalí still had a small moustache, and did some work for him. He photographed the phallic Art Nouveau swirls of the Metro and, most memorably, an orgasmic girl on a bed. Dalí incorporated this picture into a collage of his own for Minotaure, entitled The Phenomenon Of Ecstasy, in which several ecstatic female faces are overheard by a series of male ears. It was undoubtedly a reference to the notorious, banned film of the previous year, Extase, which made the future Hedy Lamarr famous. Critics have said that since the photo was Dalí's idea, Brassaï's credit is lessened, but Brassaï's remains the iconic image. Seen on its own, the photograph has a different charm - grubby and sensual, an elongated body and bare, scrunched shoulder leading to a half-open mouth. In another print, he enlarged the woman's face; it becomes a different image again: this time, the features of her face are the almost abstract subject - the slits of her closed eyes, the arched lines of her brows, the even squares of her teeth. And a small detail suddenly springs to attention: a hole in the bedcover is the same shape as her mouth, open as if ripples of ecstasy had been emitted all around her. As a result of his surrealist connections, Brassaï did a series of portraits of artists in their studios - Maillol, Matisse, Dalí, Giacometti were all delighted with their photographs - which later became a book. But soon, perhaps as a result of his contact with these people, perhaps out of nostalgia or instinct, he began to yearn to return to "the plastic arts". He showed Picasso some of his drawings, and Picasso was so impressed he didn't understand why Brassaï had chosen to specialise in photography. "You're a born draughtsman," he told him. "Why don't you go on with it? You have a gold mine and you're working a salt mine." Brassaï defended his choice, saying that he didn't consider photography as "a second profession". But the truth was more complicated. He had been disillusioned with photography for some time. At the end of 1937 he wrote to his parents in Brasso: "Photography is no longer a labour of love for me and I'm going to give it up as soon as possible." The battle to free himself from photography, as he put it, was ongoing. "Sometimes," he wrote in retrospect, "I was close to despair." Brassaï left Paris in 1940, along with some other friends, including Prévert. But he soon became anxious about his negatives, and returned. He wrote home asking for his mother's birth certificate, adding ominously, "it is sufficient to prove that two of one's grandparents are Aryan". But his war was, apparently, relatively uneventful. He spent time with Picasso in his studio, went back to drawing, and after the war married Gilberte Mercedes-Boyer, who had shared none of his pre-war life. He became a naturalised Frenchman, he made several small sculptures and wrote a great deal, publishing books on Henry Miller and Proust. He also accepted regular photographic assignments for Harper's Bazaar. But the fact was that after the war nothing was really the same. His photographs became more anecdotal, less timeless; destined, a cynic might say, for the picture postcard. Brassaï had a number of projects he had been working on - a book called Intimate Paris, for example, commissioned by a newspaper proprietor who also owned a brothel and a condom factory; a book of his narrative series, such as A Man Dies In The Street and The Balloon Seller; a book of nudes, a book of cacti. But it wasn't until 1976 that his second book of night photographs was published, under the title The Secret Paris Of The 1930s. Here, he had the chance to look back, to reflect on his nocturnal wanderings and, more strikingly, to discover that much of what he had captured had already disappeared: the tram-rail polishers, the cesspit pumpers, the market workers, the rag-pickers, the tramps. Several times he makes statements of almost pitiful nostalgia: there should be museums for pavements, for example, or reservations for homeless people like those the Americans made for their Indians. This kind of comment seems so silly it is unintelligible, except as the unformulated realisation that his world was gone. The only things left were the photographs. He died in 1984, aged 84. "Photographers of 1933," it read, "you are working for the year 2000: only then will your talent be recognised."  Brassaï: No Ordinary Eyes, is published by Thames & Hudson at £48.

fields.headline: Campaign now for bad TV
fields.standfirst: As VS Naipaul and Doris Lessing accuse the government of dumbing down culture,  James Meek argues that the arts and literature will thrive - as long as television maintains its low standards
fields.trailText: As VS Naipaul and Doris Lessing accuse the government of dumbing down culture, James Meek argues that the arts and literature will thrive - as long as television maintains its low standards
fields.body:
Once, in the late 80s, I came across the representative of an organisation called the Campaign for Quality Television. It was at the Edinburgh Television Festival. He wore a buttoned-up blue blazer, a pink shirt with a white collar and an air of self-righteousness. I thought it was a strange idea for a campaign. I suppose what the founders meant was the Campaign for Good Television, but feared that might sound too much like television which the maximum number of people would enjoy, which is not what they meant. Perhaps a more precise name would have been the Campaign for Television for Ladies and Gentlemen of Quality.

A campaign for less bias in television, for less censorship, for more local channels, these I could understand. But a campaign for good TV implies that TV is something you cannot do without, that there is no alternative to TV, that bad TV is like bad air or foul water, a health scandal. Perhaps the logic of the campaign's founders was: people cannot be weaned off television, it is compulsive, addictive and dominant, so it is essential that what people watch is of high quality, otherwise their brains will soften. On this basis, of course, there should also be a Campaign for Quality Heroin.

If, on the other hand, you take the view that television is just another medium, competing with the printed word, cinema, recorded speech and music, video, DVD and the internet, then there is no problem to campaign against, apart from the licence fee. In the mid-70s, rock and roll was vile, bland and bloated, but no one thought of launching a Campaign for Quality Rock Music. Someone did launch punk, though.

Shortly after my encounter with the campaign, I left the country, staying abroad for most of the 90s. As I prepared to return, I began to fret about those campaigners. What if, against all the odds, they had succeeded? What if all four terrestrial channels - five, even, for there was rumoured to be a new fifth channel up and running in Britain - just oozed quality from morning till the small hours? If, instead of masterpieces like I, Claudius or Twin Peaks or Pennies From Heaven being rare moments of brilliance in dull schedules, TV was great all the time? It was a terrifying thought. No one would read books any more. Libraries would close, as would theatres and cinemas, perhaps even restaurants. The internet would fail. As a reporter for a print/website newspaper, who tried to make time to write books and loved to read them, my livelihood would be at stake. It might be necessary to launch a Campaign for Bad Television.

There was another fear. At the time I left, public and political opinion had seemed to be moving solidly towards support for reform of the licensing laws. No more last orders, no more desperate binge drinking, no more hurrying home long before midnight. A Continental ease would smooth out the wrinkles of our tense drinking times. We too would be meeting up with friends at 11 pm, and three hours later still sipping wine in a cafe in the Hackney arrondissement amid the laughing, scooter-busy bustle of the night.

What hope would there be for reading or writing in this brave new world of quality television and Catalonian cafe hedonism? Proust would be pissed away over interminable brandies in the glamorous all-night bars of Clapton, Kafka dissolved in hours spent riveted to a small screen.

How proud I was of Britain, how ashamed of my doubts, when I returned to find that the lords of television, and the government, had risen to meet these twin challenges to literacy and culture. After all, making bad television is not as easy as it seems. It is not enough to be offensive, or cheap. These attributes can be seductive. Back in the 80s, there used to be an abysmal nighttime show called The Hitman and Her, in which Michaela Strachan and Pete Waterman would stand in a heaving nightclub in real time, surrounded by sweating bodies, mouthing inanities and occasionally interviewing the punters, yelling over the sound of the music : "So what do you like to do?" "Dancing and sex".

Could there have been anything less like quality? And yet in an after-pub state, it was dangerously easy to slump in front of. There was a compelling, voyeuristic quality to it - it was real. To be truly bad, to force the viewer to switch off and get up from the sofa, there must be a rare combination of money being thrown about, active contempt for the viewer's intelligence, false performances and terrible writing. It was when I saw the first five minutes of an episode of Babes in the Wood that I realised with what panache television had spurned the temptation to be good. Apart from the occasional renegade flash of inspiration, like Have I Got News For You, or the occasional import, like Seinfeld, Britain was safe for literature, music, cinema, theatre and non-TV current affairs.

As for the drinking - on reflection, it showed great lack of faith to think Britain was in any danger of acquiring an all-night cafe culture. It still seems peculiar to sit in the middle of Soho at 10.30 on a Sunday night, in the largest city in Europe, one which lays claim to be a centre of fashion and progressive lifestyles, only to watch the streets drain of people, the lights go out and the publicans bang the chair seats down on the table-tops. How courageous of the government to resist licensing law reform. Cynics might argue that it has nothing to do with the government, that the big companies have no wish to change the present arrangement, which allows them to sell huge quantities of booze to bingers without having to go to the massive extra expense of paying staff to work through the night, but we are not all cynics. I am sure the government's idea is that we all have time to read or write a little before we go to bed.

Not long ago a friend expounded to me on the recently-minted concept of "time bankruptcy". He himself was time bankrupt, he admitted. You are time bankrupt when the amount of things you have acquired which you have to process - mainly books and opera recordings, in his case - cannot possibly be read or listened to in the time you have left to live. Our lives are dominated by big choices between personal independence and family, but underlying that are the little daily choices of time, between TV time and reading time, between drinking time and creative time, which add up to another mighty choice. We know we should be more discriminating, but we are so weak, and the convivial warmth of the pub is so inviting, the lure of the moving pictures in the little box so fascinating.

Over the top of my computer screen as I try to concentrate on writing this, I can see a TV set in the distance, with the sound turned down. A low budget quiz show is on. Three possible answers flick up on the screen - A, Chernobyl; B, London's unlicensed hot dog stands; C, Wales. The contestants shift uneasily behind their lecterns. My mind begins to race. What question could possibly be tied to all three answers? For whole minutes, I'm drawn into a silent, non-quality TV broadcast. How much more dangerous if I could hear them and they were saying something interesting. No wonder, in the days before cable, digital and satellite, we used to repeat to each other that unknowing version of the terrible food/ small portions joke: "TV's terrible this week." "I know. And so few channels!"

Earlier this year, the government published a white paper declaring that in 2001, no ifs or buts, 24-hour drinking was on. We'll see whether it happens, and how many licensees actually take them up on it. But if, in future, we really are going to be able to spin out a bottle of claret in the bar between 11pm and 4am, all that stands between us and cultural collapse - as has long been the case in continental Europe - is rigid adherence to the principles of bad television. Rupert Murdoch is not low quality enough. One of his companies, after all, produced The Simpsons.

We need English Berlusconis, and perhaps European quotas protecting us from the best US television (often the best TV in Britain), to drive quality down to the point where people are hammering on the doors of public libraries, demanding to be allowed to borrow more books; to the point where I can sit down and actually listen to my CD of Billy Budd from beginning to end.

Campaigning for quality television is like lying in front of the fire, calling for someone to drag you away because you're too hot. The government's job is to teach people to read, write and use the tools of new technology, and to judiciously subsidise artistic endeavour. Governments do not have the power to create or destroy culture. That's the public's business, and to suggest governments or prime ministers have control of some kind of cultural joystick with which they can steer the country towards a particular cultural compass point, as Doris Lessing and VS Naipul did last week, is to misrepresent culture as a top-down thing. We do not live in a totalitarian state, so governments are not the arbiters of culture; television is not the only medium of art, entertainment and information, so we can switch it off, if we have the strength. And the worse it is, the easier.

I watch TV. I like it. Television has been a part of my life, and will remain so, until the last edition of Channel Four News is replaced with a celebrity house makeover show, the celebrities in question having had non-speaking jury member roles in Ally McBeal. But I could do without it. It is a great eater of time, and I fear it might have eaten too much already. Perhaps there is one small, legislative change the Campaign for Quality Television could campaign for. They could change their name to the Campaign for Quality Television or No Television, and argue that on all remotes, the off button should be four times the size, illuminated, and right in the middle.

They could change their name to the Campaign for Quality Television or No Television, and argue that on all remotes, the off button should be four times the size, illuminated, and right in the middle.

webTitle: Feeding Flintoff ego does a fat lot of good

fields.headline: Feeding Flintoff ego does a fat lot of good
fields.trailText: Forty-two runs biffed in a one-day game and everything is rosy again. "All right for a fat lad" was Andy Flintoff's reaction to his man-of-the-match award on Thursday. He may have had his tongue in his cheek but as he appears to have no cheekbones it's hard to tell.
fields.body:
Forty-two runs biffed in a one-day game and everything is rosy again. "All right for a fat lad" was Andy Flintoff's reaction to his man-of-the-match award on Thursday. He may have had his tongue in his cheek but as he appears to have no cheekbones it's hard to tell.

I wonder how he celebrated. Rehydration first, perhaps, followed by fruit juice, no alcohol and an evening meal of chargrilled chicken breast (skin off, of course) and steamed vegetables? Yeah, well . . .

Flintoff played the innings of an angry man at Old Trafford, which is fine. It happens. One of the most brutal cameos I have ever seen was the 79 scored by another chub, the then England captain Mike Gatting, in the Faisalabad test in 1987 - before the Shakoor Rana bombshell later in the game - as a response to his belief that his side had been cheated in the first test in Lahore.

There was an extra adrenal surge from Flintoff, no doubt, and the England management can sit back and purr in the knowledge that their strategy has worked in part. For make no mistake, the stories this week about his weight and his attitude have been a strategy to shame him into action, and if there has been backtracking in the past few days (Flintoff's ballooning to almost 18st has been the fault of the press and nothing to do with calorific intake, apparently) then trust me, the stories were leaked from an England hierarchy which was starting to despair of ever getting through to him.

But let's wait and see just how far into Flintoff's psyche they have reached. Not too deep, would be my early judgment, given some of the irrational and misplaced support he has been given, not least by the county that let him get out of condition in the first place.

He has been reported variously to have been embarrassed and angry by the criticism, which, as the object of the exercise in the first place, is good. However, some of the other reactions before and after Thursday's victory over Zimbabwe are so shortsighted as to defy belief.

Some cite Colin Milburn as a comparable case. Well, Ollie was indeed much loved, but his enormous weight handicapped his career (fact, and there is no point in saying it should not have) to the extent that he played only nine tests. He lost an eye in a car accident after a routine 20-pint drinking binge at Sywell aerodrome near Northampton (I'd seen him in action there on other occasions, so don't accuse me of exaggeration) and died of a heart attack aged 48. So scarcely a good choice of role model there.

Then there were the headlines and captions, "Flintoff answers his critics" and "Flintoff has the last laugh". Last laugh? The last laugh will come not from a merry tonk in the Manchester gloaming but from a concerned management when he is able to demonstrate the long-term commitment, in the form of a genuine and lasting lifestyle change, that they are seeking from their employee.

But in any case, let us look at some of the reasons why it is not okay, as many would seem to believe, for a professional athlete in the modern era not to explore every avenue open to him in the pursuit of excellence.

The physiology is straightforward, is it not? Excess weight produces strain on the heart and on the joints. It is indisputable, too, that the risk of exacerbating a back condition, chronic or otherwise, is increased if extra weight is carried.

Those who deny that this has a bearing on Flintoff's current condition are not speaking from a position of strength and had Mike Atherton, a martyr to his back, developed Gatting's build I bet he would not be playing cricket today.

Then the practicalities. The modern game, at both test and one-day level, is a genuinely athletic exercise. Speed off the mark is essential, for not everyone can stand at slip all day. Running between the wickets? I think that the use of the third umpire has amply demonstrated that most run-outs are close calls, a foot or so, and that more speed can accumulate runs, save wickets and win matches.

Finally, if selected, Flintoff may be required to bat for long periods in sapping heat and humidity in Pakistan and particularly Sri Lanka this winter. Lack of stamina in such conditions means lack of concentration.

Whom would you put your money on to ride out the conditions better: a 17-stone Flintoff or the wafer-thin Atherton? England cricketers need all the help they can get, so why don't we all wise up?

fields.headline: Fraud's on the cards
fields.trailText: I've always thought signatures were daft. Not the autograph book variety, but the ones you have to stick on credit or debit card receipts.
fields.body:
I've always thought signatures were daft. Not the autograph book variety, but the ones you have to stick on credit or debit card receipts.

The signature I scrawl doesn't look anything like the best handwriting effort that's on the back of the card but this is meant to be the best available proof that I am the legitimate card holder. There's no photograph, no PIN number - the only hi-tech defence between this card and a £3,000 spending spree are a couple of scribbles with a ballpoint pen.

So I'm always puzzled when people complain about the insecurity of buying goods over the internet with their credit cards. And it seems especially unreasonable when the same people are quite happy to give their details to a complete stranger on the phone. For all they know, when they're buying flights or cinema tickets, it could be the Crazy Temp from Hell on the other end of the line, about to begin a crime rampage using their credit card numbers.

But reasonable or not, online trading seems to cause anxiety among credit card holders, with an American Express survey showing that 73% of consumers have doubts about using credit cards over the internet.

"Our research shows that a significant number of people are worried about shopping online. By giving their card and other personal details to a 'faceless' retailer, they feel exposed," says head of credit cards Debra Davies.

In an attempt to assuage these fears, American Express is planning to upgrade online security with a card reader which will plug into their customers' computers. The credit card is inserted into this device, which along with a PIN number, acts as an electronic "key" that lets you use the card online.

But how great is the risk of our cards becoming the subject of a cyber-swindle?

Last year £5m was lost in online card fraud, a little over 2% of the total for plastic fraud. Although this figure might rise there has been an "over-hyping" of the risk, says Richard Tyson-Davies of the Association for Payment Clearing Services (APACS).

While we might have night mares about teenage hackers trying to intercept our card numbers as we buy our groceries over the net, Mr Tyson-Davies makes the point that there are much easier ways of getting hold of credit card details for anyone so inclined.

In fact, while much of the worry is about transmission of card details, encryption has made this the safest part of the process. The vulnerable point isn't the machines that transfer data, it's dodgy human beings at the other end you need to worry about.

Among the online card scams that have been uncovered has been a website that can randomly generate the sequences of numbers and letters of genuine credit cards - with a pornographic website having been caught using these numbers to make fraudulent charges against credit card accounts.

This was a relatively small-scale fraud, but in an attempt to prevent more serious problems with bogus charges against cards, a number of organisations, including APACS, are working on the development of digital "signatures" which will authenticate the identities of online buyers and sellers. This is being driven at first by the need to confirm exchanges between businesses, but will filter down to consumers.

The biggest growth area in credit card fraud is the practice known as "skimming", where a card used in a restaurant or in a shop is copied and a counterfeit produced using the information. This cloned card is then used to buy goods until the real cardholder gets a statement showing that they've been leading a double life.

So in an attempt to block off this path, credit companies such as Barclaycard are putting silicon chips into cards that are much more difficult for counterfeiters to copy than magnetic strips.

But for consumers who still feel jittery about online shopping, the best security isn't a piece of gadgetry but the more practical offer of purchase protection, available from most major credit cards. If goods bought online fail to arrive or are broken, the credit card will cover losses. The Office for Fair Trading recommends that online shoppers should always use credit cards because of the protection they offer.

Finally, I don't want to stoke anyone's paranoia, but one e-commerce security risk that so far I've not had explained is what happens if your whole computer gets stolen. If you use a laptop for e-shopping (or online banking) will your card and banking details still be retrievable from the computer's memory? If your laptop has become an electronic wallet, should you cancel your cards when it's stolen?

Answers on a virtual postcard.

Email: coughlan-sean@hotmail.com

webTitle: Put your affairs in the hands of the experts

fields.headline: Put your affairs in the hands of the experts
fields.standfirst:
Finding an accountant to take care of your tax affairs is not as daunting - or as expensive - as you may think. Liz Stuart has a guide for the financial novice
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Taxguard, a firm of tax experts, which this week published a survey of accountancy charges, says that 42% of people they questioned think they pay too much for their accountant, and almost half say they do not understand how their accountant calculates their bill.
fields.body:
Taxguard, a firm of tax experts, which this week published a survey of accountancy charges, says that 42% of people they questioned think they pay too much for their accountant, and almost half say they do not understand how their accountant calculates their bill.

In spite of this, the value of having an expert's assistance in what remains a complex area is obvious. You could be claiming back money spent on clothes, computers, tools and even cleaning products and haircuts.

So how do you find a good accountant? Simon Adams, 44, from Brixton, went freelance six years ago, having been a book editor for Dorling Kindersley, and now writes non-fiction children's books. He found his accountant, Nick Mason of Dunbar & Co in Lambeth, through a combination of personal recommendation and luck.

"I was going to have a mixture of fully employed and self-employed status in one tax year and I felt I needed some help with doing my returns. I was able to put my accounts together, but it was what to do with them after that which I was unsure of. I was walking along my high street and just happened upon this firm, although a friend later recommended them to me also.

"At the initial meeting the accountant explained what he would need from me. I understood everything I needed to - obviously if I had understood everything about tax I would not have been there in the first place."

He says the most useful part of the service is that the accountant predicts what his next tax bill will be, meaning he can plan his finances. He pays Dunbar & Co £423 a year including VAT, which he regards as good value, working out as it does to no more than around two days' earnings.

Christian Webb, partner in Portsmouth-based graphic design company Intuition, decided he needed an accountant when he established his business two years ago. "We are very busy and would not really have had time to do the accounts ourselves. Besides, it makes sense to leave jobs to the professionals," he says.

He heard about Taxguard by word of mouth and following an initial meeting with the company's regional manager, took them on. Intuition, which will turn over around £200,000 this financial year and employs five people, pays around £1,500 a year for Taxguard's services, which include free telephone advice at any time during the working day.

It is important to decide exactly what you will need from an accountant. If you can complete your tax return, but cannot calculate your capital gains, it makes sense to find someone who will just do the calculations for you.

Whether or not you will need to establish yourself as a limited company will depend on the nature of what you are doing. Mr Mason says: "Generally speaking, there is no reason to set up a company - this involves far more bureaucracy - unless you are going to be ordering heavily on credit, in which case you may need the limited liability status, and also the rate of tax is more beneficial, with a starting rate of just 10%.

"But if you are a journalist or an actor it will be better to operate as self-employed as it gives you much more flexibility."

If you do not have a personal recommendation, it is worth shopping around for your accountant, as with all financial services. Call three firms, explain to them precisely what you need and ask them for a quote. You may find they are reluctant to do this over the phone and so you will have to go their offices in person; some people do not charge for an initial consultation. "It should be like a beauty parade - you find out whether you really like the accountant in front of you or not," says Mason.

You should also find out what the hourly rate is and insist on a list of terms and conditions. This may all take some time, so it is worth starting your quest when there is no tax deadline looming. The Inland Revenue does not give any advice on finding an accountant, but if your area of work has a journal, specialist tax advisers - who will understand the specifics of your profession - will advertise in this.

According to Taxguard, a self-employed person who has their records in fairly good order, turning over between £30,000 and £50,000, should expect to pay around £395 plus VAT a year for an accountant, or £450 if they have their receipts stuffed into a carrier bag. If you are a one-person company with VAT registration, this figure will be closer to £650 plus VAT for the more organised client and £950 for the messy-case scenario.

For further information:
www.taxguard.com,
www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk, Dunbar & Co, tel 0207-820-0082

fields.headline: Taking your pound around
fields.standfirst:
Is it cheaper to drink port in Portugal or take a little sherry in Jerez? Liz Stuart scours Europe for the best place to park your purse
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The euro may be recovering, but the pound is still strong enough for holiday bargains to be found on the continent.
fields.body:
The euro may be recovering, but the pound is still strong enough for holiday bargains to be found on the continent.

Spain is still the number one choice for British holiday makers, according to Thomas Cook. The peseta is down 3% on the pound compared with last year, so you will effectively be saving £15 on a £500 purchase. A 24-shot camera film will cost just £1.60 in a Costa del Sol supermarket, compared with £6.25 in Cyprus, and your postcard and stamp to the UK will set you back a mere 40p, against £1 from Zante.

Greece, our second most popular holiday destination, is even more of a bargain. The pound is 8% up on summer 1999 and the drachma is 510 to the pound, depending on where you buy.

If you have a large family, then costs in a country will be as important to you as the price of the flight and accommodation. If there are four of you, the difference between the cheapest and the most expensive destinations is as much as three times. In Tenerife, which has the cheapest resorts overall for eating and drinking, a week of evening meals will cost just £200, but in Sorrento, Italy, this rises to £600.

Beware of making assumptions about what you believe to be good value or expensive countries, when it ain't necessarily so. Madeira, which conjures up images of the well-heeled residing at the stately Reid's hotel, is in fact cheaper than "bargain basement" Florida for food and drink.

Turkey may not be quite the bargain you expect. The Turkish Lira has almost halved against the pound, but any gains have largely been wiped out by high domestic inflation. A bottle of suntan lotion in Bodrum will cost the equivalent of £9, more than anywhere else in Europe, and hiring a car for a week will set you back £248.

It depends your idea of a good time, but if drink is your poison then the cheapest beers in Europe can be found in Spain, Malta and Madeira. Vinophiles should think about heading for southern Portugal; a bottle of house red costs from £2.60 in the Algarve.

If you want to do your sightseeing by hire car, a week's rental of the most basic model is just £74 in the Costa del Sol and £78 in Majorca. Madeira is cheap for petrol at 25p per litre. Remember that car hire is often cheaper if you book in advance.

If you prefer to be chauffeur driven then the best value taxis can be found in Cyprus and Tenerife, where a 5km journey costs from £2.90 and £3.20 respectively. But when in Italy... get the bus. In Sorrento the same trip will cost more than £13 by cab and petrol is an astronomical 77p a litre in Sicily.

Thomas Cook retail managing director Manny Fontenla-Novoa, says: "Our cost of living survey shows that the Mediterranean is certainly the place for a value-for-money break. Not only can you keep your family entertained very cheaply indeed, there are also some excellent last minute holiday deals around this summer, which means that holidaymakers who have not yet booked their break could make additional savings."

Be warned, however, that some holiday companies offering late booking deals have the cheek to charge a late booking fee.

Read the small print.

How foreign restaurant prices compare

What it will cost a family of four on a week's holiday to eat a three-course meal with a bottle of wine and coffee every evening:

Tenerife £199

Costa del Sol £227

Cyprus £244

Turkey £251

Majorca £270

Maderia £310

Algarve £312

Zante £337

Sicily £341

Malta £443

Florida £462

Sorrento £616

Source: Thomas Cook

Turkey may not be quite the bargain you expect. The Turkish Lira has almost halved against the pound, but any gains have largely been wiped out by high domestic inflation. A bottle of suntan lotion in Bodrum will cost the equivalent of £9, more than anywhere else in Europe, and hiring a car for a week will set you back £248. It depends your idea of a good time, but if drink is your poison then the cheapest beers in Europe can be found in Spain, Malta and Madeira. Vinophiles should think about heading for southern Portugal; a bottle of house red costs from £2.60 in the Algarve. If you want to do your sightseeing by hire car, a week's rental of the most basic model is just £74 in the Costa del Sol and £78 in Majorca. Madeira is cheap for petrol at 25p per litre. Remember that car hire is often cheaper if you book in advance. If you prefer to be chauffeur driven then the best value taxis can be found in Cyprus and Tenerife, where a 5km journey costs from £2.90 and £3.20 respectively. But when in Italy... get the bus. In Sorrento the same trip will cost more than £13 by cab and petrol is an astronomical 77p a litre in Sicily. Thomas Cook retail managing director Manny Fontenla-Novoa, says: "Our cost of living survey shows that the Mediterranean is certainly the place for a value-for-money break. Not only can you keep your family entertained very cheaply indeed, there are also some excellent last minute holiday deals around this summer, which means that holidaymakers who have not yet booked their break could make additional savings." Be warned, however, that some holiday companies offering late booking deals have the cheek to charge a late booking fee. Read the small print. How foreign restaurant prices compare What it will cost a family of four on a week's holiday to eat a three-course meal with a bottle of wine and coffee every evening: Tenerife £199 Costa del Sol £227 Cyprus £244 Turkey £251 Majorca £270 Maderia £310 Algarve £312 Zante £337 Sicily £341 Malta £443 Florida £462 Sorrento £616 Source: Thomas Cook

webTitle: Cheap insurance is just a click away

fields.headline: Cheap insurance is just a click away
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Pop into a branch of Going Places and one week's travel insurance will set you back £39.99. But pop on to the internet and you can find similar cover for under a tenner.
fields.body:
Pop into a branch of Going Places and one week's travel insurance will set you back £39.99. But pop on to the internet and you can find similar cover for under a tenner.

Unfortunately, you have to know where to go in cyberspace, and it took me an hour before I found the best quote, from online broker www.screentrade.co.uk. I started by typing in "travel insurance" at www.yahoo.co.uk, which instantly came up with 281 sites offering cover, plus its own insurance centre. The list of sites was not encouraging; none of the names were instantly recognisable, many were duplicate sites, and some seemed to have travel insurance added as an afterthought following a long list of other insurances.

A surprising number of US-based sites featured, which is largely useless for UK-based travellers looking to arrange insurance for a week in the Med this summer. Many are also no more than pages of information with a telephone number at the bottom. As most net users expect to be able to make an instant transaction online, the idea of having to go through a call centre as well seems to defeat the object.

For example, Yahoo lists PHA (www.demon.co.uk/dayco/phatrav.html), which asked me to fill in a detailed form. But rather than giving an instant quote, it said I would be contacted by telephone or email. Two hours later, I was still waiting. Instead I tried Yahoo's own insurance centre, operated by www.insure.co.uk. Again there was a lengthy form, but at least this time I obtained a quote. For a single person on a one-week holiday in Spain in August, it gave me three quotes: £13.58 via a Lloyd's syndicate, £15.80 with CGU and £16.40 from Axa.

I also asked for quotes for an individual annual insurance policy. The same three insurers came up, this time with quotes of £39, £49 and £60 respectively. All would allow me to buy online.

These quotes were certainly a lot better than the high street (and Going Places doesn't even sell an annual policy) but they turned out not to be the best.

My next move was to access one of my favourite financial sites, www.find.co.uk, which acts as a portal for a huge range of financial products. Its travel insurance centre lists 67 UK travel insurers, with a quick description so that you know if you're going to a broker or a direct seller.

Sitting near the top is AA Insurance Services (www.theaa.co.uk). It had one of the most simple and user-friendly sites, but its quotes failed to live up to expectations. It offered me one-week cover at £21.08 and an annual policy at £89.85.

www.columbusdirect.co.uk, probably the best-known cheap travel insurer, was another easy-to-use site and it offered lower quotes than the AA. It would cover me for a week for £17 and £59 for an annual policy - although it was still not the best. Unfortunately another cheapie, www.journeywise.co.uk, had a glitch on its system which stopped me obtaining a quote.

Next I tried www.screentrade.co.uk, which promises that it will offer the cheapest quote, or refund the difference between its quote and any cheaper one you obtain. It lived up to its promise.

Screentrade asks for more information, but uses your postcode so that you don't have to type out your address. It's also a broker, so it gives you a range of quotes and, just as importantly, displays very clearly each policy's level of cover and exclusions.

For one week in Spain, it offered me a policy from Direct Travel at £9.50, but also displayed four other slightly more expensive quotes which offered higher levels of cover. For example, Direct Travel's £9.50 policy gives you £5m in medical expenses cover, while for £15 you can have Primary Direct's policy, which pays out up to £10m.

The big savings come if you buy an annual policy. Screentrade found an annual policy, Europe only, for £33 with Direct Travel, or £45 for worldwide. Next was Primary Direct, with its £63 worldwide policy, again offering twice as much medical expenses cover.

Remember, travel agents are now banned from forcing you to buy their insurance, despite giving you the impression that special deals are only available if you do. A few minutes on the net can find you a deal at a fraction of the cost of the agents' cover.

webTitle: Get the most for your sterling

fields.headline: Get the most for your sterling
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The beleaguered Euro has been picking up against the pound recently, but holidaymakers need not despair - you will still get more for your sterling than you did last summer.
fields.body:
The beleaguered Euro has been picking up against the pound recently, but holidaymakers need not despair - you will still get more for your sterling than you did last summer.

In Turkey you could, in theory, get 42% more for your money because the lira has crashed since last summer. In practice, price inflation will cancel out much of the extra lira you get for your pounds, but it's still good value.

In Greece, which, like the UK, is not a member of the euro, the drachma has fallen 8% since last summer. This means that, on a purchase of £500, you will get an extra £40 worth of local currency.

The difference is less attractive in the Euro-land countries of France, Italy, Spain and Portugal. Since last summer, the euro has devalued by 3% against the pound, so £500 will now buy you £515 worth of goods. Of course, the cost of living is much lower in the rest of Europe, so you will be able to make the extra £15 stretch a lot further. A bottle of wine can be bought for less than £3 in some sunny spots.

One of the few places where you will pay more than last year is America. The pound has fallen 2% against the dollar, so you'll now get $730 for £500, instead of the $745 you would have got last year - a difference of about £10.

And Thomas Cook suggests you take some holiday items with you, such as suntan lotion: in Turkey, one bottle can set you back £9.

fields.headline: Empty lives, full of noise
fields.trailText: I'll Go On Barbican Pit, London ****
fields.body:
I'll Go On Barbican Pit, London ****

"My life - a joke that still goes on." So speaks Molloy in Samuel Beckett's novel, the first of the agonising post- war trilogy of being and nothingness that spans Mol loy, Malone and The Unnamable. These are works that read more like the longest suicide note in history than novels. Only there is no body. Out of the ashes of these books was born the consummate artist who wrote Godot, Happy Days and Krapp.

Beckett notoriously disliked seeing his work adapted from one medium to another, but it was wise of adaptors Gerry Dukes and Barry McGovern to ignore this. Their expert filleting of Beckett's "wordy gurdy" down to a manageable 75 minutes is a triumph. For as the lives of the protagonists dissolve so does the narrative, until all you have are voices. A very simple, pure kind of theatre. Even purer here, because one actor, the brilliant McGovern, plays the three voices, which are also just one voice - that of the author - and many voices, all the world's Molloys, Malones, Murphys, Merciers, and Morans, who conjoin in one jabbering scream of despair.

First there is Molloy in his hated mother's room, his life a slippery confusion of hilarious narratives about crashed bicycles and dead dogs and parrots. It becomes increasingly clear that this man's identity is as doubtful as his stories. There are no certainties here, only a dissolution. An inevitable melting into a state worse than amnesia, a sense of someone we sighted long ago and had forgotten. Perhaps a glimpse of ourselves as we pass the mirror.

Things get worse with Malone, a man who tells jaunty stories while he waits to die - already, in McGovern's desperate, astonishing performance, an effigy on his own tomb. This is the reduction of the world to eating and excreting while you wait for the final oblivion.

But there is no end. The Unnamable brings us someone, now utterly unidentifiable, in purgatory, forced in mounting panic to speak. A frenzy of words like a terrible storm that obliterates him entirely, words like bullets that cut him down. It is this voice, so insistent, so unstoppable that it follows you in the silence as you leave the theatre. All the way home. All night it whispers insistently in my ear: my life - a joke that still goes on and on and on.

Until July 29. Box office: 020-7638 8891.

fields.headline: Slim presence
fields.trailText: Aimee Mann Shepherds Bush Empire, London ***
fields.body:
Aimee Mann Shepherds Bush Empire, London ***

US artist Aimee Mann is in the strange position of having an Oscar nomination, for a song on the Magnolia film soundtrack, yet being without a record deal. She had two successful albums in the 90s, and recorded a third, but amid major label machinations and the pressure to come up with a hit single, she was dropped. Mann's popularity, though, is still intact. Tonight the venue is sold out and a rapt crowd listens to her every wry word.

The only problem is they also have to listen to her husband, Michael Penn, who shares the stage throughout. Brother of the famous Sean, he is a singer/songwriter of note in the US, but over here he is relatively unknown. The crowd sits patiently through his REM-meets-Phil Ochs musings, becoming more animated every time Mann takes the mike. The couple have dubbed their show "Acoustic Vaudeville"; efforts to keep things goofball also feature deadpan US comedian Patton Oswalt. "Neither of us is particularly funny or charming," says a self-deprecating Mann, "so Patton will do our banter for us." Oswalt darts on stage, grabs the mike and shouts: "Right you muthafuckers! Are you ready to rock?!!"

At which Mann, rangy in top-to-toe denim and long blonde hair, performs a number of her nasal, folky vignettes, backed by a three-piece band. On record Mann can be a prosaic experience, her songs never quite taking off, but live she is compelling. As she stands swaying with her guitar, each carefully observed line is casually brought to life, such as, "She's got the river down which I sold her," on 4th of July, or "Now you know/It's not going to stop till you wise up," on Wise Up. She plays her Oscar hit, Save Me, and is just beginning to get into her stride when Penn takes over. He warbles through five numbers and actually concludes the set.

By the second encore the crowd are bewildered and restless; it's Aimee Mann they want to see. When she asks for a request she receives a barrage of offers and is a little shaken. Somewhat reluctantly, she sings Ghost World, a strong track from her new (website-available) album Bachelor No 2. Penn sensibly retires to the wings while Mann allows her voice, vulnerable and emotive, to soar. It is a poignant moment.

fields.headline: A smoulder to cry on
fields.trailText: Fierrabras Buxton Opera House **
fields.body:
Fierrabras Buxton Opera House **

"I work on my opera and read Walter Scott!" enthused Schubert in 1823. Posterity perhaps wishes he had concentrated on one thing or the other. Scott's misty romanticism permeates every crevice of Schubert's ramshackle final opera like a case of rising damp putting paid to a flimsy structure.

It was a bad time for German opera; given the competition from Rossini, Schubert might have been better advised to stick to songs and symphonies. Fierrabras never saw the light of day in the composer's lifetime. But when you consider that Fierrabras is sandwiched between Die Schöne Müllerin and Death and the Maiden, it becomes clear that the opera was no juvenile folly, but a critical cog in Schubert's creative development.

Great swaths of the ensemble writing - ardent, optimistic and mostly dashed off in 11 days - are packed with melodic delights which bear comparison with anything from the young composer's oeuvre. Hummable it may be; sadly, intelligible it is not. Josef Kupelweiser's plot unwinds like a kitten mauling a ball of wool. Suffice to say that it takes place during Charlemagne's interminable campaigns against the Moors, and that everyone has fallen in love with someone from the other side.

But it offers a new sense of purpose to the revitalised Buxton Festival, all too often bogged down in recent years with lame retreads of 18th-century comedies. Newly-installed artistic director Aiden Lang has clearly relished the opportunity to match a quixotic curiosity with a quality cast, including Thomas Randle, Anne Dawson and Christine Bunning. None of them look entirely comfortable, however, in their medieval-spaceman cocktail outfits.

Randle is seriously short-changed in the title role: after an impassioned start, Schubert seems to have forgotten that the hero's presence would be very much enhanced if he had something to sing. No matter: Randle has smouldering stage presence, and is the only member of the cast successfully to hurdle the horrible passages of spoken dialogue. Lang helpfully translates these into basic English, but really they would have far better been left in the original gibberish.

In the pit, Lionel Friend eloquently guides the Northern Chamber Orchestra through a reminder that some occasionally inspired music suffers only in the service of some truly appalling dramaturgy. As far as a reassessment of Schubert's viability as an opera composer goes, it makes out a very good case for Rossini indeed.

In repertory until July 22. Box office: 01298 72190.
