fields.headline: Plagued by error and inefficiency
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Overcharging, poor service, incorrect billing, inaccurate estimations, aggro. These were just some of the problems which Jobs & Money readers say they have experienced at the hands of the utility companies.
fields.body:
Overcharging, poor service, incorrect billing, inaccurate estimations, aggro. These were just some of the problems which Jobs & Money readers say they have experienced at the hands of the utility companies.

Our article on switching suppliers last week prompted an unprecedented reaction from people frustrated and angered by the long-winded process; many of them have been trying to move their account for two years or more, without success. Both the former public companies and the new suppliers are guilty of error and inefficiency.

Several people complain of the time it has taken to switch. John Clarke from Cheshire swapped from BG, the erstwhile British Gas, to Manweb. His tale is a saga of delay and inaccuracy.

Mr Clarke signed a direct debit form for a combined gas and electricity deal in April 1989. By September the next year, this had still not been implemented. When finally it was, Manweb started to draw £75 a month from his account as opposed to the £60 agreed estimated meter reading. The problems were not resolved until June 2000, more than two years later.

"I estimate that the interest lost by my credit balance far exceeds the discount for direct debit payment. I await their response to my request for a refund before I will consider whether to continue with that method of payment or even whether to carry on as a Manweb customer. Have I saved money? Possibly, if I get a refund. Has it been worth the hassle? NO!" he says.

Another reader, Alan Hudson, summarises his problems: it took more than four months to change (from BG to Beacon); BG refused twice to let him switch for "inexplicable reasons" and BG gave incorrect information regarding payment. He says he even suspects the lack of co-operation on BG's behalf may be a ploy to keep customers.

Gavin Elliot also had problems with the process of the switch, also from BG to Beacon. He says: "My average quarterly bill doubled as it seems incorrect information was passed from the old to the new supplier. It took months to get the matter sorted out." The problem was resolved, but three years on, his quarterly estimated bills have again risen to exceed his historic and current usage patterns.

Other readers complain of bad service, with one part of a company seemingly ignorant of what another part has communicated. Lesley John alleges that she received "repeated unpleasant demands" for £50 from BG, with no explanation given, when she tried to switch to another supplier. After three months the company apologised, blaming a miscalculation. But still the threatening letters continued, she writes.

Richard Ehlers, a pensioner from Downham Market near Peterborough claims he was switched to the wrong supplier in the first instance. When eventually he was signed up to Northern Electric and Gas his meter reading was ignored and the supplier's own, much higher, estimation was used instead. "Northern Electric's level of communication with customers was abysmal and at no time have they offered explicit financial recompense for my inconvenience," he fumes.

Many people raised concerns and recommendations, about the sources of the electricity and gas supplied. Suggested vendors of cleaner energy are Unit(e), RSPB and, shortly, Ecotricity, which anticipates its domestic licence will be granted by the end of the summer. It supplies energy from pale green sources such as landfill sites and sewerage plants as well as deep green sources like wind power.

The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds is offering non-fossil fuels - from a mixture of hydro and solar power and organic household waste - through Scottish & Southern Energy.

"Virgin will probably get my contract because of its keenness to promote overall reductions in energy use, backed up by a cash return," says Steve Cragg by email.

Several respondents say that they cannot tell whether or not they are saving money and that they would not have switched had they known how problematic it would prove.

"Have I saved money? No idea - I can't work it out. I certainly would never again change utilities if all is running well with the existing supplier. The potential problems outweigh the modest savings by a considerable margin," says Mr Elliot.

These were just some of the problems which Jobs & Money readers say they have experienced at the hands of the utility companies. Our article on switching suppliers last week prompted an unprecedented reaction from people frustrated and angered by the long-winded process; many of them have been trying to move their account for two years or more, without success. Both the former public companies and the new suppliers are guilty of error and inefficiency. Several people complain of the time it has taken to switch. John Clarke from Cheshire swapped from BG, the erstwhile British Gas, to Manweb. His tale is a saga of delay and inaccuracy. Mr Clarke signed a direct debit form for a combined gas and electricity deal in April 1989. By September the next year, this had still not been implemented. When finally it was, Manweb started to draw £75 a month from his account as opposed to the £60 agreed estimated meter reading. The problems were not resolved until June 2000, more than two years later. "I estimate that the interest lost by my credit balance far exceeds the discount for direct debit payment. Possibly, if I get a refund. Has it been worth the hassle? NO!" he says. webTitle: Summon up the energy to make that big switch

fields.headline: Summon up the energy to make that big switch
fields.standfirst:
You can certainly save money by swapping your gas and electricity syppliers. But, as Jessica McCallin found out the hard way, it takes a lot of time and effort
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: It's the tyranny of choice. It used to be simple; electricity came from the electricity board, gas from British Gas. Now you can choose between 25 suppliers, all proclaiming how much you save by switching.
fields.body:
It's the tyranny of choice. It used to be simple; electricity came from the electricity board, gas from British Gas. Now you can choose between 25 suppliers, all proclaiming how much you save by switching.

This week Jobs & Money road-tested the suppliers and found it was true. You will save money - around 30% of your total bill if you're lucky. But the effort involved to check you've got the best deal (it will take you about seven hours in all) almost outweighs the cost saving, and at the end of it you'll be left with that uneasy feeling that you may still have got it wrong.

Choice in the gas and electricity market spells confusion rather than liberation.

I live in a south London flat, with gas from BG and electricity from London Electricity; turning the thermostat down, lagging the loft and paying by direct debit is the most I've done to cut bills. But under the onslaught of radio and TV adverts telling me to switch (and last week Richard Branson's Virgin joined the fray) I resolved to change suppliers.

The first hurdle is working out what you are paying. It took about an hour to accurately calculate how much I spend and how many units or kiloWatts per hour (kWh) I use. This is around 2500 kWh of electricity a year, at a cost of £204, and 15,000 kWh of gas, at a cost of £316.

The next step is to find the list of alternative suppliers. The Office of Gas and Electricity Markets' website (www.ofgem.org.uk) was useful, but basic - it doesn't include the different perks and packages that can make a large difference to your bill.

Price comparison websites such as www.buy.co.uk and www.blays.co.uk also failed to give this information. What's more, the utility companies regularly change their prices, and as the Ofgem site is not updated every day, the only way get the most accurate quotes was to phone each company. This took five hours.

Contacting 25 different suppliers was bad enough but comparisons were made near impossible by the variety of ways companies give quotes:

VAT. Some include it, some don't.

Staggered rates. At some you pay less the more energy you use. Others just have one standard tariff.

Standing charges. Some quote them on a daily basis, others on a quarterly basis and others on an annual basis.

Quote basis. Some give the unit prices and do a calculation for you. Others give you their prices, leaving you to calculate. Others give comparative quotes; rather than telling you their kWh price, they ask who your current supplier is then tell you how much you would save by switching.

The results? Virgin Energy came out cheapest; £182.50 for gas (a saving of £133.50), beating Eastern Energy's £183 by only a smidgen. On electricity, Virgin was cheapest by a long shot; £146.50 (a saving of £57.50), with the next best quote, £162.90, from Northern Electricity.

British Gas, Energy Supplies UK and npower were the most expensive for gas, all quoting £220. They were also among the most expensive electricity providers, charging, respectively, £193, £197 and £200.

The highest electricity charges were from "green" suppliers which use renewable sources such as wind and water, although the extra is not that much; Unit(e) quoted me £220 and Servista £213.

Perks may also be worth considering. Amerada offers air miles, while Energy Supplies UK throws in free boiler and locksmith cover. More importantly, you can check how often switching suppliers results in a complaint, by checking Ofgem's website. The two biggest gas offenders, Midlands Gas and Northern Electric and Gas were not on my shortlist. Neither were the two worst electricity offenders, Independent Energy and Yorkshire Electricity.

Although Virgin was best on price, I chose my new supplier on environmental grounds: the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds (RSPB), which has an agreement with Scottish and Southern Energy, to supply energy from renewable sources.

I will also go through RSPB for my gas. Getting gas from environmentally friendly sources is trickier than electricity, so the RSPB says it will plant trees to absorb the carbon dioxide my gas produces and fund research projects into sustainable energy instead. I worked out that I will pay about £213 a year this way.

In short, with RSPB my bill will fall from around £500 a year to around £420. Sorry, Richard Branson, you're cheaper at £330 a year, but, to be frank, I've decided instead to make my own personal contribution to cutting fossil fuel use and figure that the more people join green energy schemes, the more wind and water power we will see.

Tricks of the trade

Regulators claim that the excesses of energy sellers have been reined in. Don't believe it. Here's some doorstep tricks:

"All your neighbours have already signed up" - never true but makes you feel left out and appear inadequate.

"I'm only in this area tonight" - this implies you only have one chance to join up, which is nonsense.

Comparing apples with pears - sellers concentrate on competitors' expensive tariffs and their own cheapest.

Dual fuel confusion - having one supplier instead of two gives extra chances to bamboozle with figures.

Assuming rates will stay unchanged - prices are not fixed and your supplier might be about to cut their quotes. They won't tell you.

Claiming to have run out of explanatory material - Asking for paperwork helps delay a decision. But they always have application forms.

webTitle: Were you a victim of the dot.com bubble?

fields.headline: Were you a victim of the dot.com bubble?
fields.standfirst: Rupert Jones looks at the rise and fall of five stocks that were firm favourites with investors who rushed into this year's hi-tech buying frenzy
fields.trailText: Five months ago, the hi-tech stocks goldrush was in full frenetic swing, with private investors clambering over each other to pile money into little-known internet and technology companies, often on the basis of online bulletin board tips and outrageously optimistic predictions about prospects.
fields.body:
Five months ago, the hi-tech stocks goldrush was in full frenetic swing, with private investors clambering over each other to pile money into little-known internet and technology companies, often on the basis of online bulletin board tips and outrageously optimistic predictions about prospects.

Now, with many of these investors nursing hefty paper losses after share prices crashed in March and April, quite a few people will be wondering ruefully whether they were seduced by the shimmer of fool's gold.

Jobs & Money has looked at five stocks that were darlings of the fleeting tech stocks boom. Pacific Media, Scoot.com, Medi@Invest, Digital Animation and eVestment all featured in the top 10 most popular share purchase lists issued by stockbroker Charles Schwab during February, elbowing out the former stalwarts such as privatisation stocks. But all are now conspicuous in their absence from the latest top 10 buys list issued by Charles Schwab this week.

The five share price graphs above vividly depict the puncturing of the dot.com bubble. Looking back at the tech stocks frenzy earlier this year, Jeremy Batstone at NatWest Stockbrokers says: "People thought it was a casino where they couldn't lose."

He was completely amazed by the willingness of many individuals to part with their cash so readily. "It was very much a case of standing over a manhole and throwing money down it."

Many small investors, nursing burnt fingers, have decided to pull out of the market altogether, while others have scaled down their trading activities. The result has been a sizeable drop in stock exchange trading volumes during the last couple of months - and fewer appearances in the press by Martha Lane Fox of lastminute.com.

Figures from the London Stock Exchange show how online sharedealing rocketed last year, fueled by the launch of cheap net-based share trading services. The average number of transactions a day ballooned to 134,000 in January, hitting a peak of 157,000 a day in March. Since then, volumes have dropped dramatically, with May seeing just 104,000 transactions per day on average. Anecdotal evidence suggests June and July will show even more of a slump. On Monday, for example, fewer than 1bn shares changed hands - the sort of figure usually seen in the period between Christmas and new year.

It's a far cry from February, when the share-trading boom left some of the new sharedealing services struggling. Some, such as Halifax, were forced to close their doors temporarily to new customers, while at others, such as Charles Schwab, investors complained about hour-long waits to get through on the phone.

Although the party appears to be over, it hasn't stopped companies rushing in to join the already crowded online sharedealing market. Three weeks ago Virgin launched a service, and Egg's dealing facility goes live next week, promising "very competitive" fees. Ironically, details of Egg's sharedealing facility emerged in the week that its own share price hit a new low of 134.5p.

Financial services website Interactive Investor International, has had an even tougher time. The company listed in February and the shares soared past the 400p mark. This week they stood at 45p-46p.

It's been a similar story with our five highlighted shares:

Pacific Media. One of the most widely-held hi-tech stocks, this AIM-listed company started life running cinemas and has garnered considerable interest among investors as a result of its e-commerce dabblings. From around 1p last autumn, the share price soared to 14p in late January then slumped to around 3.5p this week.

Scoot.com. An online publishing and information company, it made the news last month by announcing it had won the backing of its French media and utilities group partner Vivendi to snap up the free advertising newspaper group Loot for £190m. After languishing below 50p, the share price started rising at the end of last year, hitting 351p on March 10 before promptly taking a dive. This week it stood at around 125p.

Digital Animation Group. A special effects and games animation company whose biggest recent claim to fame is that it developed Ananova - billed "the world's first virtual cyberchick newsreader" - for the Press Association's new media division. Earlier this month Ananova and the PA division were bought by mobile phone operator Orange for £95m. Despite this, the share this week stood at around 96p-98p, far below its early February high of 390p.

Medi@Invest. This media and internet investment company announced in May that it had acquired 33% of computer games development company Software Creations for £6.65m. The share price stood at around 7p-8p in November, topped 90p in mid-January, fell relentlessly since early February, and was back at 7p-8p on Wednesday this week.

eVestment. An AIM-traded internet incubator firm that invests in young net and e-commerce-related businesses in the UK and overseas. Its share price climbed to 44p on February 11 but was this week languishing at around 11.5p.

What should you do if you hold these shares? Alex Scott, internet analyst at Barclays Stockbrokers, says that in the case of Pacific Media, Digital Animation and eVestment, he would be "steering pretty clear".

Scoot.com is likely to continue making losses for another couple of years but at least it is managing to roll out its services and show signs of delivering on its business plan. While Mr Scott doesn't regard Scoot.com as an out-and-out "buy", he would hold on to the shares. If there are cheap buying opportunities, it might be one where you want to build up your holding.

If you bought into all these stocks last autumn, you are likely to be sitting on a gain, even after all that's happened in the last few months, says Mr Scott. As to whether you should hold or sell, it partly depends whether you can afford to hang on in the hope of a recovery that may never happen.

NatWest Stockbrokers' Mr Batstone also rates Scoot.com as a "hold," but has little time for Pacific Media, which he says "was a penny share at the best of times" and is unlikely to regain its former highs.

Were you a winner or loser in the dot.com frenzy? Email us with your experiences at jobs.and.money@guardian. co.uk

fields.headline: RSPCA slates dog fight film
fields.standfirst: A film that features dog fights is to be shown at the Edinburgh film festival, despite protests from the RSPCA.
fields.trailText: A film that features dog fights is to be shown at the Edinburgh film festival, despite protests from the RSPCA.
fields.body:
Amores Perros - Love's A Bitch - won plaudits and prizes when it was premiered at Cannes in May, and it will be screened in full at the festival next month despite it being highly unlikely to be passed by the British film censor for general showing. Mexican director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's debut has been called a "Pulp Fiction for grown-ups", weaving together three violent and tragic stories and with dogs as the common element.

The first and most powerful strand is that of an illegal dog fighting den in Mexico City in which pit bull terriers, alsatians and rottweilers fight to the death.

Jose Maria Ribo, director of the Cannes Critics' Week, where the film won the main prize, described the film as a "remarkable, important movie which should be seen despite what people think of the subject matter". He said the dogs wore special plastic muzzles during the fighting scenes that stopped their jaws snapping shut; animals that appeared to die had in fact been drugged.

Even so, the British board of film classification is unlikely to allow the film to be shown without extensive cuts, which its defenders claim would neuter its visceral power.

A spokeswoman for the board, Sue Clarke, said: "Baiting animals is a no-no as far as we are concerned, no matter how good the film is.

"The regulations are very clear, even if it is proved that that the animals did not suffer. We had a similar case a few years ago with a Chinese film about cock fighting, where the cocks wore rubber spurs so they would not injure themselves. Anything which involves goading or cruelty to animals is unacceptable. "Context is no defence."

The RSPCA recently launched an anti-dog fighting campaign, offering rewards for the arrest of baiters. A spokeswoman said: "We are very concerned about this film. Any film, especially an award winning one, which might imply that these practices are acceptable, has to be condemned. We are also worried about how it was shot. Even if these plastic muzzles were used, the dogs must have been goaded into attacking each other."

Guardian critic Jonathan Romney described the film as the "most exciting piece of pure narrative shown at Cannes this year", but no British distributor has picked it up as yet, and Ms Clarke said that it had not been submitted for classification.

Lizzie Francke, director of the Edinburgh fortnight, Britain's leading film festival, said: "This is an extraordinary film, and it would be a crime if it was not seen in Britain. No animals were harmed. I would not dream of showing it if I knew they had been. I have seen a more powerful film about the destruction people wreak on each other than this. I found myself crying at several scenes. I'd much rather make a stand for this film than many others which have attracted similar controversies." She hoped a distributor would be brave enough to pick up the film.

Another highlight of the festival, which starts on August 13, is the premiere of Terence Davies' The House Of Mirth, shot in Glasgow and starring Gillian Anderson, omitted for this year's Cannes.

Stephen Daldry's The Dancer, a hit at Cannes, will be shown, though it has been renamed Billy Elliot to distinguish it from Lars Von Trier' Dancer In The Dark, which won the Palme D'Or at Cannes and will also will be shown at Edinburgh. In The Mood For Love, from the Hong Kong director Wong Kar-Wai, and loosely based on Brief Encounter, will get its British premiere.

A spokeswoman said: "We are very concerned about this film. Any film, especially an award winning one, which might imply that these practices are acceptable, has to be condemned. We are also worried about how it was shot. Even if these plastic muzzles were used, the dogs must have been goaded into attacking each other." Guardian critic Jonathan Romney described the film as the "most exciting piece of pure narrative shown at Cannes this year", but no British distributor has picked it up as yet, and Ms Clarke said that it had not been submitted for classification. Lizzie Francke, director of the Edinburgh fortnight, Britain's leading film festival, said: "This is an extraordinary film, and it would be a crime if it was not seen in Britain. No animals were harmed. I would not dream of showing it if I knew they had been. I have seen a more powerful film about the destruction people wreak on each other than this. I found myself crying at several scenes. I'd much rather make a stand for this film than many others which have attracted similar controversies." She hoped a distributor would be brave enough to pick up the film. Another highlight of the festival, which starts on August 13, is the premiere of Terence Davies' The House Of Mirth, shot in Glasgow and starring Gillian Anderson, omitted for this year's Cannes. Stephen Daldry's The Dancer, a hit at Cannes, will be shown, though it has been renamed Billy Elliot to distinguish it from Lars Von Trier' Dancer In The Dark, which won the Palme D'Or at Cannes and will also will be shown at Edinburgh. In The Mood For Love, from the Hong Kong director Wong Kar-Wai, and loosely based on Brief Encounter, will get its British premiere.

fields.headline: US tobacco fight: a timeline
fields.trailText: 1954: Industry faces first liability lawsuit by lung cancer victim alleging negligence and breach of warranty. Suit dropped 13 years later.
fields.body:
1954: Industry faces first liability lawsuit by lung cancer victim alleging negligence and breach of warranty. Suit dropped 13 years later.

1964-1970: Surgeon General Luther Terry releases reports concluding smoking causes lung cancer. The Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act requires surgeon general's warnings on cigarette packs. Government requires one antismoking advertisement for every three cigarette ads.

1971 -1980: Broadcast ads for cigarettes are banned. Officials rule all airlines must create nonsmoking sections. Insurers begin offering discounts on life insurance premiums to nonsmokers. Warnings strengthened on cigarette packages and ads. Nicotine-based chewing gum approved as quitting aid. San Francisco requires businesses to accommodate nonsmokers. Government bans smoking on short domestic airline flights. Surgeon general concludes nicotine is an addictive drug.

1990: Smoking banned on interstate buses and all domestic airline flights of six hours or less.

1992: Nicotine patches introduced.

1993: Vermont bans smoking in indoor public places.

1994: Executives of seven largest US tobacco companies swear in congressional testimony that nicotine isn't addictive and deny manipulating nicotine levels in cigarettes. Amtrak bans smoking on short and medium-distance trips. Brown and Williamson documents show tobacco executives discovered smoking's risks before the surgeon general did. Mississippi files first of 24 state lawsuits seeking to recoup millions from tobacco companies for smokers' Medicaid bills.

1996: Liggett Group, smallest of major tobacco companies, settles claims with five state attorneys general and promises to help them against other companies.

1997: Federal judge rules government can regulate tobacco as a drug. But industry is allowed to continue advertising. Landmark settlement, subject to congressional approval, calls for unprecedented restrictions on cigarettes and on tobacco makers' liability in lawsuits. Industry to spend $368bn over 25 years, mainly on anti-smoking campaigns, use bold health warning on packs, curb advertising and face fines if youth smoking doesn't drop enough. The first state to settle with tobacco, Mississippi agrees to $3.6bn deal with companies including Brown and Williamson, R.J. Reynolds, Philip Morris and Lorillard Tobacco. Florida reaches settlement reported to be $11.3bn.

1998: Texas settles with the tobacco industry for $15.3bn over 25 years. Tobacco executives testify before Congress that nicotine is addictive under current definitions of the word and smoking may cause cancer. Minnesota and Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Minnesota reach a $6.6bn settlement with the tobacco industry. Despite pressure from President Clinton, Senate rejects a proposed $1.50-per-pack tax increase on cigarettes. After lengthy debate, the Senate effectively kills settlement bill that would have cost tobacco companies at least $516bn over 25 years.

In November, 46 states embrace a $206bn settlement with cigarette makers over health costs for treating sick smokers.

Cigarette prices expected to rise 35 cents to 40 cents a pack to fund settlement.

1999: Patricia Henley is awarded $51.5m in damages against Philip Morris Cos. A state judge later cuts the verdict to $26.5m. Philip Morris is appealing the award. A jury in Portland, Oregan, awards the family of Jesse Williams $79.5m against Philip Morris in punitive damages plus $821,485 in compensatory damages for medical costs and pain and suffering. The judge later reduces the punitive damages to $32 million. Philip Morris is appealing.

A Tennessee jury also clears three tobacco companies of liability in the deaths of three smokers. In July, in the first class-action lawsuit by smokers to go to trial, a Florida jury says five tobacco companies engaged in "extreme and outrageous conduct; in making a defective product that causes emphysema, lung cancer and other illnesses. Meanwhile, two tobacco companies are cleared of wrongdoing in the death of a smoker from lung cancer by a Louisiana jury.

In September, the Justice department sues the tobacco industry to recover billions of government dollars spent on smoking-related health care, accusing cigarette-makers of a "coordinated campaign of fraud and deceit."

March 2000: A San Francisco jury orders Philip Morris and RJ Reynolds, the two largest tobacco companies in the US, to pay $20m in punitive damages. This followed a $1.7m compensatory damage award on 20 March to Leslie Whiteley for medical costs and pain and suffering. Her husband, Leonard, is awarded $250,000 for lost of companionship. Both companies are appealing.

April 2000: In the second phase of the landmark Florida class-action trial, the jury awards two smokers $6.9m in compensatory damages. The jury awards a third smoker $5.8m, but determines that he cannot collect because the four-year statue of limitations had run out.

July 2000: A Mississippi jury rejects a $102m wrongful death suit Wednesday filed against RJ Reynolds tobacco by the widow of a longtime smoker who died of lung cancer.

July 2000: A jury ordered the tobacco industry Friday to pay $145bn in punitive damages to sick Florida smokers, a record-shattering verdict.

webTitle: How US states tried to save the tobacco companies

fields.headline: How US states tried to save the tobacco companies
fields.trailText:
Florida and several tobacco-producing states passed laws designed to protect the tobacco industry in case of a crippling verdict in the
class-action lawsuit brought by Florida smokers.
fields.body:
Florida and several tobacco-producing states passed laws designed to protect the tobacco industry in case of a crippling verdict in the class-action lawsuit brought by Florida smokers.

In Florida, defendants who appeal a verdict generally must post the full award as a bond while appealing damages. But these new laws cap the bond that tobacco companies would have to post during appeals.

State legislators and the tobacco industry say the laws protect companies from certain bankruptcy. But anti-tobacco organisations say the caps unfairly shield cigarette makers and violate the Constitution by failing to respect court decisions from other states. Below is a list of state caps on the bond cigarette makers would have to post during appeals:

 Florida: $100m or 10% of the companies' net worth, whichever is lower.

 Georgia: $25m  Kentucky: $100m  North Carolina: $25m  Virginia: $25m

webTitle: What's next in the tobacco case

fields.headline: What's next in the tobacco case
fields.standfirst: What's next in the Florida class-action suit against the tobacco industry
fields.trailText:
• Post-trial motions:
Industry is expected to challenge the $145bn punitive verdict as excessive. It will renew mistrial motions deferred by the judge during trial and will ask the judge to apply Florida's four-year statute of limitations to void smoker Frank Amodeo's $5.8m compensatory award.
fields.body:
 Post-trial motions:
Industry is expected to challenge the $145bn punitive verdict as excessive. It will renew mistrial motions deferred by the judge during trial and will ask the judge to apply Florida's four-year statute of limitations to void smoker Frank Amodeo's $5.8m compensatory award.

 Appeal bond:
Once the judge enters a final judgment, he must decide whether the industry must put up $100m as a bond while it appeals the verdict - as prescribed by a law enacted during the trial - or whether it must put up 115% of the verdict under the old law.

 Appeal:
Industry will appeal certification of the smokers as a class, other pretrial rulings and perceived trial errors - notably mistrial motions challenging decisions by the judge and dramatic behavior by smokers' attorney Stanley Rosenblatt.

webTitle: Nick Park and Peter Lord live online

fields.headline: Nick Park and Peter Lord live online
fields.standfirst: On Thursday 13 July, the duo behind Chicken Run were live on our talkboards to answer your questions
fields.trailText: Nick and Peter Hello, it's Peter here, ready and willing! And Nick here too!
fields.body:
Nick and Peter Hello, it's Peter here, ready and willing! And Nick here too!

Ben2222 So dear fellows, did you compromise any of your ideas to appeal to the damn Yanks then, chaps?

NickandPeter No, I don't believe we did compromise. We always found that DreamWorks were very respectful of us as British film-makers and gave us all the freedom we wanted to make our own movie.

Tally43 So, why chickens? Wouldn't using humans (or even dogs) have given you more options?

Nick and Peter It *had* to be chickens. Scientific study proved that they are silliest animals in creation, but our idea was to do a prisoner of war escape drama with chickens. The two things have to go together. We never sat down and thought what film can we make with chickens? for example, we never thought of making the sound of music with chickens, and I'll be very happy to never have another chicken in a film again after this.

Tally43 So what animals *would* you cast in Sound of Music? Or what other films should be remade with the Aardman twist?

Nick and Peter Beavers as the Von Trapp family and rainbow trout as the Nazis, but perhaps Julie Andrews would be a chubb...

SKDavies2 Is DreamWorks happy that you continue to work out of Bristol? How involved were they in Chicken Run?

Nick and Peter They were very happy for us to work out of Bristol. In fact, so were we! it was good to have the Atlantic ocean between us but their involvement was very useful. Jeffrey [Katzenberg] jetted over about once every nine weeks, or so. I would compare him to a football coach, really, on the sidelines, we were never under any pressure to do or change anything. there was a lot of healthy arguments but we've had that with the BBC too, with Wallace and Gromit - you get that with any production. but they were very happy to let us get on with it, really.

kd Given all the casting hoo-ha that is going on with Harry Potter, would you ever consider doing the film yourselves as clay-mation?

Nick and Peter No! we like to write our own stuff, as brilliant as Harry Potter is.

Barquing Hullo chaps, without stooping to arse-licking, I really enjoyed your film. One question though, How do you determine whether or not a breed of bird is sinister (like the penguin) or heroic (like .. uh .. chickens) and does this peculiar need to animate poultry come down to some kind of masochistic streak in getting all those feathers "just right" ?

Nick and Peter I think it's a question of either playing along with what the animal seems to suggest, or you (probably in the case of penguins and chickens) you go completely against what tyey seem to suggest. It's not so much what the animal it, it's more how it behaves, or how you can make it behave through animation. I think you can really treat any animal in any way, really. I don't think there's any rules to it. And, yes! to the masochist/chicken feathers question.

sezzyboy hiya Nick and Peter, Thought Chicken Run was great fun. However, Gilbert Adair of the Indy on Sunday obviously didn't, finding sinister overtones in many bits of the film. How do you respond to critics who are obviously miserable old gits? (And is he right with his observations?)

Nick and Peter Handling the critics is something you shouldn't take too seriously. Some make good points and some completely miss the point... One critic criticised a reference to ET as being too much a Spielberg reference. I don't recall ever putting a Spielberg reference in the movie. One has to just shrug off most of these kinds of criticisms. The response I'm getting from the public is, to me, much more important. I sometimes think, it took four and a half years to make the movie - how long does it take to write the review? (Nick)

withnail20 Hello Nick and Peter, Is there to be a Rex The Runt movie? Or another series, at least? I'm a huge fan. Also, what are your thoughts on the Animal Rights activists leaping aboard the bandwagon of your film? Are you vegetarians? It'd be nice to think that sales of Free Range eggs will rise as a consequence of Chicken Run.

Nick and Peter Yes, there is another series being planned, and, incidentally, Richard Goleszowski is also directing the next Aardman feature, which is roughly based on the tortoise and the hare fable. I'm not sure when the shooting of the next Rex the Runt series is planned. With regards to animal rights activists, we didn't really intend the film to have a political message, it was just a story that is as much about people as it is about chickens. I'm not particularly vegetarian but I guess I am against mass exploitation of anything, including animals. And, yes, it would be nice if Chicken Run had some influence on the egg or chicken market.

SpankTM Aside for your obvious animation skills, the films you've both worked on have revealed a real sense of narrative pacing, comic timing and the verve to pull off a big action-packed finale. Ever been tempted to apply those talents to a live-action movie? (Hey, it worked for Tim Burton...)

Nick and Peter No, the simple answer is no - never have. I've occasionally done a bit of filming with real actors and I always find it totally terrifying! They don't stand still where you put them, and they need to be fed and humoured and generally looked after. the whole pace of live action always astonishes me so I think we'll stay in out own peaceful world of stop-frame. (Peter)

Datta Any clues you can give us about what's going to happen in the Wallace and Gromit movie?

Nick and Peter Hi Pete here! Nick's got an idea for the next W+G movie, and I could give you a couple of hints but if I did he'd kill me. He's been guarding the secret with his life. So, sorry!

Badgerfish Hello, Do you ever lose your patience and tear the models apart in fits of ill-advised rage?

Nick and Peter Almost every day an animator is tempted to do this because animation can be the most frustrating job in the world. But the animators know that if they did this they would just have to shoot the shot again and it would probably be even more work so we take out our frustration on something else. there was one time where we discovered ginger's head lying on the floor with a huge bootprint on it - some people claim it was an accident but I don't believe it!

Stephend2 It seems that long after your films are through at the cinema or TV, the characters live on in those funny sheep backpacks, talking alarm clock tableaux, and so on. Do you have any creative control over the merchandising that gets made as a result of your work?

Nick and Peter With W+G merchandising, because it happened relatively slowly, over several years we did manage to keep quite strong creative control over it, which I'm very happy about. To be honest, with CR, Nick and I haven't had the time or the opportunity to keep tight creative control over every detail, but we have a department at Aardman who look after things on our behalf on this side of the Atlantic. And Dreamworks look after things in America. (Peter)

RichardM Would you consider doing a full length feature in any medium other than clay, or do you think it's better to stick to your own niche? I was glad to see that barring Yank/Aussie Mel Gibson Chicken Run made no concessions in terms of setting, vocabulary and accents to the American audience. Is the intention for this to continue, or will the next film be something like Wallace and Gromit do America? Or if not Wallace and Gromit are you planning any US-based characters at the behest of DreamWorks?

Nick and Peter Yes, thanks! we tried out hardest to make the film British in every way and we certainly don't intend to start making films set in America, or with more American characters. we think that we do our best work making films about what we know, and Chicken Run has been successful enough in America to prove what we've always believed - that the American public can enjoy a very British film if it's well done. I don't expect that there'll be any guest American voices in the next W+G film, but Nick loves to surprise us so who knows? (Peter)

MeatTakeshi Afternoon chaps. The Tortoise and the Hare is your next feature, have you signed any vocal talent onboard yet? If so will you be casting another US box office draw, such as Mel Gibson? There was talk of a Chicken Run sequel as the 4th feature in your DreamWorks deal dependent on box office, recent reports have suggested this is dead and buried, is this case? Will we ever see the return of Feathers McGraw, the most feared bird since Joan of Arc?

Nick and Peter No, no voices signed up yet for the Tortoise and the Hare but, again, it's going to be set in Britain and we think we'll have some good and surprising names for you. as far as I'm concerned, there has been no talk of a Chicken Run sequel. And Nick and I aren't interested in doing one, certainly not at the moment, We're chickened out!

Tamara Hi chaps. Were you worried, with Mel Gibson involved, that Chicken Run wouldn't be historically accurate and that decent, honest British chickens would be made to look like complete bastards?

Nick and Peter We think we've done our bit to set poultry history to rights. Everything that rocky does in the film can be supported by reliable documentary evidence. As you see, British chickens are uniformly honest and honourable.

dan314 Hello. Where does your curious obsession with machinery, which seems to feature in much of your work (from trousers to chicken pie machines) come from? Also, if the wrong trousers were wrong before they went wrong, what was wrong with them in the first place?!

Nick and Peter It's funny about the obsession with machinery. I think there's lots of references. Nick and I are both fans of the English illustrator Heath Robinson. The styling of the machines seems to be derived from sci-fi of the 50s, maybe films like HG Wells The Time Machine, but also miraculous machines that can do anything, have always been a popular favourite in comics and cartoons. I'm sure that Beano characters in the past were always building amazing machines like this, and think of Wily Coyote who sends of to the ACME company for machines that can do just about anything. We're both frustrated inventors, really, and through animation we can make machines that really work. (Peter)

ASIDE: RichardM dan314> Surely the trousers weren't wrong in the sense that they had gone wrong. Wallace fell into them and on realising that they weren't his trousers that he was expecting to fall out of bed into exclaimed something like: "They're the wrong trousers!"

Datta RichardM/dan314> "Gromit! It's the wrong trousers! And they've gone wrong!"

RichardM Datta> Ah, yes! So it's both, and they were only wrong after Feathers McGraw had tampered with them.

grover In a recent documentary where I first saw your faces, I couldn't take my eyes from your mouth movements - identical to your creations'. Since everyone in Aardman must master these idiosyncratic "GromitGrimace" expressions in their work, and since these so obviously originated from your own mirror, my question is this: does everyone working at Aardman now move their mouth like yours?

Nick and Peter Yes, it's part of the job description for any animator that they have to move their mouth exactly like me! (Nick)

yurigagarin Hi, Nick and Peter What did you make of Toy Story, and how do you think the Americans regard your style of animation? Do they think it's quaint and English, or do they wish they had the artistry to make films like that too?

Nick and Peter Speaking, for Nick here, I think we're both fans of both the Toy Story films, John (Lasseter) is a great director, and he tells really good stories which is the most important thing. The Americans do seem to find something special in the Englishness of our work. I suppose the humour is much less familiar to them than it is to an English audience. Whatever the reason, they have given us great reviews!

naomi2 What's your favourite scene in the movie? When I saw it the pie machine sequence brought the house down

Nick and Peter The pie machine sequence is the most action-packed scene, apart from the ending but it's hard to choose a favourite really as different scenes have their own merits, like the dance scene. I particularly like the scene of Rocky and Ginger up on the roof chatting, which I think is beautifully animated by our Belgian animator Guionne Leroy. It's very sensitive and touching. (Nick) I like the scene at the end when Fowler reminds us of what the joke of the whole film is - all these heroics and they're *just* chickens! (Peter)

Nick and Peter Bye now - we've got to dash off to a signing session at Borders on Oxford Street for 7pm. Thanks for all your questions, it was nice chatting and sorry we didn't have time to answer all of them. Bye!

Unanswered questions

sezzyboy I have to say that I think Feathers McGraw is my favourite character ever. How can a mute penguin be so insanely evil??? So who are Peter & Nick's favourites??

Hussain I am a student who will be studying Film & Video at Surrey Institute. I am very pleased that British animation has been recognised by Hollywood. I hope that both of you will establish your own production company to rival. Dreamwoks and Disney. By the way! Where is my all time hero MORPH? A quick suggestion I along with countless others would like to see a MORPH movie. KEEP UP THE GREAT WORK!

schindler Hi Nick and Peter, I haven't seen Chicken Run - it's not out in Germany yet. Do you have any control over the synchronisation when your films are dubbed into foreign languages? If so, by what criteria do you judge the voices chosen for the different characters.

blackbird21 did you have specific actors in mind when you came up with the idea for chicken run? sezzyboy Hello again, Atom films has been a pretty big success. Do you think by the time the next Wallace and Gromit (feature) film comes out, everyone will just sit at home and download it off the internet? I think what I'm trying to say is: you seem to be able to use the modern (internet) and the traditional (claymation) to your advantage. Where would you prefer your films to be shown? on the net or in the cinema?

barquing How do you respond to accusations of being too English and perhaps too twee?

Ben2222 Which clay animation person/chicken did you like animating the best?

Berious Hello gentlemen, So, are either of you vegetarian, or do you regularly enjoy chicken?

dan314 Me again. What came first, Peter Sallis' voice, or Wallace?

rgsharp Do you ever feel like making a 'serious' film?

RichardM "I'll be very happy to never have another chicken in a film again after this". Glad to hear that. Someone above mentioned a Chicken Run 2. I feel that would be a mistake.

I sometimes think, it took four and a half years to make the movie - how long does it take to write the review? (Nick) withnail20 Hello Nick and Peter, Is there to be a Rex The Runt movie? Or another series, at least? I'm a huge fan. Also, what are your thoughts on the Animal Rights activists leaping aboard the bandwagon of your film? Are you vegetarians? It'd be nice to think that sales of Free Range eggs will rise as a consequence of Chicken Run. Nick and Peter Yes, there is another series being planned, and, incidentally, Richard Goleszowski is also directing the next Aardman feature, which is roughly based on the tortoise and the hare fable. I'm not sure when the shooting of the next Rex the Runt series is planned. With regards to animal rights activists, we didn't really intend the film to have a political message, it was just a story that is as much about people as it is about chickens. I'm not particularly vegetarian but I guess I am against mass exploitation of anything, including animals. And, yes, it would be nice if Chicken Run had some influence on the egg or chicken market. SpankTM Aside for your obvious animation skills, the films you've both worked on have revealed a real sense of narrative pacing, comic timing and the verve to pull off a big action-packed finale. Ever been tempted to apply those talents to a live-action movie? (Hey, it worked for Tim Burton...) Nick and Peter No, the simple answer is no - never have. I've occasionally done a bit of filming with real actors and I always find it totally terrifying! They don't stand still where you put them, and they need to be fed and humoured and generally looked after. the whole pace of live action always astonishes me so I think we'll stay in out own peaceful world of stop-frame. (Peter) Datta Any clues you can give us about what's going to happen in the Wallace and Gromit movie? Nick and Peter Hi Pete here! Nick's got an idea for the next W+G movie, and I could give you a couple of hints but if I did he'd kill me. He's been guarding the secret with his life. So, sorry! Badgerfish Hello, Do you ever lose your patience and tear the models apart in fits of ill-advised rage? Nick and Peter Almost every day an animator is tempted to do this because animation can be the most frustrating job in the world. But the animators know that if they did this they would just have to shoot the shot again and it would probably be even more work so we take out our frustration on something else. there was one time where we discovered ginger's head lying on the floor with a huge bootprint on it - some people claim it was an accident but I don't believe it! Stephend2 It seems that long after your films are through at the cinema or TV, the characters live on in those funny sheep backpacks, talking alarm clock tableaux, and so on. Do you have any creative control over the merchandising that gets made as a result of your work? Nick and Peter With W+G merchandising, because it happened relatively slowly, over several years we did manage to keep quite strong creative control over it, which I'm very happy about. To be honest, with CR, Nick and I haven't had the time or the opportunity to keep tight creative control over every detail, but we have a department at Aardman who look after things on our behalf on this side of the Atlantic. And Dreamworks look after things in America. (Peter) RichardM Would you consider doing a full length feature in any medium other than clay, or do you think it's better to stick to your own niche? I was glad to see that barring Yank/Aussie Mel Gibson Chicken Run made no concessions in terms of setting, vocabulary and accents to the American audience. Is the intention for this to continue, or will the next film be something like Wallace and Gromit do America? Or if not Wallace and Gromit are you planning any US-based characters at the behest of DreamWorks? Nick and Peter Yes, thanks! we tried out hardest to make the film British in every way and we certainly don't intend to start making films set in America, or with more American characters. we think that we do our best work making films about what we know, and Chicken Run has been successful enough in America to prove what we've always believed - that the American public can enjoy a very British film if it's well done. I don't expect that there'll be any guest American voices in the next W+G film, but Nick loves to surprise us so who knows? (Peter) MeatTakeshi Afternoon chaps. The Tortoise and the Hare is your next feature, have you signed any vocal talent onboard yet? If so will you be casting another US box office draw, such as Mel Gibson? There was talk of a Chicken Run sequel as the 4th feature in your DreamWorks deal dependent on box office, recent reports have suggested this is dead and buried, is this case? Will we ever see the return of Feathers McGraw, the most feared bird since Joan of Arc? Nick and Peter No, no voices signed up yet for the Tortoise and the Hare but, again, it's going to be set in Britain and we think we'll have some good and surprising names for you. as far as I'm concerned, there has been no talk of a Chicken Run sequel. And Nick and I aren't interested in doing one, certainly not at the moment, We're chickened out! Tamara Hi chaps. Were you worried, with Mel Gibson involved, that Chicken Run wouldn't be historically accurate and that decent, honest British chickens would be made to look like complete bastards? Nick and Peter We think we've done our bit to set poultry history to rights. Everything that rocky does in the film can be supported by reliable documentary evidence. As you see, British chickens are uniformly honest and honourable. dan314 Hello. Where does your curious obsession with machinery, which seems to feature in much of your work (from trousers to chicken pie machines) come from? Also, if the wrong trousers were wrong before they went wrong, what was wrong with them in the first place?! Nick and Peter It's funny about the obsession with machinery. I think there's lots of references. Nick and I are both fans of the English illustrator Heath Robinson. The styling of the machines seems to be derived from sci-fi of the 50s, maybe films like HG Wells The Time Machine, but also miraculous machines that can do anything, have always been a popular favourite in comics and cartoons. I'm sure that Beano characters in the past were always building amazing machines like this, and think of Wily Coyote who sends of to the ACME company for machines that can do just about anything. We're both frustrated inventors, really, and through animation we can make machines that really work. (Peter) ASIDE: RichardM dan314> Surely the trousers weren't wrong in the sense that they had gone wrong. Wallace fell into them and on realising that they weren't his trousers that he was expecting to fall out of bed into exclaimed something like: "They're the wrong trousers!" Datta RichardM/dan314> "Gromit! It's the wrong trousers! And they've gone wrong!" RichardM Datta> Ah, yes! So it's both, and they were only wrong after Feathers McGraw had tampered with them. grover In a recent documentary where I first saw your faces, I couldn't take my eyes from your mouth movements - identical to your creations'. Since everyone in Aardman must master these idiosyncratic "GromitGrimace" expressions in their work, and since these so obviously originated from your own mirror, my question is this: does everyone working at Aardman now move their mouth like yours? Nick and Peter Yes, it's part of the job description for any animator that they have to move their mouth exactly like me! (Nick) yurigagarin Hi, Nick and Peter What did you make of Toy Story, and how do you think the Americans regard your style of animation? Do they think it's quaint and English, or do they wish they had the artistry to make films like that too? Nick and Peter Speaking, for Nick here, I think we're both fans of both the Toy Story films, John (Lasseter) is a great director, and he tells really good stories which is the most important thing. The Americans do seem to find something special in the Englishness of our work. I suppose the humour is much less familiar to them than it is to an English audience. Whatever the reason, they have given us great reviews! naomi2 What's your favourite scene in the movie? When I saw it the pie machine sequence brought the house down Nick and Peter The pie machine sequence is the most action-packed scene, apart from the ending but it's hard to choose a favourite really as different scenes have their own merits, like the dance scene. I particularly like the scene of Rocky and Ginger up on the roof chatting, which I think is beautifully animated by our Belgian animator Guionne Leroy. It's very sensitive and touching. (Nick) I like the scene at the end when Fowler reminds us of what the joke of the whole film is - all these heroics and they're *just* chickens! (Peter) Nick and Peter Bye now - we've got to dash off to a signing session at Borders on Oxford Street for 7pm. Thanks for all your questions, it was nice chatting and sorry we didn't have time to answer all of them. Bye! Unanswered questions sezzyboy I have to say that I think Feathers McGraw is my favourite character ever. How can a mute penguin be so insanely evil??? So who are Peter & Nick's favourites?? Hussain I am a student who will be studying Film & Video at Surrey Institute. I am very pleased that British animation has been recognised by Hollywood. I hope that both of you will establish your own production company to rival. Dreamwoks and Disney. By the way! Where is my all time hero MORPH? A quick suggestion I along with countless others would like to see a MORPH movie. KEEP UP THE GREAT WORK! schindler Hi Nick and Peter, I haven't seen Chicken Run - it's not out in Germany yet. Do you have any control over the synchronisation when your films are dubbed into foreign languages? If so, by what criteria do you judge the voices chosen for the different characters. blackbird21 did you have specific actors in mind when you came up with the idea for chicken run? sezzyboy Hello again, Atom films has been a pretty big success. Do you think by the time the next Wallace and Gromit (feature) film comes out, everyone will just sit at home and download it off the internet? I think what I'm trying to say is: you seem to be able to use the modern (internet) and the traditional (claymation) to your advantage. Where would you prefer your films to be shown? on the net or in the cinema? barquing How do you respond to accusations of being too English and perhaps too twee? Ben2222 Which clay animation person/chicken did you like animating the best? Berious Hello gentlemen, So, are either of you vegetarian, or do you regularly enjoy chicken? dan314 Me again. What came first, Peter Sallis' voice, or Wallace? rgsharp Do you ever feel like making a 'serious' film? RichardM "I'll be very happy to never have another chicken in a film again after this". Glad to hear that. Someone above mentioned a Chicken Run 2. I feel that would be a mistake.

fields.headline: Variations in NHS standards 'unacceptable'
fields.standfirst: Ministers promise to tackle uneven quality of patient care around country, and to provide more doctors, nurses and beds
fields.trailText: Ministers have condemned 'unacceptable' variations in standards of health care that are revealed in league tables of performance by NHS trusts and health authorities across England.
fields.byline: John Carvel, social affairs editor, The Guardian
fields.body:
Ministers have condemned 'unacceptable' variations in standards of health care that are revealed in league tables of performance by NHS trusts and health authorities across England.

They show nearly five times more patients are waiting for treatment in the worst performing health authorities, than in the best.

In some areas emergency cases are invariably seen within two hours of arrival in an A&E unit. In other areas less than 40% meet this standard.

Death rates within 30 days of surgery are at least three times higher in some hospitals, than in others of the same type.

John Denham, the health minister, said the variations were not necessarily a signal of defective management or poor organisation of clinical services.

They might also be caused by inequalities in the health needs of different parts of the country. Or they might be a signal that some areas have not had enough resources to provide sufficient doctors, nurses or beds.

'Whatever the reason, the extent of these variations is unacceptable. The national plan [due this month] has to tackle these variations effectively,' he said.

It would provide for more doctors, more nurses, more beds and more comprehensive primary care services. Health authorities and trusts would then have the resources to tackle all aspects of under-performance.

The league tables measure 99 health authorities and 275 hospital trusts against 56 yardsticks of performance. Government statisticians claim to have improved the quality of data after widespread criticism last year, but warn that variations may sometimes be explained by special factors that managers or clinicians cannot control.

For example, the apparently high death rates in some teaching hospitals are the result of the most dangerously ill patients being referred there.

Mr Denham said adjustments in the format of the tables made it impossible to measure whether individual authorities or trusts were getting better or worse.

National figures for England showed reductions in deaths from cancer and circulatory diseases, and increased rates of surgery for hips, cataracts and hearts. But there was a deterioration in the figures for operations being cancelled at the last minute.

The league tables show stark variations in mortality rates. People in Manchester are more than twice as likely as people in Surrey to die between the ages of 15 and 64. Manchester comes bottom of a series of national mortality tables, with the highest rate of deaths from cancer, circulatory diseases, suicide and accidents.

The number of patients who die in hospital within 30 days of emergency surgery varied from under 3% in Portsmouth and south-east Hampshire to 5.5% in Wigan and Bolton. The Portsmouth hospitals trust came top of the table for 'very large' acute hospitals with a death rate of 2.2%, compared to 6.4% at St Helier in Carshalton, Surrey.

The tables point to big variations in trolley waits. In Sunderland and Walsall every emergency case in A&E was seen within two hours, but in Barnet and Kingston & Richmond health authorities, this target was met for less than 40% of patients.

In north Derbyshire, 89% of people were seen as outpatients within 13 weeks of GP referral, but in Portsmouth and SE Hampshire the rate was only 61%.

The number of operations cancelled for non-medical reasons on the day of, or after, admission varied from zero in the London borough of Barnet to just over 5% in nearby Camden and Islington.

Five-year survival rates for women aged 15 to 99 diagnosed with breast cancer varied from 83.7% in east Surrey to 64.5% in north Staffordshire. The five-year survival rate for people diagnosed with lung cancer ranged from 8.5% in east and north Hertfordshire to 2.1% in Rotherham. For colon cancer, the survival rate ranged from 52.4% in Herefordshire to 24.9% in the Tees health authority.

For the first time the tables include a patient satisfaction index. The proportion of patients complaining ó or saying they felt like complaining ó about GP surgery staff in the last 12 months varied between 8% in Gloucestershire to 19% in Liverpool.

The Department of Health said the tables were helping health authorities to improve performance. Managers in Sheffield saw from last yearís tables that they had high cancer mortality rates. Their rapid diagnostic outpatient services were now top of the table for delivering appointments within two weeks of referral. The authority was now in the top 10 for take-up on screening.

Lincolnshire health authority achieved an unprecedented growth in prescribing cheaper generic drugs. And Barnsley health authority took steps to reduce the amount of tranquillisers prescribed by GPs, after last yearís indicators showed doctors prescribed twice the national average.

Mr Denham said: 'We have made it clear the NHS needs more doctors and more nurses. We are investing in additional critical care beds and the development of more comprehensive primary care services.

'At the same time, these performance indicators enable the local health service to identify where their performance falls below that of the best and we expect measures to be taken to improve poorly performing services.'

webTitle: Barmby signs for Liverpool in £6m deal

fields.headline: Barmby signs for Liverpool in £6m deal
fields.trailText: Everton have agreed to sell midfielder Nick Barmby to Liverpool in a £6m deal.
fields.body:
Everton have agreed to sell midfielder Nick Barmby to Liverpool in a £6m deal.

The 26 year-old England international has agreed a four-year contract which will bring him around £30,000 a week - a significant increase on the deal he recently rejected at Goodison Park. He will undergo a medical at Anfield on Monday to seal the move.

Earlier today Everton released a statement which said: "Everton and Liverpool have today agreed the transfer of Nick Barmby to Liverpool in a package worth up to £6million. The clubs wish to emphasise that negotiations have continued over the past week in a spirit of goodwill and integrity and they both wish each other success in the forthcoming season."

Barmby will almost certainly face a barrage of abuse on his return to Goodison Park next season. He is the first player to leave Everton for their bitter local rivals since Dave Hickson crossed Stanley Park in 1959.

Barmby's desire to leave the club shocked Everton's management, who believed they were progressing towards a satisfactory conclusion to discussions over a new contract. But his return to favour with England in the build-up to Euro 2000 appears to have changed the situation. Everton's chief executive Mike Dunford claimed at the time: "We have met all of Nicky's requests in the new contract. But you can say that his getting back into the England squad has complicated matters."

The signing of Barmby takes Gerald Houllier's spending to just under £50m during his time in charge at Anfield.

webTitle: Britain sending more bullets to Sierra Leone

fields.headline: Britain sending more bullets to Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: Britain announced further military support for the Sierra Leone government yesterday, including more ammunition for its army.   The announcement came a day after President Ahmed Tejan Kabbah's army was accused by a human rights organisation of killing civilians.
fields.body:
Britain announced further military support for the Sierra Leone government yesterday, including more ammunition for its army. The announcement came a day after President Ahmed Tejan Kabbah's army was accused by a human rights organisation of killing civilians.

The Ministry of Defence said 5m rounds of rife ammunition would be delivered subject to Sierra Leone securing the agreement of the Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) to waive a moratorium on the supply of small arms to the region. Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, said the ordnance was also being provided "subject to confirmation that it will be used only by regular SLA [Sierra Leone Army] soldiers in accordance with international humanitarian law and human rights standards and not by child soldiers". He said the ammunition, along with boots, ponchos and other items of personal equipment, were being flown to Freetown to meet "urgent operational needs".

Last month Britain provided the SLA with 5m rounds of rifle ammunition and 4,000 mortar rounds. In May it supplied 10,000 self-loading rifles which, it said, would be subjected to "controlled release under the supervision of British officers".

Last year 7,500 British rifles were supplied to President Kabbah's forces as part of a £10m weapons package. Human Rights Watch in New York has expressed concern that the Sierra Leone government caused civilian casualties and massive civilian displacement in helicopter gunship attacks on suspected rebel positions. It said the attacks in May and June in the towns of Makeni, Magburaka and Kambia resulted in at least 27 civilian deaths, 50 wounded civilians and the displacement of tens of thousands of civilians.

The organisation called on the Sierra Leone government and its British military advisers to ensure that government forces respected international humanitarian law and protected civilians. "It is unacceptable for the Sierra Leone government to start dropping bombs on a crowded market place in the hope of hitting a small number of rebels," said Peter Takirambudde, executive director of the Africa division of Human Rights Watch. Displaced civilians have described several air attacks on public places, including crowded markets. The helicopter attacks caused a massive civilian exodus which emptied entire towns and villages.

webTitle: Madrid gets ready for Real decision

fields.headline: Madrid gets ready for Real decision
fields.standfirst: Sean Ingle on the presidential campaign that could teach Gore and Bush a thing or two
fields.trailText: Mid-summer in Madrid, and the city is struggling. The heat salsas close to 100 degrees, and the suffocating smog hangs heavily. Not surprisingly, most madrileños with money have long since evacuated to their seaside retreats. But those with an attachment to Real Madrid are still lingering; devouring the machinations, dissecting the pledges and counter-pledges - and eagerly awaiting the denouement of a presidential campaign which has been extraordinary even by the standards of Spanish football.
fields.body:
Mid-summer in Madrid, and the city is struggling. The heat salsas close to 100 degrees, and the suffocating smog hangs heavily. Not surprisingly, most madrileños with money have long since evacuated to their seaside retreats. But those with an attachment to Real Madrid are still lingering; devouring the machinations, dissecting the pledges and counter-pledges - and eagerly awaiting the denouement of a presidential campaign which has been extraordinary even by the standards of Spanish football.

This Sunday, a significant number of the 66,000 Real Madrid members entitled to vote will take the Number ten line out to Begona, make the short walk to the Multisports Pavilion at the Ciudad Deportiva and place their votes for the president of Real in the urns provided. In theory they will choose between two construction magnates with big egos and even bigger wallets. In practice they are democratically determining the direction of the club for the next four years - something football followers in Britain can only dream about.

Until recently the Madrid fans seemed certain to re-elect Lorenzo Sanz, who has ruled the club since 1995. He is the archetypal Spanish football owner: rich, vain and omnipotent. (Last summer for instance, Madrid's manager John Toshack pleaded with him to buy a centre-half. Unfortunately that was where Sanz's son Fernando played, and instead he blew £25m on Nicholas Anelka.) Real's second Champions League victory in two years has made him the most successful Madrid president for a generation, and he is quick to remind supporters that: "Nobody can prevent me from appearing, like Santiago Bernabeu, in the golden history book of the club."

One man who would like to try is his rival for the presidency, Lorenzo Perez. Perez, whose prospects were written off completely at the start of the race, needed something to perk up his campaign, and so duly made made what seemed like an outrageous pledge: to bring Barcelona's Luis Figo to Real if he won. And this despite the player's £40m buy-out clause in his contract. Zinedine Zidane might be on his way as well too, he hinted. Sanz, not used to being upstaged, quickly dismissed Perez's offer as "a joke, probably to be followed by the signing of Claudia Schiffer."

Then, strangely for an election campaign, Perez's pledge turned out to be true. Well, the Figo part anyway. Because a day after claiming he would be "mad" to leave Barcelona, the Portuguese playmaker admitted: "I have an offer from senor Florentino Perez and that is why I want him to win the elections." And the offer? A cool £2m advance plus £5m-a-year in wages.

The next day events took a further twist when the Spanish daily Marca revealed they were in possession of a contract - dated July 1st and signed by Figo's agent Jose Veiga - stating that Figo would pay Florentino £20m if he didn't sign for the European champions. Additionally, the document also committed Perez to giving Figo £20m if he became Real president and then didn't sign him. The deal looked done and delivered. The only question was whether the Madrid fans would take the Figo bait and elect Perez?

The press had a field day, dubbing the saga "The Figo Affair." But secretly Sanz was seething. And earlier this week he launched the imaginatively titled: 'Save Real Madrid' campaign. Or more accurately, save it from Perez and Figo. "These cheap shots at buying votes offered by the other candidate have one objective which is none other than to keep the club for himself," Sanz claimed. "However, our members aren't stupid. They won't allow themselves to be bought."

Sanz then announced he would send a video of Figo - his hair dyed in Barcelona colours - insulting Real after Barca won the Primeria Liga last year ("Madridistas, cry babies, hail the champions!") to all 66,000 members with a vote to remind them of the Portuguese players past sins. And the following day he announced that he'd made an offer £15m offer for Mallorca striker Diego Tristan. "The signing of Diego Tristan is a reality, unlike the nonsense circulating regarding Luis Figo," he claimed.

The past few days have seen a further spate of claims and denials as both candidates attempt to steal a march on the other. But it is still an exercise in democracy that is completely alien to our domestic leagues. Much of this is down to the structure of Spanish football. While most Premiership clubs are plcs, in Spanish law football clubs are non-profitable institutions. You can't buy shares in Real Madrid or Barcelona - instead you become a member (usually by purchasing a season ticket) which entitles you to vote in the elections for the president and board.

But despite the seeming advantages of this system over our own locked boys' club, not everyone is convinced. "The media are covering the Real Madrid and Barcelona elections like a political election," says Inigo Gurruchaga, the London correspondent of El Correo. "In England no-one knows who the chairman of West Ham is, but in Spain they are on the TV and radio every day. It's a kind of sickness in Spanish football."

And a political campaign that is closer to a beauty contest is not necessarily good news for the club either. Becuase the members aren't accountable for the debts of the club, they usually vote for the biggest sugar Daddy. Not surprisingly, most madrileños with money have long since evacuated to their seaside retreats. But those with an attachment to Real Madrid are still lingering; devouring the machinations, dissecting the pledges and counter-pledges - and eagerly awaiting the denouement of a presidential campaign which has been extraordinary even by the standards of Spanish football. This Sunday, a significant number of the 66,000 Real Madrid members entitled to vote will take the Number ten line out to Begona, make the short walk to the Multisports Pavilion at the Ciudad Deportiva and place their votes for the president of Real in the urns provided. In theory they will choose between two construction magnates with big egos and even bigger wallets. fields.headline: Debate on parliament
fields.trailText:
The power of parliament has been so seriously eroded that MPs are unable
        to hold the government to account, William Hague warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The power of parliament has been so seriously eroded that MPs are unable to hold the government to account, William Hague warned yesterday.

In a highly personalised attack on Tony Blair , Mr Hague said: "You have created a government of secret briefings and leaks and gimmicks and gossip, in which power rests with unelected advisers, spin doctors and cronies." He told MPs: "Parliament has been steadily diminished and is now no longer able to do its job properly. When this house is diminished, marginalised or sidelined, democracy itself is harmed."

Mr Hague was opening an opposition-led debate on the relationship between the parliament and the executive. Mr Blair , in response, mocked Mr Hague for raising "piddling points" and failing to address the "big" issues of the time, calling the Conservatives' choice of debate a "piece of extraordinary eccentricity".

During a bitter exchange before a packed chamber, Mr Hague said the "rights and relevance" of parliament was being "progressively diminished" by a government whose behaviour was characterised by "weakness and cowardice".

He opposed the planned reforms of Commons voting procedures, saying the changes were a further "serious assault" on the power of backbench MPs. Instead he called for recommendations in the report by constitutional expert Lord Norton this week to be enacted. These include taking the appointment of MPs to select committees out of the hands of party whips, and returning prime minister's questions to two slots a week instead of the present single 30-minute slot.

Mr Blair dismissed Mr Hague's claims as the speech of "a 16-year-old who used to read Hansard under the bedclothes". He insisted that despite his own voting record of only 5% - compared to one of 32% for Mr Hague - he had spent as much, if not more, time in the Commons answering questions than previous prime ministers.

He said the government was already modernising the Commons, but changes such as the reforms of the Lords and the devolution of power to Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and, in London, to a mayor, had brought power "closer to the people and hold government to account".

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, said it was hard to take the Tories' complaints seriously when they had proved so "lousy" in government and opposition.

The former Tory prime minister, John Major, said some Labour modernisation proposals were welcome but others were "potty". The overall balance of them threatened to turn the Commons into an "irrelevance" with even the weapon of delay to be "stolen" from the opposition.
