fields.headline: CJD death cluster investigated
fields.standfirst:
Link is likely to be genetic not geographical say scientists
Department of Health: BSE
The written answer in the House of Lords
fields.trailText: The Leicestershire village of Queniborough is at the centre of a major investigation into the human form of mad cow disease after it emerged that three people there have died of the illness.
fields.body:
The Leicestershire village of Queniborough is at the centre of a major investigation into the human form of mad cow disease after it emerged that three people there have died of the illness.

Junior health minister Lord Hunt told the House of Lords last night that there are four confirmed cases and one probable case of new-variant CJD (Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease) in Leicestershire, out of only 75 nationwide.

Two of the victims of the disease, Stacey Robinson and an unnamed victim, had lived in Queniborough, a village of 2,297 inhabitants just north of Leicester. Another, Pamela Beyless, of Glenfield, was a frequent visitor to the village. All three died in 1998.

In May, when a 19-year-old man died at the Leicester royal infirmary, health officials said it was "highly probable" that a 24-year-old man in the county also had the disease.

"Statistical experts advise it is unlikely that the higher number of cases in Leicestershire will have occurred by chance," Lord Hunt revealed in a written answer in the House of Lords.

The Department of Health has launched an investigation into the disease "cluster" in the area, working with experts from the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, the national CJD surveillance unit and the London school of hygiene and tropical medicine.

Health officials in Leicestershire have discovered two factors which play a part in contracting the disease - genetic susceptibility and exposure to the infection. But they stressed that villagers should not worry, because the connection between the cases was more likely to be genetic than geographical.

"It is unlikely these cases are linked geographically - rather it was the victims' genetic susceptibility," said Dr Philip Monk, a consultant in communicable diseases at Leicestershire health authority. "We are now interviewing the relatives of the victims to try and establish what common connection they may have had."

"When you have got five people who live in a close area, we have a much greater chance of finding the common factor. I wouldn't say that we will do that, but we have a greater chance that we can find the common factor which explains how the prion protein which causes this disease enters into humans and causes new variant CJD," he told Radio 4's Today programme.

David Taylor, the Labour MP for Leicestershire North West, said the cluster was a major concern for local people. "I want a parliamentary debate on it, and I do want to see some central support and national guidelines or care standards issued to local authorities and NHS trusts to deal with this dreadful disease.

"We have got to learn lessons from this. There must be some local factors which have added to the genetic predisposition and the exposure to the prion protein which have made this area especially vulnerable. Let's find out what they are as quickly as possible."

CJD support groups welcomed the investigation. CJD support network chairman Clive Evers said he thought the cluster was "clearly significant".

The reaction of Queniborough villagers was mixed. One member of staff at the Britannia Inn said: "We still serve beef on a Sunday and our sales haven't been affected at all."

Villager John Shelley said: "This is a worrying thing, and it is surprising that this link is to our own village. They have got to get on top of it, and from a research point of view it's probably good that they can concentrate on such a small area. It's not like they found three people with a link to London."

But Rosemary Handley said she had owned a shop in the village for many years and dismissed the scare as "complete rubbish".

"This is all just jealousy because we live in such a beautiful place and people who live in the city don't like that."

webTitle: Chinese director Jiang Wen banned from film-making

fields.headline: Chinese director Jiang Wen banned from film-making
fields.trailText: Chinese director Jiang Wen, whose Devils at the Doorstep (Guizi Lai Le) won the prestigious Grand Prix at this year's Cannes festival, has been banned from making films for seven years in his native country.
fields.body:
Chinese director Jiang Wen, whose Devils at the Doorstep (Guizi Lai Le) won the prestigious Grand Prix at this year's Cannes festival, has been banned from making films for seven years in his native country.

Industry magazine Screen daily reports that his film, about China during the time of Japanese occupation, has been judged to be 'insufficiently patriotic' by the Chinese authorities.

According to news agency reports, Wen's film is said to undermine his country because it "seriously distorts Chinese history". Apparently, the film's Chinese soldiers do not hate the Japanese army enough and too much time is given to the Japanese national anthem and national flag and "demonstrating the power of the Japanese army this way hurts the feelings of the Chinese people." The film also qualified as vulgar for showing a donkey on heat.

Consequently Jiang, who starred in several films by Zhang Yimou and turned director with 1994's In The Heat Of The Sun (Yangguang Canlan De Rizi), is banned from appearing on film or TV for seven years and is not allowed to direct or produce. The executive producer, Dong Ping, receives a two-year ban and is to have his name removed from Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, which he co-produced.

Devils at the Doorstep has also been denied a certificate allowing its release in mainland China. As a knock-on effect, the Chinese release of Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger - which does have a certificate - has also now been postponed.

The Chinese Film Bureau has called for the return of copies of Devils at the Doorstep from abroad, though this seems unlikely to happen as the film was post-produced overseas and the master copies are now outside China.

fields.headline: Business in brief
fields.trailText: Warning of fraud surge
fields.body:
Warning of fraud surge

The government faces the prospect of a surge in economic crime unless it moves rapidly to make tackling fraud a priority for Britains police forces, George Staple, the chairman of the fraud advisory panel said yesterday. He said individual police forces should be mandated to produce anti-fraud strategies backed up with extra resources to deal with crimes estimated to cost up to £12bn a year.

BMW to build new factory

The new BMW to be launched in 2004 will be produced at the Regensburg factory in Germany, the group said yesterday. But a new plant will be built to cope with extra volume and a decision on its location is expected to be taken by the middle of next year. BMW announced the new model at the time it revealed it was to sell the Longbridge plant.

Hyder approval expected

The European commission is today expected to give the go-ahead for Western Power Distribution to proceed with its contested £464m bid for Welsh multi-utility Hyder, putting more pressure on rival Nomura to raise its £403m offer.

fields.headline: Pass notes no. 1377 Cliff Richard
fields.trailText: Sir Cliff Richard
fields.body:
Cliff Richard

Age: Sir Clifford will be 60 on October 14.

Appearance: Mad scientist in Gerry Anderson puppet spectacular, vacuum-moulded from orange plastic.

In the news because: Sir Clifford is rarely out of the news. One minute his nauseating Millennium Prayer is being "banned" by Radio 2 on the way to becoming one of the biggest hits of his career, the next he's camping out at Wimbledon, snuggling up to Pete Sampras's clone-a-blonde girlfriend and getting acquainted with Steffi Graf.

Sir Clifford doesn't do that sort of thing with girls, surely? Careful. Sir Clifford is a man of depths, most of them hidden.

Wasn't it at Wimbledon that Cliff staged his memorable impromptu "Cliffstock"? It was. With backing vocals from Pam Shriver, Virginia Wade and Martina Navratilova, Clifford "entertained" a captive audience during a rain break at the 1996 championships.

But there's more, no? There is actually. It was at Cliff's mansion, or restored farmhouse at any rate, in Portugal that Cherie Blair and gurgling baby Lionel, sorry, Leo, recently sought a Third Way to escape from the domestic servitude of 10 Downing Street.

Another fine example of the Blairs' talent for making friends with rich people who have luxury accommodation to offer? Please! This was a well-deserved break for the hardest-working woman in showbusiness.

And did she play tennis? Our man up a tree with the long lens was unable to verify this.

But shouldn't Cherie have been at home with Tony and Euan in their hour of darkness? We now know from the PM's haggard appearance, accident-prone demeanour and disastrous gambit of quoting Longfellow that she should.

But hey, who said parenthood was easy? Not Sir Clifford, anyway. Very true. He had sound reasons for singing Bachelor Boy lightly.

Not to be confused with: Sir Vivian Richards, Sir Keith Richards, Sir Tim Henman.

webTitle: Swanton's wartime Wisden goes on display

fields.headline: Swanton's wartime Wisden goes on display
fields.standfirst: In the latest instalment of wisden.com's gossip column, Charles de Lisle finds out how Jim Swanton kept up spirits in a Japanese POW camp, reveals how Marcus Trescothick once reached 4000 runs with the last ball of the season and explains how Zimbabwe are cashing in on their good form
fields.trailText: Swanton's wartime Wisden becomes a museum piece
fields.body:
Swanton's wartime Wisden becomes a museum piece

One of the late EW Swanton's most coveted possessions is about to go on public display for the first time, at Lord's. It's a softback copy of the 1939 Wisden Cricketers' Almanack which sustained the spirits of the great cricket writer in the three-and-a-half terrible years he spent in a Japanese prisoner-of-war camp during the Second World War. The book was also much pored over by fellow prisoners.

"My 1939 Wisden," Swanton wrote later, "was the solace (sic) and in such demand that it could be lent out only for periods of six hours." Swanton added that it might be "the most read copy of Wisden ever published".

"Jim" Swanton, who died in January, aged 92, left no specific instructions about the 1939 Wisden, but his literary executors, John Woodcock and George Plumptre, have decided it should go to the MCC Museum at Lord's. "It's the obvious place," says Woodcock, former cricket correspondent of The Times. "It's a book of enormous interest and great value. I'm sure it will give a lot of pleasure."

The '39 Wisden, which should go on show at Lord's in time for the one-day final on July 22, won't be instantly recognisable: because of its eventful life, it has been rebound several times. "It's a strange and unique item," says Stephen Green, the museum's curator. "I think it must have been one of the prisoners' lifelines to sanity."

The day Trescothick reached 4000 runs - off the last ball of the season

Marcus Trescothick's confident start to his England one-day career comes as little surprise to those who remember his feats as a schoolboy. As a 15-year-old, Trescothick amassed no fewer than 4000 runs, at an average of 68, in the summer of 1991, when his new opening partner Alec Stewart was already in the England team. His rich form was displayed for a variety of sides: the West of England, Avon Schools, Somerset youth teams, and the youth and first XIs of his local club, Keynsham, near Bath.

"Marcus seemed to get century after century," says his father, Martyn. "He had a golden year." Martyn and his wife Lin, who were at The Oval and Lord's last weekend to see their son's 79 against Zimbabwe and 49 against West Indies, can't remember quite how many centuries Marcus collected in 1991, but they think it was at least ten. That's the number recorded on a special certificate presented to him by his then sponsors, the Classic Bat Company, well before the triumphant season was over.

It had a suitably dramatic climax. Trescothick started his last match, a friendly for Keynsham firsts, needing 85 to reach the magic 4000. Batting at No. 3, he had to watch the openers put on 170, and only got to the wicket with 20 overs left. Some ferocious hitting got him to 83 with one ball of the innings remaining. "Marcus ran it off the bottom edge to the keeper, and they ran one," recalls his dad. "The keeper shied at the stumps, and missed, and they ran an overthrow. So Marcus finished 85 not out."

Zim players double their money

Zimbabwe's dominance in the early part of the one-day series may owe something to the fact that, of the three teams, they have the sharpest financial incentive to do well. Under a hitherto unknown bonus scheme introduced this year, the Zimbabweans' match fees are doubled if they win a Test or one-dayer. If they win the one-day final - for which they have already qualified - match fees for that game will be trebled.

Strong incentives for individual performances have also been introduced. These apply to any player reaching 50, taking three wickets or three catches in a Test or one-day innings, and are increased for those reaching other landmarks (a century, five wickets etc). David Ellman-Brown, chief executive of the Zimbabwe Cricket Union, says: "We believe that team and individual bonuses help maximise performance."

It's true, of course, that the tourists are being paid a good deal less than they'd like for the three-month trip to England, and that the early weeks were disrupted by a bitter pay dispute with the ZCU. Ellman-Brown says his players are being paid much more than the reported £3000 basic for the tour, though he won't disclose figures. Nor will he say how much extra the average player has so far earned in performance-related bonuses.

Those three straight wins also ensured Zimbabwe a clean sweep of the prize money available in the first few games: £30,000 (£10,000 per victory) plus £4500 for three Player of the Match Awards (£1500 each). That's very big money in their terms.

England and West Indies still have a strong incentive to turn things round. Not only is there that prize money on offer, but England are on a team bonus from the ECB of £10,000 per win in the qualifying stages, with an extra £70,000 for a tournament victory.

West Indies pick up no bonuses for qualifying wins, but a series victory would bring their players US$50,000 (£33,333) from the tour sponsors. And don't forget that whichever of the three teams wins the tournament will collect an additional £20,000 in prize money.

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). You can e-mail him at cdelisle@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Byers approves ITV merger plan
fields.trailText: Trade Secretary Stephen Byers today approved a merger between TV giants Carlton Communications and United News and Media.
fields.body:
Trade Secretary Stephen Byers today approved a merger between TV giants Carlton Communications and United News and Media.

He also gave the go-ahead for Granada Media to mount a buy-up bid for either of the two other companies. The long-awaited announcement potentially paves the way for the eventual creation of a single company to run the whole ITV network.

Mr Byers' decision to allow the proposed Granada deals comes after they were cleared in principle by the Competition Commission. But he ruled in favour of a UNM-Carlton merger despite the commission's fears that this could be expected to operate against the public interest.

For this reason, Mr Byers said such a merger could go ahead only on condition that UNM disposed of its franchise for the Meridian region within six months of the date of completion of the deal. He has asked the director general of fair trading to obtain that undertaking.

Today's rulings come eight months after Carlton and UNM surprised the UK media industry by announcing an agreed, nil-premium £8.3bn merger.

After Granada promptly revealed it was interested in buying either of the two other companies, the commission was asked to investigate the desirability of one or all of the deals.

Publishing the commission's report today, Mr Byers said: "The UK media scene has changed radically since the early 1990s.

"It is important that we allow ITV to develop in a way which allows it to compete effectively in an increasingly diverse market.

"My decisions today should ensure that there is effective competition in the ITV sector, protecting the interests of viewers, advertisers and programme-makers."

A Department of Trade and Industry spokesman later clarified the situation, explaining that today's decision on Granada's position would allow it to bid for either Carlton or UNM. But if a merger between the latter two took place first, Granada had not been given the go-ahead to bid for a new joint company.

fields.headline: Spielberg to tackle Holocaust again
fields.trailText: Steven Spielberg, together with documentary film-maker James Moll, has assembled a group of international directors to make a series of documentaries about the Holocaust set in five countries
fields.body:
Steven Spielberg is to work again on the Holocaust. Following 1993's Oscar-winning Schindler's List, the director, together with documentary film-maker James Moll, has assembled a group of international directors to make a series of films about the Holocaust set in five countries.

As chairman and founder of the Shoah Foundation, which maintains an archive of testimonies of Holocaust survivors, Spielberg's work has been crucially important in terms of maintaining and heightening awareness of the horrors of the second world war, particularly the Holocaust.

Produced under the auspices of the Shoah Visual History Foundation, the one-hour television documentaries will be shown in Poland, Argentina, the Czech Republic, Russia, and Hungary. Distribution is planned for the television and educational video markets in each of the five countries in 2001.

The documentaries will be comprised largely of Holocaust survivor testimonies from the Shoah Foundation archive in the language native to each of the five countries.

According to Spielberg, the project came about "in response to many demands from educators all over the world to teach the history of the Holocaust, confront Holocaust deniers and racial hatred."

fields.headline: Morgan Freeman - part three
fields.trailText: Part three of the Morgan Freeman interview at BFI Southbank
fields.body:
Questions from the audience On being thought of as the perfect Abraham Lincoln | going back to theatre | Working with Neil LaBute | Working with Gene Hackman | On seeing himself on screen | Who he'd like to work with | The Patriot | Oscar politics | His favourite films | Other roles within the film world | Comedy | On playing Nelson Mandela | Might he play a pimp again? | Reactions to Glory | Filming long takes | Why he choose not to star in Bopha! | The work he is most proud of

RJ: I think that this is a pretty good time to bring some people in, I am sure that a lot of you have some questions.

Q1: An American critic recently wrote that you would be the perfect casting for Abraham Lincoln. Apart from the gravitas and the dignity, what sort of essential American qualities do you think he saw in you?

MF: How can you say apart from the gravitas and the dignity because that's all he means?! I am not sure how he got from wherever he got from to Abraham Lincoln, but I don't even know how, I can't even begin to answer.

Q1: Do you think there is anything specifically American in you that he sees?

MF: Well, no. Because I don't have any other experience, I've travelled a lot, but I am essentially American. All my input has been American, it has not been Abraham Lincoln. I don't have the same feeling about Abraham Lincoln as you might do.

RJ: You're a pretty good president in Deep Impact, you know, that moment when you say 'Hello America' I believed you.

Q2: Can you imagine any situation where you might go back on the stage?

MF: Yeah. I can imagine a situation.

Q2: And could you explain what the situation might be?

MF: Well we are constantly looking for something new to do. I've always said I wanted to do King Lear and I was at one point going to do it at the Shakespeare Festival, in the park. That was the last play I did, Shakespeare. Now, I've been doing movies non-stop for years and I'm getting what actors seem to get - lazy. Stage is really hard work. You've got to do it every night. Not like doing it once and walking away. If you do it, you've got to commit at least six months to it [makes snoring sound]. So, if a good, new - y'know Driving Miss Daisy was a play, first. I saw it even before it was written - I was at Playwright's Horizon to see another play and on their little calendar was a little blurb about coming events. The coming event was this play by Alfred Uhry about a Jewish woman and her chauffeur in Atlanta, periods of 1960 to whatever, over a period of 25 years. And I thought: "Oh, that looks good" and it came to pass that I did that. Something new, something exciting, I think that is what I would be drawn back by.

RJ: He's just worked with the playwright Neil LaBute, people think of him as a film-maker, but he is essentially a playwright before he was a film-maker. The director of A Company of Men and Friends and Neighbors. In his new piece [Nurse Betty], which is something very special. Give us an indication of what he was like to work with - because he didn't write this, did he?

MF: Neil has been like a kind of teddy bear. He is kind of a large man and he's warm, cuddly and huggable.

RJ: That's not very evident in his work

MF: No, it's not. But he's sort of a minch. Is that the right word? He's easy going, he doesn't tense up about stuff. There's a sense of smooth, easy, lots of laughs. When we're kicking back and having fun, we're doing the work. It's flowing. I loved him. I have this feeling for him. I have seen two of his movies - and ooph. But this movie was kind of a departure, but in the same kind of dark vein that he likes to work in. I'm an easy lay, I guess I can say that.

Q3: Have you any plans to work with Gene Hackman again? - the two of you on screen blows my mind.

MF: We don't make plans. All actors say, "Let's do it again," but the chances are slim, or none that you will do it again, but it does happen. We do move round in circles like that and sometimes we intersect again. And of course if the opportunity ever presents itself, Gene and I will doubtless leap at it.

Q4: What was it like to see yourself on screen for the first time? [ sound clip 6 ]

MF: Good question. The answer is not what you think. I pretty much cut my teeth, that is, I grew up on the stage. The big difference is that on the stage I see me through you. I see me through the audience. You are my reflection of my work and I always walk away from the theatre expanded. I'm fantastic, I'm really good. Then you do a film. And now you see yourself and you're not so good. I thought I looked better than that, now you all become liars, I cannot trust you, because I know. The big fear is that one day, you're going to know.

MF: That was a good answer, wasn't it? It was the truth. I cannot stand watching myself. I can, y'know, it's not nearly the same. It's humbling to watch yourself, to see yourself up there.

Q4: Are you talking about performance or your grey hair?

MF: I am talking about everything - the performance, what I look like - I don't have to look, if I stand up and some lady goes: "Ooh". My whole thing changes. . .

Q5: Is there anyone that you really want to work with that you've missed?

MF: Oh yeah. Anybody. I don't want to call out any names because I may leave out the main ones, but whomever that you can think of that I have not worked with is who I want to work with.

Q6:</B There's a lot of noise in the UK at the moment about the movie The Patriot - any thoughts?

MF: I haven't seen it and I don't know anything about it.

Q7: Is there any politics involved as to why you were nominated for an Oscar for Shawshank but didn't get it? [ sound clip 7 ]

MF: No. No politics or stories at all. The problem with the Academy Awards, and to me it's a big problem, is that if you don't win it, you lose it. I think in all cases, the Academy - you've got a vote and sometimes you can't really separate it. So you might toss a coin. You might go on the fact that you know this actor longer than you know that one. You might go on the fact that you've seen this one in more pictures. I don't think it has anything to do with race.

Q8: What are your favourite films?

MF: I don't know, Riders of the Purple Sage. Anything. I think I was maybe 15 years old when I saw John Wayne as Kurt Evans in Angel and the Badman. I don't like John Wayne today, but when I was 15, he was what was happening to me. The first movie that I remember was King Kong. It always has this mythic place in my memory. Moby Dick was a book I read, one of the two books I read, that turned into a movie that was as good, but I wasn't a child then. When I went to movies when I was a kid, I had people I liked and whatever those people were in. . . and those people: Jay Maynard, John Macbrown, Jimmy Wakely - do you know who these people were? My point. But they were Saturday cowboys. (Makes shooting noises), that was the soundtrack, man. Horses never walked, they would run all day. Six-shooters could shoot 18 times.

RJ: What were you saying yesterday that there were movies you really liked?

MF: Dead Man Walking, American Beauty - anything I was in.

RJ: Enough of that.

Q9: Aside from directing and acting, is there any other part of film-making you would like to do? Costume?

RJ: Is it time for Morgan Freeman the costume maker? That is a great question!

MF: You got close, I married one. No, I'm sidling, inching, into producing. Which will be an easy move for me because I have this incredible partner who was really born to produce, so I just sort of tag along with her and get credit. That's if I have any other career. . . I am probably going to move further and further into that aspect of it.

RJ: I even saw that you're producing the new David Fincher movie. Big hundred million dollar sci-fi flick.

Q10: Are you going to do some comedy? 'Cause you're really funny!

MF: My dignity. . . My persona as a dignified, wise, fatherly (grandfatherly perhaps) doesn't lend itself in that direction - so first comedy chance I get of course, I'll be right out there. I think my next movie [Nurse Betty] might be billed as comedy.

RJ: It's a two-hander - with Chris Rock, and a must-see.

Q11: Have you met Nelson Mandela, and how do you feel about playing him?

MF: Yes I have and Mr Mandela and I have a pact that whenever we are within a thousand miles of each other that we will get together because I need to spend as much quality time with him before I play him on film. I need to know him very well, and he understands that and so we get together as often as we can. We just had dinner in Washington DC about a month ago - the other part of your question was what?

Q11: How do you feel about playing him?

MF: Oh, I'm honoured and terrified that I won't live up to the job of really presenting this man. Ben Kingsley as Ghandi sort of bench-marked that for us. If you don't do at least that good, maybe you should stay at home. So. . . it's a serious challenge, but I am really looking forward to it. One of the best directors around is going to direct it, [Elizabeth director] Shekhar Kapur, so I think we're going to come out of that alright.

Q12: The character in Street Smart [a pimp]- do you think you'll ever do a character like that again?

MF: I'll never do that one again. No. [ sound clip 8 ] The problem that finding something like that, you know what happened behind Street Smart is that every script that I got after that was like, that. People say, if you do something well, then the people who send you scripts say 'This is right up your alley, this is what you do well'. It's a strange kind of compliment, because it really isn't a compliment. That's not what I do well, I do everything well. I mean, I'm an actor. That's not me, don't send me a script saying 'I wrote this with you in mind'. No you didn't. You wrote it with a character in mind. Maybe something you saw me do, but it's not me. So don't do that. Write a script and say that maybe you'd like Morgan Freeman to try and play this - but you can't write it with me in mind.

Q13: Are there any more characters you'd like to play?

MF: No, I've done it. That's it, I'm over. What do you mean?

Q13: Is there anyone else you'd like to portray?

MF: Oh, is there an Abraham Lincoln somewhere in my future? After Mandela you mean? He wrote a book about his thing and he said that he would like for me to play it. Will it happen again? I don't know. I am not dying to play just historical characters, but I do very much like historical material because I think that I for instance, know that I am informed about history through books and movies. You can teach me more I have some concept of, having seen it in the movies or read about it in a book, than you can if I have not. The danger is always that in Hollywood we tend to rewrite history to match what we need to say. Which means that it's no longer history, it's somebody's fiction. But pictures like Glory, where we strove mightily to be accurate, I think are important and I like to do those.

RJ: You're also going through a period where you're making choices which are way out there, I mean, working with Neil LaBute is a new kind of challenge and you're both distinguished. . . and I don't think that anyone believed what I was saying earlier about the character in Moist, which in itself tells you quite a lot about the movie, doesn't it? Can you tell us what that character is, in Moist.

MF: It's a wonderful concept. The character that I play is an international thief. Right now he's busy stealing sperm and eggs because people are stock-piling it for later use and so if there was a millionaire who wants, for instance, Richard's sperm, and I know that he's got some stored up. . . I could get it for you wholesale. That's the premise of the movie.

Q14: I teach American History and I try to use Glory but I often get quite negative reactions from parents and administrators (because of the violence of the battle scenes) - do you have any advice as to what I can say to them?

MF: 'Yes Sir' or 'Yes Ma'am'. The kids will go back and they will slow it down when they get home or y'know. There may be differing reasons why parents would not want them to see that, other than the ones you and I would jump at.

Q15: It says in our programme notes that you did long takes (of seven or eight minutes) for Under Suspicion. Is that for real, and was it hard work?

MF: That's for real and because it's dialogue driven, it was easy to do like that. Because Under Suspicion is essentially a play, they don't need a lot of cuts and uh - We're aware that there is a lot of close-ups in films by people who've done television. Small screens seem to demand that immediacy, whereas a film doesn't, a film can sustain a tableau. If you have a scene that you can choreograph as a tableau so that the scene is seamless; then, number one, you're going to save time and time is money; and number two, you're going to be more immediate in your story without a lot of jumps and things. And I think it's helpful, did you find it that way? Yes.

Q16: Why did you choose not to star in Bopha! as well as directing?

MF: Number one, I felt very strongly that Danny Glover was the better choice of actor for the role. I am not one who thinks he can do everything and survive, and that was the case for Bopha! Number two, I was not ready to try to direct myself in my first effort at directing. I didn't want to. It's very difficult, I think. Well, that's primarily it. I didn't want to play the lead. If I hadn't directed, I wouldn't have played the role.

RJ: If I can ask one final question - of all your body of work, what's the one that you're most proud of? I know you feel very good about a lot that you've made, you've made that very clear tonight, but -

MF: Most proud of Glory. My favourite character is in Street Smart and everything else is just work. I'm not downplaying it, it's y'know -

RJ: You can look at a lot of other actor's careers, and you could say, I mean, Gene Hackman, I'm obviously a huge fan of, but you look at some of the choices that Gene's made and you think, 'What was he thinking about doing this film?' He's never bad in those films, 'cause he's too good. But he's made some seriously weird choices of movies - I mean he's been in some real crap.

MF: I think you can punch Gene Hackman right along with Michael Caine. Michael says, 'It's work and I'm an actor, so, sure, I'll do it'. It's a paycheque. And like you say, they're never bad, so why not?

RJ: But you never regarded it in that way?

MF: No, if I hate the script I'm never going to get past that fact. No.

RJ: Do you think you're still pushing the boat out, do you think you've learnt new things, you're trying new things still?

MF: I'm always trying new things and learning new things. Once you think you've got it all, you should lie down. If there isn't anything more you can learn - go off and die.

RJ: Don't do that on us, because I think we've had a pretty amazing evening in your company tonight and I think it's been a great honour sharing the stage with you.

MF: You've all been, let me tell you, extraordinarily wonderful. Laughed at all my little jokes.

Sound clips

 "The big mistake was Driving Miss Daisy" (2mins 06)
 "You're never going to get away from being a black actor" (1 min)
 "Method is a misnomer" (41 seconds)
 On Somerset in Se7en (1min 19)
 On working with Eastwood in Unforgiven (1min 14)
 "On screen I see me through the audience" (1min 19)
 "The problem with the Oscars is that if you don't win, you lose" (34 seconds)
 "I do everything well, I mean, I'm an actor" (51 seconds)

fields.headline: Video roundup
fields.standfirst: The Limey | Music of the Heart | A Walk on the Moon
fields.trailText: The Limey | Music of the Heart | A Walk on the Moon
fields.body:
The Limey
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
FilmFour/VCI Cert 18
***

Steven Soderbergh sends Terence Stamp to California to avenge the death of his daughter in an enjoyable, if rather self-conscious, gangster movie that would be a film noir if it weren't for all that sun.

Tel stays as cockney as ever, baffling laidback Angelenos with his talk of "tea leaves" and "my old China" (there's even a "blimey"). His quarry is smooth rock promoter Peter Fonda, his daughter's lover when she died. Stamp needs to know what happened and will stop at nothing to find out - pointedly, the film's opening music is the Who's The Seeker.

The Limey provides so many forcible reminders of a range of old movies that it's more like a film studies class than an original work. Into the mix go Get Carter and Point Blank (uncouth hard man forces way into world of dodgy rich blokes); The Hit, which had Stamp as an existential old villain at its core; Poor Cow, which is used for flashbacks of the young Stamp, including Stamp sings Donovan; and any early 70s Nic Roeg film for its structure mixing flashbacks, flash- forwards and scenes that may be reality or may be happening only in the imagination.

Since Stamp is seen shooting people who are alive in the next scene, the whole film could be read as an elaborate revenge fantasy in the mind of a man made mad by grief. The Limey is agreeably lean, mean and tense but it seems a bit insubstantial too - we don't know a lot more about any of its characters by the end, so it's hard to care much.

Music of the Heart
Rental
Buena Vista Cert PG
***

Could anything look less like a Wes Craven sleeve than the above? It is, though. The godfather of slasherdom could hardly get further from his usual genre than this feelgood tale in the rather dodgy genre of white middle-class women winning over inner-city kids to education.

Most recently Michelle Pfeiffer was winning young hearts in Dangerous Minds. Here, it's Meryl Streep, as a violin teacher in Harlem. I realise this sounds terrible, but against all odds, Streep largely pulls it off with a hyper performance. There's nothing saintly about this tough, tyrannical character, an abandoned wife with two sons who starts teaching out of sheer necessity, but it's hard to think of a part where Streep is so likeable.

She makes the story at least half-believable, with fine support from Angela Bassett. The story is based on fact and previously inspired an Oscar-nominated documentary. The film is keen to activate your tear ducts, but boasts a pretty good script and some nicely-timed comedy payoffs too.

A Walk on the Moon
Rental
Paramount Cert 15
**

A modestly pleasant drama about a woman (Diane Lane) torn between hubby and kids and a freewheeling stranger. It's set in 1969 and aligns its story to the social changes of the time, with heavy over-emphasis. So Lane's first infidelity takes place while the moon landings are on TV (jumping on virgin territory and all that) and their first serious date is a trip to the Woodstock rock festival.

All this makes a violent contrast to the routine Jewish summer holiday from New York to the Catskills in a cosy, old- fashioned resort with cheesy comics onstage while hubby - Liev Schreiber, better known as Cotton Weary, one of the few to survive from Scream 1 to 3 - stays home to mind his TV repair business. To muddy the waters further, embarrassed daughter Anna Paquin - of The Piano fame - is contemplating her first sexual encounter.

First-time director Tony Goldwyn (grandson of Sam) is clearly in favour of letting a little colour and excitement into these humdrum lives. Sex and colour seem as inextricable here as in Pleasantville - Viggo Mortensen's tempting itinerant makes a living selling bright blouses and the couple's Woodstock experience is a welter of tie-dye and face paint. The implication is that straight man Schreiber is going to have to get hip to Hendrix and Dylan or he's history. Soap opera material but played with conviction.

The Limey is agreeably lean, mean and tense but it seems a bit insubstantial too - we don't know a lot more about any of its characters by the end, so it's hard to care much. Music of the Heart Rental Buena Vista Cert PG *** Could anything look less like a Wes Craven sleeve than the above? It is, though. The godfather of slasherdom could hardly get further from his usual genre than this feelgood tale in the rather dodgy genre of white middle-class women winning over inner-city kids to education. Most recently Michelle Pfeiffer was winning young hearts in Dangerous Minds. Here, it's Meryl Streep, as a violin teacher in Harlem. I realise this sounds terrible, but against all odds, Streep largely pulls it off with a hyper performance. There's nothing saintly about this tough, tyrannical character, an abandoned wife with two sons who starts teaching out of sheer necessity, but it's hard to think of a part where Streep is so likeable. She makes the story at least half-believable, with fine support from Angela Bassett. The story is based on fact and previously inspired an Oscar-nominated documentary. The film is keen to activate your tear ducts, but boasts a pretty good script and some nicely-timed comedy payoffs too. A Walk on the Moon Rental Paramount Cert 15 ** A modestly pleasant drama about a woman (Diane Lane) torn between hubby and kids and a freewheeling stranger. It's set in 1969 and aligns its story to the social changes of the time, with heavy over-emphasis. So Lane's first infidelity takes place while the moon landings are on TV (jumping on virgin territory and all that) and their first serious date is a trip to the Woodstock rock festival. All this makes a violent contrast to the routine Jewish summer holiday from New York to the Catskills in a cosy, old- fashioned resort with cheesy comics onstage while hubby - Liev Schreiber, better known as Cotton Weary, one of the few to survive from Scream 1 to 3 - stays home to mind his TV repair business. To muddy the waters further, embarrassed daughter Anna Paquin - of The Piano fame - is contemplating her first sexual encounter. First-time director Tony Goldwyn (grandson of Sam) is clearly in favour of letting a little colour and excitement into these humdrum lives. Sex and colour seem as inextricable here as in Pleasantville - Viggo Mortensen's tempting itinerant makes a living selling bright blouses and the couple's Woodstock experience is a welter of tie-dye and face paint. The implication is that straight man Schreiber is going to have to get hip to Hendrix and Dylan or he's history. Soap opera material but played with conviction.

webTitle: What a way to run a railway

fields.headline: What a way to run a railway
fields.standfirst:
Railtrack chief apologises for 'truly dreadful' disruption but says Britain suffers from the wrong kind of weather

Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, yesterday accepted responsibility for huge delays caused by its "truly dreadful'' £5.8bn upgrade of the west coast main line. The delays caused by work on the approach to Euston station in London are causing disruption up the line as far as Glasgow, particularly at weekends. Railtrack faces legal action from Virgin Trains and other train operators to recoup up to £10m.
fields.body:
Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, yesterday accepted responsibility for huge delays caused by its "truly dreadful'' £5.8bn upgrade of the west coast main line. The delays caused by work on the approach to Euston station in London are causing disruption up the line as far as Glasgow, particularly at weekends. Railtrack faces legal action from Virgin Trains and other train operators to recoup up to £10m.

Making his grovelling apology to thousands of listeners to the BBC's Today programme, Mr Corbett said: "I'm afraid it's been truly dreadful, and it has been largely down to us and our contractors. We are trying to do a hell of a lot of work and the way we have been doing it has not been good enough. I am very sorry about that.'' Mr Corbett's confession came as the shadow strategic rail authority released nationwide figures showing that train punctuality is getting worse: 80% of the 25 rail companies ran a worse service between April and June this year, compared with the same three months last year.

Mike Grant, the SSRA's chief executive, said: "These are disappointing results and demonstrate the urgency of the rail franchise renewal process we are embarking on.'' Mr Corbett was forced into an admission that Railtrack was in a dire plight after bitter criticism from Chris Green, Virgin Trains' chief executive. He said that the work at Euston was rather like having in a builder who randomly switched off electricity, water and gas.

Asked if he was offering any defence, Mr Corbett replied: "No, not really.'' Asked if anybody should be sacked to put the project back on track, he said: "Absolutely. And we have got our best team on the job and we have to get it right, and it's not acceptable.''

The pain is greater for Mr Corbett, who uses the line every day from his home near Berkhamsted, Hertfordshire. "It therefore gives me a particular interest,'' he said. But he declined to offer his own resignation. Mr Green, who has given Railtrack 28 days to come up with plans to rescue the project or face legal action, said: "The level of existing disruption to passengers on existing trains is quite unacceptable, and we've just got to stand up and say so.''

He laid the blame on Railtrack and its contractors. "We don't expect them to be breaking wires, breaking pipes, setting up electrification systems with no electricity in them which then cause massive delays to innocent passengers.''

Mr Corbett praised Railtrack for presenting the Virgin Trains board with a 30- point plan to improve the situation. "If they can, the passengers get a normal railway again. If they can't, I'm afraid it's 'see you in court' because this is really serious stuff.''

Robin Gisby, a Railtrack senior executive, added his apologies but pointed out that Railtrack had been compensating Virgin and other companies by between £8m and £9m for its failures. Over the next month, Virgin could expect to receive an extra £500,000 in compensation.

Virgin said it was mystified by the figures. They did not match up to anything it could understand. Passengers delayed by more than one hour were given a 25% reduction on their next fare and a 100% reduction if the delay was more than two hours.

Climate
Mr Corbett later risked the further wrath of passengers by blaming delays in services on the British climate. Answering questions from shareholders, he said: "The target is to deliver a railway that does not freak out with the weather. We do have the wrong kind of weather. It is the biggest cause of Railtrack's delays."

Reflecting problems caused by continuing fluctuations in the weather, Mr Corbett said: "I am afraid that a terribly wet day can cause problems. Equally very hot days can cause some rails to buckle. On one hot day last month, we had three days' delay in one.''

For good measure, Railtrack also blamed a 34% increase in delays on increasing suicides. The company was unable to say how many, but said that they occurred at "busy times of the day and at busy junctions''.

The annual meeting ended with new horticultural revelations about burgeoning buddleia at the side of railway lines and their threat to safety. It is a problem that is causing Chris Leah, Railtrack's head of safety, sleepless nights. He conceded that British Rail's old style "slash-and-burn'' tactics had been much more successful. BR also used harsher chemicals to get rid of the buddleia scourge, but tighter environmental regulations prevent their use. "We are not removing the buddleia fast enough. We have to do more,'' he said.

fields.headline: Balkan deconstruction
fields.standfirst: Milosevic gets it wrong, again
fields.trailText: As so often in the past, President Slobodan Milosevic's latest attempt to throw his weight around may have the opposite effect to that intended
fields.body:
As so often in the past, President Slobodan Milosevic's latest attempt to throw his weight around may have the opposite effect to that intended. The man who more than any other has re-Balkanised the Balkans is well on the way to completing the task of dismembering Yugoslavia that he began a decade ago. After the departure from the Yugoslav federation of Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Macedonia, and the loss of Kosovo, only rump Serbia and Montenegro remain. The main reason why Montenegro, too, has not already gone its own way is a justified fear that the Belgrade bruiser could react by launching yet another war.

Milo Djukanovic, Montenegro's president, often talks of holding an independence referendum but holds back, worried about the response of federal army units and minority Serbs on his soil and of the Milosevic gang, including ultra-nationalist rowdies like Serbia's deputy prime minister, Vojislav Seselj. Mr Seselj declared this week that the pro-western Mr Djukanovic should be arrested as a traitor. Such wild statements are an invitation to violence. But while the Montenegrin leader is used to threats, there is no denying that tension has risen sharply since Mr Milosevic's parliamentary toadies conspired to fiddle the constitution last week to allow him another term after 2001. This complex gerrymandering also further diminished Montenegro's position relative to Serbia.

Mr Djukanovic's response was robust. He said the changes effectively rendered the Yugoslav federation null and void and that Montenegro would boycott federal elections due this autumn. His republic was being pushed ever closer to independence, he said. "We cannot sacrifice our future to satisfy the aspirations of the dictator in Belgrade to rule forever."

The supposedly crafty Mr Milosevic may well have miscalculated again. His move brought an oblique warning from Nato to back off and proposals from Serbia's opposition parties to join forces with Montenegro. In Dubrovnik this week, the Czech, Croatian and Slovenian presidents gave Mr Djukanovic an unusual show of personal support. While backing Montenegro's right to secede, they predicted Mr Milosevic's machinations could backfire and bring down the final curtain on Yugoslavia. If he does eventually flee to Russia, Mr Milosevic could get a job as a demolition expert. But given his track record, he would probably blow himself up.

webTitle: Tell it like it really is

fields.headline: Tell it like it really is
fields.standfirst:
If only the government were always as honest and modest as Tony Blair was on Wednesday...

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: If only the government were always as honest and modest as Tony Blair was on Wednesday...
fields.body:
What do you usually do with company annual reports? Straight-to-bin is the normal response. Journalists are connoisseurs of these glossy monstrosities which land on our desks from every business, charity, media organisation, the BBC and even the Guardian Media Group has one too. Just about everyone thinks it necessary these days to lay out their triumphs, complete with fulsome introduction from the chairman (how rarely chairwoman). Some beaming, all-purpose, middle-aged gent in suit astonishes us with the news that, yes, it really has been yet another very good year.

Sadly, the government's annual report is much the same - a glib, misleading, filigree of fact and factoid wrapped up in layers of omission. It has all the credibility of, say, a report from the Robert Maxwell group of companies. It exudes the pleasingly airy unreality of an investment prospectus for some particularly shaky proposed new dot com. How about inyourdreams.UKplc.com? What is this utopia? Where is this magic realm where every citizen is happy, yes really smiling, in every single photograph? Every problem that isn't already solved is just about to be. Will the state soon have to wither away for lack of anything else to do? It is hardly surprising that the print-run has been drastically cut back this year. You just wonder what kind of tin-eared image-maker imagined that anyone could read this stuff and not want to hurl it across the room. The pensioner with 75p? The hard-pressed nurse or teacher? The patient waiting for an operation? It is patronising, dumbed down and reads like a North Korean beetroot crop report. The odd thing about all this is that anyone reading it would hazard a guess that such persiflage must disguise a host of dreadful failures, lapses, gaps and blunders. Not so. That is what's so crazy. The beetroot crop really was quite good. Far more important, beetroot futures are terrific, better than at any time in living memory.

In his spectacularly confident and commanding Downing Street press conference on Wednesday, the prime minister set a very different tone, which had even enemy newspapers full of unaccustomed praise: "By any standards Tony Blair had a remarkable story of success to tell yesterday. . ." (Mail); "Tony Blair turned the political tide. . ." (Standard); "Blair gets a grip" (Sun); "Tony Blair staged a spirited fightback yesterday" (Telegraph). What was it that suddenly had these tigers eating out of his hand? Honest dealing, plain speaking and modesty about the good story he did have to tell. Still so far to go, he kept saying and they liked him all the better for it. He spoke of the future, of plans laid out, schemes afoot. He laid out the scale of the problem on issue after issue, never minimising the mountains to climb. He spoke of investing in the future. It was this theme he returned to yesterday in the Commons: "investment, investment, investment" is now added to his triple education pledge, alongside a repeated commitment to "opportunity for all". All this is convincing because his vision is underpinned by the very large sums of money no one can deny are at last pouring in.

We may believe in the future, but a long list of achievements doesn't convince yet. We see the money but we see few results. A clever and far more honest part of the annual report includes a website where you fill in your post code and it tells you what the situation is on your own home ground. Here you get plain truth: in Lambeth I find six beacon schools doing well and five with "serious weakness". I find only marginally fewer patients waiting for operations while the numbers waiting for their first out-patient appointment has nearly trebled, pretty bad. I find there are fewer policemen than there were in 1997. But on the other hand, 4,400 families are now drawing working families' tax credit, (guaranteeing them at least £214 a week). All this confirms everything I see about me and I believe it. If and when things improve, I shall believe that too. I believe that the economy is going well, because I see signs of spending all around in shops and bars. But I also see signs of desperate poverty. Labour had better be careful about its promises on fairness and opportunity when all the signs are that it would take swingeing great income taxes on the richest to make any effect at all on the gap between rich and poor. Yesterday's official poverty figures made grim reading. Tony Blair speaks powerfully of "Labour's programme of national rejuvenation". But results take time.

The rhetoric must never get ahead of the delivery: a good plan or good money spent is only input. Successful outcome is all that matters to the punter. For example, when the annual report claims "Walk-in centres are sited on the high street, in shopping centres, in pharmacies - anywhere that's convenient for patients", it makes me cross. There is no such thing anywhere in Lambeth, let alone in my high street. Meanwhile my local quite large GP clinic (Clapham Manor Health Centre, just to name and shame) is shut all evenings and weekends. My GP has no appointment free until August 7. I know how often Tony Blair protests at the user-unfriendly NHS: some walk-in centres are opening - but for most patients, so what? Any audience, be it the Tory press or the Women's Institute, can tell at once the difference between honesty and political cant. When Blair penned a dreadful speech to the WI, he got the bird. When, chasing after headlines, he threw out a bit of rubbish penal policy about locking up 4,000 more criminals, it was mocked for transparent opportunism as loudly by the law and order fanatics as by liberals. But when he threw himself open to any amount of questions, no prepared text, just straight eye-to-eye answers, he got well-deserved praise. The political speech, the manifesto, the annual report - they are all vain, boastful, intellectually insulting forms of discourse. Once off the set text, no politician dares use those pompous, high-flown phrases. That hollow moralising would make anyone blush in ordinary conversation. The election campaign has begun, the call to arms was sounded this week. On one side the Tory tax-cutting strategy is shaping up nicely to create a genuine ideological battle between the two sides. Theirs will be that old, low appeal to base wallets and handbags, a quick bribe and the devil take the hindmost: it has proven pulling power. On the other side Blair offers an inspiring vision of long-term social investment in the future. However, even on election day it may still be more promise than resounding delivery. Blair will need every ounce of trust he can muster, not to be squandered on unconvincing speeches or policies. Alastair Campbell says in Michael Cockerell's documentary tomorrow night: "Over time, believe me, the real message of this government is going to get out, the real record of this government is going to get out." But from now on the message has to be low-key until people can see it all around them with their own eyes.

fields.headline: WorldCom abandons merger with Sprint
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: WorldCom, America's second biggest long-distance call carrier, abandoned its $120bn (£80bn) merger with rival Sprint yesterday after regulatory and court challenges threatened to torpedo the deal. The collapse of the merger paves the way for Deutsche Telekom to make a bid for Sprint, in which it has a 10% stake.
fields.body:
WorldCom, America's second biggest long-distance call carrier, abandoned its $120bn (£80bn) merger with rival Sprint yesterday after regulatory and court challenges threatened to torpedo the deal. The collapse of the merger paves the way for Deutsche Telekom to make a bid for Sprint, in which it has a 10% stake.

Ron Sommer, chief executive of Deutsche Telekom, has said the German group's strategy as making its presence in the US as big as its operations across Europe. WorldCom and Sprint were forced to abort their merger because of demands by the US justice department to divest Sprint's internet, long-distance and local telephone operations, leaving it only the mobile phone division. A day later the deal was further knocked back by Mario Monti, the European competition commissioner.

WorldCom said the demands made by the US justice department would have eliminated the customer benefits and "financial synergies" which supported the proposal. Bernie Ebbers, chief executive of WorldCom, said: "We very much regret that our merger with Sprint was not allowed to proceed. The benefits of this merger were clear and compelling."

Sprint is the third largest long distance carrier in America and together with WorldCom and AT&T the companies control 80% of that market. Regulators were concerned the merger would lead to less innovation and higher prices.

Regulators were concerned the merger would lead to less innovation and higher prices.

webTitle: It's cool to make money, but not to be frank about it

fields.headline: It's cool to make money, but not to be frank about it
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: In early 1995, life looked good for young Mathieu Nouzareth. He had just completed an MBA in the US on an exchange programme from university in Grenoble and had landed a job with a multimedia business start-up in New York. Then one day a new chief executive was appointed. By the end of the week Nouzareth and everyone else in the company had been fired.
fields.body:
In early 1995, life looked good for young Mathieu Nouzareth. He had just completed an MBA in the US on an exchange programme from university in Grenoble and had landed a job with a multimedia business start-up in New York. Then one day a new chief executive was appointed. By the end of the week Nouzareth and everyone else in the company had been fired.

"That's where I really got in touch with the American way of doing business," he says. So it was back to Paris with no job and no money - only a desire to sell the internet to a nation which regarded it as anything between a passing fad and another demonstration of American economic imperialism.

The 23-year-old 's first move was to join forces with his younger brother, Romain, 20. Together they set up a company, Web Concept, creating websites for others. It was an uphill struggle. "We had no money and for the first five or six months we used my brother's flat (the younger Nouzareth was still a law student) in Paris. The banks did not want to give us money, neither did the venture capitalists." Faced with a struggle against indifference, ignorance or outright hostility, the Nouzareth brothers got used to being seen as more than slightly crazy. But they persevered. "It was only in 1997 that things really took off for us. For two years it was really tough; not having any experience we made lots of mistakes." He recalls working 80 to 100 hours a week.

Although Nouzareth does not put a precise moment on the breakthrough, he notes that in 1997 the company was beginning to drag in orders from some of corporate France's biggest names. The brothers were on their way. Within two years the business had been sold to the Swedish firm Icon Medialab. Nouzareth will not disclose the purchase price but acknowledges that, though he continues to run the business for Icon, he has no need to work again.

"But what would I do? I am 28 years old. If I did not work I would grow bored very quickly." But in the new France is money, the making of money - even in large quantities - still a taboo subject? Nouzareth, a big, friendly, slightly shambling man with still the hint of a schoolboy air, grows reflective.

When Web Concept was sold to Icon, Nouzareth said he was afraid people would be very negative. After all, the French attitude to someone who makes a lot of money is that it cannot have been earned honestly. "In fact, every one was very happy for us. People said we had worked hard and that we deserved it," he says. But since the dot.com world has run into turbulence Nouzareth detects a change in some attitudes. "It's not that cool any more."

But does that mean France is locked in a world where money-making remains a cause for suspicion? Nouzareth thinks things are changing, though slowly. "The older generation are still of the old mindset: that money is bad. But the younger generation thinks much more about making money. A lot of young people see themselves as being entrepreneurs or, if they are not going to be entrepreneurs, then they will work in an entrepreneurial environment."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText:
Rio Grande
(John Ford, 1950)
8pm, Carlton Cinema
The conclusion of Ford's great cavalry trilogy, following Fort Apache and She Wore A Yellow Ribbon. John Wayne leads the troop again, as Colonel Yorke, whose efforts in the Indian wars - rescuing kidnapped children, getting close again to trooper son Claude Jarman Jr and estranged wife Maureen O'Hara - are all to do with affirming family values in the wilderness. And it's also a beautifully staged, highly realistic picture of cavalry life: "suffering and hardship", as Yorke calls it.
fields.body:
Rio Grande
(John Ford, 1950)
8pm, Carlton Cinema
The conclusion of Ford's great cavalry trilogy, following Fort Apache and She Wore A Yellow Ribbon. John Wayne leads the troop again, as Colonel Yorke, whose efforts in the Indian wars - rescuing kidnapped children, getting close again to trooper son Claude Jarman Jr and estranged wife Maureen O'Hara - are all to do with affirming family values in the wilderness. And it's also a beautifully staged, highly realistic picture of cavalry life: "suffering and hardship", as Yorke calls it.

The People Vs Larry Flynt
(Milos Forman, 1996)
10.15pm, FilmFour
The story of porn merchant Larry Flynt's 70s legal battle to win the right to publish his raunchy Hustler mag. Woody Harrelson is dynamite as the Cincinnati stripclub owner heading for a showdown in the Supreme Court, and Love is a big surprise as his wife. The problem is, Forman is just too coy about Flynt's product.

Sphere
(Barry Levinson, 1997)
12midnight, Sky Premier
Another blockbuster from the Michael Crichton factory, with a group of scientists sent to the bottom of the sea to investigate a spacecraft - and inside it, a mysterious sphere. Levinson is less interested in the action and suspense than in the interplay of his stars: Dustin Hoffman's intuitive psychologist; Sharon Stone's highly strung biochemist, and Samuel L Jackson's logically minded mathematician.

Ladybird Ladybird
(Ken Loach, 1994)
2.45am, FilmFour
This is the drum-banging, outraged Loach as in the early Cathy Come Home days, with an unsparing, gruelling account of a Liverpool woman's attempt to hang on to her family and her man in the face of bureaucratic intransigence. In her acting debut, stand-up comedienne Crissy Rock is awesome: raw, real, and bitterly funny, in the best Loach style. Vladimir Vega plays her new partner, a gentle refugee a world away from her previous violent lovers.

fields.headline: Queen's bank is fined £50,000
fields.trailText: Coutts, the Queen's bank, has been fined £50,000 by regulators for mismanagement of its personal equity plan business. The regulator Imro has told Coutts to pay 634 investors a total of £225,000 in compensation for "failing to act with due skill, care and diligence in relation to the administration of its Pep business". The firm will also pay Imro £32,140 costs.
fields.body:
Coutts, the Queen's bank, has been fined £50,000 by regulators for mismanagement of its personal equity plan business. The regulator Imro has told Coutts to pay 634 investors a total of £225,000 in compensation for "failing to act with due skill, care and diligence in relation to the administration of its Pep business". The firm will also pay Imro £32,140 costs.

An Imro official described the fine as "appropriate", explaining: "It is not meant to be punitive but it will reflect the seriousness of the action, for example, how it affected investors and how quickly the company acted to rectify the situation."

Coutts informed Imro in September 1997 when it became aware of the problems. The company said it detected problems dating back to March of that year. Julie Cooper of Coutts said: "It was our own internal compliance team that discovered the problems and alerted Imro. We have since completely restructured the Peps office and have a new management structure in place." Imro said: "The problems were more about bad administration than anything else." It was satisfied Coutts acted quickly to deal with the situation and had taken measures to ensure payments to investors. All payments have been processed.

Charges against the bank included delays in processing applications, late investment of some monthly subscriptions and administrative errors.

Coutts outsourced administration of its Peps business in February 1998. This is the first ruling against the company.

fields.headline: £11bn store failure rocks Japan
fields.trailText: Japan was rocked yesterday by the second biggest corporate failure in its history, prompting fears that a new wave of bankruptcies could kill off the nascent recovery in the world's number two economy.
fields.body:
Japan was rocked yesterday by the second biggest corporate failure in its history, prompting fears that a new wave of bankruptcies could kill off the nascent recovery in the world's number two economy.

Sogo, a large department store chain, filed for bankruptcy with debts of ¥1.87 trillion (£11.6bn), after a planned bailout with taxpayers' money had to be abandoned in the face of intense public opposition. The collapse shook the markets yesterday and pushed down the value of the yen, but analysts said it was a positive sign that Japan is finally getting serious about weeding out its weakest companies.

Sogo is one of Japan's most prestigious firms, with a 170-year history and stores in all of Japan's main cities and 14 overseas branches. But overexpansion during the bubble economy of the late 1980s took it deeper into debt. This did not matter while friendly domestic banks and protectionist bureaucrats ensured a steady stream of top-up loans. But this lifeline ended earlier this year when an American consortium took over one of its biggest lenders, the Shinsei Bank, formerly known as the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan.

To fill the gap, the government drew up a ¥100bn rescue plan that would have been funded with public money. But polls have shown the public is tired of politicians using taxes to rescue badly managed firms. Amid a media backlash and a boycott of Sogo by consumers, government leaders begged the company to voluntarily file for bankruptcy. "There has been growing criticism that our restructuring plans would be tax-funded," said Sogo president Kyoichi Yamada. "This has damaged our corporate image and hurt our business condition."

As well as Sogo's 10,000 employees, the collapse is a blow for unpopular prime minister Yoshiro Mori, who warned yesterday of the dangers of a knock-on effect. "We need to discuss how to prevent a chain reaction of bankruptcies and how we can secure employment for workers," he said. Speculators are focusing on the next possible victims. The Nikkei-225 index fell 305 points, or 1.7% yesterday. Worst hit were banks and ailing construction companies, such as Hazama and Kumagai Gumi, who had been hoping for a public bailout.

Business leaders expressed fears that the high-profile failure could cast a pall over the economy. "We are worried that this could pour cold water over consumer spending," said Toshifumi Suzuki, vice-president of Keidanren, Japan's biggest business group. Political leaders acknowledged that the sudden U-turn over the Sogo bailout will make it difficult for Japan to return to its "convoy system" in which bureaucrats brokered backroom deals to ensure strong firms helped the weak to survive.

webTitle: Life and death on a rubbish dump

fields.headline: Life and death on a rubbish dump
fields.standfirst: Waste land: A despairing survivor of the landslide that killed hundreds
fields.trailText: Nicamor Gacura squashed one more piece of rotting cardboard into a wooden crate already full with similar ripped-up boxes and tied it up with a piece of plastic cord he pulled off a badly punctured bright yellow rubber dinghy.
fields.body:
Nicamor Gacura squashed one more piece of rotting cardboard into a wooden crate already full with similar ripped-up boxes and tied it up with a piece of plastic cord he pulled off a badly punctured bright yellow rubber dinghy.

"This feels like it is at least 60 kilos," he said, lifting it up. That means another 60 pesos [90p] for us."

The "us" is his team of seven other rag-clad scavengers who have earned the right to trawl one tiny area of the enormous Payatas rubbish dump, a stench of an eyesore on the north-eastern edge of metro Manila that takes more than a third of the Philippine capital's daily waste.

Home to 20,000 scavengers and supporting a community five times that number, Payatas has become a national symbol of the nation's massive poverty crisis. And it is a problem that is growing at a rate of several thousand tonnes of waste a day.

Mr Gacura's motley crew consists of two other men, one woman and four boys, the youngest of whom, known as Knock-Knock, is only seven years old. Their allotted patch is about three-quarters of the way up one side of the 70ft- high mountain of refuse that covers an area larger than three football fields.

"If we go far outside our area we are likely to get mugged," said team member Rico, 14, who reckons he has had a total of about two terms of formal schooling. "There is a strict hierarchy here and everyone has to respect it."

In an average 10-hour day they will fill about six crates of cardboard, several sacks of plastic mineral water bottles and aluminium cans that sell for 32 cents each, and anything else they can get their hands on.

"From time to time we might find some money and very occasionally we come across some jewellery," Mr Gacura said. "But our most common luxury item is copper wire." This goes for 40 pesos a kilo with the plastic coating removed or half that with it still on. The plastic is removed by burning it off, a process that creates a haze of toxic smoke.

The team's daily takings, which usually come to about 1,000 pesos, are divided proportionally, depending on who has done the most work.

Knock-Knock did not make much money yesterday: he was more interested in playing with a small Power Ranger-type doll that he had found coated in rotting vegetables. He did not care at all that the figure had lost one arm and half a leg, and was missing its helmet.

This week has been anything but normal, however. At 7am on Monday morning, the team, bleary-eyed after a relatively unproductive night shift, was just about to head home when disaster struck. "We heard a noise like a low-flying aeroplane and then realised that the dump was moving," Mr Gacura said.

Within seconds it was obvious that a massive landslide of rubbish was beginning.

"There was nothing we could do except watch in fear as this huge section of the dump collapsed onto our homes," he said. "If we had not been working the night shift, we would have been killed. The family in the next-door house, who were just about to start work, were all killed." People who were awake fled with whatever valuables they could carry. Norma de Lara, 22, has moved into a 5ft by 4ft hut in Mr Gacura's team's patch with the four teenage children of her husband's first marriage. They have no spare clothes, bedding, plates, pots or pans; but they do have a second-hand TV, a battered stereo and a Mickey Mouse clock stuck at 10.30. "When I'm no longer in such shock, I'm going to sell the stereo," said Mrs de Lara, who is five months pregnant.

"I hope I will be able to hang on to the TV."

No one knows how many people died in the tragedy. The official death toll last night was 150, with 173 listed as missing, but most witnesses say this is just a fraction of the number that perished as many of the scavengers were not registered with the authorities. "I reckon more than 1,000 people must have been killed," said Henry Pugao, whose house used to be 60ft from the rubbish but is now right next to it.

"The houses were so tightly packed together and they were full of children because there was no school that day because of a one-day general strike."

It is easy to believe his estimate. Despite working round the clock, the rescuers' half-dozen excavators have barely reached the remains of the flimsy shanties made out of little more than wooden planks and corrugated iron, let alone the bodies buried inside them.

"We are not expecting to find any more survivors," said Colonel Jaime Canatoy, in charge of the 300 soldiers leading the rescue efforts. "There is so much methane gas in this garbage that anyone under there must be dead by now. But there are always miracles."

The methane is a serious health hazard. Out of nowhere a plume of it will suddenly emerge from the dump and make its way skywards. "Inhaling it won't kill you but it is not pleasant," Mr Gacura said.

While the gas is not an instant killer, it is one of the factors that has reduced the scavengers' life expectancy from 54 to 48. Respiratory problems, diarrhoea, skin infections, TB and malnutrition are all part of everyday life, although Mr Gacura, who has lived on the dump for six years, says he now barely notices that he is permanently ill.

"It's like the smell," he said. "When we first arrived it was a real problem. But now we are used to it. We just have to get on with life as best we can." Despite being sick all the time, Mr Gacura does not regret leaving his job as a construction labourer and moving to the dump. "Here I have no boss, I can work when I want and I am guaranteed cash in my hand every day. Back then I was only paid once a week and it was much harder to manage the money." He and his team are among the lowest of the low at Payatas. Whenever another truck full of rubbish arrives on the dump they look enviously at the people rummaging around in the back. "That's the next step up," he says. "Those guys get first pick of the rubbish so they usually get the best stuff. We have to take what they don't want."

Even further up the food chain are people such as Edita de la Questa, who run the dump's junk shops, a euphemism for the wholesalers who process what people such as Mr Gacura and his team collect.

"I used to be a scavenger," she said, "but then in 1994 I heard a knock on my door. It was a priest asking me if I wanted to join a credit scheme run by the Catholic church." Her first loan, of 4,000 pesos (£60), took two years to repay. Since then she has gone from strength to strength in selling the rubbish at an 80% mark-up to recycling factories and has just taken out a loan for 250,000 pesos.

ot only is Mrs de la Questa a member of the credit union, she has also joined the Payatas Waste Pickers Development Project. This group makes handicrafts and other products out of the rubbish. They have been so successful that they were asked to showcase their goods at Expo 2000, currently taking place in Hanover. Unfortunately the project could not raise the funds to send anyone there.

Like everyone else making a livelihood out of the rubbish, Mrs de la Questa is terrified about the consequences of the landslide. "The mayor has said that the dump will close next Monday while the council assesses whether it should be allowed to stay open. That could take till the end of the year and I only have enough trash to survive for five months."

The authorities are proposing a site five miles away, too far for most of the scavengers to trek to each day. "Let's just wait and see," Mr Gacura said. "Nothing is certain yet. We all hope Payatas will stay open. Without it we have nothing, no money and so no life."
