Respiratory problems, diarrhoea, skin infections, TB and malnutrition are all part of everyday life, although Mr Gacura, who has lived on the dump for six years, says he now barely notices that he is permanently ill. "It's like the smell," he said. "When we first arrived it was a real problem. But now we are used to it. We just have to get on with life as best we can." Despite being sick all the time, Mr Gacura does not regret leaving his job as a construction labourer and moving to the dump. "Here I have no boss, I can work when I want and I am guaranteed cash in my hand every day. Back then I was only paid once a week and it was much harder to manage the money." He and his team are among the lowest of the low at Payatas. Whenever another truck full of rubbish arrives on the dump they look enviously at the people rummaging around in the back. "That's the next step up," he says. "Those guys get first pick of the rubbish so they usually get the best stuff. We have to take what they don't want." Even further up the food chain are people such as Edita de la Questa, who run the dump's junk shops, a euphemism for the wholesalers who process what people such as Mr Gacura and his team collect. "I used to be a scavenger," she said, "but then in 1994 I heard a knock on my door. It was a priest asking me if I wanted to join a credit scheme run by the Catholic church." Her first loan, of 4,000 pesos (£60), took two years to repay. Since then she has gone from strength to strength in selling the rubbish at an 80% mark-up to recycling factories and has just taken out a loan for 250,000 pesos. ot only is Mrs de la Questa a member of the credit union, she has also joined the Payatas Waste Pickers Development Project. This group makes handicrafts and other products out of the rubbish. They have been so successful that they were asked to showcase their goods at Expo 2000, currently taking place in Hanover. Unfortunately the project could not raise the funds to send anyone there. Like everyone else making a livelihood out of the rubbish, Mrs de la Questa is terrified about the consequences of the landslide. "The mayor has said that the dump will close next Monday while the council assesses whether it should be allowed to stay open. That could take till the end of the year and I only have enough trash to survive for five months." The authorities are proposing a site five miles away, too far for most of the scavengers to trek to each day. "Let's just wait and see," Mr Gacura said. "Nothing is certain yet. We all hope Payatas will stay open. Without it we have nothing, no money and so no life."

webTitle: Putin picks off opponents who matter most wages partial war on corruption

fields.headline: Putin picks off opponents who matter most wages partial war on corruption
fields.trailText: It has been an alarming week for Russia's powerful business oligarchy, stunned by an explosion of criminal investigations instigated by President Vladimir Putin.
fields.body:
It has been an alarming week for Russia's powerful business oligarchy, stunned by an explosion of criminal investigations instigated by President Vladimir Putin.

In the space of five days, five of the country's biggest businesses have come under the scrutiny of state agencies, which have begun investigating alleged tax evasion, confiscating documents and examining the legitimacy of lucrative privatisation deals. These activities have brought allegations of creeping authoritarianism in the Kremlin.

Throughout yesterday a sense of nervous expectation reigned as those leading business magnates not yet picked out waited to see who would be the next victim of Mr Putin's new war against Russia's tycoons. Heightening this atmosphere of unease, Vladimir Gusinsky, head of the media group MediaMost who was briefly imprisoned by state prosecutors last month, said that as investigations into his business dealings continued he lived in fear of his life. "In Russia there used to be a police regime. It disappeared temporarily and now it is being rebuilt," he told a Spanish newspaper.

As he campaigned for the presidency earlier this year, Mr Putin gained popular support by promising to crack down on the country's reviled oligarchs: the small group of businessmen who exploited the chaos of Russia's transition to capitalism to turn themselves into millionaires.

This week appeared to be the point at which he put the promise into practice. But as his spotlight turned on MediaMost, the natural gas company Gazprom, the nickel producer Norilsk Nickel, Russia's biggest oil company Lukoil, and its biggest car manufacturing firm Avtovaz, there was growing suspicion that he was acting not against corruption but against political disloyalty.

Analysts described the campaign as extremely selective and some warned that it was a new example of Mr Putin's fondness for a "neo-authoritarian" style of governing. "It's an extremely serious state of affairs when criminal investigations are waged against so many major Russian companies at once," Vyacheslav Nikonov, president of Moscow's Political Foundation, said. "But these figures have been targeted selectively, on the basis of two criteria - their loyalty or disloyalty to the president and their political weight."

The investigation of the alleged embezzlement offences by Mr Gusinsky are seen as an open attack on press freedom. But Mr Gusinsky is not the only figure among those attacked this week who posed a threat. Rem Vyakhirev, the Gazprom chairman, who came under indirect scrutiny during the searches of his building on Tuesday, represents a challenge to the Kremlin administration, not least because of the stake his company holds in MediaMost's NTV. It gives loans which have helped the often vigorously anti-Putin channel to survive. Vagit Alekperov, head of Lukoil, has links with several television stations and a joint stake, with Vladimir Potanin, head of Norilsk Nickel, in the daily paper Izvestiya. Mr Potanin, Mr Vyakhirev, Mr Alekperov all signed a widely publicised letter from Russia's most powerful business figures to the general prosecutor last month, protesting against the arrest of Mr Gusinsky and saying they feared for the future of democracy.

Mr Potanin's name headed the list, and in days the beginnings of the campaign to reverse the privatisation of Norilsk Nickel were launched by Moscow prosecutors. "This is not a struggle against oligarchs as a whole. It is a fight with those figures who are not loyal to the government but who are somehow connected with the opposition," the political analyst Dmitri Furman said. Wednesday's move against Avtovaz seemed at first to undermine this theory. Russia's most notorious oligarch, Boris Berezovsky, has historically had strong links with the car manufacturer and the tax evasion charge seemed to suggest that the anti-oligarch war was being widened to include Kremlin-friendly figures. But Mr Berezovsky's current involvement with the firm is unclear. In any case, the authorities have yet to tighten their grip on a variety of other key pro-Kremlin oligarchs who made up "Yeltsin's family", the men who wielded backroom influence during Boris Yeltsin's regime and who actively promoted Mr Putin's rise to power - notably Roman Abramovich, the young and immensely rich head of the oil group Sibneft.

As this week's scandal developed, Mr Putin agreed to hold a round-table discussion later this month with some of the leading oligarchs. "In the abstract, Mr Putin's campaign against the illegal activities of various oligarchs and their apparently illegal influence is completely acceptable and essential for the democratic development of Russia," Mr Furman said.

"But the struggle is taking place in the context of an undemocratic, authoritarian regime. The logic of this campaign seems to be an attempt to liquidise any political or economic power which asserts its independence from the Kremlin."

Famous five take a rap
Secret service officials and state prosecutors swarmed through MediaMost's headquarters on Tuesday, seizing files. Its chief, Vladimir Gusinsky, was held last month on embezzlement charges. Prosecutors seized documents from natural gas giant Gazprom's headquarters on Tuesday, investigating its financial links with MediaMost. The prosecutor general's office told Vladimir Potanin on Tuesday to hand over £93m for an alleged underpayment when Norilsk Nickel, which he heads, was privatised in the 90s. Tax police announced on Wednesday that they had opened a criminal case against Lukoil for tax evasion. The company won 1999's "honest taxpayer of the year" award. They also announced on Wednesday that they had opened a tax evasion case against Avtovaz, which produces Ladas. Kremlin insider Boris Berezovsky had links with Avtovaz, but his current involvement is unclear.

webTitle: France goes the extra mile for the metre

fields.headline: France goes the extra mile for the metre
fields.trailText: A 375-mile long red and white tablecloth is ready to be unfurled. Fridges the length of France are stuffed with cold chicken and chilled wine. Four million people have received personal invitations. Now only the weather can spoil a unique event - the July 14 Incredible Picnic.
fields.body:
A 375-mile long red and white tablecloth is ready to be unfurled. Fridges the length of France are stuffed with cold chicken and chilled wine. Four million people have received personal invitations. Now only the weather can spoil a unique event - the July 14 Incredible Picnic.

Part of the millennium festivities, the picnic needed months of state-backed planning and millions of pounds of business sponsorship.

The meal will commemorate the introduction of the metric system 200 years ago, one of the republics most lasting achievements, which is why Bastille Day was chosen for the one-off affair.

Revolutionary surveyors devised the measure after travelling the length of the Paris meridian, a line of longitude running from Belgium to the Pyrenees, providing the continuous link for the north-south community meal which starts precisely at noon.

Everyone, including tourists, will be welcome to bring along hampers and join the privileged guests whose towns and villages are cut by the meridian - Greenwichs rival for meantime until an international agreement less than a century ago reduced its status for navigation and timekeeping.

The Paris observatory will transmit a laser beam at night to show the meridiens route through Paris, where the biggest section of lIncroyable Piquenique will take place.

Tourist centres like the Avenue de lOpéra, the Louvre and the Luxembourg Gardens will be linked by banqueting tables. Seven miles of main roads will be cordoned off to accommodate the diners, while the Comédie Française will project Molières Mariage Forcé on a giant screen. Picnickers on the Pont des Arts footbridge have been told to bring two hampers - one to share with passersby - and there will be free meals at the Luxembourg Gardens, where the public is invited to join 14,000 mayors and senators.

The senate will also stage the biggest of many concerts, with the popular singer Patricia Kaas, a choir of 400, and the Lille national orchestra.

All the 337 towns and villages along the meridian, including Prats-de-Mollo in the Pyrenees, which stands at 2,400 metres (7,870ft) will put on their own shows. Most will be focus on local food products and wine. At Orly airport, south of Paris, the public viewing platform will be opened for the first time in more than 30 years because the meridian runs through it.

Weather forecasters threw a shadow over the celebrations last night by saying that of one of the wettest Julys on record was likely to continue - a prospect that could also dampen the traditional Bastille Day celebrations, including the military parade this morning, dancing in the streets and a gigantic firework display around the Eiffel Tower tonight.

webTitle: South Africa told HIV drug will save babies

fields.headline: South Africa told HIV drug will save babies
fields.standfirst:
Durban conference Scientists press Mbeki for new treatments

International Aids Conference
UN Aids programme
fields.trailText: The South African government must allow pregnant women to be given drugs that can prevent them from passing HIV to their babies, the chairman of the international Aids conference in Durban declared yesterday.
fields.body:
The South African government must allow pregnant women to be given drugs that can prevent them from passing HIV to their babies, the chairman of the international Aids conference in Durban declared yesterday.

Hoosen Coovadia, an eminent South African paediatrician, said the results of trials in his country into the efficacy of nevirapine, released at the conference, showed conclusively that the drug could reduce mother-to-child transmission of the virus.

President Thabo Mbeki, who has dismayed scientists and campaigners by refusing to acknowledge unequivocally that HIV causes Aids, said he wanted firm proof that nevirapine worked before he would act.

Prof Coovadia said the results meant there was no further excuse for delay. "To my mind the position is absolutely clear and the government will have to make a decision. In high prevalence countries, the only cost is the cost of the drugs. Nevirapine is virtually free."

He was speaking at a meeting to promote the Durban Declaration, which states that HIV causes Aids. It was signed by 5,000 eminent scientists and launched a week before the conference opened last Sunday.

While scientists have said that the declaration is not aimed at any individual, it has been seen as an attempt to put a stop to President Mbeki's flirtation with dissident views, which they believe may jeopardise efforts to change sexual behaviour and obtain treatment for the infected in Africa.

The president has described his agnosticism as a justifiable desire to ask questions about the epidemic. He has set his face against AZT, which prevents mother-to-child transmission, arguing that its toxicity may outweigh its benefits.

Nevirapine has fewer side effects and is more effective than AZT in preventing such transmissions. Its manufacturer, Boehringer Ingelheim, has offered to supply it free of charge for five years to developing countries which want it.

There are signs that the South African government may now accept nevirapine, albeit slowly. On Monday it quietly agreed to a pilot project which will give drugs to 24,000 women in labour in Soweto to prevent them passing the virus to their babies.

The Soweto project is the work of the French government-funded organisation, the International Therapeutic Solidarity Fund. The ITSF, whose president is the British paediatrician Professor Catherine Peckham, was set up to send Aids drugs to the developing world.

Two years ago the ITSF proposed to supply AZT to expectant mothers but ran into tough government opposition. The Soweto pilot was only approved earlier this year. It is expected to expand to three as yet unnamed provinces.

The position of the South African ministry of health is that this is merely an extension of the trials because the drug is not yet licensed in South Africa.

Access to treatments and prophylactic drugs have been a big issue at the conference. Campaigners have lobbied passionately for cheaper versions of anti-retroviral therapies to be made available.

The Paris branch of Act-up, the activist group which put Aids on the agenda in the US, plastered hostile slogans on the exhibition stands of the drugs companies Merck, Sharpe and Dohme and Bristol Myers Squibb this week.

The director general of the World Health Organisation, Gro Harlem Brundtland, was also the target of protesters. At one meeting she was confronted by an angry crowd which opposed her efforts to reach agreements with drug companies on lower prices.

Activists say the only way to force drug companies to slash their prices from $10,000-$15,000 a year to the $1000 or less which would make the drugs affordable in poorer countries is through competition. They believe the developing world should be encouraged to buy cheap, generic copies of Aids drugs, rather than negotiating for small discounts from major firms.

"We have heard from the generics industry that the price could be as low as $200," said Daniel Berman, coordinator of Médecins sans Frontières' access-to-medicines programme. But countries need support to take the generics road. Under a World Trade Organisation agreement which protects intellectual property rights, all members must implement patent legislation by 2006.

Those that have not yet done so are free to buy generic drugs. Those that have, including South Africa, could argue for an exemption on the grounds that it is a public health emergency.

Swaziland's parliament is to debate a bill requiring the mandatory sterilisation of people with HIV/Aids. But a health ministry spokesman dismissed the proposal, saying that sterilisation would not curb the spread of Aids.

webTitle: Europe 'caving in to US firms' on approval for GM foods

fields.headline: Europe 'caving in to US firms' on approval for GM foods
fields.standfirst:
GM debate: special report
The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: The European commission was yesterday accused of caving in to pressure from large US biotechnology firms after it signalled it would rush through a controversial proposal to scrap the current Europe-wide moratorium on approval of new types of genetically modified food.
fields.body:
The European commission was yesterday accused of caving in to pressure from large US biotechnology firms after it signalled it would rush through a controversial proposal to scrap the current Europe-wide moratorium on approval of new types of genetically modified food.

In an outburst which angered environmental activists, the commission said the time had come to accept that gm food did not pose a serious threat to public health and that new types of gm food should be approved.

No new gm crops have been authorised for sale or use in the 15-state EU for around two years after public concerns about the safety of gm food prompted Europe's environment ministers to demand a stricter regulatory framework.

But the commission yesterday vowed to do its utmost to push through a directive governing gm food which it claims is far tougher than its predecessor and will include provisions on the labelling and traceability of any new food approved.

Although the content of the new directive has to be definitively approved by the European parliament and EU governments, it could become law by the end of the year, kick-starting the EU's moribund approvals system.

In an unprecedented step, the commission is lobbying for the new directive to become law as soon as it is endorsed in Brussels, and thinks it cannot afford to wait for individual countries to implement its provisions, a process which could take a further two years.

"The scientific evidence that is available to all of us is that there is no scientific danger in any gm foods," David Byrne, the commissioner in charge of consumer protection, said yesterday. He acknowledged that many consumers did not want to buy gm products, but promised the new legislation was sufficiently rigorous to guarantee the safety of gm food as far as this was scientifically possible.

Margot Wallstrom, the environment commissioner, added her voice to calls for urgent action and said doing nothing would leave the commission vulnerable to a rash of lawsuits from biotechnology companies.

"The moratorium is illegal and unjustified and we cannot stop advances in new technology by refusing to act," she said.

The commission's proposals will be discussed this weekend when EU environment ministers meet in Paris.

Greenpeace accused the commission of being in the pocket of US biotechnology giants such as Monsanto who are desperate to get their products approved in Europe.

"The commission is bowing to US threats with a proposal which flies in the face of current consumer and member state concern," spokeswoman Isabelle Meister said.

A recent EU poll found that 66% of Europeans viewed GM food as a health hazard. Eighteen gm food products have been approved for commercial use in the EU.

webTitle: Israel turns away former Cat Stevens

fields.headline: Israel turns away former Cat Stevens
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The 1970s pop star formerly known as Cat Stevens, who converted to Islam in 1977 after his brother brought him a Koran from Jerusalem, has been denied entry to Israel, a government spokesman confirmed yesterday, accusing him of supporting the Islamist movement Hamas.
fields.body:
The 1970s pop star formerly known as Cat Stevens, who converted to Islam in 1977 after his brother brought him a Koran from Jerusalem, has been denied entry to Israel, a government spokesman confirmed yesterday, accusing him of supporting the Islamist movement Hamas.

The British musician, who changed his name to Yusuf Ibrahim, was held for several hours at Tel Aviv airport on Wednesday morning before being returned to Germany.

He knew before he came here that he would not have permission to come in, said Moshe Fogel, the government spokesman. His interest in Hamas is not purely verbal and in that sense he is not considered a tourist who comes to see the sights.

We do not feel any obligation to allow people into the country who have in the past shown support for the Hamas terrorist organisation, which is responsible for blowing up buses in the centre of Tel Aviv.

He would not give details of the alleged support, but said it was tangible.

Yusuf Islam told an Israeli paper that he was held for three hours without water or access to a toilet in a windowless cell 2 metres square.

He called his expulsion a disgrace.

In recent years he has campaigned for Afghan refugees, Bosnian Muslims, and for funding for Islamist schools in Britain. He has also endorsed Hamass opposition to the Middle East peace process.

With his re-entry to public life has come the relaunch of his musical career: an album of religious material in 1995, and A is for Allah, which was launched at the House of Lords last March.

Mr Fogel said Yusuf Islams faith was not the reason for his deportation.

webTitle: Profit warning forces Airtours to invite bid

fields.headline: Profit warning forces Airtours to invite bid
fields.trailText: Airtours issued a profits warning yesterday but signalled its willingness to enter merger talks with its German rival C&N. Shares in Britain's largest tour operator dropped by 17% after it revealed that profits could slump by up to £60m from the £156m delivered last year.
fields.body:
Airtours issued a profits warning yesterday but signalled its willingness to enter merger talks with its German rival C&N. Shares in Britain's largest tour operator dropped by 17% after it revealed that profits could slump by up to £60m from the £156m delivered last year.

The holiday market is notoriously volatile and prone to over-capacity and much of the damage is being inflicted by its operations in contintental Europe rather than in Britain. The trading statement came as Airtours took full control of Frosch Touristik (FTi), a loss-making German travel company in which Airtours had held a 36% stake for the last two years.

Tim Byrne, group managing director of Airtours, predicted that further consolidation would take place in the German market and made it clear that Airtours intended to take part in the action. After being blocked by regulators in its attempts to take over its British rival, First Choice, Mr Byrne has kept the door open for talks with C&N, one of its main competitors in Germany.

There were three big operators in Europe - Preussag, the German company which recently bought Thomson Travel, Airtours and C&N - and it would be a "good idea" for Airtours to tie up with C&N, he said.

Quashing speculation that David Crossland, the chairman of Airtours - who owns a 10% stake - was standing in the way of a deal, Mr Byrne said that as a quoted company it would be "honour bound" to follow up realistic offers.

Airtours described its bookings for this summer as "very satisfactory" at 18% up on last year, but its investment in new markets, particularly in Germany - and a reorganisation of its existing business -had dented its profits.

The acquisition of FTi had cost £25m while a reorganisation of its French, Belgian and Dutch operations was costing £15m.

In addition, changes in accounting rules cut profits by £10m while the weakness of the euro against sterling reduced the profits of its Italian Costa Cruises business by £5m when translated into pounds. The group is also trying to make cost savings of up to £10m a year in Britain by centralising its operations in Rochdale. That move will result in one-off costs this year.

Airtours' woes knocked the shares of other tour operators, including First Choice, which fell 8.5p to 122.5p, and Preussag. The latter is thought to be feeling the same kind of pain being experienced by Airtours in Germany, Europe's biggest market for holidays. Airtours shares ended at 254p, down 53p.

Airtours admitted yesterday that it expected to incur "substantial losses" in Germany this year but Mr Byrne outlined plans to increase its exposure to the market, even though it is burdened with over-capacity.

One target for co-operation is LTU, the large German leisure airline mainly owned by Swissair. It is described as a prime example of the over-capacity in Germany, with too many seats on many routes.

FTi has doubled in size in two years and has 2.2m customers. It made a pre-tax loss of £14.4m last year. By taking control of the group and installing new management, Airtours aims to stem the losses.

Despite fierce competition in the travel industry, Airtours is in expansionary mode. It is in talks with the owners of Hotetur, a Spanish hotel group.

webTitle: Generation e storms a new Bastille

fields.headline: Generation e storms a new Bastille
fields.trailText: Jet fighters have been roaring over Paris this week rehearsing for today's annual celebrations of Bastille day, commemorating the moment in 1789 when, according to romantic 19th century historians, the tide which swept away the monarchy became irresistible.
fields.body:
Jet fighters have been roaring over Paris this week rehearsing for today's annual celebrations of Bastille day, commemorating the moment in 1789 when, according to romantic 19th century historians, the tide which swept away the monarchy became irresistible.

But as France celebrates the revolution which overturned one ancien régime is another, slower, less dramatic but equally profound change under way? Is France's post-war structure of a centralised, dirigiste state controlled by an interlinked elite and where citizens looked to the Elysée, the Matignon and the local mairie for authority and support, giving way to a more risk-based, independent, even Anglo-Saxon, approach? Or is the air of change more symbol than substance?

France is in confident mood. It has just assumed the presidency of the European Union with an agenda aimed at taking at least some of the 15 member states into a new dimension. The economy is on the rise. France has taken over Germany's role as powerhouse of Euroland. A new generation of French executives which includes Vivendi's Jean-Marie Messier and Maurice Levy of Publicis are making names for themselves with bold international mergers and acquisitions.

The French stock exchange is heading an alliance bidding for the leadership of pan-European equity trading as well as playing a central role in a planned global alliance. To put the icing on the cake, the French national football side has added the Euro 2000 title to the 1998 World Cup.

Finance minister Laurent Fabius reflected the bullish mood in a speech this week. Growth would be 3.5% this year and 3% next. In the past three years a million new jobs had been created. Unemployment would soon fall below 2m.

Marc Viénot, a senior civil servant during the post-war reconstruction of France who now heads the Paris Europlace - the organisation dedicated to promoting the French capital's claims as a leading financial centre - puts it this way: "I had 15 years in the Treasury. At the age of 30 I had more power than when I was chairman of Société Générale."

But the days when state control was all-embracing are over. Privatisation, not least under the current Socialist administration, has curtailed its reach.

Mr Vienot believes the process of change is accelerating. "We have a new generation, English-speaking, interested in new technology." It is a generation which is more likely to look at the world from a European than a purely French perspective - "except for football".

Some of the younger generation, however, accept that change is happening but still sound a cautionary note. Guilaume Gicqueau, a 26-year-old account manager with a website design company, argues that though France was slow to catch on to the internet it is making up for lost time. "There are so many opportunities and more and more jobs are being created all the time. Rather than growing independently of the established system, I think the internet is going to force traditional businesses to adapt themselves, to have a broader outlook.

"But it hasn't happened yet. Despite the significant evolution, people are still frowned upon if they decide to start up on their own. People see it as a betrayal, as something dangerous and unknown. France is still very frightened of the unknown, especially if it means adopting a more American-style attitude to work."

But Xavier Ducasse, an account manager at an electronics company, argues: "Big French businesses are finding they have to change considerably, which means moving away from the France that everyone knows, a centralised bureaucracy controlled by civil servants. The pyramid structure is opening up, and now, for the first time, people are being employed for their personality as well as their qualifications."

Critics, however, still find grounds for complaint. The introduction of the 35-hour week went down badly with many employers. At one point they even took to the streets to demonstrate their dissatisfaction. Medef, the French equivalent of the CBI, is pressing for more reforms on issues such as health insurance and pensions.

Unemployment, though falling, remains close to double figures. The OECD warned that the reduction in working hours might push up costs and damage competitiveness unless implemented in a flexible way.

The widespread support for José Bové, who was taken to court for damaging a branch of McDonald's, is seen as an indication that old attitudes towards open markets and free trade die hard in France.

Even Mr Fabius acknowledges there is much still to be done. "It would be absurd to deny the difficulties, the reforms which are still to be accomplished," he says.

But at least today, as the jets roar overhead, much of France will still feel there is plenty to celebrate.

webTitle: Italy sets pace on debt relief

fields.headline: Italy sets pace on debt relief
fields.trailText: Italy threw down the gauntlet to the rest of the Group of Seven industrialised nations yesterday by passing legislation setting a new standard for debt relief in developing countries.
fields.body:
Italy threw down the gauntlet to the rest of the Group of Seven industrialised nations yesterday by passing legislation setting a new standard for debt relief in developing countries.

In a move that is likely to embarrass other nations, the country committed itself to faster, deeper and wider debt relief and suggested that in order to benefit from it countries would not necessarily have to undergo tough economic reform programmes.

The initiative follows sustained public pressure for action and enables the Italian government to claim the moral high ground when it attends next week's G7 annual economic summit in Japan, where debt relief will be one of the main items on the agenda.

By contrast, the US House of Representatives rejected on Wednesday most of the money Bill Clinton wanted for financing debt relief.

A spokeswoman for Jubilee 2000, the global coalition of charities campaigning for debt relief, said the Italian legislation represented a distinct move away from HIPC, the heavily indebted poor countries initiative, the World Bank-International Monetary Fund debt relief programme.

The new legislation commits Italy to cancelling a minimum of $4bn (£2.67bn) and a maximum of $6bn of debts within three years of the passing of the bill and could allow up to 78 countries to qualify for debt relief rather than the 40 or so included in the present HIPC programme.

Jubile 2000 said countries could qualify for aid simply by demonstrating it would be used to reduce poverty.

fields.headline: Vivendi delays environmental float
fields.trailText: French media and utilities group Vivendi yesterday delayed the flotation of its environmental and transport business just as the offer was about to go ahead.
fields.body:
French media and utilities group Vivendi yesterday delayed the flotation of its environmental and transport business just as the offer was about to go ahead.

The offer has now been restructured, with a reduced guide price, and rescheduled for next week.

Vivendi said demand for shares in Vivendi Environment had totalled $5.1bn (£3.2bn) for the $4.1bn worth of shares on offer but blamed the last minute postponement on a lacklustre response to the offer from institutional shareholders who are thought to be concerned about the groups planned $29bn (£19.3bn) merger with Seagram and the sheer weight of new issues hitting the Paris market.

Direct demand in the institutional offering would not, in the light of current market conditions, have assured a satisfactory listing for investors, it said in a statement.

Analysts said that in addition to concerns about the Seagram deal there was some anxiety that Vivendi bondholders converting their securities into shares in Vivendi Environment would immediately sell out, depressing the share price.

The offer had beenm pitched at institutions, with only 10% of the 83m shares on offer set aside for retail investors. But in the face of institutional apathy Vivendi is restructuring the offer to capitalise on retail demand.

Some $1.6bn worth of shares will be set aside for convertible bond holdersand the remaining $2.5 bn will be on offer equally to institutional and retail investors. Vivendi said the guide price for institutions has been cut from $36-$41 to $33-$36.

It is very unfortunate. As utilities go it is a very good business and has good growth. But no ones looking at it on a standalone basis, said a London analyst.

Increasing the retail allocation is one way to get it [the offer] done but it is clear the stock isnt flying off the shelf, according to one banker.

The offer was initially sandwiched between the stock market debut of the Eads and France Telecoms internet subsidiary, Wanadoo.

Vivendi Environment will now come to the market in the immediate aftermath of the Wanadoo issue.

webTitle: 'It is not good policy, just cheap politics'

fields.headline: 'It is not good policy, just cheap politics'
fields.standfirst:
MAFF area on TB in cattle and badgers
National Federation of Badger Groups
fields.trailText:
The two men looked nervous and uneasy. Dressed in combat style clothes and carrying a shovel they came down the steep hillside to the Land Rover parked in the narrow Cornish lane .
They had just finished digging in badger traps amid the blackthorn and brambles of a field. The traps were part of the controversial government experiment to establish the source of TB in cattle.
fields.body:
The two men looked nervous and uneasy. Dressed in combat style clothes and carrying a shovel they came down the steep hillside to the Land Rover parked in the narrow Cornish lane . They had just finished digging in badger traps amid the blackthorn and brambles of a field. The traps were part of the controversial government experiment to establish the source of TB in cattle.

The cull has provoked strong feelings in the area, with protesters claiming that hundreds of traps have been destroyed since the west Penwith experiment began while at least one farmer in the area has changed his mind about taking part in the trials. Simon Cargeeg, 47, who farms 180 acres at Botallack, said that although no threats had been made, the presence of around 30 demonstrators outside the farm was intimidating.

"They seemed pretty intent on not letting this happen and I don't need the aggro. I have a young family and I suppose I felt intimidated by the presence of a large number of very angry people." Police said protesters' claims about the number of traps destroyed were probably correct. But they had so far received only a handful of complaints about theft or criminal damage to Ministry of Agriculture property.

West Penwith farmers have been divided about the cull. Some private landowners have refused to allow traps to be laid on their land and more than half of National Trust tenant farmers in the neighbourhood are said to have declined to take part.

The artist Kurt Jackson, who has a smallholding near St Just, is among those who have refused."It's partly a moral thing," he said. "Thousands of badgers are killed on the road every year so why can't they be examined to test for the incidence of TB?" Despite the reservations of some farmers, the National Farmers' Union is keen to see a speeding up of the trials because of concern about the continued rise of TB in cattle. Cornwall, it says, has a greater problem with the disease than any other county.

Robert Knowles, chairman of the Cornwall NFU, who farms 350 acres, is among those in favour of the trial. Although his own dairy herd of 170 cattle shows no sign of TB he knows of neighbouring farmers who are under restriction and unable to move cattle off their farms because they have been diagnosed with the disease."If we are going to prove whether badgers give TB to cattle an experiment like this has got to be done."John Maule, 43, who runs a 20 acre organic smallholding at Leswidden, near St Just, disagrees. He has refused to allow the cull on his land. "We have never had TB in our cattle which is part of my worry. If you have not got TB you have probably got a healthy population of badgers because they are territorial and keep out the infected ones."If you kill all the healthy badgers the sett will become repopulated, usually by unhealthy ones that have been kicked out from other setts." "My other gripe is that it is just cheap politics. What happens if they find out that badgers do cause bovine TB? Is the next step to kill every badger in the country? That is not going to be politically acceptable."They should develop a vaccine for TB in cows and look at the welfare conditions in which they are kept because very few organic farmers get TB in their cattle and they are more stringent on welfare."

fields.headline: Orange bets on £300m cyber fund
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The mobile internet battle intensified yesterday when Orange launched a £300m cyber fund as part of its strategy to develop content on its web portal.
fields.body:
The mobile internet battle intensified yesterday when Orange launched a £300m cyber fund as part of its strategy to develop content on its web portal.

Orange, Britains third biggest mobile phone operator, said the cyber fund would take equity stakes in small technology start-ups and set up research and development centres - known as imaginariums - in North America, Singapore and London.

Hans Snook, chief executive of Orange, said the company was also in discussions with fixed line telephone and cable companies, likely to include Energis, NTL and Telewest, to combine mobile and fixed line services in one package, mainly to corporate customers. The first partner is likely to be Energis.

We will soon announce the first reciprocal virtual network operation, where a national fixed line operator will utilise the Orange network, supported by Orange customer service, Orange services and Orange billing, all under its own brand label, Mr Snook said.

fields.headline: Market forces
fields.trailText: News that the United States might use the long arm of the law to crack down on expensive drugs rocked the pharmaceutical sector and the wider market yesterday. The share prices of the big drug companies fell as investors had their first chance to react to a proposal made by the chairman of the senate finance committee to offer drug coverage to all the 39m beneficiaries of Medicare.
fields.body:
News that the United States might use the long arm of the law to crack down on expensive drugs rocked the pharmaceutical sector and the wider market yesterday. The share prices of the big drug companies fell as investors had their first chance to react to a proposal made by the chairman of the senate finance committee to offer drug coverage to all the 39m beneficiaries of Medicare.

Analysts said that greater state participation in drug management raised the prospect of the US government trying to force down drug prices, either through legislation or buying power. Goldman Sachs said the proposal supported "a neutral at best" stance towards the sector. Glaxo Wellcome shares were the worst affected, shedding 63p to £19.11, closely followed by AstraZeneca, off 98p at £30.82, and SmithKline Beecham, down 26p to 869p. Undermined by the weak performance of the three pharmaceutical firms, the main FTSE 100 ended 42.8 points easier at 6,475.7.

Technology stocks were the best blue-chip performers, aided by the continued strength of the Nasdaq, which is now back above the 4,000-point level.Freeserve led the pack, rising 21.5p to 335.5p amid speculation that takeover talks with Germany's T-Online might be back on track. Strong figures from US firm Motorola underpinned the advance in chip designer ARM Holdings, up 41.5p at 766.5p. Analysts at CSFB expected ARM to report strong figures next week for the first half.

With worries of a profit warning banished, accountancy software group Sage continued to shine, gaining 27p to close at 580p.Compass appreciated 20p to 818p after Goldman Sachs highlighted its attractions. With a market value now available for Granada Media, Goldman estimates that Compass's management has effectively acquired Granada's roadside and contract catering assets for less than half of what they are worth.

News that Diageo is discussing a potential merger of its Pillsbury food division with US group General Mills failed to inspire. The shares closed down 12.5p at 599p.

British Airways rose 7p to 389p following a broadly positive assessment of the benefits of a merger with Dutch carrier KLM. Dresdner Kleinwort Benson said that although the deal was not the perfect solution it addressed both companies' strategic weaknesses and might even provide BA with an alternative to US partner American Airlines.

Among second-tier stocks, Independent Energy continued its upward march, adding 117.5p to 865p. The company has reportedly applied to the government for permission to build a 220-megawatt power station in Kent.

NXT, the audio equipment group, surged 70p to £11.35 after signing a speech processing technology deal with the BBC. A positive reaction to its recent acquisition of Canadian group Teklogix boosted Psion 45p to 710p.

On the downside, building materials group RMC slipped 65.5p to 733p as analysts took the red pen to forecasts after a trading update. Deutsche Bank said it would cut its full-year pre-tax profit estimate by 10-15%.

IMI sank 20p to 220p after Merrill Lynch lowered its rating and Airtours dropped 53p to 254p following a shock profits warning.

European Motor Holdings fared better, shooting up 9.5p to 55.5p with the appearance of Trefick on its shareholder register. Trefick has acquired a 5.67% stake.

Glass manufacturer Darby Group, which finished the session down 0.25p at 11.5p, attracted attention after 22.9m shares changed hands. The company said Swedish investor Peter Gyllenhammar had taken a 16% stake in the company. Mr Gyllenhammar specialises in making investments in small, undervalued companies.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Car prices 76% higher in UK
fields.body:
Car prices 76% higher in UK

New cars cost up to 76% more in Britain than in other parts of Europe, official figures from Brussels revealed yesterday.

Of the 73 models in the European commission comparison tables, 65 were more expensive in Britain than anywhere else in the European Union.

EC competition commissioner Mario Monti said that he would "continue to investigate possible restrictive practices by car manufacturers which impede EU citizens from buying a car in another member state".

US tie-up for FTSE

FTSE International said it and Frank Russell Company have formed a strategic collaboration to further strengthening the global profile of both companies.

The tie-up will result in greater US penetration for FTSE's global indices and greater European penetration for Russell's US indices, it said. Under the deal, Russell will adopt the FTSE Global Classification System for its US Equity Indices, while FTSE will provide real-time calculations of the Russell Indices starting next year.

M&S plans discount shops

Marks & Spencer said yesterday it planned to open a chain of discount stores and join its rivals in targeting Britain's growing band of bargain hunters. M&S said it would open three stores this autumn, offering discounts of more than 30% as part of a plan to open about 10 discount outlets. The stores will be styled as factory outlets, offering surplus stock from the company's main stores, M&S said.

British Gas in recruiting drive

British Gas plans to recruit 2,000 service engineers over the next five years in an effort to stem a 15-year decline in the number of trainees. British Gas, the trading arm of Centrica, which retains 14.5m gas customers, said it would take on more than 1,000 apprentices and an equal number of adults, with a special drive among lone parents, women and ethnic minorities.

KLM and BA make it official

KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said yesterday it and British Airways planned to file an official merger proposal with the EU's competition authorities by early next month. "There's a draft proposal with the European commission at the moment and the timing is to put down the formal proposal for a full merger at the end of July or at the start of August," a KLM official said.

Manufacturing growth slows

Expansion in Britain's hard-pressed manufacturing sector slowed to its weakest rate for a year in the second quarter but services remained buoyant, according to the British Chambers of Commerce, which said it expected the decline to continue.

fields.headline: Current affairs 'safe on BBC1'
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Plans to shift serious programmes from BBC1 to BBC2 will not leave the main channel devoid of demanding current affairs, executives promised yesterday.
fields.body:
Plans to shift serious programmes from BBC1 to BBC2 will not leave the main channel devoid of demanding current affairs, executives promised yesterday.

Greg Dyke, in his first appearance as director general before the Commons media select committee, confirmed that the corporation had embarked on a fundamental review of its television output, but pledged not to alienate viewers along the way.

Mr Dyke said that as multi-channel digital television became more widespread, the BBC had to adapt. There had been a "scandal" when the Home Service was relaunched as Radio 4, yet few would now suggest it was the wrong decision. Sir Christopher Bland, the BBC chairman, added that it would be a "strategic error of the first order" if the BBC did not prepare now for the digital age.

There has been widespread concern about the future of BBC television since Mark Thompson, the director of television and one of Mr Dyke's most trusted colleagues, delivered a speech in Canada suggesting that BBC channels should eventually become "genre-based". BBC1 would broadly be an entertainment channel, BBC2 would carry more serious programmes, BBC Choice would become a youth and comedy channel called BBC3, while BBC Knowledge would evolve into an arts and culture channel, BBC4.

The BBC's plans are a response to research carried out in households that have signed up to digital television, which shows a radical shift in viewing patterns. The Sky electronic programme guide (EPG), which enables subscribers to select from a list of channels by type, such as news or comedy, means viewers are far less wedded to one particular channel.

Asked about the future of staples such as Panorama, Question Time and Songs of Praise on BBC1, Sir Christopher said: "There are no plans to move, at this stage, any specific programmes anywhere else."

webTitle: Diageo in talks about Pillsbury sale

fields.headline: Diageo in talks about Pillsbury sale
fields.trailText: Diageo confirmed yesterday that it is in talks with General Mills over a possible sale of its Pillsbury subsidiary.
fields.body:
Diageo confirmed yesterday that it is in talks with General Mills over a possible sale of its Pillsbury subsidiary.

"There is no certainty that these discussions will lead to a transaction," Diageo said in a statement released to the stock exchange yesterday.

The two companies did not provide financial details, but the deal is expected to be a stock swap valued at about $10.5bn (£7bn).

Diageo has been under pressure to divest the food side of its business.

In a trading statement issued on Tuesday, Diageo's group chief executive, John McGrath, said the spirits and wine business had performed strongly in the past year.

However, Pillsbury's sales in North America were down about 2%, he said. Pillsbury's brands include Häagen Dazs, Green Giant and Old El Paso Mexican foods.

Diageo's shares were down 12.5p, or more than 2%, to 599p in trading yesterday.

Speculation about Pillsbury's future rose after Diageo announced in June that it was working on a part flotation of its Burger King subsidiary.

Analysts said the purchase of Pillsbury could help General Mills reduce its dependence on the slow-growing cereals market.

"This gets General Mills more diversified and into some other areas which have a faster growth potential," said Prudential Securities analyst Jeffrey Kanter.

"In the end, you get a more powerful General Mills."

fields.headline: Whistleblowers forced to quit
fields.trailText: When seven former care assistants blew the whistle on colleagues who were abusing frail residents of a Bupa-run home for the elderly they were forced to resign, an industrial tribunal in Ashford, Kent, heard yesterday.
fields.body:
When seven former care assistants blew the whistle on colleagues who were abusing frail residents of a Bupa-run home for the elderly they were forced to resign, an industrial tribunal in Ashford, Kent, heard yesterday.

Eileen Chubb, 41, of Orpington, Kent, described how whimpering residents of the 65 bedroom Isard House in Bromley, were left in their own urine, physically attacked and robbed by staff.

Drugs were out of date, bed linen unwashed and relatives of dying residents forced to sleep in armchairs, she claimed.

Mrs Chubb told the tribunal: In August 1997 I went on holiday for two weeks. My line manager, Maria Keenaghan, promised that three of my particularly vulnerable residents would be cared for. But when I returned one of them was dead and the other two had urine burns on their skin.

Mrs Chubb, who worked as a care assistant at the home for three years until May 1999, said: Maria would purchase her toiletries with the residents money. She would also take sweets and newspapers that the residents families had bought for them.

Mrs Chubb said she reported her concern to the homes manager, Carole Jones, but the abuse got worse.

She said residents hid in their rooms and begged her not to let certain members of staff go near them.

Mrs Chubb and Karen Hook - one of six other whistleblowers - reported the abuse to the registration and inspection unit. After that Mrs Chubb said she was ignored by other staff.

On May 14, the seven whistleblowers met with Des Kelly, the director of Bupas First Care Partnerships.

He told them to stay away from work until he had dealt with the problem, she said.

In a case brought under the Public Interest Disclosure Act which protects whistleblowers, Eileen Chubb, Karen Hook, Renee Warwick, Elizabeth Martin, Lee Elkin, Linda Clarke, and Margaret Roffy claim unlawful dismissal. All seven took sick leave, but claim they were unable to return to work because of harassment.

The hearing continues.

webTitle: The night Sellafield turned into a shooting gallery

fields.headline: The night Sellafield turned into a shooting gallery
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: Boredom is recognised as a serious problem at nuclear facilities. It leads to staff becoming so torpid they fail to notice alarm lights flashing, as happened in the 1980s at the notorious Three Mile Island power plant accident in the US.
fields.body:
Boredom is recognised as a serious problem at nuclear facilities. It leads to staff becoming so torpid they fail to notice alarm lights flashing, as happened in the 1980s at the notorious Three Mile Island power plant accident in the US.

In the battle to stay awake workers are known to play games and indulge in dangerous pranks. But using the corridors of the giant plutonium reprocessing works at Sellafield as a shooting gallery was a step too far for British Nuclear Fuels.

When a target and expended rounds of plastic bullets were found inside the "controlled area" of the high security £1.8bn facility on June 20, a full investigation was ordered. A gun had clearly been smuggled into the facility and out again, through some of the toughest security devices in Britain. The discovery came on top of a torrid few months for BNFL. The lack of safety culture had been criticised, data on plutonium fuel had been falsified, nuclear fuel had been sabotaged with screws, and police had failed to find who had cut the wires to five robotic arms in the waste plant, bringing the whole place to a halt. The orders went out that under no circumstances was the public to be told of the latest embarrassment.

A week later baffled management resorted to appealing to those responsible to own up. To their relief, two electricians stepped forward - they had in fact been "testing" a gun to while away the long hours after repairing it in the plant's workshop during their night shift, and then taken it home again. They had neglected to clear up the spent rounds and the target.

Armed plant police believed the weapon to be an air rifle, and tracked down the gun, which fired plastic rounds. Worried that sackings might lead to unwanted publicity, BNFL reclassified the incident as a "breach of discipline" rather than the more serious "breach of security". Last week the two men were severely reprimanded and taken off shift work for three years - something which involves considerable loss of earnings.

A spokesman for BNFL said the gun did fire plastic pellets, but it was not a serious gun. It was owned by one of the electricians' children and the father "had brought it in for repair, and subsequently tested it inside the works".

He added: "In the end it was a toy, not a real gun, made of plastic, so it was a question of wasting company time rather than a security matter. Not the worst thing that has happened to us recently."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: null
fields.body:
Cancer-clear man dies

A patient who was told he did not have cancer has died after doctors failed to diagnose a tumour.

Bill Stewart, 52, from Lundwood, near Barnsley, had four months of tests at Barnsley hospital, South Yorkshire, and was told that there was nothing wrong with him. He died in hospital in Leeds.

Postwoman wins appeal

A village postwoman sacked for holding over promotional mail so she could complete her round when it was snowing has been reinstated by the Royal Mail on appeal.

But Jean Wratten, 62, who lives opposite the post office in Brabourne Lees in Kent, has been transferred to Ashford sorting office, seven miles away.

£12.6m Foyle sale

A leaf from the Gutenberg Bible, the first book printed with movable type, in around 1455, fetched £28,200 out of a total of £12.6m raised in a three-day sale of the Foyle collection.

This was double the expected total and represents the highest price to have been paid at a European auction for a private library.

Surprise delivery

A woman who went into hospital suffering from backache gave birth to a boy four hours later.

Claire Argo, 27, had two minutes to tell boyfriend Paul Tommy, 30, she was pregnant before she was whisked off into the delivery suite at Doncaster royal infirmary.

£270,000 award against GP

The high court yesterday awarded £270,000 damages against a GP to a woman whose husband died from complications after catching chicken pox from their children.

In 1996 Danny Makepeace, 30, of Waltham Cross, Hertfordshire, contracted a rare complication, pneumonitis, due to the chicken pox.

Kibbutz case arrest

A Thai national has been arrested in connection with the rape of a 31-year-old British volunteer worker on an Israeli kibbutz on the Golan Heights, the Foreign Office said yesterday.

Leeds tops hooligan league

fields.headline: Poverty gap hits Labour boasts
fields.standfirst:
Release of annual report 'hides' embarrassing figures
New Labour in power: special report
The government's annual report
fields.trailText: Evidence yesterday that a widening gap between rich and poor pushed 500,000 more people below the poverty line in Labour's first two years in office marred Tony Blair's most sophisticated attempt yet to sell his government's record to sceptical voters.
fields.byline: Larry Elliott, Charlotte Denny and Michael White
fields.body:
Evidence yesterday that a widening gap between rich and poor pushed 500,000 more people below the poverty line in Labour's first two years in office marred Tony Blair's most sophisticated attempt yet to sell his government's record to sceptical voters.

The government was accused of "sneaking out" the embarrassing figures - which indicated that there were fewer poor people in John Major's last two years in Downing Street than under Mr Blair - on the same day as the third of Labour's annual reports to voters was launched in person by the prime minister in the Commons.

Data from the department of social security revealed that the number of people living in households on less than half average income rose from 16.9% to 17.7%, as the incomes of the rich grew three times as rapidly as those of the poor.

Underlining the root cause of the government's uneasy relationship with the elderly, the DSS figures showed the number of pensioners living below the poverty line rose from 2m to 2.4m - accounting for 80% of the increase.

Steve Webb, the Liberal Democrat social security spokesman, said: "I am not surprised that these damning figures have been sneaked out on the same day as the government's annual report. This proves that the growth in poverty during the Tory years has continued under Labour. Pensioners in particular have had a raw deal, and these figures do not even take account of the derisory 75p pensioners got in April."

"The figures are devastating," said David Willetts, Conservative social security spokesman. "They give the lie to the figures published in the annual report today. On the government's own preferred measure of poverty the numbers below the poverty line are rising."

The annual report boasted that 1m children had been lifted out of poverty under Labour, but the DSS's own figures showed an increase from 3.3m to 3.4m in Labour's first 24 months in office. A breakdown of the government's figures showed how the incomes of the richest have been rising faster under Labour than under the Conservatives. The richest 10% of the population saw their household incomes rise by 7.1% in the first two years of Labour, compared with 4.3% in the last two years of the Conservatives. The poorest 10% saw their incomes rise by 1.9% under Mr Blair.

Alistair Darling, the social security security, said: "Poverty on this scale inherited by this government took years to build up. Today's report confirms the scale of the problem we need to turn around."

This theme was also highlighted by the annual report, which was hedged around with admissions that there was still "more to do" to make Britain a fair and efficient society.

Ahead of next week's comprehensive spending review the prime minister promised "investment, investment, investment" in health, education, pensions and other public services over the coming four years.

"There is a lot done - but a lot more needs to be done and this Government will do it," he said. The glossy analysis omitted key national statistics and a list of pledges fulfilled - making it harder to compare with last year's equivalent report. William Hague called it "another gimmick from a government of gimmicks" and said the report ranged from the banal to the completely untrue - voters knew most of Labour's claims had not been fulfilled, he said. Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, seized on a chance to call his Labour allies "judge and jury" on their own 1997 manifesto commitments. "If we all wrote our own end of term reports, we'd all give ourselves top marks," he said.

webTitle: Environment is key to cancer risk, says study

fields.headline: Environment is key to cancer risk, says study
fields.standfirst: Cancer is overwhelmingly caused by where you are, what you do, and what happens to you in life, rather than by what you are, a study of almost 90,000 twins has shown.
fields.trailText: Cancer is overwhelmingly caused by where you are, what you do, and what happens to you in life, rather than by what you are, a study of almost 90,000 twins has shown.
fields.body:
Adding a new chapter to the age old debate about whether nature or nurture lies at the root of disease, researchers in Scandinavia found that environmental factors were linked to twice as many cancers as inherited genetic factors.

Even identical twins, who share the same genes, had only a 10% chance of getting the same cancers.

Scientists have long argued that cancer is caused by a combination of environmental factors, such as smoking, diet, pollution and radiation from the sun, together with the actions of damaged genes.

The questions were how far people were doomed to cancer through having been born with faulty genes in the first place, and how far their genes were damaged by the environment.

With the rapid advance of genetics knowledge in the past decade, some scientists had begun to play down the importance of nurture over nature in cancer susceptibility.

But the results of the exhaustive study of twins from Sweden, Finland and Denmark, published in the New England Journal of Medicine, suggest that genetic inheritance contributes a small proportion of the risk of getting cancer.

Environmental factors are more important than gene factors, and thats important to remember, especially since everyone thinks that everything is solved now that we have the human genome in our computers, said Paul Lichtenstein, of Stockholms Karolinska Institute, who led the research team.

This was echoed by Tim Key, senior scientist at the Imperial Cancer Research Fund in Oxford.

Coming a couple of weeks after the deciphering of the human genome, this is a reminder that as well as studying genes a lot of work needs to be done on the environment at the same time.

The signs that lifestyle is the key to cancer have been apparent for a long time. Stomach cancer in Britain has dropped by half over the past 50 years, for instance - a change which cannot be accounted for by genetics.

When people emigrate from one country to another, their genes do not change, yet their cancer susceptibility does. Women moving from Japan to the US have been shown to have increased their risk of breast cancer by four or five times.

Scientists already know that about 35% of cancers are caused by smoking, with perhaps another 30% diet related.

Dr Key said that the Scandinavian study, the largest ever of its kind, showed the dangers of fatalism among relatives of cancer victims.

Even if you have a high risk because you have a family history, you still probably wont get cancer, and what you do with your life is much more important. You should not smoke, you should take care of your diet. Those things do make a difference.

The new research is double edged, because despite the overall conclusion that inheritance makes a minor contribution to cancer susceptibility, it showed that in three cancers - prostate, colorectal and breast cancer - genes play a significant role.

The study found that genetic factors accounted for 42% of the risk of getting prostate cancer, and 35% and 27% respectively of the risk of getting the other cancers.

These figures are not explained by scientists existing knowledge of inherited gene mutations, signifying that researchers still have much work to do to identify cancer susceptibility genes.

webTitle: Public shouldn't have to carry the can

fields.headline: Public shouldn't have to carry the can
fields.trailText: Notebook: Vivendi's decision to delay the flotation of its water, waste treatment, energy and transport arm is an embarrassment, even if the reasoning is sound enough
fields.body:
Risks in turning to retail investors

Vivendi's decision to delay the flotation of its water, waste treatment, energy and transport arm is an embarrassment, even if the reasoning is sound enough. Though it may provide the opportunity to ensure a reasonable after-market for Vivendi Environment, the postponement has again thrust the link-up between Vivendi and Seagram, and the attendant doubts, into the spotlight.

Jean-Marie Messier is going to have his work cut out to ensure that his status as the doyen of a new generation of energetic, ambitious, globally minded French executives is not to sustain a hefty knock.

Vivendi has clearly looked at the offers that came in for the Environment launch and seen an opportunity to capitalise on the strength of retail demand. But is it right in the longer term to look to retail investors to make up for a degree of institutional apathy?

The French market was already looking a little tired ahead of yesterday's postponement. Shares in Eads, the aerospace combine, are still below the offer price, while the ennui is not confined to Paris - last month's offering of Deutsche Telekom stock is another trading below the issue price. Markets are largely treading water and institutional investors are clearly looking forward to the summer break.

Asking retail investors to take up the slack is a risky affair. One the one hand retail demand is growing in Europe and has plenty of ground to make up before it starts to rival US levels. Retail investors will become increasingly important to both initial offerings and secondary demand. But if they find themselves being left with issues on which the institutions are less than enthused and the institutional view proves correct that appetite could soon be blunted. And retail investors may bring additional volatility to the markets. Much of the increase in private investor activity has come through online dealing. Just as it is becoming easier and cheaper to get into the market, the same can be said of the exit route.

Retail investors may prove to have even shorter time horizons than their institutional counterparts. They can also be expensive to service.

Just think of the bill for providing coffee and croissants at the annual shareholders' meeting.

If and when

There are sure to have been a few quiet chuckles in some of the old economy outposts of the Halifax's sprawling banking empire yesterday after news that techno-hitches would delay the start of Intelligent Finance.

Since IF was announced in February little has been heard of the branch network and lending business that provides Britain's biggest mortgage lender with most of its £1.8bn annual profit. Instead, the 37,000 Halifax staff have read all about the trendy new internet project, its elite team of managers and its Fatboy Slim theme tune. There is also the £120m being pushed in the direction of cyberspace to build a business not expected to make a profit for three years.

Yesterday's evidence that Jim Spowart's team is fallible after all will have been greeted with some delight among the Halifax rank and file. While Spowart is clearly doing his best to rectify things, spare a thought for the top Halifax management who must keep things together.

Managing the change from old economy company to new is perhaps the biggest issue facing the directors of many of Britain's biggest companies. Most will be presented with tricky personnel issues, having to lavish time and attention on the new baby but not forgetting the first-born.

Few will find it easy, some will fall by the wayside trying. Those who are able to integrate the two with minimum disruption to staff morale and day to day operation might even survive.

Fizzy Orange

Today or Monday, mobile phone group Orange, freshly liberated from Vodafone AirTouch, is likely to announce an alliance with a big fixed-line telecoms operator, and every one assumes the company will be Energis.

This is a natural link-up, but it rather goes against the grain of the presentation yesterday, where Orange's boss, Hans Snook, banged on for close to an hour about how the mobile, or the coming wave of portable gizmos, will become the primary point of entry for the internet. Fixed line is so yesterday.

Mr Snook wants us all to live in OrangeWorld, where it seems that everything that moves carries a little trademark symbol. The future is Orange Travelling to the Orange Mall in an Orange Car, worrying about your Orange Health and forgetting to go to the Orange Bank. What is more, Mr Snook is threatening to "enrich" OrangeWorld with ideas hatched in a new breed of "imaginariums." If the man is not careful, someone might commit him to one.

fields.headline: Corrs join EU anti-piracy campaign
fields.trailText: Irish pop band the Corrs yesterday joined synthesiser maestro Jean-Michel Jarre in a high profile campaign against music piracy on the internet, aiming to alter a new European directive on the issue.
fields.body:
Irish pop band the Corrs yesterday joined synthesiser maestro Jean-Michel Jarre in a high profile campaign against music piracy on the internet, aiming to alter a new European directive on the issue.

The International Federation of Phonographic Industries (Ifpi) estimates that there are at least 25m illegal music files on the internet, with up to 1bn downloads every year.

Jim Corr, guitarist, keyboard player and songwriter for the family outfit, argued that downloading music on the net without paying for the privilege was akin to theft.

"Most people would not dream of stealing a CD from their local record store. In the same way we don't think it's cool to go cyber shoplifting.

"In just an eight-hour period, over 18,000 illegal Corrs music files and over 17,000 Jean-Michel Jarre files were found on the internet."

Jay Berman, Ifpi chairfman, called on Euro MPs and EU governments to tighten up the provisions of a European copyright directive which would allow people to make private copies of their favourite songs.

"There is nothing private about 200m people on the internet mass-producing your music. It is not private copying if businesses are making copies without the consent of the artist or the record company."

Ifpi says some 600,000 music industry jobs are at stake and that the £8bn European music industry lost almost £1bn last year because of piracy.

The head of Sony Music Europe said yesterday the battle between the record industry and music websites could be settled if downloaders ploughed cash into artist development.

Paul Russell said it would be possible to accept companies such as Napster if they used their online advertising revenues to pay and promote their artists.

"If they came along and said 'We are smarter than you. We are going to sign up artists and we are going to invest in their careers and we are going put their music up and its free and we pay artists from advertising' If that was their position I could deal with that."

webTitle: If I got uptight about lateness Id have a stroke

fields.headline: If I got uptight about lateness Id have a stroke
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Jacqui Mott, 40, is a secretary at a firm of surveyors in London. She commutes to Euston from Milton Keynes, Buckinghamshire. She says she is tired of excuses.
fields.body:
Jacqui Mott, 40, is a secretary at a firm of surveyors in London. She commutes to Euston from Milton Keynes, Buckinghamshire. She says she is tired of excuses.

Mainly we hear about signal problems or that they are waiting for a guard whose train has been delayed arriving.

Most people are usually good humoured about it but when the train is crammed and there is no where to sit people can get angry. Thats especially a worry for me because Im six months pregnant.

Most of the time it just makes us smile. I dont think we take what they say very seriously.

At the moment they have put up posters about repair work on my line  whatever they say, in the end you are still late. I just give my boss an apologetic look.

Sara Harris, 27, is a junior executive at Cable and Wireless. She commutes five days a week from Leighton Buzzard, Bedfordshire, on a service she describes as dismal.

It seems to have got even worse since they introduced the summer timetable.

The other day the 7.45 was delayed an hour and the driver told us it was due to a track failure in a tunnel while the guard said it was problems with the train in front.

I think they try to explain the reasons for delays to us but sometimes it looks like they are making things up.

My boss is fairly understanding when Im late because she is quite often delayed coming in from Sutton on Connex trains.

My travel works out at £2,592 for the year which is a hell of a lot to pay if it doesnt get you in to work on time.

Ron Low, 60, is a tax accountant with an oil company in London. He commutes five days a week from Northampton to Euston and says that, despite occasional delays, he still considers the service to be reasonable.

Although last week there was a problem when the 7.13 was cancelled. The next train was also delayed because, we were told, four carriages had not been attached.

Then I believe it was engineering works on the line at the London end that finally made us 45 minutes late.

I dont let it bother me. If I got uptight about it I would get a stroke.

Fortunately they take a lenient view of lateness at work. I make up time after work or later in the evenings. We have flexible working days to cope with this kind of problem.
