fields.standfirst:
Hostages emerge from parliament but democracy and the multi-ethnic constitution lie in ruins
The Fiji coup: special report
fields.trailText: Fiji's political crisis seemed far from over last night, despite the freeing of political hostages, the appointment of a new president, and plans by the rebels to hand over their weapons today and claim amnesty.
fields.byline: Christopher Zinn and agencies in Suva
fields.body:
Fiji's political crisis seemed far from over last night, despite the freeing of political hostages, the appointment of a new president, and plans by the rebels to hand over their weapons today and claim amnesty.

The political system and the economy remained in turmoil. The New Zealand government said the country was slipping into anarchy, and Australia - deploring the rebels' credo of race-based politics - advised its 1,700 citizens registered with the high commission in Fiji to leave.

Outside the capital, Suva, prisoners rioted and one man was shot dead.

People taking advantage of the power vacuum to settle land disputes seized two more holiday resorts, yet another blow to the vital tourism industry which is now in ruins.

Hotels in the islands report that their occupancy rate has fallen to 10%.

The rebel leader, George Speight, released the last 18 of his hostages yesterday and the country's Great Council of Chiefs responded by appointing his nominee president.

He is Josefa Ilo Ilo, a former vice-president .

The drama began on May 19, when an armed gang invaded parliament and Mr Speight, announced that he had overthrown the first ethnic Indian prime minister in the name of indigenous Fijians.

The gang took 27 people hostage, including the prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and members of his cabinet.

Mr Chaudhry, who was forced to resign half way through his 56 days in captivity, was among the last 18 hostages released yesterday.

The releases followed a deal reached on Sunday in which the military authorities, who took temporary control on May 29 to try to stop the violence and looting that broke out after Mr Speight's coup, accepted his demands.

These were that the multiracial constitution should be scrapped, the democratically elected Mr Chaudhry should be formally overthrown, and Mr Speight and his henchmen should receive amnesty for any acts committed in their campaign to make indigenous Fijians paramount.

After he was freed yesterday, Mr Chaudhry said he had a continuing role in politics and bore his captors no ill will, even though on one occasion they beat him up.

Just before he was freed he hugged Mr Speight, and some of the hostage MPs and their captors were in tears.

But it is unclear how Mr Chaudhry, a former trade union leader who was elected prime minister 14 months ago, can have any role in the government to be appointed by the new president, in which Mr Speight is expected to have an important role behind the scenes.

"My priority is that the nation must get back on its feet," Mr Chaudhry said.

"There are a lot of people there who have suffered because of what's [happened] and they're our priority."

The Indian Fijians, whose forebears were brought to the islands by British colonialists more than a century ago, make up 44% of Fiji's population, although 67,000 fled overseas after two coups in 1987. Indigenous Fijians make up 51%.

Now that the multiracial constitution is gone, many thousands of Indian Fijians from the educated middle class and business elite are expected to leave the country.

It guaranteed them, among other things, a share of power in government.

Amnesty International said it was gravely concerned that the abolition of the 1997 constitution left human rights inadequately protected.

"There are no human rights guarantees for the various people who have opposed the coup, as well as ethnic Indian Fijians," it said in a statement.

"These individuals have been subjected to threats of death or other forms of physical violence, and to attacks upon their person and property."

The Australian prime minister, John Howard, welcomed the end to the hostage crisis yesterday but said his country was disturbed at Fiji's slide into race-based politics.

"This was a criminal act which denied a democratically elected government its constitutional right to govern in the interests of the people of Fiji," his statement said.

"The Australian government remains profoundly disturbed at the abrogation of the Fijian constitution and the racially based approach apparently being taken to future constitutional arrangements."

His statement made no specific mention of the military authorities, but their acquiescence remains in doubt.

One of the spokesmen for the armed forces confirmed yesterday that Mr Speight and his men would get amnesty.

"There may be a few processes that need to take place, with regard to the processing of this amnesty for him and his group, and those associated with the political crimes, so to speak," Major Howard Politini said.

"But yes, effectively he goes free."

The head of the Trade Union Congress, Felix Anthony, said that people were still deeply worried about Fiji's political future.

"I think that there is going to be a fair bit of opposition as to what political decisions are being made now and what will be made in the next couple of days, not only from the Indian community but from the population at large, who cherish democracy and the rule of law," he said.

The two-month hostage crisis has opened the door to civil unrest, a range of groups taking advantage of the disarray. The seizure of resorts by local groups caused the Australian authorities to urge travellers to defer their visits to Fiji.

The groups responsible for the seizures say they were acting in support of Mr Speight's faction. But in reality they appear to be people taking matters into their own hands in pursuance of previous land disputes.

The military authorities said yesterday that two more tourist centres - the Buca Bay and Rukuruku resorts - had been seized, bringing the total number to four. The other two are the expensive Laucala Island and Turtle Island resorts.

The Fiji Hotel Association said it was concerned that there could be more copy-cat seizures by villagers making land claims.

Another military spokesman, Lieutenent-Colonel Filipo Tarakinikini, said: "There's still a lot of mopping up operations to be done throughout the country, and that's where the military will work in conjunction with the police to take care of all that."

webTitle: Obstacle race to find the running-mates

fields.headline: Obstacle race to find the running-mates
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Al Gore's chance of overturning George W Bush's lead in the US presidential race now hinges on his choice of running-mate and on the timing of the announcement, increasingly alarmed Democratic insiders believe.
fields.body:
Al Gore's chance of overturning George W Bush's lead in the US presidential race now hinges on his choice of running-mate and on the timing of the announcement, increasingly alarmed Democratic insiders believe.

With Mr Bush again stretching his national poll lead into double figures, Mr Gore aims to announce his Democratic vice-presidential choice earlier than previously intended, in an attempt to recapture the initiative.

Mr Bush is expected to announce his running-mate on the eve of the Republican convention in Philadelphia, which starts on July 31. Mr Gore is hoping to unveil his vice-presidential choice on August 4, immediately after the Republican convention ends.

The Gore camp hopes that this manoeuvre will help to seize the news agenda from his rival, minimise any post-Philadelphia poll boost for Mr Bush, and allow Mr Gore to arrive at the Democratic convention in Los Angeles on August 14 on an upswing.

With the presidential campaign currently in a pre-convention season lull, both men are polishing their vice-presidential shortlists, a generally well-guarded backroom process which nevertheless provides hundreds of column inches of media speculation.

Mr Bush's shortlist is being drawn up by his father's former defence secretary Dick Cheney, while Mr Gore's final selection will come from a list compiled by the former Clinton administration secretary of state Warren Christopher.

Both men have been quietly interviewing the likely candidates before submitting their chosen finalists to a detailed personal vetting process, including their financial, tax and medical histories.

By general consent, Mr Bush has a much stronger field of possibilities from which to choose, a reflection in part of the Republicans' advantage in having 30 state governors to choose from, compared with the Democrats' 18 (there are two independents), and 55 US senators compared with the Democrats' 45.

Judging by his campaigning stance since the end of the primary contests, Mr Bush seems increasingly likely to opt for a Republican moderate to strengthen his claim to the electoral centre-ground, a decision which would anger many rightwing activists and enable Mr Bush to present his leadership as a break from the past.

The current favourite on the Republican side seems to be Governor Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, a decorated Vietnam veteran who is in favour of abortion rights despite being a Roman Catholic. A timely new poll yesterday showed that with Mr Ridge on the ticket, Mr Bush could carry Pennsylvania by 51% to 39%; without Mr Ridge, he would lead by only 44% to Mr Gore's 40%, uncomfortably close to the polling margin of error.

Governor Frank Keating of Oklahoma is also widely tipped as a possible Bush "soulmate" nominee. The New Jersey governor, Christine Todd Whitman, another Republican moderate, is under consideration too, but is considered a longshot.

Among senators, few believe that John McCain can be persuaded to join the Republican ticket, even if Mr Bush wanted him. Mr McCain's ally Senator Chuck Hagel of Nebraska, though, is another matter: a smart pragmatist and another Vietnam veteran.

Fred Thompson of Tennessee is another possibility, not least because he could embarrass Mr Gore in his home state.

By common consent Mr Gore's choice is much more difficult. Not only are there deep divisions among Mr Gore's advisers about the kind of candidate they should select, but the field is much thinner than the Republicans'. That fact, along with Mr Bush's poll lead, has led to speculation that Mr Gore may go right outside the traditional pool of politicians and select a national personality, such as the NBC television news anchor Tom Brokaw, or the former treasury secretary Robert Rubin.

If he follows Bill Clinton's example in 1992, Mr Gore will choose someone who would be a political soulmate, sending a message that he intends to lead from the centre. In that case, Senator Evan Bayh of Indiana, a former state governor, would be central casting's idea of "Gore's Gore".

But Mr Bayh is a relative unknown, and a bit too like Mr Gore in background. For that reason, Democratic moderates are pressing the claims of Senator Joseph Leiberman of Connecticut, an Orthodox Jew whose record of criticising Mr Clinton during the impeachment crisis might give the Democratic ticket a moral authority which some argue it could use.

Increasingly, though, the name in the moderate frame - at least among Washington observers - is Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts. Mr Kerry is another party moderate, a Catholic and a Vietnam veteran (though he opposed the war).

If Mr Gore chooses instead to put someone from a key state on the ticket, Senator Bob Graham of Florida would be an obvious choice. Mr Graham is many people's frontrunner, not least because he is also already close to Mr Gore politically and personally.

All the president's men

The good news for Al Gore is that the vice-presidency is a more reliable stepping stone to the presidency than any other office in US politics. One in three vice-presidents has gone on to the highest office.

The bad news is that only one vice-president in the past 164 years - George Bush in 1988 - has been elected to the White House at the end of his stint in the number two job.

Seven out of the 21 20th century vice-presidents got the ultimate political upgrade. But, with the exception of Mr Bush, all of them did so amid tragedy, scandal or after first suffering political defeat.

Teddy Roosevelt became president in 1901 after the assassination of William McKinley, the first of four 20th century vice-presidents to benefit from the death of a president in office.

Vice-President Calvin Coolidge succeeded Warren Harding, who died in 1923.

Harry Truman had the presidency thrust upon him when Franklin Roosevelt succumbed to a cerebral haemorrhage in April 1945.

The 20-year cycle of presidential deaths in office brought Lyndon Johnson to the White House in November 1963 after John Kennedy was assassinated.

Richard Nixon has gone down in history as the only president to resign. But he holds another unique historical distinction - as the only vice-president to reach the White House after first losing a presidential election. After two terms as Dwight Eisenhower's deputy from 1953, Nixon lost the 1960 presidential contest, but fought back to win the White House in 1968. Nixon's resignation at the height of the Watergate scandal in 1974 brought Gerald Ford to the presidency in yet another unique set of circumstances. Mr Ford ran for the presidency in the subsequent 1976 election, but was defeated by Jimmy Carter, a complete Washington outsider.

webTitle: The rhetoric and the reality: how ministers' claims of success check out

fields.headline: The rhetoric and the reality: how ministers' claims of success check out
fields.standfirst:
The Guardian's chief political correspondent Patrick Wintour looks at some of the government's key manifesto pledges
The government's annual report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The government's third annual report is designed to provide a checklist of how well ministers have done against 179 selected manifesto commitments. Repeatedly the report says: "We have only just begun. We need to do more.'' Here the Guardian's chief political correspondent Patrick Wintour looks at some of the government's key manifesto pledges, the claims the report makes on meeting these commitments, and then gives a check against which these  assertions can be matched.
fields.body:
The government's third annual report is designed to provide a checklist of how well ministers have done against 179 selected manifesto commitments. Repeatedly the report says: "We have only just begun. We need to do more.'' Here the Guardian's chief political correspondent Patrick Wintour looks at some of the government's key manifesto pledges, the claims the report makes on meeting these commitments, and then gives a check against which these assertions can be matched.

Education
Pledge: Over the course of a five-year parliament we will raise the proportion of national income spent on education. Claim: Spending per pupil in England has risen in real terms by £300 since 1997. Education will rise by 0.1% of national income in 2000-01 and by 0.2% in 2001-02, compared to 1996-97. Check: Claim is true and the government is on target to meet the pledge. Spending will rise in real terms by 3.2% per year over the parliament, and over the period of the comprehensive spending review by 5.2% per year. But average spending on education under the Tories between 1992-93 and 1996-97 as a proportion of GDP was 5%, compared with 4.7% for the whole of the Labour parliament.

Pledge: We will reduce class sizes for five, six and seven-year-olds to 30. Claim: 177,000 infants are now in large classes, compared with almost half a million in 1997. By September 2000 there are expected to be as few as 3% (around 50,000) of infants in classes over 30. Check: True, but class sizes for secondary schools have risen 0.2%.

Pledge: All local education authorities must demonstrate that every school is improving. Ministers will order a "fresh start" for failing schools, close the school and start afresh on the same site. Claim: For 15 schools, fresh starts have been used. A further 32 failing schools have been closed, with children transferring to more successful schools nearby. Check: True - overall doing OK.

Pledge: Within a decade every child will leave primary school with a reading age of at least 11 (barely half do today). Our numeracy taskforce will develop equally ambitious targets. Claim: Some 80% of 11-year-olds should reach the standard expected for their age in literacy by 2002. The 1999 results showed a 6% rise to 71%. We have introduced a similar 75% target for numeracy. 1999 results showed a 10% increase to 69%. Check: David Blunkett has promised to resign if he does not meet these targets. On course to stay in office.

Pledge: Teachers will be entitled to positive support from parents to promote good attendance and sound discipline. New pupil referral units so that schools are protected but these pupils are not lost to education or the country. Claim: Spending on truancy, discipline and exclusions has risen from £17m in 1996-97 to £140m in 2000-01. Check: Exclusions still rising, but conflictinbg advice from government as to if exclusions should be encouraged.

Health
Pledge: We will cut NHS waiting lists by treating an extra 100,000 patients as a first step, by releasing £100m saved from NHS red tape. Claim: As of March 2000, in-patient waiting lists were 104,000 below the number inherited. Check: True, but number of out-patient waiting lists is 496,000, doubling from 284,000 since government came to power.

Pledge: Hospitals will retain autonomy over day to day administrative functions, but boards will become more representative of local communities they serve. Claim: Since the government took office, 49% of NHS appointments have been women, and 12.2% have come from ethnic minority backgrounds. This compares with figures of 39% and 5% immediately before the election. Check: Public appointments commissioner denounced ministers for appointing 284 Labour councillors to boards and only 59 from other two parties.

Pledge: We will raise spending on the NHS in real terms every year and put the money towards patient care. And a greater proportion of every pound will go on patient care, not bureaucracy. Claim: NHS has had its biggest ever increase in resources - an immediate cash boost this year of £2bn plus average annual growth of 6% over next 4 years. Check: True, but Britain will still be behind in per capita spending in Europe. Spending in first two years lower than average for the Major years.

Pledge: End waiting for cancer surgery, thereby helping thousands of women waiting for breast cancer surgery. Claim: More than 95% of women with suspected breast cancer now seen for their first out-patient appointment within two weeks of urgent referral. This year, we will extend that to all cancer patients. Check: True, but doctors claim waiting time less important than seeing appropriate specialist.

Pledge: Smoking is the greatest single cause of preventable illness and premature death in the UK. We will therefore ban tobacco advertising. Claim: At present a legal challenge from the UK tobacco industry has prevented us from implementing the European directive banning tobacco advertising, Check: Advertising likely to continue for some events until 2006.

Crime Pledge: The police have our strong support. We will relieve them of unnecessary bureaucratic burdens to get more officers back on the beat. Claim: The relevant provisions of the Youth Justice and Criminal Evidence Act 1999 will be piloted in seven areas from summer 2000, ahead of expected national implementation in 2002. Check: Government unable yesterday to directly answer the pledge or explain the meaning of the claim. Police numbers have fallen in 33 out of 43 forces.

Pledge: Child protection orders will deal with young children suffering neglect by parents because they are left out on their own far too late at night. Claim: Local child curfew in force since 30 September 1998. Child safety orders under the 1998 Act implemented nationally on June 1, 2000. Check: Not a single curfew application made by police or councils; only two child safety orders, both in Sunderland.

Pledge: New parental responsibility orders will make parents face up to their responsibility for their children's misbehaviour. Claim: Parenting orders implemented nationally on June 1, 2000. Check: Only 42 imposed in pilot areas.

Pledge: Community safety orders will deal with threatening and disruptive criminal neighbours. Claim: Anti-social behaviour orders introduced April 1999, more than 80 granted. Check: Very low take-up by council as violent crime increases by 10%.

Pledge: Britain is a multiracial and multicultural society. All its members must have the protection of the law. Claim: Recommendations of Stephen Lawrence inquiry were accepted including extension of anti-discrimination laws. New ethnic minority targets set for police forces. Check: Reporting of racially aggravated offences rising - 11,0000 between April and September 1999 alone. Police say this reflects growing confidence in the policy by minority groups Pledge: The vicious circle of drugs and crime wrecks lives and threatens communities. We will appoint an anti-drugs supremo Claim: Keith Hellawell was appointed to head the UK anti-drugs co-ordinating unit, which has set ambitious targets for cutting availability and use of dangerous drugs. Check: Even the government admits progress is slow, and one third of all property crime is drug related. Drug treatment and testing orders due to go nationwide, but pilots showed a third of them had to be revoked for breaches. Soft drug use amongst children stabilised, surveys show.

Economy and welfare
Pledge: Stable low inflation conditions for the long term. Claim: Inflation has averaged 2.5%. Check: Bank of England's independent committee a success, but inflation still higher than many EU countries.

Pledge: Stop growth of an underclass. Claim: We have cut long-term unemployment among 18 to 24-year-olds by 124,000 and unemployment has fallen by 407,000 since the election (as at May 2000) and is at its lowest for 20 years. Check: Proportion of population living in working age workless families has decreased, but only from 21% in 1994-95 to 18% in 1998-99.

Pledge: We must crack down on dishonesty in the benefit system, starting with a clampdown on housing benefit fraud, estimated to cost £2bn a year. Claim: We have tightened up access to benefits. Check: Housing fraud prosecutions fell by 60,000 in 1998-99. Level of income support and job seekers allowance errors are on the increase and total benefit fraud estimated as high as £7bn by MPs' public accounts committee.

Pledge:System for dealing with asylum seekers is expensive. We will ensure swift and fair decisions. Claim: On course to deliver target of most initial asylum decisions within two months and most appeals within a further four months by April 2001. Check: Asylum applications up 22% on previous year last month, even if number of decisions had risen to 10,765 in May, double the figure for last year. Overall backlog had doubled from 57,000 in 1996 to 102,0000 at end of 1997.

Democracy
Pledge: We are committed to a referendum on the voting system for the House of Commons. An independent commission on voting systems will be appointed early to recommend a proportional alternative to the first past the post system. Claim: The independent commission reported in October 1998. The timing of a referendum has not yet been decided. Check: Enthusiasm for reform is rapidly dampening and no referendum in this parliament and probably not in the next.

Pledge: In time we will introduce legislation to allow the people, region by region, to decide in a referendum whether they want directly elected assemblies Claim: Work is in progress examining new models of regional governance where there is strong popular demand for them. Check: Government undecided on the merits of this one.

Pledge: Establish a London mayor, Scottish parliament and Welsh assembly. Claim: All achieved. Check: Claim 100% true, even if Tony Blair has been criticised for failing to allow regional parties to make their own choice of candidate or leader.

Pledge: We will ban foreign funding of political parties. Claim: Measures to ban foreign funding of political parties and to require parties to disclose large donations are included in the political parties bill. Check: Donations from EU based companies will be allowed and bill still not on statute book. Others

fields.bodyText: The government's third annual report is designed to provide a checklist of how well ministers have done against 179 selected manifesto commitments. Repeatedly the report says: "We have only just begun. We need to do more.'' Here the Guardian's chief political correspondent Patrick Wintour looks at some of the government's key manifesto pledges, the claims the report makes on meeting these commitments, and then gives a check against which these assertions can be matched. Education Pledge: Over the course of a five-year parliament we will raise the proportion of national income spent on education. Claim: Spending per pupil in England has risen in real terms by £300 since 1997. Education will rise by 0.1% of national income in 2000-01 and by 0.2% in 2001-02, compared to 1996-97. Check: Claim is true and the government is on target to meet the pledge. Spending will rise in real terms by 3.2% per year over the parliament, and over the period of the comprehensive spending review by 5.2% per year. But average spending on education under the Tories between 1992-93 and 1996-97 as a proportion of GDP was 5%, compared with 4.7% for the whole of the Labour parliament. Pledge: We will reduce class sizes for five, six and seven-year-olds to 30. Claim: 177,000 infants are now in large classes, compared with almost half a million in 1997. By September 2000 there are expected to be as few as 3% (around 50,000) of infants in classes over 30. Check: True, but class sizes for secondary schools have risen 0.2%. Pledge: All local education authorities must demonstrate that every school is improving. Ministers will order a "fresh start" for failing schools, close the school and start afresh on the same site. Claim: For 15 schools, fresh starts have been used. A further 32 failing schools have been closed, with children transferring to more successful schools nearby. Check: True - overall doing OK. Pledge: Within a decade every child will leave primary school with a reading age of at least 11 (barely half do today). Our numeracy taskforce will develop equally ambitious targets. Claim: Some 80% of 11-year-olds should reach the standard expected for their age in literacy by 2002. The 1999 results showed a 6% rise to 71%. We have introduced a similar 75% target for numeracy. 1999 results showed a 10% increase to 69%. Check: David Blunkett has promised to resign if he does not meet these targets. On course to stay in office. Pledge: Teachers will be entitled to positive support from parents to promote good attendance and sound discipline. New pupil referral units so that schools are protected but these pupils are not lost to education or the country. Claim: Spending on truancy, discipline and exclusions has risen from £17m in 1996-97 to £140m in 2000-01. Check: Exclusions still rising, but conflictinbg advice from government as to if exclusions should be encouraged. Health Pledge: We will cut NHS waiting lists by treating an extra 100,000 patients as a first step, by releasing £100m saved from NHS red tape. Claim: As of March 2000, in-patient waiting lists were 104,000 below the number inherited. Check: True, but number of out-patient waiting lists is 496,000, doubling from 284,000 since government came to power. Pledge: Hospitals will retain autonomy over day to day administrative functions, but boards will become more representative of local communities they serve. Claim: Since the government took office, 49% of NHS appointments have been women, and 12.2% have come from ethnic minority backgrounds. This compares with figures of 39% and 5% immediately before the election. Check: Public appointments commissioner denounced ministers for appointing 284 Labour councillors to boards and only 59 from other two parties. Pledge: We will raise spending on the NHS in real terms every year and put the money towards patient care. And a greater proportion of every pound will go on patient care, not bureaucracy. Claim: NHS has had its biggest ever increase in resources - an immediate cash boost this year of £2bn plus average annual growth of 6% over next 4 years. Check: True, but Britain will still be behind in per capita spending in Europe. Spending in first two years lower than average for the Major years. Pledge: End waiting for cancer surgery, thereby helping thousands of women waiting for breast cancer surgery. Claim: More than 95% of women with suspected breast cancer now seen for their first out-patient appointment within two weeks of urgent referral. This year, we will extend that to all cancer patients. Check: True, but doctors claim waiting time less important than seeing appropriate specialist. Pledge: Smoking is the greatest single cause of preventable illness and premature death in the UK. We will therefore ban tobacco advertising. Claim: At present a legal challenge from the UK tobacco industry has prevented us from implementing the European directive banning tobacco advertising, Check: Advertising likely to continue for some events until 2006. Crime Pledge: The police have our strong support. We will relieve them of unnecessary bureaucratic burdens to get more officers back on the beat. Claim: The relevant provisions of the Youth Justice and Criminal Evidence Act 1999 will be piloted in seven areas from summer 2000, ahead of expected national implementation in 2002. Check: Government unable yesterday to directly answer the pledge or explain the meaning of the claim. Police numbers have fallen in 33 out of 43 forces. Pledge: Child protection orders will deal with young children suffering neglect by parents because they are left out on their own far too late at night. Claim: Local child curfew in force since 30 September 1998. Child safety orders under the 1998 Act implemented nationally on June 1, 2000. Check: Not a single curfew application made by police or councils; only two child safety orders, both in Sunderland. Pledge: New parental responsibility orders will make parents face up to their responsibility for their children's misbehaviour. Claim: Parenting orders implemented nationally on June 1, 2000. Check: Only 42 imposed in pilot areas. Pledge: Community safety orders will deal with threatening and disruptive criminal neighbours. Claim: Anti-social behaviour orders introduced April 1999, more than 80 granted. Check: Very low take-up by council as violent crime increases by 10%. Pledge: Britain is a multiracial and multicultural society. All its members must have the protection of the law. Claim: Recommendations of Stephen Lawrence inquiry were accepted including extension of anti-discrimination laws. New ethnic minority targets set for police forces. Check: Reporting of racially aggravated offences rising - 11,0000 between April and September 1999 alone. Police say this reflects growing confidence in the policy by minority groups Pledge: The vicious circle of drugs and crime wrecks lives and threatens communities. Check: Even the government admits progress is slow, and one third of all property crime is drug related. Drug treatment and testing orders due to go nationwide, but pilots showed a third of them had to be revoked for breaches. Soft drug use amongst children stabilised, surveys show. Check: Bank of England's independent committee a success, but inflation still higher than many EU countries. Pledge: Stop growth of an underclass. Claim: We have cut long-term unemployment among 18 to 24-year-olds by 124,000 and unemployment has fallen by 407,000 since the election (as at May 2000) and is at its lowest for 20 years. Check: Proportion of population living in working age workless families has decreased, but only from 21% in 1994-95 to 18% in 1998-99. Check: Housing fraud prosecutions fell by 60,000 in 1998-99. webTitle: Harry Potter and the secrets of the chamber

fields.headline: Harry Potter and the secrets of the chamber
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Sketch: The New Statesman once ran a competition to find the most off-putting welcome from a hostess at a party. The winner was: "Come in, Sir Geoffrey is on sparkling form tonight!"
fields.body:
The New Statesman once ran a competition to find the most off-putting welcome from a hostess at a party. The winner was: "Come in, Sir Geoffrey is on sparkling form tonight!"

If they had a similar prize for the line most likely to drive an onlooker from the chamber, it would be William Hague's yesterday: "I now turn to my own proposals for parliamentary reform." It certainly caused me to leg it to the cafeteria, fast. As Mr Bennet said to one of his daughters, performing at a soiree: "No, no, my dear, you have delighted us enough."

I arrived in the chamber an hour or so earlier, having watched most of the new BBC2 programme about No 10, Alastair Campbell and the media. The film, to be broadcast tomorrow, reminds us that Downing Street always becomes a closed self-supporting bunker, in which the prime minister and his staff genuinely believe they are doing the best they can for the country, while suffering the cruel barbs of a vicious opposition, bitter, disputatious backbenchers on their own side, and the media, which are mean-spirited, slapdash and cowardly.

This is a view that hardens as the months and years go by, and things are not helped when the enemy does get things wrong. For instance, this week Tony Blair has made two full statements, opened the tributes to the Queen Mum, handled his usual question time, and yesterday faced a debate initiated by the Tories on, among other topics, his failure ever to turn up in the House of Commons.

Before that yesterday he made a statement about the government's annual report, a rather absurd document that purports to list New Labour's multitudinous achievements. As William Hague pointed out, the contents range from the banal to the "completely untrue".

On page 47 it claims that "this year saw the opening of the UK Sports Institute in Sheffield". Mr Hague said: "As everyone in Sheffield knows, not a brick has been laid  and the whole thing is now to be sited in London.

"How are we to believe this rubbish? No wonder they only sold 49,000 copies last year, and 41,000 were bought by the government. It's not exactly Harry Potter, though it requires as much imagination to believe it."

There was a classic New Labour moment. The former Northern Ireland secretary Peter Brooke asked with downbeat diffidence whether the prime minister could provide us with "a preliminary explanation of the illustration on page 24".

As MPs riffled through the report they saw a big picture of one of those pop-out pill dispenser things, with random coloured pills marked "nurses", "hospitals" and "GPs", each next to a date. It looks good, it implies a pious hope for the future, and it means nothing whatever.

Next Mr Hague began his attack on the government's political culture. He made some good points, but rather spoiled the effect with too many pointless statistics. Does anyone care that Robin Cook has only voted 15% of the times that he could? Does Mr Hague expect the foreign secretary to say to Madeleine Albright: "Oops, must fly home to vote in the royal parks (trading) bill, or our majority might drop to 189!"

By the time Mr Blair replied, the Speaker had slipped out and been replaced by her deputy, Alan Haselhurst. But this did not stop Mr Blair from calling him "Madam Speaker" on at least 20 occasions.

Mr Haselhurst bore it manfully for the first dozen times, then diffidently pointed himself out. The prime minister apologised graciously, then did it again, at least six more times. He must be awfully rattled.

fields.headline: Thatcher trademark bags £100,000 for charity
fields.trailText: Most grown men might quake at the prospect of a handbagging from Lady Thatcher. Ian Rushbrook is positively revelling in it.
fields.body:
Most grown men might quake at the prospect of a handbagging from Lady Thatcher. Ian Rushbrook is positively revelling in it.

The Scottish businessman has paid £100,000 for the Iron Ladys trademark bag at an auction in aid of Breast Cancer Care. The Ferragamo clutch was one of 15 celebrity bags in a 10-day online sale but was by far the most sought after.

Rigid of structure and firm of clasp, it was often wielded by Lady Thatcher during her term of office, closing with a brisk snap the day she left Downing Street.

Mr Rushbrook, investment director of the Edinburgh-based Personal Assets Trust and Collective Assets Trust, was so keen to get his hands on his heroines designer number that he upped his initial offer of £63,000 to £100,000 to beat an American bidder.

For over 20 years I have admired Lady Thatchers willpower, drive and ability, he said. What she did for Britain was desperately needed and seemingly impossible but she has never had anywhere near the level of credit that she deserves. While the handbag is a piece of history in its own right as Lady Thatchers famous trademark, it is really incidental to my two aims of helping an outstandingly good cause while at the same time paying a personal tribute to a great national leader.

The black handbag, which contains a note written by the former prime minister, attracted 63 bids during the auction, which raised £103,000.

Jerry Halls handbag went for £720 after receiving only 18 bids, Cherie Booths tiger-striped donation made £490 following 38 bids and Mo Mowlams offering raised £302 with 24 bids.

Isabel Campbell, fundraising and marketing director of Breast Cancer Care, said the charity was delighted at how much had been raised.

Lady Thatcher, meanwhile, said she was thrilled that her bag had fetched so much. My handbags did good service in cabinet and I am pleased they are still having the right effect.

webTitle: Modern image for Miss World at 50

fields.headline: Modern image for Miss World at 50
fields.trailText: First the bad news. Miss World's return to terrestrial TV was such a success last year Channel 5 is showing it again. The good news is that it will come from the Millennium Dome and be compered by Jerry Springer.  Even in this post-feminist age when women are allowed to be girlie if they choose, the pageant forever associated with the worst of 1970s male chauvinism has had to make concessions to political correctness.
fields.body:
First the bad news. Miss World's return to terrestrial TV was such a success last year Channel 5 is showing it again. The good news is that it will come from the Millennium Dome and be compered by Jerry Springer. Even in this post-feminist age when women are allowed to be girlie if they choose, the pageant forever associated with the worst of 1970s male chauvinism has had to make concessions to political correctness.

This year, to mark its 50th anniversary, Miss World will have a higher purpose. Perfect teeth and a love of children and animals will no longer be enough, according to its ageing founder, Eric Morley. Rather, the 21st century Miss World is all about "beauty with a higher purpose". Nor will the 100 or so contestants be asked to parade in bikinis in the chill of the dome. The swimsuit heats will be conducted away from prying eyes in the Maldives.

"Sixty per cent of the audience are women. It is not about ogling men at all," said Mr Morley yesterday. "And I bet not many people know that the girls have raised £100m for children's causes down the years."

But a Miss Angola asked two years ago what she would do if she won the big prize said, "Party! House! Mercedes!" Her reply was tactfully translated by officials as: "She would be very proud to win for her country." While Britain may still be mildly embarrassed, Mr Morley, now 82, claimed that Miss World has never been so popular abroad.

"Since we stopped doing it live in the UK we have grown from 36 countries to 135 countries and we now have a 2bn audience worldwide. They did us a favour really [taking it off TV]. The girls haven't changed that much down the years. They've got a lot taller - you won't see many below five foot six now - but I think people still prefer normal women than very thin supermodels. I can only think of one winner who went on to be a model.

"Many of the women use the prize money and experience to further their education and among them have been doctors, lawyers, computer engineers and architects."

The dome's chief executive, Pierre Yves Gerbeau, is thrilled and believes landing the contest is a coup. But the Conservative women's spokesman, Theresa May, said: "If this is the best they can do to celebrate Britain's heritage in the Millennium Dome, then they are lacking in imagination. Given that this comes at a time when the government has called a symposium on how women present themselves, this looks like a bit of hypocrisy."

Unlike many of her predecessors, the present Miss World, 22-year-old Yukta Mookhey, has had a scandal-free reign. Her victory was seen as a national triumph in India, and a career in Bollywood films beckons. She said yesterday that it had been "the greatest year of her life".

Mr Morley said it was fitting that the final would be staged in the dome since he started Miss World as a way of livening up the Festival of Britain in 1951. "There was no page 3 in those days, of course, and the swimsuits were thought of as very risqué."

The Miss World contest, which is being run in conjunction with the Asian TV network Zee, will be held on November 30.

webTitle: New land seizures lead to violence in Zimbabwe

fields.headline: New land seizures lead to violence in Zimbabwe
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: President Robert Mugabe's government will begin widespread seizures of white farms today after sending army units into townships near Harare and other cities which supported the opposition.
fields.body:
President Robert Mugabe's government will begin widespread seizures of white farms today after sending army units into townships near Harare and other cities which supported the opposition.

Hopes that Zimbabwe would return to normal after the June parliamentary elections have been dashed by the government's heavy-handed actions.

Mr Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF resorted to violence in the election campaign but it only managed to win 62 of the 120 elected parliamentary seats. Now Mr Mugabe appears to be using state force to reinforce his authority over the country.

The government will begin confiscation of 160 white-owned farms today, Nathan Shamuyarira, the industry minister from the ruling Zanu-PF party, said, adding that the government will take possession of 20 farms in each of Zimbabwe's eight rural provinces and will settle government supporters there immediately.

But fear reigned in some rural areas yesterday as dozens of white farmers were told to vacate their properties immediately or face death.

"No one is certain what is going to happen," said Tim Henwood, the president of the Commercial Farmers Union (CFU). "The government said officials would notify us which farms are to be taken, but we have not been informed. All around the country farmers are getting death threats."

The government last month earmarked 804 farms for compulsory acquisition, prompting more than 500 owners to lodge legal appeals.

The farms to be taken today were supposedly picked from more than 200 farms that did not appeal against the seizure orders. But Mr Mugabe's supporters have ordered the evacuation of farms that were not listed at all. More than 1,000 farms are now occupied.

Harare and two other cities were tense yesterday following the deployment of army and police units in township areas.

The troops were sent into the townships to prevent any violence following the parliamentary elections, a police spokesman said yesterday. But township dwellers complain that the units attacked peaceful citizens and Harare employers said scores of workers had suffered beatings. The army deployment appears to be government retaliation against Harare's townships for backing the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC).

One resident of Mbare township said: "We were seated, having our drinks and listening to the jukebox, when they [soldiers] stormed in and demanded that we all stand up and show them respect.

"When we did as they had asked they picked out two people and said they wanted to show us what they could do to misguided people. They then began beating the two with the butts of their rifles."

Chief Superintendent Wayne Bvudzijena, a police spokesman, said the charges against the police and army units had not been substantiated and they would continue to patrol potential "flashpoints".

He said people beaten by the patrols should report to the police, who were in control of the joint operation.

ZimRights, a human rights watchdog, condemned the reported attacks on civilians. Its chairman, Nick Ndebele, said: "Political violence should not be substituted with army or police violence."

But Mr Mugabe's supporters have ordered the evacuation of farms that were not listed at all. More than 1,000 farms are now occupied. Harare and two other cities were tense yesterday following the deployment of army and police units in township areas. The troops were sent into the townships to prevent any violence following the parliamentary elections, a police spokesman said yesterday. But township dwellers complain that the units attacked peaceful citizens and Harare employers said scores of workers had suffered beatings. The army deployment appears to be government retaliation against Harare's townships for backing the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC). One resident of Mbare township said: "We were seated, having our drinks and listening to the jukebox, when they [soldiers] stormed in and demanded that we all stand up and show them respect. "When we did as they had asked they picked out two people and said they wanted to show us what they could do to misguided people. They then began beating the two with the butts of their rifles." Chief Superintendent Wayne Bvudzijena, a police spokesman, said the charges against the police and army units had not been substantiated and they would continue to patrol potential "flashpoints". He said people beaten by the patrols should report to the police, who were in control of the joint operation. ZimRights, a human rights watchdog, condemned the reported attacks on civilians. Its chairman, Nick Ndebele, said: "Political violence should not be substituted with army or police violence."

webTitle: Postcode guide to services at grassroots

fields.headline: Postcode guide to services at grassroots
fields.trailText: The annual report is on the internet for anyone to see how their city, town or village is doing. Website visitors can put in their postcode and discover progress reports on their schools, hospitals and police forces. Here we pick the postcodes for Tony Blair and William Hague's constituency bases. The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, lives in Scotland, not covered by the website, so we look at how the party's home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, fares.
fields.body:
The annual report is on the internet for anyone to see how their city, town or village is doing. Website visitors can put in their postcode and discover progress reports on their schools, hospitals and police forces. Here we pick the postcodes for Tony Blair and William Hague's constituency bases. The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, lives in Scotland, not covered by the website, so we look at how the party's home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, fares.

Tony Blair
Constituency: Sedgefield
Postcode: TS29 6DU
The prime minister's constituency is one area where his mantra of education, education, education should be chanted. The north-east has the highest levels of unemployment and the lowest levels of GCSE results; it was perhaps as a result of these unwelcome statistics that the area benefited from the New Deal for Schools.

The local education authority budget allocation for 2000-01 is £212.26m, up £9.24m on last year. The number of infants in classes larger than 30 is down from 6,123 in 1997 to 1,330 - 8.1% of pupils - this year. The area has four Beacon-status schools but also four with serious weaknesses.

The local health authority budget allocation is up by 6.52% on last year at £453m. In-patient waiting lists have dropped to 11,656, but only by 845 since 1997, a decrease of 6.75%. However, out-patients waiting for an operation have nearly tripled from 1,997 to 5,922.

In Durham the average time from arrest to sentence for persistent young offenders has been cut by 33 days, a fall of 27.5%. Notifiable offences between October 1998 and September 1999 dropped to 49,180, compared with 52,474 a year earlier. Police numbers in the area have stayed almost constant: 1,555 in 1999, compared with 1,559 in 1998.

The report says that, thanks in part to the New Deal, long-term youth unemployment has fallen by 56% in Sedgefield since 1997, while unemployment in the north-east fell from 9.9% in February-April 1999 to 8.5% in the same period this year.

William Hague
Constituency: Richmond
Postcode: DL7 8EG
The leader of the opposition's constituency appears to have done rather well. Richmond has more than 760 foreign-owned companies employing 100,000 people, although areas of high unemployment remain, including in South Yorkshire, which has qualified for EU funding worth £760m in the next few years.

The LEA budget allocation for 2000-01 is up from £219.37m to £232.15m, and while there are still 1,500 infants in classes with more than 30 pupils, this is down from 4,808 in 1997. Six schools have achieved Beacon status; however, there are eight schools in special measures or with serious weaknesses.

The health authority budget allocation is up 6.52% on the previous year, bringing the total for 2000-01 to £453m. People waiting for in-patient operations are down from 15,315 in 1997 to 14,611. However, there has been a 37.5% rise in those awaiting out-patient treatment from 3,641 in March 1998 to 5,005 in 2000.

The average time from arrest to sentence for persistent young offenders in North Yorkshire has been cut by 33 days, or 26.4%. Crime is down by only 0.1% on notifiable offences. There were 66 fewer police officers in 1999 than in 1998, a drop of nearly 5%, in the North Yorkshire force.

Unemployment in Yorkshire and the Humber fell from 6.9% in February-April 1999 to 6.3% in the same period this year, and long-term youth unemployment has fallen by 56% in Richmond since 1997.

Simon Hughes
Constituency: North Southwark & Bermondsey
Postcode: SE1 3UJ
An inner-city Lib Dem constituency in London highlights the stark differences in how effectively the government is tackling the varying problems faced by rural as against urban constituencies.

In Southwark attempts to reduce class sizes appear to be working, with 410 infants, 4.63%, in classes larger than 30, down from 800 in 1997. The LEA budget allocation for 2000-01 is £130.40m, up £6.59m on last year, and four local schools have achieved Beacon status. However, there is a high level of failing schools, with 17 in special measures and with serious weaknesses.

In-patient waiting lists have dropped markedly from 19,261 in 1997 to 17,371, but this is accompanied by a big increase in out-patients waiting to be treated: 6,432, compared with 2,612 in March 1998.

The crime rate, at 13.11 offences per 100 of population, is above the national average of 9.98 offences and has increased by 8.7% from 920,095 notifiable offences in London between October 1997 and September 1998 to 1,000,380 for the following year. The average time from arrest to sentence for persistent young offenders has been cut by 57 days, a fall of 35.6%, but the number of officers in the Metropolitan police has dropped from 26,106 to 25,885.

Long-term youth unemployment has fallen by 63% in North Southwark and Bermondsey since 1997, while unemployment in the London region fell from 7.8% in February-April 1999 to 7.4% in the same period this year.

fields.headline: Education: a true vocation
fields.trailText: Surprise, surprise - Nick Davies retreats to proposing the unthinkable: bring back selection (Dutch lessons can save our schools, July 12). Of course, like the Dutch, we need more bakers than lawyers, more mechanics than doctors. The real trouble is that we value doctors and lawyers more than we value bakers and mechanics. We differentiate between vocational and professional and we reward them differently. To emphasise that differentiation by reintroducing formal selection, however heavily disguised, will exacerbate the problem.
fields.body:
Surprise, surprise - Nick Davies retreats to proposing the unthinkable: bring back selection (Dutch lessons can save our schools, July 12). Of course, like the Dutch, we need more bakers than lawyers, more mechanics than doctors. The real trouble is that we value doctors and lawyers more than we value bakers and mechanics. We differentiate between vocational and professional and we reward them differently. To emphasise that differentiation by reintroducing formal selection, however heavily disguised, will exacerbate the problem.

One of the main reasons for the failure of GNVQs was that they were seen as a hand-out to the less able. Surely vocational qualifications should be for all? Even doctors and lawyers need business training, need to know about healthy cooking, gardening and motor mechanics. GNVQs also offer qualifications in basic literacy and numeracy, skills which all young people need.

We are still more impressed with a first in classics from Oxbridge than a first in engineering from the other places. Class dictates educational values and norms because that is shown to be the most effective way of securing class differences.
Bruce Abbott
Milton Keynes BAb6094773@aol.com

 The revised national curriculum has now got aims for education. This in itself is progress. These do not, though, include any specific reference to nourishing individual diversity or of preparing young people for satisfying work.

As a result, we still have a largely liberal curriculum modelled on the aspirations of the 18th-century gentry. It will be difficult to justify developing different strands in the curriculum at Key Stages 3 and 4. It simply did not occur to the "great and good" who revised the curriculum that vocational aims and curriculum tracks were worthy of consideration.

There needs to be a genuine debate on the aims of our education system and both employers and trade unions, as well as educators, need to exert themselves more vigorously if new perspectives are to be developed. Perhaps Nick Davies's final article will prove to be a catalyst.
Prof Christopher Winch
University College, Northampton christopher.winch@lineone.net

 I was at a technical high school in Northampton from 1947-52, entry to which required a pass in the 11-plus. In practice, if you go to a vocational school your career is almost fixed. I told the careers person that I wanted to be a journalist and he said, "Nonsense, you are good at maths, have had a technical education, you must be an engineer."

I thus progressed to chartered status and I have regretted ever since that I did not have the wide range of possibilities open to my contemporaries at the local grammar school.
Ian Hamilton
Richmond, Surrey ianham63@hotmail.com

 It struck me on reading Nick Davies's report that the art & design GCSE, which is an ostensibly practical and to a great extent vocational course, is anomalous when seen against other similar qualifications.

For historical and social reasons it has long been recognised as an academic exam, although many of its candidates are not the most able in these ways. In many schools and sixth forms, art and design courses act as a motivating subject, instilling confidence and aspiration.

If it can be done with art and design, why not with construction or catering? It's a matter of parity of esteem - a classless Britain needs a classless exam system.
Matthew Smith
Surrey Institute of Art and Design mssmith@surrart.ac.uk

fields.headline: Campbell show direct from No 10
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: A BBC2 documentary on the battle between the Downing Street press secretary, Alastair Campbell, and political journalists at Westminster will expose the frequent indignity of a modern prime minister's life.
fields.body:
A BBC2 documentary on the battle between the Downing Street press secretary, Alastair Campbell, and political journalists at Westminster will expose the frequent indignity of a modern prime minister's life.

The BBC's behind-the-scenes cameras catch Tony Blair in a variety of embarrassing situations. They include an attempt to record his weekly website interview which is ruined by a malfunctioning tape-recorder. "I thought we were supposed to be on top of technology in this government,'' the prime minister complains before recording it again.

Mr Blair reveals to film-maker Michael Cockerell that it was his decision to pull his press spokesman off frontline duties briefing the media - "his equivalent of doing prime minister's questions every day" - so he could concentrate on strategic planning of government news management.

By that test Mr Campbell emerges well from his decision to cooperate with the News From Number 10 documentary to be screened tomorrow: very much the dedicated official masterminding Downing Street's efforts to "get the government's message to the public'' despite what he denounces as the media's own spin.

He invariably appears witty and calm, even-tempered and reasonable when sparring with the villains of the piece, the lobby correspondents. He chides the "rubbish'' produced by the "disillusionment industry'' more in sorrow than in anger.

But his elected boss emerges from Mr Cockerell's film in a less dignified light. At one point Mr Blair turns up shirt-sleeved in the press secretary's room while Mr Campell remains seated. At another, he is seen running down the main corridor at No 10 to greet the Greek prime minister who has arrived early.

Mr Blair is seen cosying up to tabloid editors including David Yelland of the Sun who is later heard musing: "I don't think the Blairs are Sun readers''.

A women's magazine editor asks: "What do you think about the way women dress at work?'' "I think it's great,'' Mr Blair replies. Master and spokesman discard their jackets as well assorted consonants and aitches in favour of an impressive informality inside No 10. Mr Blair is only once addressed as "sir". Mr Campbell calls him Tony.

Mr Campbell's role as the man directing Mr Blair's image is most graphically seen when the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, arrives at Downing Street. Using a laptop computer just inside the famous black door he realises that the Russian interpreter is spoiling the photographers' shot of the two leaders. All it takes is a word in his earpiece and the embarrassed interpreter can be seen leaping to one side as quickly as any on-message Blairite backbencher.

On another occasion the Sunday Telegraph is forced to retract a story when Mr Campbell threatens to sue. He says the media are trivial and "self-obsessed'' and living in a fantasy world. They call him manipulative and over-powerful. Both sides call each other the real spin doctors. Mr Campbell does not get it all his own way and is seen admitting that Frank Dobson's campaign to be mayor of London "has not been the most fantastic spectacle''. But he manages to get a reporter to change the subject when Mr Blair is being questioned about Ken Livingstone's victory. In the end media and messenger agree they have different goals.

"What you desire is to have stories, day after day after day,'' Mr Campbell tells reporters over a made-for-TV dinner. "Our desire is for change.''

fields.headline: Marked down
fields.standfirst:
Strange saga of Blairs big idea

New Labour in power: special report
The government's annual report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair initially envisaged his governments annual report as the British equivalent of the US presidents state of the union address - a stock taking exercise for the nation.
fields.body:
Tony Blair initially envisaged his governments annual report as the British equivalent of the US presidents state of the union address - a stock taking exercise for the nation.

Instead it was reduced to something of a publishing oddity.

The first two reports were intended to be equivalent to a companys annual report and accounts. The only difference was the figures were not subjected to independent audit by a firm of accountants.

Last years report entitled, So what are we doing, did not force the Stationery Office printers into overtime. Downing Street was forced to buy back 41,000 of the 100,000 copies printed, sold exclusively through Tescos.

This year the report has been transformed into a multi-media experience - a parliamentary statement, a glossy hard copy 65-page report available in newsagents and Tescos, a series of films available on the internet and a forest of statistics - also on the net - telling every voter in England and Wales what is happening in their local school, hospital, employment office and police station.

In a bid to avoid ending up on the remainder counter, the print run has been cut to 50,000, and the price kept to £2.99. Despite the multimedia over-kill, the government says it has spent less money - £170,000 this year rather than £180,000 in 1999. The aim this year is to convince voters that life is changing on the ground. The current Whitehall catchprase is think thousands, not billions - try to make the statistics relevant to ordinary voters.

webTitle: Judge lets woman die 'to release her soul'

fields.headline: Judge lets woman die 'to release her soul'
fields.trailText: A judge yesterday granted an order allowing a mother in a permanent vegetative state for 21 years to die, after hearing that her husband believed it was the only way to free her soul.
fields.body:
A judge yesterday granted an order allowing a mother in a permanent vegetative state for 21 years to die, after hearing that her husband believed it was the only way to free her soul.

The high court granted permission for life sustaining treatment to be withdrawn from the woman, aged 54, who had been in a coma since New Year's Eve 1978. She had suffered oxygen deprivation, resulting in substantial brain damage, while giving birth by caesarean section to a healthy son she never got to know.

Her husband, aged 74, supported the application yesterday, believing "her soul is in limbo and it is time for it to be released".

Mr Justice Johnson was told that the husband believed his wife would have wanted to have been around for the 21st birthday of their child last December.

The judge added: "Now, that milestone in his life having passed, the family have decided that the best interests of this lady lie in no further steps being taken to maintain her life, such as it is. They are convinced that this is what she would have wanted."

The woman, known only as Mrs E, was described as being "lively and vivacious" before the accident. The judge granted an order to the NHS trust in London treating her, allowing for the discontinuation of all life sustaining treatment and medical support measures, including nutrition and artificial hydration.

Appropriate medical supervision and treatment would continue to be provided "as would be appropriate to ensure that she suffers least distress and retains the greatest dignity until such time as her life comes to an end".

Granting the declaration, the judge said: "This has been a difficult decision for the family, and in particular for the husband and child of this lady, but they are now convinced this is what is best for her.

"There is total unanimity of view among the doctors, the nurses and the family that the best thing for Mrs E is for the court to grant the declaration that has been sought."

The judge said that Mike Hinchcliffe, from the official solicitor's office, had been appointed to investigate the circumstances of Mrs E. He had spoken to the husband, who said he had waited to make the "momentous decision" until the couple's son, known in court as A, had grown up "so that his wife can be kept visible for A so that he knew that he had a mother as he grew up". This had also given the son the chance to participate in the process of obtaining yesterday's declaration.

It is estimated that judges have granted orders covering 18 to 20 patients in a permanent vegetative state allowing them to die since the first such case, that of Tony Bland, in 1993. Yesterday the court heard a report from a professor who had examined Mrs E. The professor concluded that there was "no benefit to her in continuing medical treatment with artificial hydration and nutrition".

A spokesman for the official solicitor, who represented Mrs E's interests, said she had continued to breathe unaided and was not judged by doctors to be brain dead. He added: "The state has to be deemed permanent for the application to be granted. Several experts have determined that her condition is permanent. She is in PVS, unresponsive and unaware, and there is no prospect of recovery."

A British Medical Association spokeswoman said: "The courts have decided that for the time being the most appropriate way to deal with what should happen in cases of PVS should be review by the courts.

"There are a lot of patients in conditions with no hope of recovery which place doctors in a difficult ethical dilemma. I don't think it would be right for every difficult case to go to court. You need a body of good practice so decisions can be made in a good and sensitive way."

The judge granted an order to the NHS trust in London treating her, allowing for the discontinuation of all life sustaining treatment and medical support measures, including nutrition and artificial hydration. Appropriate medical supervision and treatment would continue to be provided "as would be appropriate to ensure that she suffers least distress and retains the greatest dignity until such time as her life comes to an end". Granting the declaration, the judge said: "This has been a difficult decision for the family, and in particular for the husband and child of this lady, but they are now convinced this is what is best for her. "There is total unanimity of view among the doctors, the nurses and the family that the best thing for Mrs E is for the court to grant the declaration that has been sought." The judge said that Mike Hinchcliffe, from the official solicitor's office, had been appointed to investigate the circumstances of Mrs E. He had spoken to the husband, who said he had waited to make the "momentous decision" until the couple's son, known in court as A, had grown up "so that his wife can be kept visible for A so that he knew that he had a mother as he grew up". This had also given the son the chance to participate in the process of obtaining yesterday's declaration. The professor concluded that there was "no benefit to her in continuing medical treatment with artificial hydration and nutrition". He added: "The state has to be deemed permanent for the application to be granted. Several experts have determined that her condition is permanent. She is in PVS, unresponsive and unaware, and there is no prospect of recovery." A British Medical Association spokeswoman said: "The courts have decided that for the time being the most appropriate way to deal with what should happen in cases of PVS should be review by the courts. "There are a lot of patients in conditions with no hope of recovery which place doctors in a difficult ethical dilemma. I don't think it would be right for every difficult case to go to court. You need a body of good practice so decisions can be made in a good and sensitive way."

webTitle: Chinook campaigners in direct appeal to Blair

fields.headline: Chinook campaigners in direct appeal to Blair
fields.trailText: The government yesterday came under intensified pressure to reopen an inquiry into the crash of an RAF Chinook helicopter into the Mull of Kintyre when all-party campaigners decided to go over the heads of defence ministers and appeal directly to Tony Blair.
fields.body:
The government yesterday came under intensified pressure to reopen an inquiry into the crash of an RAF Chinook helicopter into the Mull of Kintyre when all-party campaigners decided to go over the heads of defence ministers and appeal directly to Tony Blair.

Their decision to seek a meeting with the prime minister follows an exchange in the Commons on Wednesday, when Martin Bell, independent MP for Tatton, told him the issue was "a question of natural justice". Mr Blair replied: "I'm happy to give it my personal attention".

All 29 people on board, including 25 senior security and intelligence officers, were killed in the crash on June 2, 1994. Though an RAF board of inquiry and a subsequent Scottish fatal accident inquiry said the cause of the crash could not be determined, two senior RAF officers blamed the pilots, Jonathan Tapper and Richard Cook. They accused the pilots of "gross negligence" - a ruling which had to pass the RAF test of "absolutely no doubt whatsoever" - despite evidence of serious technical problems with the Chinook's electronic engine control system, called Fadec. This evidence was not presented to the inquiries, even though the Ministry of Defence was aware of it at the time. Documents seen by the Guardian and Computer Weekly magazine show that defence ministers have persistently misled MPs, notably about the cause of an accident involving an RAF Chinook in 1989. Lewis Moonie, junior defence minister, was the latest to mislead MPs when he told the Commons two weeks ago that the accident was only the result of wrong testing procedures. The documents show that the MoD blamed the 1989 accident on Fadec's "faulty design".

In a separate move, Lord Chalfont, the former Foreign Office minister who chairs the newly formed Mull of Kintyre group, has tabled a motion urging peers to set up a select committee to scrutinise the evidence, including concern about the Chinook expressed by the MoD's airworthiness assessors. "We have been given answers that are not consistent with the facts," he said, blaming the inaccuracy of ministers' replies on officials. "This is wholly unacceptable."

webTitle: Tokyo police question missing woman's friend

fields.headline: Tokyo police question missing woman's friend
fields.trailText: The search for the missing British woman Lucie Blackman gathered momentum yesterday as Japanese police questioned her best friend for clues, while Ms Blackman's father appealed to the public for information.
fields.body:
The search for the missing British woman Lucie Blackman gathered momentum yesterday as Japanese police questioned her best friend for clues, while Ms Blackman's father appealed to the public for information.

Louise Phillips, who has known Ms Blackman since she was a child, has been questioned by detectives for more than 10 hours for each of the past four days, The two 21-year-old women flew together to Japan, shared an apartment and worked in the same Tokyo hostess bar, the Casablanca. The police have not talked to any of the other women who worked in the bar.

The Guardian has learned that the two women, both from Sevenoaks in Kent, are so close that the manager of the bar allowed Ms Phillips to collect Ms Blackman's pay on her behalf on the day she went missing.

Ms Blackman, a former British Airways stewardess, disappeared on July 1 after telling Ms Phillips that she was going on an afternoon date with a customer she had met at the hostess bar. Two days later, Ms Phillips received a telephone call from a man calling himself Akira Takagi, who said Ms Blackman had joined him for spiritual training at a cult in Chiba prefecture, a neighbouring part of Tokyo.

Police have traced the call to a public phone box in Chiba, but detectives believe the name Akira Takagi and the mention of a religious sect are red herrings. As the investigation has gathered pace, detectives have searched the flat shared by the two girls. They have also taken fingerprints and photograph of Ms Phillips.

A spokesman for the Azabu police station denied that Ms Phillips was a suspect. "This is routine," he said. "We have to talk to Ms Phillips because she is our main source of information." The Blackman family have stopped talking to Ms Phillips.

Yesterday, in his first press conference since arriving in Japan on Wednesday, Mr Blackman said: "Like a lot of girls who are close, they talk a lot to each other about where they are going or who they are seeing. "But Louise does not have any knowledge about the person that Lucie allegedly met on that afternoon on July 1."

He appealed to the public for more information about his daughter's whereabouts. "Lucie is a very noticeable lady in Japan," said Mr Blackman of his blonde, blue-eyed daughter. "We are keen to encourage the Japanese public to come forward if they have seen her."

Mr Blackman, a property developer from the Isle of Wight, dismissed the theory that she had been abducted by a cult. "Lucy is a Roman Catholic and while she wasn't a great practising Roman Catholic, she took no large interest in religion generally. The thought that she became interested in a cult over a Saturday afternoon is very unlikely."

Although Mr Blackman spoke of the stress his family was under, he was composed in his first press conference since arriving in Japan yesterday. The only outward sign that things were not as normal was that he wore no socks with his suit.

He rejected suggestions that his daughter might have run away to escape debts, saying she owed a manageable £4,500 to her credit card company and bank. With little money and no Japanese language skills, it is unlikely that she would have run off alone.

Ms Blackman also left behind a boyfriend she had met since arriving in Japan on May 4. No details of his identity have been released, but he is believed to be a member of a western embassy. Police have questioned the man for background information about Ms Blackman.
