webTitle: Three men in search of a peace that is already working

fields.headline: Three men in search of a peace that is already working
fields.standfirst:
Complete collapse of the Camp David talks would not change much

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Camp David gathers together the threads of failed promise, disappointed expectations, personal political disaster, and the hope of a breakthrough which will redeem everything and everybody, in a drama which ought to be compelling.
fields.body:
Camp David gathers together the threads of failed promise, disappointed expectations, personal political disaster, and the hope of a breakthrough which will redeem everything and everybody, in a drama which ought to be compelling.

The American president who has convened the talks came to power at a time of general optimism, which he for a while embodied. He is spending his last months in office grasping for solutions to at least some - perhaps, now, it is only one - of the problems which many hoped he would have disposed of long ago.

The Israeli prime minister was a lacklustre leader in opposition who was then magnified by office into a giant who was going to deal with everything with military dispatch, but whose plans for Lebanon and Syria came unstuck, and whose coalition collapsed spectacularly just as he set off on his peace mission.

The Palestinian chairman is a weary old fox whose virtue is that he has kept the Palestinian nation alive but who wields power both deviously and corruptly.

Three men in search of success, yet excitement is lacking. The sense that we are reading yesterday's newspaper is a strong one. The reason is that Israelis and Palestinians already have a peace - in that they recognise each other's existence, work together in various ways, conspire constantly to gain advantage, have moments of amity but mainly dislike each other, and usually stop short of violence.

Peace, perhaps, should be something more fundamental than this. But it cannot be as long as Israel sees itself as an exclusively Jewish state which happens to include some Arabs, and as long as both Israeli and Palestinian politics exhibit such exclusionist tendencies. Peace between Palestinians and Israelis, one Israeli commentator explained years ago, was not about getting married, but about getting divorced.

It is the divorce papers that are being discussed in the United States, and much of what they will contain is known in advance. Israel will keep Jerusalem, keep its main settlements, get its way on water and roads and on Palestinian demilitarisation. The Palestinian state will be at best weak, at worst unworkable, at least in the longer run. If there is a deal, it will not change the nature of the limited "peace" between Arabs and Israelis, and if there is no deal, or some kind of fudge, the relationship will also remain essentially the same.

Even if there is a complete collapse, it is unlikely to lead to general hostilities. How could it? The disparity in force between the two sides is so large. It is known that the Israeli army has been training for some time for emergency operations in the West Bank, but if anything is certain it is that Israeli generals and politicians do not want such exercises ever to become a reality. Nor do the Palestinians.

Why is it so difficult to give formal expression to what in a way has already been agreed? On the Palestinian side, the reason is that a piece of paper would make clear how much the Palestinians had been forced to give away, and would be a political liability for all those associated with signing it.

That is why some Israeli observers believe that Yasser Arafat may be tempted to reject a deal and then proclaim his state. It would be a show of defiance, he might calculate, that would lay to rest charges that he is an Israeli puppet, and prompt comparison with the late Syrian leader Hafez al-Assad, who went to his grave refusing compromise. Afterwards, no doubt, relations with Israel could be discreetly resumed and the peace process begun anew.

On the Israeli side, there is also a fear of future politics. Ehud Baraks troubles have shown the Israeli political system at its most dysfunctional. A particularly pure kind of proportional representation produces a range of mainly bull-headed parties, whose purpose is to extract maximum advantage for their special constituencies. The change in 1992 to a directly elected prime minister, which was supposed to strengthen the executive and make such party manoeuvring less effective, has had the opposite result. Pay-offs strew the path of any Israeli coalition, and the pay-offs have been used to create autonomous sub-societies, financed by public funds, which tribal entities then go on to make fresh demands.

The system is double geared, so that creating a consensus on domestic policy usually involves giving in to blackmail on foreign and security policy, and vice versa. Barak, for instance, promised to end some categories of exemption from military service for the Orthodox, but had to retreat in an attempt to win agreement to his position in the peace negotiations. Typically, he made this and many other concessions but lost his coalition anyway.

The feeling that much of their leverage would disappear after a final settlement with the Palestinians must contribute toward the obstinacy and unreliability of most Israeli political parties when faced with the choices that are necessary if there is to be such a settlement. Who knows what Israeli politics would be like after a settlement? Much traditional ideology would have been stripped out along the political spectrum, settler influence would be diminished, and the power of the religious parties reduced, once their ability to strike bargains on security policy had disappeared.

Israeli politicians might have to confront the question of whether it is wise to allow the religious to continue to consume an undue share of resources while, in some instances at least, contributing little in return. They might have to tackle constitutional and electoral reform. They might have to admit Israeli Arabs to real political participation. They might have to deal directly with the country's ethnic and class divisions. They might have to consider dismantling at least part of the military and security apparatus that they have created over the years.

No wonder a ripple of disquiet moves through the Israeli political class. On this analysis, reluctance to settle is not grounded on concrete objections to territorial changes or to the establishment of a Palestinian official presence on the fringes of Jerusalem. No, they fear instead the loss of the issue itself - the loss of the threat which has given Israeli society coherence and which at the same time has given certain narrow groups such disproportionate power.

It is usually wrong to see much symmetry between Israelis and Palestinians. But it is true that Palestinian public life would be similarly changed. Once the national struggle in its old form is over, the purpose of politics would have to be redefined, and a Palestinian state might be very ill-equipped to undertake that task. So, after all, it has to be concluded that Camp David is exciting, not in the substance of the discussions but in the implications if a deal is struck. At that moment a new politics will begin for both societies.

webTitle: Friends and foes threaten the badger cull

fields.headline: Friends and foes threaten the badger cull
fields.standfirst:
Programme to test animal's role in rising incidence of bovine TB is being compromised by protesters' disruption and farmers' impatience
MAFF area on TB in cattle and badgers
National Federation of Badger Groups
fields.trailText: The government's attempts to establish whether badgers are the prime cause for the rising incidence of TB in cattle are under increasing threat from activists seeking to wreck a limited cull of the wildlife.
fields.body:
The government's attempts to establish whether badgers are the prime cause for the rising incidence of TB in cattle are under increasing threat from activists seeking to wreck a limited cull of the wildlife.

Meanwhile farmers angry at what they see as government inaction to stop the spread of the disease outside the culling zones in the west country are boasting that they are shooting animals illegally.

Evidence from the badger cull will take at least another two years to collect. It could be 2004 before ministers decide a national policy for eradicating bovine TB, which is also prevalent in the sharply rising badger population.

But activists are destroying traps, picketing farms, damaging Ministry of Agriculture property and allegedly threatening officials, farmers and landowners in attempts to halt the experiment. Police wildlife officers say they have been taken aback by the number of farmers who claim they have broken British and international law by killing badgers, knowing they could not be held to account because of a lack of independent evidence.

The government has been given special dispensation by the guardians of a European wildlife convention to kill badgers in designated areas but yesterday the National Farmers' Union and other industry groups proposed farmers should be allowed to go further and destroy wildlife suspected of TB infection under licence outside the trial areas.

They pointed to a more than 25% increase in cattle slaughtered over the past year because of TB. Restrictions on the movements of herds were costing farmers £3 per animal per day even though they were compensated for animals that had to be killed because they tested positive for TB.

Lady Hayman, the minister in charge of the anti-TB measures, who vowed the government would press ahead with the trials, said about 1,400 badgers had been culled since 1998 but culling has so far started in only half of the 10 proposed areas. "The assumption for the whole trial was for 12,500 and that is something like a quarter of the number of badgers killed on the roads each year. The trials are not a wholesale slaughter of the badger population. They are very tightly controlled and limited in order to get the evidence we need."

Lady Hayman said apparent lack of action to combat the TB problems outside the cull areas was not due to lack of political will or money but "not knowing what is the most effective thing to do".

Most farmers and landowners were taking part in the trials - up to 90% in some areas - despite heavy pressure from activists. "It is a long term strategy and people are looking for short term solutions. I wish I could provide short term solutions."

She added that badgers were "a very endearing animal" but "I don't think I am any more sentimental about badgers than about any other animals. This is as much an issue about welfare of cattle as badgers", which could not be "completely off limits" because they attracted a great deal more affection than other animals.

Lady Hayman conceded she faced problems in forcing through the trials. "It is not just a matter of a difficult policy you have to push through against opposition or get the resources for. It is being in a situation in which you don't have enough evidence on which to be certain of the right way forward."

The cull is costing £7m a year, with other research costing £4m, cattle TB testing £12m and compensation for the well over 6,000 cattle that have had to be destroyed another £5m. She denied any suggestion the government was neglecting other ways of combating TB, including vaccines for cattle or wildlife, better management of farms, and improved cattle breeding. There were likely to be several causes for the big increase in bovine TB.

Lady Hayman said she would consider any proposals for alternative strategies to the cull, but her scientific advisers had warned against allowing any killing outside the trial zones for fear of damaging their reliability. They said that so far disruption had not been enough to wreck results, although it did delay the cull in Herefordshire.

webTitle: Restoration drama £3m appeal for Austen family mansion

fields.headline: Restoration drama £3m appeal for Austen family mansion
fields.trailText: The launch this morning of a £3m appeal to restore a Jane Austen family mansion, as an international study centre for early English women's writing, will mark the end of decades of bitter wrangling over the fate of the Grade II* listed house.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The launch this morning of a £3m appeal to restore a Jane Austen family mansion, as an international study centre for early English women's writing, will mark the end of decades of bitter wrangling over the fate of the Grade II* listed house.

It has been the only blot on the picture book prettiness of the Hampshire village of Chawton, where Austen lived and wrote many of her most famous works.

Today villagers, Jane Austen scholars and academics, including Germaine Greer, will mingle in the great hall of the house which was once the home of Jane Austen's brother Edward, and is still owned by his descendants.

Sandy Lerner, an American computer millionairess, who bought a long lease on Chawton Manor in 1992, will pledge to match every pound raised, from her family's charitable trust.

Repairs are under way at last on the Elizabethan mansion, left empty and decaying since the 1980s. The roof is watertight again, and flower arrangers from the parish church have camouflaged the most visible rot in ivy and carnations.

Villagers mounted a campaign to block the mansion's conversion into a country house hotel. They were almost as horrified when the lease was bought by a Californian computer whizz. Ms Lerner promises that Chawton House Library will open as a non-residential study centre in July 2003. There is still a vast amount of work to be done. Conservators are working on dry rot, wet rot, death watch beetle and woodworm.

The library will house Ms Lerner's collection of more than 6,000 early English novels by women, many the only surviving copies, which is described by Michael Wheeler of Southampton University, who is in charge of the academic side of the project, as "one of the best specialist literary collections in the world".

Many of the authors were known to Jane Austen, who lived and wrote in a modest house in the village, 10 minutes' walk away. Edward was living in splendour at the manor, having been adopted by the childless Knights. Jane was a constant visitor.

"I don't think it's likely she did any of her major writing here, except possibly letters and little things to entertain the children," Professor Wheeler said.

"What she did do was gain ideas. She took a keen interest in the estate management and improvements, and there are features now being restored in the grounds, including the ha-ha and the wilderness, which appear in several of her books."

Prof Wheeler admits that some of the collection is obscure. "They are not all masterpieces. But they show us what was being written, and what was being read, and what Jane Austen herself read."

webTitle: Put the PM on the air

fields.headline: Put the PM on the air
fields.trailText: I note Polly Toynbees description of the coverage by some media of the prime ministers press conference (Time to turn cameras on the media mob, July 13).
fields.body:
I note Polly Toynbees description of the coverage by some media of the prime ministers press conference (Time to turn cameras on the media mob, July 13).

I agree with her: the voters should be given access to media briefings. If a full written account can appear on the Downing Street Online site, why shouldnt the public be able to see and hear what is being said? The BBC would be delighted to broadcast the briefings on BBC News 24 or BBC Parliament.
Tony Hall
Director, BBC News

 After Lord Runcies visit to Liverpool in 1980, when he was howled down by anti-papists, he and two colleagues appeared at a table near me on the train to Euston (Primate who discarded Anglican image, July 13). Unfazed by the protest he greeted the dining car steward with the words: Nothing like a riot to give you a good appetite for lunch.
Richard de Zouche
Neston, Cheshire  Lord Runcies military service (Obituary, July 13) is commemorated by the 3/4 march bagpipe tune Dr Robert Runcie MC, by Pipe Major A Macdonald, Scots Guards.
David Macdonald
Blandford, Dorset

 Can anyone supply one convincing reason why marches asserting sectarian hatreds and notions of supremacy should be allowed to continue in public places in the 21st century (UVF man shot as loyalists fall out, July 13)?
Kirsten Cubitt
Sheffield  Given Andy Flintoffs sensitivity about his weight (Sport, July 11), will you stop referring to him as the all-rounder.
Robert Petty
Coalbrookdale, Salop  My daughter was also offered a gold American Express card (Letters, July 13); she is at university and has debts of over £5,000.
Will Baker
Fareham, Hants

fields.headline: House rules
fields.standfirst:
Devolution is one thing, but reform of the London parliament is proving an intractable problem

Lords reform: special report
Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: When Tony Blair eventually moves out of Number 10, he will rightly be remembered as the United Kingdoms greatest constitutional reformer since the 19th century. He will have removed virtually all the hereditary peers from the Lords, granted devolution to Scotland and Wales and introduced proportional representation for elections to the European parliament.
fields.body:
When Tony Blair eventually moves out of Number 10, he will rightly be remembered as the United Kingdoms greatest constitutional reformer since the 19th century. He will have removed virtually all the hereditary peers from the Lords, granted devolution to Scotland and Wales and introduced proportional representation for elections to the European parliament.

There will, however, be a strong objection to his standing as a reformer. He has barely introduced any changes to the operations or constitutional position of the Commons. Westminster still has the feel of a riverside club whose hours are more suited to gentlemen barristers than to modern professionals.

Blairites insist the past three years have seen Westminster transformed. MPs are able to escape earlier on Thursdays. There are more opportunities for backbenchers since Westminster Hall was opened for morning debates. Select committees have an expanded role in pre-legislative scrutiny of bills.

The government last week accepted a recommendation that sittings should end at 10pm, promoted by modernisers who have been campaigning for family-friendly hours. Its a breakthrough, says Harriet Harman, the former social security secretary. But traditionalists were horrified, saying that the reform represented a dangerous tightening of the executives grip over the legislature. Nicholas Winterton, the maverick Tory MP for Macclesfield, described the plans as monstrous because they will cut the amount of time devoted to debating government bills, thereby reducing the powers of backbenchers. Under the proposals virtually all legislation will be timetabled - to ensure a 10pm close - which will end the ability of backbenchers to prolong debates with line-by-line scrutiny of bills.

Margaret Beckett, leader of the house, forced through her proposals with the support of the Liberal Democrats, insisting they are fair-minded and do not undermine backbenchers. She pointed to the cross-party committee to be set up after the Queens Speech every year to discuss the business of the coming session - an unprecedented novelty.

However, Mrs Becketts attempts to cast herself as a moderniser and a guardian of backbench rights have been undermined by her summary dismissal of the ground-breaking recommendations of the Commons liaison committee. This is made up of the chairs of all the Commons select committees. In March it confronted the executive and demanded party whips should be stripped of their role in appointing members of their committees, which gives the executive a tool for control. Its members, who gave their report the provocative title Shifting the Balance, vented their anger at Mrs Beckett on Monday when she finally appeared before them. Their frustrations were echoed in a pamphlet published this week by the Hansard Society*, which described Mrs Beckett's response as regrettable and lauded select committees as one of the few parliamentary success stories of recent times. The reports author had in mind the humiliation meted out by the foreign affairs committee to Sir John Kerr of the Foreign Office during the arms-to-Sierra Leone debate in 1998.

Fresh ideas on Commons reforms have been emanating from the opposition benches, as the Tories cast themselves in the unlikely role of modernisers. In a recent pamphlet Andrew Tyrie called for the prime minister to be called before a special committee once a month and for a parliamentary day to be devoted to committee work with no sitting of the house. To underline his claim that parliament is in a mess, Mr Tyrie highlighted the prime ministers voting record which is shown in the chart, comparing him with predecessors. He was somewhat undermined this week with the publication of figures showing Tory MPs have none too impressive a record in the lobbies.

William Hague embraced reform this week with the publication of a report commissioned from the political science academic Lord Norton. It calls for a strengthening of the Commons in holding the government to account. Prime ministers questions should be restored to its twice weekly slot and committees beefed up to give them greater independence. Nortons 90 recommendations made a persuasive case for drawing the head of government more into parliament.

But if Mr Hague became prime minister, would he really take up the mantle of reform? His support for Norton was reminiscent of Lord Hailshams enthusiasm for strengthening MPs in his 1976 Dimbleby lecture. He complained that the commons had become an elective dictatorship as it slavishly toed the government line. Within three years, he had been made lord chancellor by Margaret Thatcher and no more was heard of his charge.

Unfettered prime ministerial control of the Commons is a prize Downing Street is unlikely to surrender, whoever is in power. How long this can be sustained in a rapidly changing world is open to question, a thought which prompted Mr Brazier to conclude his pamphlet by making the point about the relevance of our representatives: The lack of change in the Commons perhaps explains why it seems at odds with so much of a fast-moving society.

*Alex Brazier: Systematic Scrutiny, reforming the select committees, www.hansard-society.org.uk

Nicholas Watt is the Guardians political correspondent
nicholas.watt@theguardian.com

webTitle: Missing girl's family told she may be dead

fields.headline: Missing girl's family told she may be dead
fields.standfirst:
E-fit of Sarah Payne suspect
Graphic: What's happened to Sarah?
Sussex police
Timetable: Sarah's disappearance
fields.trailText: The parents of missing eight-year-old Sarah Payne were last night coming to terms with the possibility that their daughter might not be found alive, police said.
fields.body:
The parents of missing eight-year-old Sarah Payne were last night coming to terms with the possibility that their daughter might not be found alive, police said.

Detectives investigating the schoolgirl's disappearance near her grandparents' home at Kingston, West Sussex, almost a fortnight ago said all the possible outcomes had been discussed with Sarah's family.

"I have discussed with the Payne family a number of options and one of those options is that Sarah may not be found well and safe," said Detective Sergeant Sean Scott, a family liaison officer with Sussex police.

"The family are realistic but still hold on to the hope that she is safe, as do the inquiry team." He said they continued to cling to the hope that Sarah would be found safe and well but they were being realistic and accepted the possibility that this might not happen.

Detectives yesterday brought the focus of the investigation back to Sussex, saying they were almost certain she had been abducted and hidden somewhere in the countryside. Superintendent Phil Clarke, leading the search, said he was almost convinced the girl had been abducted. Repeated searches of the area near where she vanished had failed to throw up any evidence of a possible accident or misadventure.

He said: "If she has been abducted, almost certainly from the outset she has been hidden, whether in premises or somewhere in fields or woods.

"It seems to me that wherever Sarah is at the moment she is very well hidden and there is an intention on the part of the people or person who is hiding her that she should not be found."

Search teams were yesterday focusing on an area from Kingston up a corridor around the A24 as far north as Crawley and stretching from Horsham as far east as East Grinstead. As the search through fields and woodlands got under way, detectives appealed to landowners, farmers, gamekeepers, utility workers and anyone else with local knowledge who might know where it was easy to hide someone.

Supt Clarke said: "If there are people out there who are thinking where would I put a little girl or keep a little girl where she would never ever be found, those are the people I would like to look in those places today and tomorrow and probably for the next few days until we have found Sarah."

Police insisted they were not despondent, but merely realistic. The assistant chief constable of Sussex, Nigel Yeo, said: "We are working on the basis that this is a missing person inquiry and that Sarah is still alive unless there is a reason not to."

A further appeal was made for information about the white Transit-style van seen in Kingston Lane on the weekend that Sarah went missing, particularly somebody seen changing the rear doors of a white van or removing the internal wooden panelling. Detectives were still investigating the sighting of a man with a child resembling Sarah at a motorway service station in Cheshire.

PC Tony Burstow, 50, a community beat officer in Worthing, West Sussex, was drafted in on day one of the search for Sarah.

"There is always that hope that you may be the one that will find her alive. Being a family man myself with four children and two grandchildren, an event like this does take right to the heart. I can imagine what the parents are going through.

"I was in on the Sunday to search the area. We trudged through wheatfields, down country lanes. The support from the public was fantastic. There were people coming from everywhere. When we searched one cornfield, you just couldn't see the end of the line.

"I have been involved in various major investigations, but this one is different. With all the others there was always a crime scene and you work out from there. But with this one we just don't know.

"On the Monday we set up the house to house team. We have been searching house to house now for 12 days. Forty-two officers knocking on doors, interviewing, searching houses and gardens, trying to pick up any information that could be of use.

"It's hard to switch off. I have had one rest day in a fortnight, it is draining, these are long hours, but the ultimate aim is to find her."

PC Burstow was speaking to Rebecca Allison

webTitle: PM accused by Hague of 'gimmicks and gossip'

fields.headline: PM accused by Hague of 'gimmicks and gossip'
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The power of parliament has been so seriously eroded that MPs are now unable to hold the government to account, William Hague warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The power of parliament has been so seriously eroded that MPs are now unable to hold the government to account, William Hague warned yesterday.

The Tory leader accused the Labour government of damaging public confidence in democracy by doing more than any other in living memory to accelerate that loss of power, and he called on the prime minister to bring in urgent reforms to reassert the authority of the Commons.

In a highly personalised attack on Tony Blair, Mr Hague said: "You have created a government of secret briefings and leaks and gimmicks and gossip, in which power rests with unelected advisers, spin doctors and cronies." He told MPs: "Parliament has been steadily diminished and is now no longer able to do its job properly. When this house is diminished, marginalised or sidelined, democracy itself is harmed.''

Mr Hague was opening an opposition-led debate on the relationship between the parliament and the executive. Mr Blair, in response, mocked Mr Hague for raising "piddling points" and failing to address the "big" issues of the time, calling the Conservatives' choice of debate a "piece of extraordinary eccentricity".

During a bitter exchange before a packed chamber, Mr Hague said the "rights and relevance" of parliament was being "progressively diminished" by a government whose behaviour was characterised by "weakness and cowardice".

He said: "It's time we had a prime minister who understood he's accountable to parliament, a prime minister who spent time at the palace of Westminster instead of seeking the first opportunity to escape back up Whitehall.'' Mr Hague opposed the planned reforms of Commons voting procedures, saying the changes were a further "serious assault" on the power of backbench MPs.

Instead he called for the recommendations in the report by constitutional expert Lord Norton this week to be enacted.

These include taking the appointment of MPs to select committees out of the hands of party whips, returning prime minister's questions to two slots a week instead of the present single 30-minute slot, and a parliamentary investigations officer to look at cases where information has been withheld from parliament.

Mr Blair dismissed Mr Hague's claims as the speech of "a 16-year-old who used to read Hansard under the bedclothes''.

He poured scorn on the Norton report, and insisted that despite his own voting record of only 5% - compared to one of 32% for Mr Hague - he had spent as much, if not more, time in the Commons answering questions than previous prime ministers.

He said the government was already modernising the Commons, but changes such as the reforms of the Lords and the devolution of power to Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and, in London, to a mayor, had "made changes of fundamental consequence... to bring power closer to the people and hold government to account".

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, said it was hard to take the Tories' complaints seriously when they had proved so "lousy" in government and opposition.

The former Tory prime minister, John Major, said some Labour modernisation proposals were welcome but others were "potty". The overall balance of them threatened to turn the Commons into an "irrelevance" with even the weapon of delay to be "stolen" from the Opposition.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: So soon after Mr Tony's agents dismissed Ken Follett's charge about malicious gossip, I am shocked and distressed to hear a rumour about the foreign secretary. According to this gossip, in 1995 Cookie was seen (by a veteran Labour backbencher) in a private Harley Street clinic, fixing a £3,500 price on a cosmetic operation on his ears.
fields.body:
So soon after Mr Tony's agents dismissed Ken Follett's charge about malicious gossip, I am shocked and distressed to hear a rumour about the foreign secretary. According to this gossip, in 1995 Cookie was seen (by a veteran Labour backbencher) in a private Harley Street clinic, fixing a £3,500 price on a cosmetic operation on his ears.

So soon after Mr Tony's agents dismissed Ken Follett's charge about malicious gossip, I am shocked and distressed to hear a rumour about the foreign secretary. According to this gossip, in 1995 Cookie was seen (by a veteran Labour backbencher) in a private Harley Street clinic, fixing a £3,500 price on a cosmetic operation on his ears. The rumour doesn't specify whether or not he went through with it at the time  but presumably not, given the latest claim that Cookie has been spotted at the same clinic within the last fortnight. How preposterous. The notion that Cookie is eager to prepare himself should the leadership become vacant is less preposterous by far than the idea of a senior cabinet minister - the self-styled leader of the left, indeed - flirting with private medicine. Margaret, the first Mrs Cook, who is said to know all about the 1995 consultation, is out of the country, while Pat Barry at the FO denies any surgery. So that's all right then. Cookie has such an indistinct face, does he not? This is obviously yet another case of mistaken identity.

This is just as hard to believe as Cookie's first faltering step on the road to becoming Tom Cruise's stunt double  but Rolls-Royce has agreed to lend us the blue convertible Corniche, with RR1 numberplate, in which Boris the Jackal Johnson (by now, God willing, Tory candidate for Henley) has recently been seen driving all over north London. Janette Green at RR HQ in Crewe kindly offers us the choice of two weekends, and we are delighted to accept Friday, August 25. We haven't decided what to do with the £250,000 car, but it must be something spectacular. Suggestions welcome.

VS Naipaul's furious attack on British culture under Mr T caused a fuss this week, and it was a pleasure to hear the writer in apocalyptic mood. Sir Vidia has a fine record as a commentator. When he arrived in Britain from Trinidad in the late 1950s, he declared that "for a long time to come, the West Indians" (then an unsuccessful Test cricket side) "will not be able to play as a team". How true. Of course the West Indies have dominated Test cricket for much of the past 30 years, and won the first two World Cups, but apart from that what else have they done?

We are all looking forward to Michael Cockerell's film about Alastair Campbell on BBC2 this Saturday evening, and it's not for me to ruin any of the fun (especially the Busking With Bagpipes dream sequence involving Anji Hunter and Sally Morgan), but one tiny snippet can't do any harm. It concerns alopecian Sun editor David Yelland, who declares what a "fantastic" place he found Chequers to be when he visited the PM's holiday home. "The leader I wrote after that was probably a bit soft on him as a result," says David. Very Kelvin MacKenzie.

Meanwhile, we become intrigued with Dominic Mohan, author of the relentlessly original Sun showbiz column Bizarre. Mr Mohan, whom colleagues describe as a lovably self-effacing fellow, appears to have developed a fixation on the penis of TV presenter Jamie Theakston, suggesting again yesterday that it tends towards the compact. We ring to congratulate Mr Mohan on the scoop, and to say how doubled up we were on reading it. Gracious in accepting these plaudits, Mr Mohan denies a dangerous obsession. Mm. We'll be keeping a close eye on this in the days ahead, before deciding whether in-patient treatment is indicated.

Inclusivity is vital for a mainstream political party in the run-up to an election, of course, but might the Tories be going too far in spreading their electoral net? A reader reports that, if you go the Excite UK search engine and type the word "tits" into the search field, heading the top 10 documents that appear on screen is the official website of the Conservative party.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In our report, Life after Living Marxism, page 10, July 8, we referred to the Reason Foundation and said its "leading writer, the syndicated columnist Sandra Postrel, is author of the libertarian book The Enemies Of Freedom and frequently talks at the Hudson Institute". The Reason Foundation points out that no one of that name works at the Foundation or for Reason Magazine.
fields.body:
In our report, Life after Living Marxism, page 10, July 8, we referred to the Reason Foundation and said its "leading writer, the syndicated columnist Sandra Postrel, is author of the libertarian book The Enemies Of Freedom and frequently talks at the Hudson Institute". The Reason Foundation points out that no one of that name works at the Foundation or for Reason Magazine. The editor-at-large and former editor of the magazine is called Virginia Postrel. She is a columnist for Forbes and the New York Times but not a "syndicated" columnist. Her book is not called The Enemies Of Freedom. It is called The Future And Its Enemies: The Growing Conflict Over Creativity, Enterprise and Progress (Free Press). The Reason Foundation says Ms Postrel has never been to the Hudson Institute and has no connection with the organisation.

Kusum Wason (Bobbie), who featured in our report about the plight of some Asian women, page 6, Society, July 12, has asked us to point out that she is not a counsellor for the Southall Black Sisters. She is a voluntary worker who refers women to them.

In a report headed Capital Radio feels the £34m Beat, page 25, yesterday, we said that Beat 106 began broadcasting just nine weeks ago. Nine months ago, we should have said.

A report about theatre funding appeared twice yesterday: pages 2 and 3 in one edition, and then pages 2 and 10 in a later one. The report said, incorrectly, that the theatre at Greenwich had closed. It has not. Apologies.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: Common sense on tap
fields.standfirst: Why do we drink so much mineral water?
fields.trailText: The quality of drinking water in Britain is getting better and better every year - yet sales of mineral water are booming as never before. Why? This week the chief drinking-water inspector, Michael Rouse, revealed that 99.82% of the country's drinking water met his tough tests last year, making it better and safer than ever.
fields.body:
The quality of drinking water in Britain is getting better and better every year - yet sales of mineral water are booming as never before. Why? This week the chief drinking-water inspector, Michael Rouse, revealed that 99.82% of the country's drinking water met his tough tests last year, making it better and safer than ever. Yet sales of mineral water - more than half of the still variety - shot up 25% last year to 1.2bn litres, making it one of the fastest growing industries anywhere. This seems to defy the laws of economics as well as common sense, because mineral water is up to a thousand times more expensive than ordinary drinking water.

Tests have shown that most people cannot tell the difference between still mineral water and the tap alternative in a blind tasting, especially if, as the inspector suggests, the tap water is left for a while in a jug to allow the chlorine to evaporate (for taste rather than health reasons). The mineral water industry says that people prefer the natural minerals in their product - but the inspector says that although, overall, mineral waters have a higher mineral content than tap water, "often they are similar".

Part of the reason is British reticence. It takes uncommon social courage to ask the waiter for the refreshment that dare not speak its name, tap water - even though in a restaurant it costs several thousand times the cost of tap water (only 0.068p a litre). Another reason is that the water industry does not have an incentive to sell its product because, except in metered areas, it does not gain more income from extra sales. Everyone, of course, has the right to pay a thousand times more than they need for a similar product, but why we keep on doing so is a curious problem. The public image of drinking water is grotesquely at odds with the underlying quality of the product. What it needs is someone skilled at spinning an image. Surely Downing Street could spare someone on secondment.

fields.headline: Henri Gault
fields.standfirst: The Frenchman who discovered nouvelle cuisine
fields.trailText: Being a restaurant critic in France is a dangerous occupation. To be accepted as arbiters of taste, as were Henri Gault, who has died aged 70, and Christian Millau, with their Gault-Millau annual guide to restaurants, was thus a tremendous achievement.
fields.body:
Being a restaurant critic in France is a dangerous occupation. To be accepted as arbiters of taste, as were Henri Gault, who has died aged 70, and Christian Millau, with their Gault-Millau annual guide to restaurants, was thus a tremendous achievement.

It was all the greater because it came at a time when French eating habits seemed to be changing. No longer could it be suggested that an académie des gastronomes be created, or that while other nations nourished themselves, only the French knew how to eat. Such observations were hardly applicable to the French people of the 1960s, who were in a hurry to adopt new eating patterns and experience fast food - and were feeling the pressures of industrial catering. This transformation drew protests.

The journalist Jean Ferniot, himself the author of a book entirely devoted to potatoes, saw it as part of a crisis in French identity. In a report to the ministry of culture, he asked whether his country was still capable of creating chefs - as opposed to cooks. It was therefore no accident that, in 1969, the first edition of the Gault et Millau monthly magazine appeared, followed in 1972 by the first volume of their guide. The need for such publications had become acute, and they were soon selling more than 150,000 copies a month. In 1973, they published a manifesto, denouncing the decline of French cooking and proclaiming: There are a million dishes to invent.

Born the son of a doctor in the Eure department, Gault studied at the Lycée Carnot in Paris, then took a science degree at the Sorbonne. As a freelance journalist, he specialised in reporting stories about food and the varieties of French cuisine, and broadcast accounts of his travels and his discoveries in cooking.

In 1960, while working for the evening paper Paris-Presse, Gault made the acquaintance of Millau, then editor of the page on which Gaults culinary articles appeared, usually on a Friday evening. The papers circulation increased on Fridays, and Millau saw the commercial possibilities of writing about restaurants and cooking. In 1963, a selection of the Paris-Presse articles was a great success, but it took some time for the two men to overcome the legal obstacles that tied them to their newspaper.

There were many reasons for the success of Gault-Millau. It was no accident that the publication appeared in the closing months of Frances so-called 30 glorious years of prosperity, since the cult of restaurants assumed a public that was able to pay its way. The increase in the number of working women also had its effect on family cooking, and improved transport and refrigeration methods meant that new materials for cooking became widely available.

Gaults great discovery was la nouvelle cuisine. Although he came to regret the invention of the phrase, it was undoubtedly a great success, and is still meaningful today - unlike comparable terms in literature, le nouveau roman, or in politics, la nouvelle droite. The move was both a discovery and an incentive. The discovery was that there existed chefs who were tired of cooking traditional dishes and providing lengthy, heavy meals. Instead, they wanted a lightness of style in cooking, a freshness of materials, an insistence on quality rather than quantity. The incentive was that chefs should invent dishes, experiment with combinations of fruit and vegetables, and achieve fame through their originality. Thus, at a time when politicians were talking about modernisation, Gault and Millau appeared to be on the side of the modernisers. La nouvelle cuisine coincided with an increase in the medical emphasis on dieting.

In the 1970s, another new form of cooking, la cuisine minceur, also made its appearance, appealing to slimmers who were also gourmet-minded. The chefs, who became the owners of their restaurants, became household names - Bocuse, Guérard, Troisgros - as did Gault and Millau. The Gault-Millau guide, while informative about the dishes served, makes good reading because it adds interesting details (the restaurant in Cancale, for instance, is in a fine building where Léon Blum holidayed before 1914); it has attractive expressions (the chef will occasionally produce a Mediterranean dish to show his love for his wife, who comes from Toulon); it is definitive in its praise (if the restaurant is not humming with activity, then it should be).

Unfortunately, Gault did not get on well with Millau. Both were of the right politically, but it is said that Gault was more extreme, being a sympathiser of the National Front. They split up in 1985, and Millau, with others, ran the guide by himself. Gault continued to write, and last year produced an account of his travels in Europe. He is survived by a son from his first marriage, and by his second wife, Catherine, their son and two daughters.

Henri Gault, food writer, born November 4 1929; died July 9 2000.

fields.headline: Leonard Salzedo
fields.standfirst: Prolific composer best known for a 10-second fanfare
fields.trailText: The career of the composer-conductor Leonard Salzedo, who has died aged 78, contains some strange ironies. A prolific creator, with more than a hundred works to his credit, he was known most widely for a mere snatch of music barely 10 seconds long: the brief trumpet fanfare that once heralded the BBC broadcasts for the Open University.
fields.body:
The career of the composer-conductor Leonard Salzedo, who has died aged 78, contains some strange ironies. A prolific creator, with more than a hundred works to his credit, he was known most widely for a mere snatch of music barely 10 seconds long: the brief trumpet fanfare that once heralded the BBC broadcasts for the Open University.

Though he was born in London, as late as 1979 the Gramophone Classical Catalogue listed him as hailing from Portugal, although, in fact, he was descended from Sephardic Jews, who came ultimately from Spain. He is still occasionally confused with the French-born American composer and harpist (Leon) Carlos Salzedo (1885-1961), though they were not related.

Salzedo's music was well crafted, expertly orchestrated and bore an innate Iberian sense of colour and rhythm that - with his love of dance - became the cornerstones of his art from the very start. His orchestral catalogue alone contains a substantial body of works, including film scores, two symphonies, the symphonic poems Gabble Retchit (1955) and Paean To The Sun (1966), and the Concerto Fervido (1964). He also composed concertos, sonatas and other works for a wide variety of instruments often little used as soloists, including oboe d'amore, trumpet, tuba, harpsichord, viola da gamba and double-bass.

His chamber output centres around his cycle of 10 string quartets, but includes works for brass ensembles - several of which, such as the Divertimento And Capriccio, attracted the advocacy of the late Philip Jones, whose virtuosic ensemble recorded them - and a Percussion Concerto for four players, unaccompanied (1969).

Salzedo's most substantial contribution, however, was in the field of ballet, in which he worked as composer (with 17 scores to his credit), arranger and conductor. His first successes came while he was still a student at the Royal College of Music (1940-44), where his illustrious teachers included Isabelle Menges (violin), Herbert Howells (composition), Gordon Jacob (orchestration) and Sir George Dyson (conducting).

Salzedo's Second String Quartet (1944) - the first having already won the Cobbett prize two years earlier - so impressed Marie Rambert that she immediately commissioned a ballet, The Fugitive, from him. Her Ballet Rambert company performed this hundreds of times over the following years, and commissioned further works, including a reduced orchestration of Adam's Giselle (1945-46), the Verdi re-orchestrations The Life And Death Of Lola Montez (1954), and original scores, such as The Travellers (1963) and Hazard (1967). This last was written a year after Salzedo had taken up the post of music director, which he relinquished five years later when he moved to Scottish Ballet.

Salzedo had previously worked, with his wife, for other companies - most notably, in the immediate aftermath of the second world war, with Ballets Nègres, a group established to tap the talents of Caribbean immigrants, and for whom he wrote several piano-based dance scores. His last appointment was as director of London City Ballet (1982-86).

His greatest successes as a composer came in 1956 with the premieres, in Amsterdam, of his ballet, The Witch Boy, and, in London, of his First Symphony, the latter under the baton of Sir Thomas Beecham. The Witch Boy was extraordinarily successful; the ballet and the colourful concert suite derived from it in 1959 - pieces which the composer himself recorded for Classics for Pleasure in 1971, although, sadly, they have not been reissued on CD - have, between them, received well over a thousand performances.

Between his directorial posts with Ballets Nègres and Rambert, Salzedo earned his living by composing, and as a violinist in the London Philharmonic (until 1950) and Royal Philharmonic Orchestras. During his time in the latter, he worked as assistant to Beecham, gaining valuable experience.

In 1945, Salzedo married Patricia Clover, who survives him. They had two daughters.

Leonard Lopès Salzedo, musician, born September 24 1921; died May 6 2000

His greatest successes as a composer came in 1956 with the premieres, in Amsterdam, of his ballet, The Witch Boy, and, in London, of his First Symphony, the latter under the baton of Sir Thomas Beecham. The Witch Boy was extraordinarily successful; the ballet and the colourful concert suite derived from it in 1959 - pieces which the composer himself recorded for Classics for Pleasure in 1971, although, sadly, they have not been reissued on CD - have, between them, received well over a thousand performances. Between his directorial posts with Ballets Nègres and Rambert, Salzedo earned his living by composing, and as a violinist in the London Philharmonic (until 1950) and Royal Philharmonic Orchestras. During his time in the latter, he worked as assistant to Beecham, gaining valuable experience. In 1945, Salzedo married Patricia Clover, who survives him. They had two daughters. Leonard Lopès Salzedo, musician, born September 24 1921; died May 6 2000

fields.headline: Now wash your hands
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV: Rupert Smith
fields.trailText: People who live in glass houses shouldn't throw stones, but that didn't stop Dani Behr from having a pop at "the sort of sad prat who likes to watch large-breasted women running around in bathing suits" during Sex Sells (C5).
fields.body:
People who live in glass houses shouldn't throw stones, but that didn't stop Dani Behr from having a pop at "the sort of sad prat who likes to watch large-breasted women running around in bathing suits" during Sex Sells (C5).

Behr had been drafted in alongside Rowland Rivron to present a selection of advertisements from around the world that use sexual images to flog anything from burgers to vibrators, and she gave the impression that the whole sordid business was beneath her.

She sneered at Rivron, who set himself up as the kind of lonely self-abuser who tapes these ads for home entertainment, and joined in half-heartedly with a few pointless games. Their scripted banter failed to ignite, and we were left positively looking forward to the adverts, which is never a good sign.

Some of them were fun: a Belgian condom ad which was supposed to be erotic was weirdly reminiscent of a scene from Species (just before the heroine devours Alfred Molina), while the Argentinian equivalent showed a paterfamilias about to indulge in a threesome with two other men.

Ultimately, though, there just aren't enough funny, sexy ads to go round, and the show ran out of steam pretty early. A British campaign to stop your dog from crapping in the street showed an old man in his pyjamas using the pavement as a toilet; well, someone at Channel 5 must have found it sexy. The studio games tried to eke things out to the full hour ("We got a little bit jiggy on the table and I left my mess on the floor" announced one contestant in a confessions round), but how they're going to keep the whole thing going for a three-part series boggles the imagination.

BBC1 saw the return of Playing The Field, a drama series that started off being about women's football and has now turned into a 50-minute angst-fest. The characters competed to see who could be the most miserable. Would it be Luke (Ralph Ineson), returned from honeymoon with his wife? Or new character Holly, who was cheerful for about a minute before revealing a personal hell of spousal abuse? Or the two camp mothers who played class variations on the theme of maternal anguish?

It was a close-fought contest until the final five minutes when Luke, in a bold move, climbed up a tower and doused himself with petrol, claiming "I'm nowt wi'out Shazza" and threatened to torch himself. Luke returned to the ground, sodden but uncharred, and the laurels were his.

Far from all this muck and misery roamed Hamish Wilson, a photographer and free spirit who undertook a trek across the burning plains of Somalia and Ethiopia in the footsteps of his hero, Sir Richard Burton, in Forbidden Journey (BBC2). Burton was the first European to penetrate the forbidden city of Harrar in 1854, a feat achieved through a mixture of guile and charm.

Wilson, who's lived among the Somali people for 14 years and fought in their war of independence, found little changed. The clan system still rules, nomadic traditions of hospitality are as strong as ever, and the lifestyle (camel's milk and mutton for meals) is rough but serviceable.Slogging along the humid coastal plains, Wilson revealed himself as a skilled camel-wrangler and charming on-screen presence. With his tufty blond hair and shorts he looked not unlike Tintin, and approached even the most infuriating checks and delays with a cheerful optimism born of years of experience.

Finally he reached Harrar, and found the city open and welcoming to "infidels" - possibly explained by the fact that the entire population seems to be hooked on khat, a plant which, when chewed, imparts (said Burton) "great hilarity of spirits and an agreeable state of wakefulness". Little wonder, then, that the speeding inhabitants of Harrar are busy rebuilding their city, expanding their commerce and enjoying seven-day-long parties. Khat is now their main cash crop.

Richard Burton, of course, was the unseen star of the show. His gorgeous, elegant prose was read out with relish by Kenneth Branagh. Burton poured scorn on Harrar as "a paradise inhabited by asses" and complained bitterly that he couldn't find a good-looking man in the entire city, although the women weren't bad. Wilson was altogether less critical, but thought that feeding scraps to the local hyenas was taking things a little too far.

fields.body:
Bill Alexander, the last commander of the British battalion that fought for the republican government against General Franco's fascists in the Spanish civil war, has died aged 90. Fifteen years ago, in October 1985, he was present at the unveiling, on London's South Bank, of a memorial to the more than 2,200 men and women who left Britain and Ireland to serve in the international brigades. The South Bank memorial to the volunteers is now one of more than 55 in Britain, many of which owe much to the efforts of Bill Alexander in his role as honorary secretary of the

International Brigade Association, a position he held for more than 30 years. Bill was born in Hamp- shire, one of seven children of a rural carpenter. Despite a poor upbringing, education was encouraged in his family and, like most of his siblings, Bill went to university, studying chemistry at Reading.

Influenced by his mother's free-thinking philosophy - and the sight of hunger marchers - he joined the Communist party in 1932. He found work as an industrial chemist, where, unwilling to be seen as "manage- ment", he repeatedly turned down offers of promotion - devoting his efforts, instead, to the Print Workers' Union and the party. He also took part in the battle of Cable Street, which prevented Oswald Mosley's British Union of Fascists from marching through the East End of London.

In July 1936 came the Spanish civil war, an event that was to have a profound and lasting impact on Bill. Angered by the British government's duplicitous policy of non-intervention - Whitehall turned a blind eye to the huge levels of material support given to Franco by fascist Italy and Nazi Germany - he volunteered for the international brigades in the spring of 1937. Arriving in Spain soon after the murderous battle of Jarama, in which two-thirds of the British battalion were killed or wounded, he joined the newly-formed anti-tank battery, which was equipped with modern, high-velocity Soviet guns.

Described by a comrade as "a strict disciplinarian, but fearless", Bill soon showed that his military efficiency matched his political resolve, and was appointed the battery's political commissar. This was a position of great responsibility and equal danger, for, in addition to being expected to lead from the front, political commissars were invariably executed if captured. Bill was cited for bravery at the battle at Belchite in September 1937; four months later, at Teruel in January 1938, he was promoted to captain and commander of the British battalion. The following month he was injured in the chest and shoulder by a bullet, adding another injury to the loss of hearing in his left ear, which had been caused by standing too close to one of the anti-tank guns. He was invalided home at the end of June 1938.

Back in Britain, Bill continued to campaign for the Spanish republic, and was involved in numerous demonstrations outside the Spanish embassy. He also became Merseyside area secretary of the Communist party, which he remained until the outbreak of the second world war.

In 1940 he was recommended by the "red" Duchess of Atholl for a commission at Sandhurst, where he finished top of his year. He served in north Africa, Italy and Germany, rising to the rank of captain in the reconnaissance corps, even though the promotion board made it clear they knew his history and political background. (Many of his comrades from Spain were not so fortunate, and suffered persistent discrimination.)

After the war, Bill resumed his political activities in Britain, and, in addition to becoming Coventry secretary of the Communist party, stood unsuccessfully against Richard Crossman at Coventry East in the 1945 general election. From 1947-53, he was party secretary for the Midlands area, and, following a six-year period as secretary for Wales, became assistant general secretary of the party in 1959, a position he held until 1967. He later taught chemistry in south-east London until retirement.

Between 1989-96 Bill was was president of the Marx Memorial library in Clerkenwell, London, to which he became a frequent and well-known visitor. The library holds the International Brigade archive, where Bill researched a number of works on the international brigades, including the official history of the volunteers from Britain and Ireland, British Volunteers For Liberty (1982), No To Franco (1992) and, with others, Memorials Of The Spanish Civil War (1996).

He also wrote articles and letters challenging what he felt to be the mythology of the Spanish civil war. He was always strongly critical of the perception of the Spanish war as "the poets' war", and recently condemned Ken Loach's film Land And Freedom. He accused it - with some justification - of presenting a narrow and partisan view of the war that exaggerated the role of the British volunteers with the POUM (the Workers' Party of Marxist Unification) at the expense of the international brigaders, of whom he was justifiably proud. He once said: "I regard everyone who went there as a hero or heroine." In that view, he was not alone.

For many years, Bill was tireless in his efforts for the International Brigade Association, which he ruled with a rod of iron. He represented the organisation at numerous events, and led a group of surviving volunteers and their families on an emotional journey to Spain in 1986 to revisit the sites of the British volunteers' exploits. (The visit was filmed by the BBC for a television documentary, Return To The Battlefields.) Bill regularly gave impassioned talks about the Spanish "anti-fascist war" and what he felt to be its lessons; the importance of "strength and unity". He always turned up with numerous pamphlets and books in aid of the International Brigade Association, which he would promote with unabashed alacrity. It will not be the same without him.

Bill Alexander died as he lived, a deeply committed volunteer for liberty. He is survived by his wife Lena, and a son and daughter.

William 'Bill' Alexander, communist and soldier, born June 13 1910; died July 11 2000

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Apropos of nothing, we heard a fabulous tale of the highest glamour the other day. Joan Collins is a generous lady, it seems. And, no, this is not a reference to Collins' size - and even if she were inclined to Oprah-esque fluctuations in waist measurement, science would no doubt be able to provide a solution.
fields.body:
Apropos of nothing, we heard a fabulous tale of the highest glamour the other day. Joan Collins is a generous lady, it seems. And, no, this is not a reference to Collins' size - and even if she were inclined to Oprah-esque fluctuations in waist measurement, science would no doubt be able to provide a solution. We refer instead to her bounteous generosity as an employer. For Ms Collins, we hear, decided to host a birthday party for one of her most faithful PRs some while back. No shrinking violet herself, Collins managed to organise a right old knees-up, and get OK! magazine to pay for it by offering the magazine's snappers access.

And, in the Collins entourage, even this print-enhanced combination of expedient publicity and gratitude to a PR might have been passed off as the ultimate gift. Trouble was, all the pictures OK! chose to publish made the birthday girl look about twice her normal size (difficult, because we're assured she is "quite an attractive lady") while - surprise! - Joan looked her usual radiant self.

Staying with celebrities and OK! mag in particular, it seems the publishers of the title are not above flouncing in a fashion more suited to the subjects of the magazine. Word is already out that the next series of OK!TV - promised a healthy billing on ITV - will not now grace our screens due to a falling out between the magazine publishers and those who were due to make the show.

As one commissioning editor wisely said, you have to treat these publishers like talent (the jargon word for actors and actresses); they need just as much petting because it's down to their egos as to whether a masthead programme gets made or not. Now, who said journalists have egos?

Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: null
fields.body:
Alt-TV: Being Caprice 7.30pm, Channel 4 For 10 days earlier this year, model and aspiring pop star Caprice agreed to wear a hidden camera in her spectacles. We accompany Caprice as she sits in her flat on Valentine's Day eating yoghurt and spilling some down her trousers. We hear her fretting over her looks prior to a shoot for Hello! magazine. And we join her in a recording studio as she rails against music critics for failing to appreciate that she can actually write songs.

Airline 9pm, ITV Midway through this fourth series about Easyjet's staff, viewing figures show no sign of dwindling. This week, heavy snow at Luton airport brings chaos to the company's flight schedules and tempers are becoming frayed. "Stand back so I don't feel so intimidated," says a stressed-out employee to a woman whose bag has been missing for three days. "But we've got a barrier between us," she replies incredulously. Trainee Stephen, meanwhile, deals with drunken soccer fans at 30,000 feet.

Friends 9pm, Channel 4 "Hey, you guys." Yep, they're back. Apparently, the cast recently secured a deal which will guarantee each of them $750,000 dollars an episode for the next two years. Perhaps that explains the slightly punchier pace of this first episode, which finds the six chums emerging from a drunken night in Vegas to discover that two of their number have inadvertently got married. Not surprisingly, much angst and introspection ensues. If only all our problems were this trivial.

fields.headline: Once more unto the screech
fields.trailText: Once more unto the screech
fields.body:
There's one disaster movie that really gives a bad name to all the possible meanings of the term "disaster movie". Airport '79: The Concorde represents not only the very last gasp of the genre, it also - either accidentally or by fiendish design, it's hard to tell - beat the Airplane spoofs at their own game a full two years before the Zucker brothers and co got in on the action.

The Airport series had by that point traveled about a billion air miles from Arthur Hailey's turgid bestseller and the Burt Lancaster movie that was fashioned from it in 1969. Airport 1975 ditched every one of the original's characters except Kennedy's runway manager Joe Patroni; in place of the sprawling Grand Hotel cast of the original, we were left with Karen Black playing a stewardess flying a pilotless 747 home to safety.

By the time Airport '77 was released, the film-makers were bored with the unfriendly skies, so they crashed a plane containing both Jack Lemmon and Jimmy Stewart (star of the 1958 proto-Airport movie No Highway in the Sky) into the ocean, where the cast remained trapped for the bulk of the movie.

Also aboard by now were the familiar stereotypes that the Zuckers delight in skewering: singing nuns, kids so cute you want to choke them and a full complement of transplant organs.

Watching Airport '79, it's hard to determine whether it represents a movie franchise careening off the end of the runway and through a departure lounge packed with crippled orphans, or one taking wing on a full tank of barely concealed contempt for itself.

I first saw it before there were any Airplane movies, but when I caught it on TV a few years later (that's right: I've seen it twice), it seemed to me that the film-makers had made a huge head-start in the business of self-satire. It reminded me of someone committing suicide to avoid being murdered.

It's got everything you want in a dummkopf masterpiece. The passenger manifest includes the US Winter Olympic team, one or more transplant patients at death's door, and host of thespian burn-outs, has-beens and shoulda-known-betters.

The casting is just berserk, a satirist's dream of a bad Airport movie line-up: Alain Delon, Robert Wagner, Eddie Albert, Bibi Andersson, Cicely Tyson, David Warner, and Mercedes McCambridge, the last of whom you can see apparently turning in her grave before she was actually dead.

Priceless moments include a mid-air chase between the Concorde and a team of Russian MiG fighters (controlled by polyester-clad baddie Wagner), during which pilot George Kennedy, still grimly hanging in there as Patroni, actually opens Concorde's window at Mach 1 and starts firing his revolver at the enemy as if he's in some bad heist movie.

Soon thereafter, a grateful, fully-clad Sylvia Kristel trills "Ooh, you pilots are so manly", to which Kennedy gamely replies: "They don't call this a cockpit for nothin', baby!"

For some reason I couldn't get Airport '79 out of my mind as I watched Scary Movie, Keenen Ivory Wayans's satirical take on Kevin Williamson's Scream movies. Whereas Concorde seemed to pre-empt and predict the Airplane boom that followed, Scary Movie seems to represent the other extreme of the whole process, satire's last terminus, its dead end.

How did we get to this? Scary Movie is not only a spoof of a series of movies that were themselves a knowing, nudging, winking spoof of the whole genre of teen horror flicks that daubed drive-in screens with intestines in the late 70s; it even has the nerve to steal the original title Williamson had in mind for Scream.

It aims to satirise the more recent horror boomlet - or horror-spoof boomlet - that included the three Screams, The Blair Witch Project, I Know What You Did Last Summer, Urban Legend and The Sixth Sense. What is the point?

Even the box office figures for Scary Movie look like they're plagiarised from the Scream series. It took in a stunning $42.5m for Miramax, whose previous best opening weekend at the box office was, well, fancy that, Scream 3. Still, it must be doing something right to pull down this kind of scratch and, to be honest, Scary Movie offered quite a few good laughs as it emptied teenage wallets last weekend.

It's a step up from I'm Gonna Git You Sucka, Wayans's so-so spoof of blaxploitation movies (again, he's repeating himself - and somebody else), which resurrected five ghetto superheroes (Bernie Casey, Richard Roundtree and "Black Caesar" Fred Williamson among them) and had them strutting around, kicking asses and taking names, each with their personal soundtrack bands in tow.

What with his various spoof movies and TV shows on the Fox and UPN networks, Wayans and his myriad siblings (Damon, Marlon, etc) seem almost oppressively omnipresent. Either Wayans has sold his soul to the devil for the chance to make a million mediocre movies, or somebody else, working on a much grander scale, has sold all our souls - and Wayans is the punishment we must all now endure for all eternity.

Meanwhile, this week's other big release, Disney's The Kid, seems to derive from a spoof of the pitch for The Sixth Sense. I can see the pitch meeting in my mind's eye: "It's got Bruce Willis, see - and a kid! Come on, fellas, this stuff is dynamite, high-concept to the max - and it worked once before!"

That's all the suits needed to hear before handing over the development money. Such encounters have borne no end of shitty movies. The Kid joins their rankest ranks by failing to provide an adequately amiable brat, like Jonathan Lipnicki in Jerry Maguire or Haley Joel Osment in The Sixth Sense, and by failing to provide an adequately amiable script.

I predict The Kid will disappear as fast as Rocky and Bullwinkle did last week, after a dismal opening consigned it to the ashheap that also contains the remains of such big screen TV knock-offs as The Mod Squad, The Avengers, Dudley Do Right and McHale's Navy.

What all this means for Drew Barrymore's Charlie's Angels spoof/remake/rip-off, I will not attempt to guess.
fields.bodyText: There's one disaster movie that really gives a bad name to all the possible meanings of the term "disaster movie". Airport '79: The Concorde represents not only the very last gasp of the genre, it also - either accidentally or by fiendish design, it's hard to tell - beat the Airplane spoofs at their own game a full two years before the Zucker brothers and co got in on the action. The Airport series had by that point traveled about a billion air miles from Arthur Hailey's turgid bestseller and the Burt Lancaster movie that was fashioned from it in 1969. Airport 1975 ditched every one of the original's characters except Kennedy's runway manager Joe Patroni; in place of the sprawling Grand Hotel cast of the original, we were left with Karen Black playing a stewardess flying a pilotless 747 home to safety. By the time Airport '77 was released, the film-makers were bored with the unfriendly skies, so they crashed a plane containing both Jack Lemmon and Jimmy Stewart (star of the 1958 proto-Airport movie No Highway in the Sky) into the ocean, where the cast remained trapped for the bulk of the movie. Also aboard by now were the familiar stereotypes that the Zuckers delight in skewering: singing nuns, kids so cute you want to choke them and a full complement of transplant organs. Watching Airport '79, it's hard to determine whether it represents a movie franchise careening off the end of the runway and through a departure lounge packed with crippled orphans, or one taking wing on a full tank of barely concealed contempt for itself. I first saw it before there were any Airplane movies, but when I caught it on TV a few years later (that's right: I've seen it twice), it seemed to me that the film-makers had made a huge head-start in the business of self-satire. It reminded me of someone committing suicide to avoid being murdered. It's got everything you want in a dummkopf masterpiece. The passenger manifest includes the US Winter Olympic team, one or more transplant patients at death's door, and host of thespian burn-outs, has-beens and shoulda-known-betters. The casting is just berserk, a satirist's dream of a bad Airport movie line-up: Alain Delon, Robert Wagner, Eddie Albert, Bibi Andersson, Cicely Tyson, David Warner, and Mercedes McCambridge, the last of whom you can see apparently turning in her grave before she was actually dead. Priceless moments include a mid-air chase between the Concorde and a team of Russian MiG fighters (controlled by polyester-clad baddie Wagner), during which pilot George Kennedy, still grimly hanging in there as Patroni, actually opens Concorde's window at Mach 1 and starts firing his revolver at the enemy as if he's in some bad heist movie.
